PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal: Television Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, of the Parliament of Australia, assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
because the new standards are a result of such consultations, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to `the storyline' of a film screened,

because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

2. Deny some Human Rights and do not include others,

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights will do nothing to advance the rights of Australians, because it is dangerously ambiguous and will cause confusion within the legal system; it endangers our Federal system; and, it is to be administered in an authoritarian manner inconsistent with the present legal rights of all Australians.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill.

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not to be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.

DEBATE.TITLE: ASSESSMENT IN SECONDARY COLLEGES IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts report on assessment in secondary colleges in the Australian Capital Territory. I seek leave to make a statement relating thereto and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
DETAILED STATEMENT
(See appendix for definitions)
A. 1983-84 ANNUAL REPORT OF THE A.C.T. SCHOOLS AUTHORITY
In its report (pp 3-6), the Senate Committee states that the ACT Schools Authority's Annual Report for 1983-84 was inadequate in its reporting on:
(a) various matters of information, including office staff levels;
(b) the activities of standing committees;
(c) operational problems; and
(d) matters of public interest.

Ministerial responsibility for ACT government schools during 1983-84 rested with the Minister for Education. The Minister's publicly stated view was that the Federal Government was responsible principally for overall resourcing decisions vis-a-vis the ACT government school system, and that operational matters should be worked out between the statutory authority (the school system's governing body) and the ACT community.

The Authority therefore adopted a stance of reporting in detail to its local community through published reports and policy statements, consultation with school communities (eg regional meetings of school boards) and other interested parties (eg school visits, standing committees), formal Authority meetings and through regularly scheduled media conferences. This reporting machinery is referred to in the Annual Report.
The Authority's Annual Report for 1983-84 was prepared and presented within this framework and, in the circumstances, was thought to be appropriate.
The Authority Council will take account of the Senate Committee's remarks in the preparation of future annual reports.
B. EXTERNAL EXAMINATIONS, CONTINUOUS ASSESSMENT AND MAINTAINING STANDARDS
A major concern expressed by the Senate Committee was the use of continuous, school-based assessment rather than external examinations. The Committee stated,

``Thus the real choice in the ACT is between retaining the present system, possibly with some refinements, and using a combination of continuous assessment and external examinations. On the basis of the evidence before it, the Committee would have a preference for the latter approach.'' (Senate p 40)

The Committee, although indicating that current assessment procedures were generally supported by college staff and students, was of the opinion that external examinations would be seen to be a more objective, fairer method of assessing students' performances than continuous assessment. Generally external examinations were seen as providing motivation for teachers and pupils alike, and for providing a method of maintaining standards in both teaching and learning. In arriving at this recommendation to combine external examinations with school-based assessment, the Committee made comparisons with trends in other States and Territories, noting that only Queensland and the ACT have abolished external examinations at the Year 12 level. Basically the Committee seemed very concerned with maintaining and raising standards in the ACT secondary colleges. Although the importance of that concern cannot be denied, a number of possible avenues are available for achieving that aim. Whatever procedures are selected, they should be consistent with the general educational philosophy of school-based curriculum development that is adopted by the ACT Schools Authority. We regard it as most important that the educationally undesirable effects of external examinations, including a false view of standards, are avoided.
(i) Validity and Reliability of Assessment

The Committee recognized that because standardisation procedures are used with external examinations in Australia, examination results do not by themselves indicate a set level of student achievement. Present day criterion-referenced assessment techniques were accepted as being inadequate for use at Years 11 and 12. Unfortunately, while suggesting that external examinations be incorporated into continuous assessment, the Committee did not inquire whether external examinations measure student achievement more reliably or more validly that school-based assessment. As noted by Macintosh et. al. (p 3), one of the major problems of educational measurement is to obtain valid and reliable measurements. Validity, according to Rust (pp 85-86) relies heavily on the closest possible knowledge of the student's abilities: one of the advantages of school-based assessment. Macintosh describes the processes involved in assessment as determining the outcomes of learning from observing a student's performance of set tasks. Although recognising that because inferences are drawn from those observations and that those inferences cannot be drawn with absolute certainty, the teacher is nevertheless able to draw upon evidence collected from a number of tasks. It is the regular monitoring of performance through a variety of means which reassures a teacher that the intended outcomes of teaching have been achieved (Macintosh et. al. p 3). One of those means may be examinations if that form of assessment was approved during the accreditation process. But, in school-based assessment, the classroom teacher is intimately involved with all aspects of the development and implementation of the examination. Depending on the course, individual teachers or groups of teachers may develop the examination. School-based assessment does not preclude examinations but internal examinations have a greater potential for providing meaningful information about student performance levels than external examinations. As noted by the Senate Committee, in correspondence from Professor Power, there is no research evidence which proves that external examinations are better than school-based assessment. The evidence available points to the ACT type of school-based assessment being clearly superior to external examinations in terms of validity (assessing genuine attainment) and reliability (assessing consistency).
(ii) Relating Assessment Practices to Curriculum Aims

In arriving at its recommendation regarding external examinations, the Committee did not distinguish between (a) those attributes of student achievement which can reasonably be determined by external examinations and (b) those qualities which can be assessed under continuous assessment. Recognition was given in the Report to the inevitable consequences of an external examination impinging on the curriculum. External examinations can only assess a very limited range of competencies specified in a narrow set of objectives. Rust (p 79) has suggested that if assessment instruments are not consciously designed to meet our aims then we will be misled by the results.
Consider, for example, the aims for one Geography course:
1. To develop a geographic viewpoint.
2. To develop an understanding of the concepts and methods used in geographic inquiry.
Contrast those aims with the aims prepared for another Geography course:
1. Establish a comprehension of the major processes and patterns, their integration within and between the cultural and natural phenomena of the environment and their interaction through time.
2. Develop the ability to make personal and socially responsible decisions and to choose effectively between different courses of action with specific reference to spatial problems.
3. Create an atmosphere which provides opportunity for the formulation of attitudes and values contributing to personal development.
4. Develop skills in acquiring, understanding, communicating and applying knowledge.
5. Develop an awareness of and the abilities needed to cope with the dynamic nature of the environment.

Some of the aims of the two courses are similar, but the second course contains a much broader set of aims to be achieved and hence assessed. An examination could assess achievement of the narrow range of knowledge and understanding required in the first statement of aims. On the other hand, the valid and reliable assessment of achievement in the second Geography course would be best achieved through school-based rather than external assessment. With school-based assessment, the college and teacher may start by first establishing the aims for the course and then determine how to appropriately assess achievement of those aims. This procedure avoids assessment dictating the aims to be achieved. In a system operating with school-based curriculum and assessment the ``tail does not wag the dog''.

The ACT Schools Accrediting Agency has embarked on a major student assessment program which is heavily concerned with the quality of learning and at its October 1985 meeting a proposal was accepted that during Moderation Day 1986 teachers should determine the attributes for awarding grades in the accredited courses. In addition, some colleges have developed, over an extended period of time, their own college assessment policies. One secondary college has initiated an extensive staff development program in assessment.

At its April 1986 meeting, the Accrediting Agency considered a moderation plan to enable teachers to more accurately and consistently assess their students in relation to students studying the same or similar courses at other colleges; a plan that builds on the guidance provided by the ASAT, bids staff to compare standards between colleges, and gives colleges with demonstrably stronger groups of students the ability to override the normal moderation procedures.

Two other approaches are being developed to improve the validity and reliability of assessment practices. These will strengthen the relationship with stated aims. Both approaches, which are ``path-finding'' activities for the ACT secondary education system, will enable ACT teachers in public and private schools, to attest more readily and accurately to the quality of student levels of performance. During 1986 working parties in English, Mathematics, Science and French will investigate the use of the Structure of Observed Learning Outcomes (SOLO) Taxonomy (Biggs and Collis) which assesses one aspect of the quality of the response. That aspect is the structure or organization of the response. Also during 1986, other groups will develop what has become known as the ``Power Domains''. Those domains represent the ``integrated groupings of content, skill and process goals'' (Power p 9). The domains will be clusters of concepts and skills which Year 11 and 12 students can reasonably be expected to learn. Students will then be assessed in relation to their mastery of a domain. Identifying the domains, together with appropriate assessment instruments, will require a high degree of understanding of the particular discipline, assessment practices and learning theory. The Power Domains may provide an integrated framework for curriculum development within the colleges with realistic, assessable aims, thereby enabling teachers to more accurately describe differing levels of achievement. None of the above approaches are ``ready-made'' solutions to the problems associated with the measurement of human performance, but they are solutions compatible with school-based curriculum. They also avoid problems inherent in external examinations.
(iii) Problems with External Examinations

Parents and members of the public who have successfully passed through external examination systems accept them as providing valid, reliable measurements of performance and as a means of maintaining standards. Yet there are inherent problems which are difficult to overcome. Some problems were expressed by the Committee, but the Report did not provide any data for assessing the magnitude of these problems.

Evidence is available from external examiners' reports to suggest that examination results are used to judge the quality of teaching. For example, external examiners have reported ``. . . the general standard of the external papers showed the results of efficient teaching''. Such statements apply to teachers across an educational system, rather than to specific teachers. No doubt external examinations have the potential (with a large measurement error) for identifying poor teachers, but a number of other factors such as initial student ability and socio-economic status should be removed prior to forming a valid conclusion. As pointed out by Moore (pp 52-53), examinations were originally designed for assessing performance and for certification. With the expansion of secondary education, without a commensurate increase in tertiary places, examinations acquired two additional roles: selection for tertiary education by turning examinations into competitive events, and accountability in terms of success or otherwise at examinations. Moore warns that failure to distinguish between the acquired and original roles ``. . . leads to distortions and malfunctions'' (p 53). If teaching standards should be monitored, then measures more valid and reliable than external examinations could be devised.

But are standards of learning really maintained through external examinations? First consider whether the results obtained over a number of years are consistent. Table 1 relates to an external General Mathematics Year 12 examination and shows the means of the average mark as a percentage of the maximum possible mark for a number of years.

The variations may be explained by changes in the standards of the examination, changes in the abilities of the students, changing standards of the markers, alteration of the scaling procedures or any of a number of other reasons. On the surface the external examination results are not consistent over a period of time and would therefore not appear to represent a consistent standard. Moore suggests that the accuracy, or reliability, of examinations requires removal of fluctuations caused by examiner and marker bias, because the examiner selects the questions for the student and the marker judges the merit of the answers. Clearly ``examiners do act as something more than disinterested judges of student answers'' (Moore p 62). Just as school-based assessment may contain biases and errors of judgement, so may external examinations. By restricting access to completed examination papers the system does not facilitate discovery of biases. Under school-based assessment, estimates of a student's performance over a period of two years, by several different teachers under varying conditions and with items appropriate to the aims, will minimise assessment biases. Furthermore, there is a greater chance of uncovering biases when students, teachers and parents have free access to all facets of the assessment procedures and when acceptable appeal procedures operate.

Another way of looking at consistency is to compare school-based assessments with external examination results. From 1982 and 1984 data, Table 2 shows the grand means (on a 200 point scale) in the core parts of seven subjects. From the above table, inconsistencies over the two year period display variations within and between subjects. The largest difference, 20.41, in the grand means occurs with the external Chemistry examination results, not with the school assessments.

When commenting on a French examination, the examiners remarked ``This year's examination proved to be of uneven difficulty with many candidates finding the Listening Comprehension test and to a lesser degree the closure questions of the Reading Comprehension test to be more difficult than anticipated''. This comment highlights one of the major problems with external examinations, namely that there is very little opportunity for trialling and testing of the paper prior to its use. Whether or not a set standard is represented by a particular paper depends heavily on the intuitive judgements of the examiners and markers. Frequently, research and post-graduate students, employed to mark external examinations, are paid by the number of papers marked. All questions from the one paper are marked at the one time, allowing little time for comparisons of answers to the same question or between markers during the assessment period.

Research has been carried out by Mackay to investigate the fairness of public examinations. Mackay's study showed that ``. . . systematic marking errors which may arise from differences in marking standards of different markers and differences in optional questions are of considerable magnitude'' (p 172). Mackay concluded that ``Improved understanding among users of the results of public examinations may lead to an increase in the likelihood that the results of public examinations will be afforded the diligent, sceptical, and probabilistic treatment they deserve'' (p 174).

In the absence of an adequate base for setting and maintaining standards, all States and Territories which operate external examinations are obliged to apply standardization procedures. Those procedures involve, to varying degrees, elements of some forms of school-based assessments.

In 1972 the Working Committee on College Proposals for the ACT, chaired by Dr R. J. Campbell, considered the effectiveness of external examinations and concluded that ``. . . in its traditional form (it) is neither effective, nor reliably, nor predictive'' (p 67). The recommendation was made that the ``Higher School Certificate examination be replaced by a tested system of continuous assessment . . . to which is added, at least for the time being, an external test of the TEEP or ASAT type, suitably refined as to take account of other aptitudes besides scholastic'' (p 70). What has evolved since that recommendation is a school-based curriculum and assessment system in which consistency, validity and comparability is sought in four ways: in-college moderation procedures, monitoring of college-derived course scores, the external examination of ASAT, and extensive course accreditation procedures. Whilst acknowledging the Senate Committee's concerns over assessment procedures and given that those procedures have developed over nine years, it is considered that external examinations are not compatible with contemporary educational practice. Rather than moving to external examinations, the problems raised by the Committee are being dealt with in other ways. These are explained in the overview to this response.
(iv) The Use of ASAT

When the Senate Committee compared continuous assessment with external examination issues, ASAT was discussed separately with focus primarily on problems of using ASAT as a moderating device. ASAT is an external examination set by the Australian Council for Educational Research. The examination is a three hour objective test, with questions drawn from the four subject areas of Mathematics, Science, Social Science and the Humanities. The Committee's recommendation that the ACT incorporate an external assessment into continuous assessment is advice already met in part by ASAT. Students' scores are modified according to results on an external examination, following the recommendation in the Campbell Report. Each year's ASAT is prepared by the same organization which monitors its consistency. From the data presented earlier in this paper, ASAT has greater consistency than traditional subject-based, external examinations. Nevertheless, uncertainties in an individual student's ASAT result are recognized and the moderation procedures use the ASAT mean and standard deviation of a course, instead of individual student results.

While curriculum in the ACT remains school-based any external examination would, like the ASAT, be limited to tests of general knowledge and ability. Reference examinations have recently been mentioned for tertiary selection procedures, but none are currently in use in Australia. Their validity, reliability and usefulness at the individual level is yet to be established. An alternative might be for some form of external oversight of assessment instruments used within the colleges.
(v) Comparisons with Other Educational Systems

Comparisons with other States, particularly Western Australia, and recommendations of the McGaw Report appear to have been a factor which influenced the Committee to recommend incorporation of external examinations with internal assessment.

All State and Territory certification authorities now use a combination of internal assessment and external examination. All moreover use the external examination to moderate-in some form-the internal assessment. In two of the authorities the external examination is the Australian Scholastic Aptitude Test.

Queensland and the ACT are the only two authorities which have been able to adopt a more valid, reliable and effective moderator than the subject-based external examination. The other authorities have at various times expressed the desire to move away from the external examination but because of their long association with the public examinations have to opt for a phased shift from the fully external public examination to internal assessment. The ACT and Queensland were well placed to make a fundamental shift in the early 1970s; a time of marked social change. Both moreover viewed the shift as fundamental to major restructuring that was taking place in those areas at that stage. The McGaw and Blackburn Reports reflect a political scenario and not an educational rationale.
(vi) Standards of Learning

The data provided in Table 3.2 on page 28 of the Senate report represent an incorrect interpretation of the information provided. In 1985 99% of Year 12 students studied English; 95% Mathematics and 74% Science. A detailed explanation of the shortcomings of the table is included in Appendix 2.
C. COURSE ACCREDITATION

Course development in Years 11 and 12 in the ACT is the responsibility of the individual college. Courses prepared by the colleges are taken through an approval process that requires the course to be formally supported by the college board; examined by a specialist accreditation panel which contains teachers, academics and community representatives; approved by the ACT Schools Accrediting Agency, and in the case of courses seeking TES-classification, also approved by the Australian National University. Indeed the procedure used to ensure that the courses are of a requisite standard is very similar to that used with the colleges of advanced education.
The ACT accreditation procedures were introduced in 1975; evaluated by a committee chaired by Professor Selby Smith (University of Tasmania) and found to be very effective.
The Senate Committee in its consideration of this aspect of the ACT operations generally endorsed the current procedures, and simply pointed to some areas where refinements could be made.

The report prepared by the Accreditation Working Party also endorses the present structures; discusses each of the concerns mentioned in the Senate Report and recommends various ways and means of allaying them.

The recommendations in the report ``Course Accreditation in the ACT-A Review'' were discussed at the February 1986 meeting of the Accrediting Agency. A preferred position with respect to the Review will be formulated, circulated throughout the community and then finalised at the June 1986 Agency meeting, in conjunction with the final report from the inquiry into TES scaling. (Copies of Course Accreditation in the ACT-A Review are available from the ACT Schools Authority.)
D. STUDENT, PUBLIC AND EMPLOYER UNDERSTANDING OF, AND CONFIDENCE IN, THE ASSESSMENT PROCEDURES

The Senate Committee commended the Schools Authority for the information brochures prepared for general dissemination to the students and public. The Committee also found that the existing assessment procedures were supported, although not fully understood, by those who are most affected by them; teachers and students. The Committee, whilst acknowledging the limitations of its evidence, concluded that there is widespread community ignorance and recommended that the efforts to inform the public be expanded. The Authority has recognised the need to inform the public of educational issues and has previously established a Public Relations Reference Group to develop information programs.

The Senate Standing Committee received evidence from the Confederation of ACT Industry (CONFACT) which stated that the ``. . . certification procedures were not understood and that employers were losing faith in the ACT education system'' (Senate p 70). This may be due to employer laziness as much as to any undue complexity in our system. During 1985, the Authority initiated discussions with employers regarding the value of the information on the Year 10 and 12 Certificates. CONFACT deals mainly with students at or below Year 10, who do not commence college studies. Given the high retention rate in the ACT, those students are few in number and are atypical. Their needs are best met by a more detailed account of abilities than is to be found in a single number cypher.

Discussions have been held with such groups as retailers, banks, building societies and the Public Service Board. Frequently those discussions have involved many issues of assessment, accreditation and certification. The Agency, before making policy decisions, requires a clear understanding of employer needs, and will consider a paper about those needs at the 1986 April meeting.

The Government notes the Committee's reservations about the representativeness of the students and teachers they met during their visits to two colleges. Those reservations must equally be true of the one parent, one student, and the one lecturer who appeared as witnesses before the Committee. There is empirical evidence available from the Anderson, Saltet and Vervoorn study which investigated the shifts from 1972 to 1979 that occurred in secondary college student attitudes towards many aspects of their schooling. The investigation showed that the secondary colleges had been ``. . . an important factor in bringing about a more positive outlook towards schooling among their students'' (Anderson et. al. p 119).

The Government recognises that every effort possible should be made to increase the public's understanding, not only of assessment and certification procedures, but also of the educational philosophy upon which the ACT educational system is based. Without that fundamental understanding, discussions and decisions could be dominated by partisan interests. This may inhibit achieving the aims embodied in the philosophy which, as the committee noted, have general community endorsement. Where understanding of a new system takes time to develop, particularly when the myths of the past have to be overcome, lack of understanding does not necessarily warrant returning to a closed system of external examinations or central specification of curricula.
E. MODERATION PROCEDURES: INTRA- AND INTER-COLLEGE

Moderation procedures begin when a course is developed and presented to an Accreditation panel. Each panel consists of representatives from secondary colleges, tertiary institutions and the community. The panels, through their consultations with course developers and enforcement of accreditation guidelines, fulfil a moderating role by maintaining standards within courses and across colleges. There are several different types of moderation procedures.

Intra-college moderation usually involves groups of teachers who monitor the achievement of students. Those moderation procedures include the use of common tests, multiple marking of common assignments, team teaching of units, and faculty discussions regarding assessment and curriculum policies. Teachers may also teach the same students in different units and Heads of Department provide oversight as moderators of courses. Some faculties use a combination of qualitative and statistical procedures, such as back-scaling, to compare results and rank students. Moderation across all courses within a given college occurs at the Principal and/or Assistant Principal level.

Inter-college, system-wide moderation procedures are supervised by the Accrediting Agency's Technical Adviser. Most of those procedures are statistical, and the Adviser checks individual course scores at all colleges. Such procedures were instituted because, as suggested by Thomson (p 14) and McGaw (p 8), a basic premise of internal assessment is that, although teachers validly and reliably rank students within schools, additional moderation or scaling procedures are required to achieve comparability between colleges. School assessments are accepted as the basis for discriminating among students within colleges and the scaling procedures, based on the external moderator, are designed to remove arbitrary differences between schools.

Consensus moderation procedures operating with course scores have not been developed in the ACT because they are considered to be unwieldy. A plan for intra-course moderation across colleges, which takes advantage of their coherent nature, is being considered by the Accrediting Agency.
F. APPEAL PROCEDURES

One important recommendation emphasised by the Senate Committee was that the Authority investigate the need and appropriate procedures for appeals against assessment of Tertiary Entrance Scores (Senate p 77). Given the present policy regarding calculation of the tertiary entrance score, the issuing of unit or course scores provides the only appropriate point at which appeals can be lodged. Appeals refer to errors or breaches of the policies. Avenues other than the appeal procedures are available if anyone wants to question Authority policy.

At the beginning of a unit teachers are required to provide their students with an assessment plan, which then becomes a contract between student and teacher. Students then have the right to appeal to the college and Agency if that plan is not followed. The ACT appeal procedures are open at all levels and students have the right to appeal about the fairness, correctness and reasonableness of a decision at any stage. Those rights signify an empowering of the students and the accountability of the teachers towards the students.

Not all educational systems operate with such open appeals procedures. Consider, for example, those procedures operating in another system. In that State ``. . . candidates who receive Grade D or above in the subjects for which they have applied for consideration will receive no further consideration in the assessment of their performance in these subjects.'' Indeed the ACT is one of the few States or Territories that has integrated the freedom of information philosophy into all aspects of its assessment procedures.
OVERVIEW
The report of the Senate Standing Committee is basically an endorsement of what transpires in ACT secondary colleges. In particular, the Committee reported satisfaction with:
(a) The general acceptance and understanding amongst students and staff about the assessment procedures;
(b) the information brochures designed to explain the system to the client groups;
(c) the system checks which limit deliberate bias in the assessment procedures;
(d) the report into the accreditation procedures; and
(e) the Inquiry into TES Scaling.

In relation to external examinations, the committee acknowledged that they will not, without moderation, maintain standards and achieve comparability; nor will they provide more information about levels of achievement than the current procedures.

The Government shares the Committee's concern for the maintenance of standards and the credibility of the system; however its views on the most appropriate methods for achieving these ends differ from those of the Committee. The Government believes that it is appropriate to use moderation techniques consistent with the underlying educational philosophy of ACT secondary colleges and which also take advantage of the smallness and compactness of the ACT system.

The Senate Committee's Report makes scant reference to the underlying educational philosophy of the ACT college system or to the Schools Authority's desire, since 1976, to have the secondary colleges cater for all students wishing to complete secondary education, not just those who aspire towards tertiary education. A recent release from the Commonwealth Statistician (28/2/86) notes that the ACT's efforts to cater for the total age cohort has resulted in the ACT having virtually double the national average proportion of students continuing through to Year 12. The same report also observes that the two education systems with the highest retention rates in Australia are those with school based curriculum and assessment: the ACT and Queensland.
Wide consultation with those associated with ACT schooling would reveal the efforts that have been-and are being-made to address the issues of comparability and the maintenance of standards.

APPENDIX 1
Assessment:

Frequently the terms ``assessment and evaluation'' are all-embracing terms which refer to teaching and learning processes. In the ACT context ``assessment'' is used to describe the measurements taken to determine the learning outcomes in individuals.
Validity:
``Validity'' is a measurement term which ``. . . refers to the ability of the test to do the job we want it to . . . (it) is the most important single attribute (of a test)'' (Lyman p 21).
Reliability:

The other important concept in educational measurement is ``reliability'', which is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for validity. ``Reliability means that a test gives dependable and consistent scores'' (Lyman p 21). In more practical terms Macintosh et. al. (p 3) explains that reliability requires that ``. . . the judgement of the child's attainment should be relatively robust against changes of tester, test procedure, or occasion when marks are collected''.
APPENDIX 2

Through its Table 3.2 (p 28), the Committee reported on the percentages of students enrolled in the top ten subject areas in 1984. Unfortunately, the table contains data from two separate tables in the Year 12 Study of 1984. In combining data, two different populations of students have been used. Those two populations are (i) the number of candidates (4302) which refers to the number of students who completed one or more units in a course, and (ii) the number of students who completed one of the four types of courses. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) and the Government for responding to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on assessment in secondary colleges in the Australian Capital Territory. As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I shall make a few observations of a preliminary nature about the response. After I have studied the response in more depth, I may wish to add to the remarks I intend to make today. Some other members of the Committee may also wish to comment at a later date or later today.

SPEECH.PARA: In its report, the Committee drew attention to shortcomings in the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority's annual report for 1983-84. The Government's detailed response suggests that because of the special framework in which the Authority operated at that time, its annual report was considered appropriate. Nevertheless, the Committee considers that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority's annual reports should meet the standards which are required of all other statutory corporations. I note the Government's assurance that the Committee's remarks will be taken into account in the preparation of future annual reports, which the Committee looks forward to reading.

In chapter 3 of the Committee's report, the merits of continuous assessment and external examinations were discussed. In paragraph 3.39 the Committee recommended that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority should review the possibility of using external examinations as part of its assessment procedures in the future. The whole of that paragraph deserves study, but I shall read three pertinent sentences from that paragraph:

It is essentially misleading to argue, as some have done, that the only educational choice is between external examinations and continuous assessment . . . the real choice in the Australian Capital Territory is between retaining the present system, possibly with some refinements, and using a combination of continuous assessment and external examinations. On the basis of the evidence before it, the Committee would have a preference for the latter approach.

The Government's response, however, indicates that it is convinced of the educational and technical superiority of moderated school-based assessment. Further, the Government states that it intends to continue with procedures which are compatible with the educational philosophy of the Australian Capital Territory system. The response refers to the devolution of responsibility from the centre to the colleges, and the necessity of developing an assessment scheme that overcomes the strictures and problems of public examinations.

The Committee did not expect that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority would rush to adopt a system of external examinations. I am disappointed, however, that the main thrust of the response appears to be the denigration of external examinations. There is no indication that the Schools Authority has considered seriously the possible merits of the Committee's recommendations. In effect, the detailed response tabled today is an apologia for the current system of assessment. The only references to external examinations are designed to highlight their shortcomings. The Committee discussed some of these deficiencies in its report. Yet, in the short time I have had to examine the Government's response I have noticed that one of the references in the response appears to be less than intellectually honest.

The Government's response has presumed that the Committee is advocating the use of `subject-based, public and compulsory (examinations) for all students'. This presumption is incorrect. The Committee deliberately refrained from specifying what type of external examination might be appropriate, expecting that the Schools Authority would address itself to that question.

There are several points of detail in the Government's response on which I should comment. Firstly, the Government's response includes the statement that `it is considered that external examinations are not compatible with contemporary educational practice'. I find that comment difficult to comprehend in view of the fact that external examinations are used not only in other States of Australia but also in countries which are more prosperous and technically advanced. Secondly, the Government's response claims that the Australian scholastic aptitude test is an external examination. I doubt that an aptitude test such as ASAT could properly be described as an external examination. To claim that `the Committee's recommendation that the ACT incorporate an external assessment into continuous assessment is advice already met in part by ASAT' is, at best, a grossly spurious suggestion.

Thirdly, according to the response, the Blackburn report, the report of the Victoria Ministerial Review of Postcompulsory Schooling, in Victoria and the McGaw report, the report of the Ministerial Working Party on School Certification and Tertiary Administration Procedures, in Western Australia `reflect a political scenario and not an educational rationale'. Presumably this means that public opinion was taken into account in these two States. When the Committee took evidence it heard comments about a lack of community involvement in the change of assessment procedures in the Australian Capital Territory. If those comments are valid, and if there had been community involvement, it is interesting to speculate whether the Australian Capital Territory would now have a system of continuous assessment. The fourth point on which I should comment is the statement in the response that the Committee had noted that the philosophy of the Australian Capital Territory education system has general community endorsement. The Committee did not make any such statement.

There are many other matters which, given more time to examine the response, are worthy of comment. One of these areas is the Authority's response about appeal procedures. But these other matters can wait to a later occasion. There are two other matters, however, that I consider I must address before concluding. The Committee did not set out to write a prescriptive multi-volume report, which it would have had to do if it addressed all the issues the Government response seemed to imply it should. The Committee did hope that the Authority would use its comments-the Committee's comments-as a first step in applying its expertise to what is a complex issue.

The other matter is that I consider senators can make relevant comments in certain areas without necessarily having specialist knowledge in those areas. Indeed, it may be that a lack of such knowledge can be of benefit in that senators are able to take a fresh look at procedures which are routinely accepted by the specialists. Nevertheless, it should be noted that this Committee does have members who have a long involvement in the field of education and whose qualifications in that area are not inconsiderable. As one of those, and I expect my views will be shared by some of my Committee colleagues, I am disappointed in the lack of professionalism with which the Schools Authority has responded to the Committee's report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —(South Australia) (10.14)-The Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has been constrained in his response to this ministerial statement. It is clear that he, on behalf of the Committee and on his own behalf, is not happy or satisfied with the unbending statement of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) that all is well in the assessment system in the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and that there is no need for change, particularly the changes and considerations that were brought to the attention of the Senate by the Committee. The Senate is at a disadvantage in that the Minister's statement has not been read this morning here in the chamber but rather has been fully incorporated in Hansard. Before coming to my assessment, therefore-and I am speaking on behalf of the Opposition on this matter-I will give one or two minutes of background to the significance of this statement. The Minister's response is in two parts. The first is a four-page summary of the Government's response to the several chapters of the report of the Senate Committee and, secondly, there is a longer paper which concentrates on the merits of various forms of assessment at years 11 and 12 in the school system in the Australian Capital Territory-whether there should be school-based internal assessment or external examinations.

SPEECH.PARA: These two statements respond to a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which was completed last December. The Committee was enquiring into the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority annual report of 1983-84. During that period there were two notable public controversies in this Territory. One was the voiced and rising public concern at the credibility of the assessment system because it was not based on external examination but was school-based and thus was distinctly different from the assessment systems of all other States, except for some comparison with Queensland which is also very much reliant on school-based assessment. The second controversy that year concerned the adjustment by the Minister, Senator Ryan, of the Australian Capital Territory year 12 tertiary entrance scores on the basis of alleged sex bias. She gave extra points to the tertiary education scores of some girls in the Australian Capital Territory not on the basis of their assessment but as a systematic adjustment that she said was to give them extra points to make up for inherent bias in the method of assessment. This proved to be totally unfounded and wrongly introduced by the Minister. The following year, after the public controversy and after considerable debate by the Opposition in the Senate, the Minister's adjustment to the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority's approach was removed.

Those very considerable public controversies were not mentioned in the annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority for the relevant period. The first concern of the Senate Committee when you, Mr President, referred that annual report to it was to ask the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority to give reasons as to why there was such a deafening silence in the annual report on two matters of considerable public controversy. The second and subsequent goal of the Senate inquiry was to explore these matters and see what reassurance could be given by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that would satisfy the Senate Committee in its reporting to the Senate and would also give greater confidence to the people of the Australian Capital Territory, who had expressed these concerns, that there would be a more careful analysis.

After the various findings of the Senate Committee report, what has this Government concluded? What is its response? It has made an unbending, resolute defence of practices in the Australian Capital Territory of depending completely upon school-based assessment, thought moderated by the Australian scholastic aptitude test, for year 11 and 12. The Chairman of the Senate Committee, Senate Colston, has said just now that in part that response is less than intellectually honest. I would go much further than that, and say that it is entirely misplaced. It is gratuitous for the Government to include within its response this morning words which have not actually been used in the Senate-the speech was incorporated-including allegations that those detractors of the present Australian Capital Territory system are reliant upon myths, that they have come to their criticism on the basis of a political scenario rather than an educational rationale, and that especially employers in the Australian Capital Territory, as well as some parents, are stupid if they are critical of the present Territory practice because they lack understanding of, or lack the capacity to understand, what it is readily admitted is a complex assessment procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is arrogance.

—I agree with Senator Baume; it is arrogant to make such accusations. There is the linked accusation in the report that those who do not understand the apparently noble, right and sound assessment procedures in the Australian Capital Territory that the Minister is defending not only are acting on myths or stupid but also are lazy. There is a reference in the Minister's response to employers in the Australian Capital Territory being too lazy to understanding the ASAT moderated school-based assessment system. I regard those remarks as unnecessary and insulting to employers and parents in the Australian Capital Territory. It is unworthy of the Government and the Minister to make such a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come to the other particular controversy that I referred to earlier, and that is the alleged sex bias in the assessment procedure. In the 1980s, but especially in 1983, it became apparent that in single-sex colleges in the Australian Capital Territory girls had generally lower tertiary entrance scores and therefore it was asked how this situation may have arisen. Was it because the girls in those single-sex colleges were taking subjects that were of such a nature that they gained lower assessment points? Was it because in those schools the retention rate was so much higher than in other colleges so that students of lower ability were included within the assessment, effectively bringing down the average score? Was it because girls were undertaking subjects different from those undertaken by boys? Was it because in the actual procedures of teaching and learning in schools teachers concentrated on giving greater encouragement to boys rather than girls? Was it a question of whether girls could better undertake their studies, be more successful, in coeducational colleges or in single-sex colleges?

All those various hypotheses could be appealed to to explain the outcome, but in the midst of all those varying explanations the Minister, Senator Ryan, chose one, without sufficient evidence, and said that this outcome was the result of a systematic bias in the procedures of the assessment system itself and, therefore, the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority was encouraged by the Minister, unilaterally, to adjust those scores directly, just to give some extra points to the girls who were seen to be affected. That was done without any sound analysis, without any sound basis for doing so, and when this was brought to greater attention by debate in the Senate and public criticism in the Australian Capital Territory the Minister withdrew. Subsequently, the Committee's inquiries concentrated on this matter to some extent. There is a whole chapter in our report on it.

But there is a virtual deafening silence in the Minister's response to this matter. There is only one sentence; there is no straightforward, honest admission of her earlier mistake in 1983. Rather, there is in the Minister's response a cool, quiet statement that the Committee has suspended its final judgment on this matter because it supports the current thorough inquiry by a committee of experts drawn from the Schools Authority, from the Australian National University and from the Canberra College of Advanced Education. In fact, I believe that that inquiry evolved because of the Senate Committee's investigations into this matter. Given the inadequacy of the Government's decision in 1983 to make adjustments, it is clear on all accounts that the expert inquiry is needed. It is still being undertaken, and of course the Senate Committee has suspended its final comment until that Committee of experts reports. Of course, the Government notes that we have suspended our final assessment of this question until we have the additional evidence. That is the only reference that the Minister has made to this possible sex bias in the ASAT moderation of tertiary education scores. I find that entirely inadequate and it lacks honesty in the same way as other matters in the report that the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Colston, assessed in those terms.

Let me come back to the principal matter in the Government's response this morning-the school based assessment procedure versus external assessment. It is correct, as the Minister claims in her response, that in 1972 a working committee on college proposals for the Australian Capital Territory, chaired by Dr Campbell, who subsequently became the Chairman of the Schools Authority and who served that Authority admirably over some six or seven years, considered the effectiveness of external examinations and, as stated by the Minister, concluded:
. . . in its traditional form (it) is neither effective, nor reliable, nor predictive.

The Minister cites that finding by the original working party that set up the present assessment procedures in the Australian Capital Territory as if it were a complete reason for the present practice, but to find some inadequacies in external examinations is not in itself a sufficient argument for there not being some part in the assessment procedure for external examinations. The Senate Committee unanimously found that the Australian Capital Territory school assessment procedure ought to have an element of external examination in it. After all, this is the case in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania. In all those States there is an external examination element in the assessment at the year 12 level. That situation is not directly addressed by the Minister, except to note that the continuing inclusion of an external examination is based on a myth which persists in those States, as if the public reliance on external examinations as being necessary to assess correctly the end of school outcomes of students is a myth and that only for that reason in all these States is the external examination element being retained. That is unworthy of the Minister and the Schools Authority to so condemn the practices in the various States of Australia, not least in Western Australia, where a most competent inquiry was undertaken recently into the assessment system. In that recent inquiry there was a robust defence of the soundness of including an external examination element in the assessment procedure.

The Minister goes on to say in this statement that it is not just because myths persist in the States-of course, the enlightened Australian Capital Territory has done away with myths-but also because the States are captured by reflecting a political scenario and not an educational rationale. Let me quote from page 9 of the longer second paper of the Minister's response where she states:

The ACT and Queensland were well placed to make a fundamental shift in the early 1970s; a time of marked social change. Both moreover viewed the shift as fundamental to major restructuring that was taking place in those areas at that stage. The McGaw and Blackburn reports reflect a political scenario and not an educational rationale.

I ask the Minister whether she would be bold enough to say that directly to Dr McGaw. Would she be bold enough to accuse Dr McGaw of completing a report into the Western Australian assessment system and coming to this conclusion so as to reflect a political scenario and not an educational rationale? The accusation that is made is that this recent inquiry and the other State systems are not educationally sound but have adopted myths and politics as the basis for their continuing with external examinations.

The Senate Standing Committee on Eduction and the Arts unanimously disagrees with the Ministers of this Government. Whilst it is the case that the Minister for Territories is now responsible for the school system in this Territory, the Government as a whole is responding in this report and is taking up the arguments that no doubt have been the result of advice from the Minister for Education, the Department of Education and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. It is just not good enough for the various States and these expert educational authorities to be dismissed in such an arrogant, cursory and superficial way as to say that only the Australian Capital Territory, and perhaps Queensland, have an assessment system based upon sound educational analysis and principles and that the other States are still basing their systems on myth and political allegiance to that myth.

I think this is further compounded by the arrogance of the Minister's response that citizens in this Territory fail to understand the superior principles of the Australian Capital Territory system because they are either stupid or lazy. Page 10 of the Government's response refers to the Senate Standing Committee's evidence from the Confederation of ACT Industry, which stated:
. . . certification procedures were not understood and that employers were losing faith in the ACT education system.
The Government's response to that matter was put on page 10 of the statement in these words:
This may be due to employer laziness as much as to any undue complexity in our system.
The response states further:
Their needs are best met by a more detailed account of abilities than is to be found in a single number cypher.

In other words, the Government's response is unnecessarily making fun of employers in this Territory, as if they were trying to assess the ability of students coming from schools and seeking employment on the basis of a single number, a point score out of 100, or whether their priorities for choosing a person for employment should be based upon a single percentage. That is not the case amongst employers in the Australian Capital Territory and it is not the case amongst parents in the Australian Capital Territory. Of course there is every encouragement in this Territory, as in all parts of Australia, for parents and employers to have a full and descriptive account of the abilities of school leavers to take into account their academic achievement in a range of areas that can be quite various, to take into account their personal development and their aptitude for employment in various areas. It is entirely unworthy of the Government to respond to this Senate Committee's report by flinging off such empty criticisms at the citizens of this Territory.

On behalf of the Opposition I express profound dissatisfaction with the Government's response to the Senate Committee's report, not only in defending the original annual report's inadequate reference to these matters of controversy, but also in giving an unbending, unyielding defence of current practice in assessment, despite quite different practices in other States; despite the unanimous finding of the Senate Committee that there ought to be a change in the Australian Capital Territory and that consideration ought to be given to an external examination element within the assessment procedure; and the inadequacy of this Government reponse in its reference to the alleged sex bias by putting in one brief sentence without squarely acknowledging its error, through Senator Ryan's intervention to adjust scores in 1983.

When the Government's response becomes known to the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory and offence is caused by its accusations and arrogant criticisms of employers and parents, I think much more will rebound upon this Government. In any event, members of the Senate Committee will seek to debate this response and its inadequacies more carefully after the statement has been studied in the coming days. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes for Senator Button) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to financial assistance by the Commonwealth for certain research and development.
Bill presented by Senator Grimes, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is a step in the process of completing the Government's package to promote technology in industry and the Government's industry policy objectives. These objectives are to encourage the development of internationally competitive, export oriented and innovative industries in Australia. Australia needs to build on its innovative skills and research strengths by lifting the level of research and development undertaken by industry, by improving awareness of technology in industry and by forging strong links between industry and researchers. It is imperative that industry should develop a `technology culture' so that it becomes aware of opportunities resulting from research in Australia and overseas.

Research and development spending by Australian industry is low (0.22 per cent of GDP compared with a median of 0.98 per cent for OECD medium R&D performers) and has been declining over recent years. The Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) in its recent report on Public Investment in Research and Development in Australia said that a substantial increase in innovation and performance of industry research and development is necessary. This present level of research and development is just not good enough if Australian industry is to be internationally competitive. The Government is prepared to give generous assistance to Australian industry to become more competitive. It is now up to industry to take up the opportunities the Government has provided.

Research and development leads to the development of new and improved products which assists industry in opening up new markets, expanding existing markets and becoming more competitive. It also assists development of new or improved production processes which increase productivity and helps make industry more competitive. Most importantly, performance by industry of R&D raises its awareness of technological development and facilitates better choices in the purchase and introduction of technology.

Research and development is only one, albeit significant input to successful innovation and improved industry performance. Other elements of the innovation process including production, management, finance and marketing expertise, are also fundamental to success. Policies to promote increased R&D in Australia should therefore be seen as an integral part of our broader industry and technology policies.

The key element in the Government's effort to encourage research and development is the market forces based 150 per cent tax concession. The concession has operated since 1 July 1985 and is estimated to cost around $100m in 1986-87.

To date the signs are encouraging, already some 900 companies have indicated that they intend to make use of the tax concession scheme in 1985-86 and 1986-87. Based on data provided by these companies the anticipated increase in real R&D expenditure in 1985-86 will be in excess of 30 per cent. Further increases are expected in 1986-87.

When announcing the tax concession scheme on 29 May last year I indicated the Government's awareness that not all firms could benefit from it. For example, the 150 per cent tax concession would not support worthwhile research and development by startup firms which are important sources of innovation and wealth creation. Such firms need `up front' cash to support essential research and development projects and because, in their initial years of operation, they do not make profits, they are unable to benefit from the tax concession.

To this end the Government has decided to introduce measures aimed at filling important gaps in research and development assistance. A new scheme, the Grants for Industry Research and Development (GIRD) Scheme, with the following major elements will be introduced:

Discretionary Grants: providing a similar level of effective support as the tax concession does for taxable companies (i.e. a taxable grant of 50 per cent of eligible expenditure). These grants will have broadly similar form to the project grants of the present Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme.

Generic Technology Grants: to support new or emerging technologies of fundamental significance for industry competitiveness in the 1990s but unlikely to develop if left to the market alone; these grants would fund development of research in collaboration with industry to a stage where industry would take up further development; and
National Interest Agreements: awarded for projects with significant national benefits which would not be undertaken by industry on a commercial basis.

It might be argued that, as the tax concession is available to all companies which have tax liability, all companies without tax liability should be eligible for discretionary grants. However, in the context of limited funding the Government has of necessity opted for a selective approach. Only those enterprises which meet certain criteria will be eligible for discretionary grants. Highest priority for grants will be given to newly established firms needing up front cash to carry out their innovation projects. They would be those adjudged competent to perform or have performed the required research and development and to commercially exploit the results.

On commercial viability grounds regular loss makers who cannot demonstrate a plan to become profitable should not generally warrant support. In their case research and development support may not be the main problem.

However, there will be instances, for example, where a long established but consistent loss making firm is involved in industry restructuring for which the discretionary grant may be a very effective form of adjustment assistance.

Grants would be payable for a maximum period of three years in respect of any one project. The definition of research and development which qualifies will be the same as for the 150 per cent tax concession. Grants will be limited to certain areas initially, including manufacturing, mining, construction and computer software.

New or emerging technologies with the potential to significantly influence industrial development in the 1990's are unlikely to be fully developed if left to the market alone. The market orientated tax concession would therefore not assist research and development in these areas. Risk is high, the development time frame is often very long and sufficient appropriation of the benefits by the researcher is often not possible. Even with the 150 per cent tax concession it is doubtful whether firms will be able to adequately diversify the risk involved for optimal investment from a community viewpoint. An element of `technology push' is needed to provide the fundamental support. Yet these technologies have application over a range of industries and can strengthen or extend existing comparative advantages. They can be directed at the creation of new markets through development of new products; and they can revitalise existing industry, increasing its productivity through new and improved process technology. For the purposes of the proposed new R&D incentives these areas of technology have been labelled `Generic Technologies'.

Some examples of such broad-ranging technology areas are biotechnology, microelectronics and advanced materials. Within such areas there could be numerous technologies. For example, priority application areas for the existing National Biotechnology Program Research Grants Scheme range from plant agriculture, through veterinary, animal husbandry, pharmaceutical/medical, biotechnology equipment and instrumentation, food processing to the chemicals industry.
From time to time there will also be research and development projects with significant national benefits for which the researcher is unable to capture sufficient benefits to interest entrepreneurs.

Australia's very good record of scientific research is not reflected in the application of science and technology in industry. Support for these `Generic' and `National Interest' areas of technology could be a mechanism for bridging the gap between researchers and commercial interests, for promoting a research and development culture in which both industry and research institutions participate. The benefit of such interaction is two-way. Industry becomes aware of the opportunities R&D presents to provide new products or new/improved processes. Research institutions become aware of opportunities to extend their fields of study and to orient their work toward industry.

Biotechnology has already been identified as having potential benefits for a wide range of industries and will be the first generic technology for the purposes of the scheme. The Research Grants Scheme of the National Biotechnology Program will be incorporated in the Generic Technology Grants element of the new scheme. Other generic technologies, such as advanced materials, may be declared eligible for assistance under the scheme in future.

The GIRD Scheme will be administered by the Industry Research and Development Board with responsibility to select projects for support according to guidelines determined by the Minister. The Board will be assisted by committees with expertise in specific areas and supported by a secretariat. Firms wishing to take advantage of the 150 per cent tax concession will register with the Board. The GIRD Scheme will operate for five years from 1 July 1986 until the tax concession scheme expires. GIRD and the tax concession scheme will be reviewed at the same time.

Sunset provisions in the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976 mean that no further Commencement Grants funded under that Act will be made after 30 June 1986. A report by the consultants, Price Waterhouse, has indicated that this element of the previous Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme (AIRDIS) had not been very effective. This was supported in a report by the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board itself.

After 30 June, the Project Grants funded under that Scheme would be replaced by the Discretionary Grants under the new scheme and Public Interest Projects would be replaced by National Interest Agreements. Commencement Grants for eligible research and development expenditure incurred before 1 July 1986 will continue to be paid in accordance with the provisions in the present Act. Project Grant agreements entered into prior to 1 July 1986 will be honoured. This will also be the case with Public Interest Projects.

With the Grants for Industry Research and Development Scheme and the 150 per cent taxation concession I believe the Government has got its price subsidy support for industry research and development about right. Some smaller changes may still be required and, of course, we will monitor and, as need be, adjust our policy strategies.

Together the two schemes will help significantly improve the overall climate for research and development in industry, contributing to the development of more innovative and internationally competitive and export oriented industries in Australia. With other initiatives such as the National Industry Extension Service and revised Offsets arrangements they are an integral part of the Government's strategy to make technology work for Australia.

There are encouraging signs that the 150 per cent taxation concession has already had a positive impact on industry attitudes to research and development. I am confident that the two schemes will lead to a significant increase in the private sector's commitment to R&D and to the development of a ``technology culture'' in Australian industry.
Financial Impact Statement

The cost of the new scheme contained in this Bill in 1986/87 would be $12.5 million. In addition existing forward obligation for AIRDIS would have to be met: $45.2 million in 1986/87. The present cost of AIRDIS and the biotechnology grants scheme is about $70 million annually. Savings will therefore be around $12 million in 1986/87.

The main form of assistance for R&D in industry will be the 150 per cent tax concession. On the basis of registrations received this is estimated to cost around $100 million in regard to income tax returns for the year 1985/86. It is not possible to estimate the 1986/87 cost of that measure until registrations are received and a more precise cost will not be known for 1986/87 until tax claims for that year are made in 1987/88.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I table the explanatory memorandum for the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes a number of amendments to certain bounty and subsidy Acts administered by the Comptroller-General of Customs.

For some time it has been the practice in this Parliament to have wherever possible cognate debates on bounty and subsidy schemes. Consistent with this practice this omnibus Bill contains all of the proposed amendments to bounty and subsidy Acts which are at this time required to be dealt with in the 1986 autumn sittings. New bounty and subsidy schemes will continue to be self contained in individual Bills in the usual way.
The most important measures in this Bill, which I will detail shortly, propose amendments to-
(1) the Bounty (Computers) Act to enable bounty to be paid under the provisions of that Act on modems and multiplexers generally used with computers;
(2) the Bounty (High Alloy Steel Products) Act to introduce separate bounty schedules for high alloy steel bar products and stainless steel flat products; and
(3) the Bounty (Ships) Act to enable bounty to be paid under the provisions of that Act on certain hovercraft.

The significant amendments to the other bounty Acts acquit undertakings given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to provide a right of review of determinations by the Comptroller-General of Customs in respect of the effective registration date of premises and, in the case of the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act, decisions by the Minister in relation to the modification of bountiable equipment.

The other amendments contained in the Bill are of a formal nature which either correct minor errors discovered in the principal Acts or slightly vary schemes to ensure that any bounty or subsidy is correctly paid.
I now turn to the major amendments proposed in this Bill.

The addition of modems and multiplexers to the definition of `bountiable equipment' under the Bounty (Computers) Act is proposed as a consequence of the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report No. 352 of 5 October 1984 on telecommunications and related equipment and parts.
Modems and multiplexers are communications equipment used as the link between computers to enable them to communicate with one another.
The Government's acceptance of the IAC recommendation that a 25 per cent value added production bounty on modems and multiplexers generally used with computers was announced on 10 October 1985.

The decision to introduce this bounty on units produced after 1 July 1986 recognises the increasing convergence of telecommunications and computer technologies and the need for consistency in the assistance accorded the various segments of the information industries. The introduction of the bounty together with consequential tariff changes is designed to remove assistance anomalies between these goods and other computer equipment, reduce problems of product substitution, and complement earlier government decisions designed to foster the local computer hardware industry and avoid cost imposts associated with the widespread use of computer equipment.

Finally, in relation to this act, the provisions of clause nine of the Bill which are in similar terms to section 9 of the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act make it clear that an IAC report is not required prior to the making of any ministerial declarations for the purposes of section 5 of the Act. The provisions of section 5 of the Act provide the facility to vary the classes of equipment eligible for bounty by ministerial gazettes notice. This facility is essential to cater for the rapidity of technological change in this industry and thereby keep the Government assistance package relevant to the needs of the industry. It was the intention from the inception of the legislation that section 5 variations would be made without an IAC inquiry on each occasion, though they would still be subject to parliamentary scrutiny through the usual tabling and disallowance procedures.
