The amendments to the Bounty (High Alloy Steel Products) Act in part 5 of the Bill replace the present single schedule of bounty rates with separate schedules for high alloy steel bar products and stainless steel flat products. This alteration is proposed as a consequence of the Government's acceptance of a recommendation by the Steel Industry Authority.

When the present bounty arrangements were put in place Comsteel, the major producer of steel bar products, was also the sole producer of steel flat products. Following an industry re-organisation in April 1984 the production of bar and flat products respectively was transferred to the separate companies of Comsteel Vickers and the BHP Coated Products Division.

As a result of relatively buoyant market conditions being experienced by the manufacturer of flat products, bounty payments for both sectors of the market have been at low levels. This has been detrimental to the manufacturer of bar products, Comsteel Vickers, which is experiencing depressed market conditions.

The proposals in this Bill are thus designed to enable each sector of the industry to receive an appropriate level of bounty assistance based on product sales, as intended under the steel industry plan.
The new schedules are constructed on a similar sliding scale to the present arrangements, providing maximum assistance at uneconomic levels of output and phasing out at higher levels.

A maximum bounty rate of 20 per cent will be payable where the annual rate of sales is less than 10,500 tonnes for high alloy steel bar products and less than 10,000 tonnes for stainless steel flat products respectively. No bounty is payable where the annual rate of sales is in excess of 23,000 tonnes for bar products and 25,000 tonnes for flat products.
The previous bounty ceiling of $9 million, which applied to the combined sales of both sectors will be apportioned on the basis of $3.28m for bar products and $5.72m for flat products.
The new bounty schedules are to apply retrospectively from 1 July 1985.

The last of the major proposals contained in Part 7 of this Bill will permit bounty to be paid under the Bounty (Ships) Act on the production of hovercraft type vessel, of over 150 gross construction tons if such vessels are registered as ships and used to convey passengers or goods solely or principally over water ways.

Hovercraft were previously excluded from bounty eligibility in 1980 because there was no hovercraft industry in Australia at that time, and the construction techniques then employed and the method of propulsion, principally jet engined, were considered to relate more to the aircraft industry than to shipbuilding.

Since then, however, Australian industry has developed the capacity to manufacture air-cushioned vehicles, commonly referred to as hovercraft, using shipyard techniques and powered by diesel marine engines. These vessels are registered and controlled under the relevant shipping regulations.

As such vessels compete directly with high speed ferries and hydrofoils, both of which are eligible for bounty under the Act, it has been decided to extend the present Act to cover these air-cushioned vessels.
The impact on bounty payments is expected to be slight as hovercraft essentially compete with other high speed vessels and any hovercraft sales would be largely at the expense of the other craft.

In conjunction with the bounty proposal it is proposed that air-cushioned vehicles falling to chapter 89 of the Customs Tariff Act which exceed 150 gross construction tons and which are currently dutiable at 25 per cent, will be free of duty. This will bring hovercraft into line with the tariff treatment accorded other bountiable vessels in the Customs Tariff Act.
Financial Impact Statement
The inclusion of modems and multiplexers as bountiable products under the Bounty (Computers) Act is expected to cost an additional $3.5 million per annum in bounty payments under that Act in 1986-87.

It is anticipated that the bounty payments under the new steel arrangements in the Bounty (High Alloy Steel Products) Act will be about $4.3 million in 1985-86 compared with $3.5 million under the existing arrangements.
With respect to the proposed amendments to the Bounty (Ships) Act the market potential for hovercraft has been assessed at 2 per annum involving bounty payments of approximately $1.2 million.

However overall expenditure is expected to be minimal as the hovercraft would be essentially competing with other high speed bountiable vessels and any sales of hovercraft would largely be at the expense of those other craft.
The other proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 which is now before the Senate contains significant amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1982.
The Bill contains 10 schedules which incorporate changes-
(i) initially introduced by gazette notice and subsequently proposed in the House of Representatives as Customs Tariff proposals;
(ii) introduced directly by Customs Tariff proposals; or
(iii) which are being introduced by this Bill.

Schedule 1 to the Bill is operative on and from the first of July 1985 and provides the mechanism for the restoration of duty free admission of certain parts used in the construction or modification of bountiable vessels.

The Government's October 1984 decision on the Australian Shipbuilding Industry provided for the removal of the 2% revenue duty on imports of such ships' parts, making them duty free. This was intended to assist shipbuilders to hold down costs of inputs and improve their competitiveness against imported new vessels, which are duty free.
At that time most ships' parts were admissible at 2% under a customs by-law. This by-law subsequently lapsed on the first of July 1985 when the old commercial by-law system was terminated.

By ceasing to be eligible for the 2% duty rate provided for by the customs by-law they thus lost their eligibility for the further duty free concession. This nullified the intent of the shipbuilding assistance package.

The amendment in this schedule reinstates the eligibility of the parts for the 2% duty and consequently they will again become free of duty in accordance with the government's shipbuilding assistance decision.

Schedule 2 to the Bill, operative on and from the second of August 1985, provides for the wool content level in the pile of carpets from New Zealand eligible for duty free entry to be reduced from 80% to 78% by weight.

This relaxation of the wool content requirement has been agreed with New Zealand under the Australia New Zealand closer economic relations-trade agreement and takes effect from the date set out in the exchange of letters between the relevant Australian and New Zealand ministers.
Schedule 3 to the Bill, operative on and from the twenty-first of August 1985, complements the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Act 1985 which was passed in the 1985 budget sittings.
This schedule removes the 15% general tariff rate previously applicable to grain harvesters and certain parts for these machines.
Also included in this schedule is a consequential amendment to maintain the duty treatment applicable to certain metal parts.

The changes contained in Schedule 4 to the Bill are operative on and from the eleventh of October 1985 and implement most of the government's decisions on the industries assistance commission's report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts.
The changes arising from this report are the first stage of the two stage plan to revitalise Australia's communications equipment industry for growth into the 1990s and beyond.

Under this first stage, the Government has accepted the IAC's recommendation that tariffs on most imported telecommunications products and components be reduced from 30% to 20%. These reductions are being phased in over a four year period. The IAC's report on the industry had recommended reductions over a two year period for most products.

In agreeing to a four year phased reduction, the Government has sought the co-operation of the local industry in developing a comprehensive strategy to address the industry's long term problems. This strategy is expected to be announced by the middle of 1986.
Issues which need to be addressed to enable the local industry to become more internationally competitive, export oriented and innovative include:
The relatively small size of Australian companies;
Insufficient commitment to local research and development;
Fragmented market efforts; and
Restrictive regulatory procedures which act as a disincentive to growth.

These broad issues will be tackled in the later package of measures. From the government's side, the package would largely entail improved co-ordination of existing government activities, particularly in the areas of government purchasing, offsets, technology programs, regulation and trade strategies.

The government's decision to handle the question of assistance in two stages was the result of extended consultation within government departments, with industry groups and other interested bodies, and with the government's tripartite advisory council on the electrical, electronics and information industries. These groups are continuing to be actively involved in developing the package of industry development measures, within the framework of general government policies.

As part of its decision on the IAC's report, the government has accepted the recommendation for a 25% value added production bounty to be paid on modems and multiplexors generally used with computers. This bounty is to apply from the first of July 1986 and the duty applicable to equivalent imported goods will be reduced to minimum rates from that date. In addition, preforms used in the manufacture of optical fibre are to be subject to a general tariff rate of 20% from the first of July 1986. The relevant tariff changes are contained in Schedule 9 to this Bill.
Schedule 5 to the Bill is operative from the twenty-second of November 1985 and comprises most of the legislation to implement the government's decision on the IAC's report on re-import concessions.
The government's decision results in considerable simplification of the provisions governing the concessional entry of goods which have previously been exported from Australia.

Goods, and parts of goods, which are returned to Australia without any change to the identity they possessed when they were exported are eligible for duty free entry. Unlike the previous concession, there is no requirement that the goods have not entered the commerce of another country; no time limit after which they are not eligible for duty free entry or that their ownership has not changed. The requirement that all Commonwealth taxes and charges due at the time of exportation from Australia have either been paid and not refunded, or, if refunded, are paid again prior to duty free entry being granted, does, however, remain.

A new provision is being inserted into the Customs Tariff Act to allow the duty free admission of goods repaired overseas, or replaced, under a specific warranty applicable to previously imported goods.

One of the Government's decisions is not included in this particular schedule to the Bill. Goods exported for repair or renovation which cannot be performed in Australia are to be eligible for duty free entry under commercial tariff concession orders made by the Comptroller-General of Customs.

New provisions are being inserted into the Customs Act 1901 by the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 to enable such orders to be issued on and from the first of July 1986. The consequential amendment to the Customs Tariff Act 1982 is contained in Schedule 9 to this Bill.
A minor amendment is being made to the remaining provision relating to the concessional entry for goods returned to Australia after having undergone repair or renovation overseas.

Provided that the goods retain the identity they possessed when they were exported, the duty payable on their return will be assessed on the value of the repair or renovation only, at the ad valorem rate applicable to the parent goods. In line with the IAC's recommendation, this provision does not apply to goods subjected to alteration overseas.

Schedule 6 to the Bill puts in place tender quota provisions associated with the post-1984 arrangements for passenger motor vehicles. This schedule is operative on and from the first of December 1985.
Following amendments made last year to the Customs Act 1901 it is now possible to depart from a rigid twelve month period for tender quota allocations.

Accordingly, a period of fourteen months is being provided for the one year quota to allow a one month anticipation before the start of the calendar year and a one month carry-over after its conclusion.
Similarly, the four periods involved in the four year tender will each run from the first of December in a year to the thirty-first of January fourteen months later.
Vehicles imported under the single period tender quota scheme attract a general tariff tender quota rate of 81.5%, a premium of twenty-four percentage points over the base quota rate.
For the four year tender quota scheme the tender quota rate is 68.5%, eleven percentage points higher than the 57.5% base quota rate.
Schedule 7 to the Bill is operative from the first of January 1986 and contains a variety of amendments.

The amendment of Schedule 1 to the Principal Act removes Portugal from the list of countries eligible for developing country preference. This action coincides with Portugal's becoming a member of the European Economic Community. Similar action was taken when Greece joined the Community.
This Schedule puts in place the 1986 developing country preference and tender quota arrangements applying under the Government's textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy.
Included in these amendments are arrangements to allow for extensions of validity for textiles, clothing and footwear tender quota allocations.

Also included in this Schedule are amendments removing redundant phasing rates of duty from Schedule 3 and Part II of Schedule 4 to the Principal Act. This action has enabled further tariff simplification to occur as certain tariff classifications are amalgamated. In a similar vein, redundant phasing provisions in Schedule 5 to the Principal Act, which covers New Zealand imports, are being removed.

The final amendment in Schedule 7 amends Item 23 in Part I of Schedule 4 to the Principal Act. This Item was inserted in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1985 which was passed in the 1985 Budget sittings.

It has been found that the Item is deficient in that it does not provide concessional admission for parts of the components designated in the Item. Such parts for components were eligible for bounty payment under the previous assistance regime for heavy commercial motor vehicles and thus should receive the benefits of the provisions of Item 23. The amendment of the Item will achieve this objective.

Schedule 8 to the Bill, operative on and from the eighteenth of February 1986, provides for the application of the principles of the Government's decision to implement a revised system of tariff preferences for developing countries to the goods covered by the Industries Assistance Commission's report on tableware and other goods of ceramics.
The Government decided that, in accordance with the IAC's recommendation, the general tariff rate for the goods under reference should remain at 20%.

I will outline the principles of the new developing countries preference scheme when I come to Schedule 9 of the Bill but in regard to goods of Tariff Item 69.11, covering tableware and other goods of porcelain or China, all developing country imports will receive a five percentage points margin.

For tableware and other goods not being of porcelain or China (Tariff Item 69.12) the Republic of Korea and Taiwan Province will remain ineligible for the 15% developing country rate until the first of July 1988.
Schedule 9 to the Bill contributes most to its size. Its operative date is the first of July 1986.
This Schedule implements new preference arrangements for developing countries and for forum island countries.
Under the revised developing countries preference scheme, the developing country rate will be five percentage points below the general tariff rate, where that general tariff rate is 5% or greater.
For goods subject to other than an ad valorem rate a margin equivalent to five percentage points is being provided.

The new scheme will not apply to goods where there is no protective rate, or where goods only attract duties identical to Australian excise tariff rates. For goods incurring both excise and protective rates the new scheme will apply to the protective component but such rates have been structured so that in no circumstance will the rate be lower than the equivalent excise rate.
Developing country quotas will be abolished except where they relate to textiles, clothing and footwear products where quotas will continue until the thirty-first of December 1988.
Under the new scheme there is no provision for graduating either products or countries from it.

As a transitional measure, where action has been taken to exclude countries from the present scheme for particular products in the three years prior to the first of July 1986, they will continue to be excluded for a further two years.
The scheme will apply to products covered by the textiles, clothing and footwear industries plan from the end of the current plan on the thirty-first of December 1988.

It will apply to goods covered by the steel and motor vehicles sectoral policies from the first of July 1986. However, the current exclusions of certain countries for some cold-rolled steel products will continue until the end of the present steel plan on the thirty-first of December 1988 and quotas already allocated for the importation of motor vehicles will be continued at the existing margin of preference.

The existing developing countries scheme has distorted Australian industry policy, increased disparities in tariff assistance between like goods and created uncertainty about assistance levels for local manufacturers thereby hampering restructuring and business planning. It has also led to increasing friction with Australia's developing country trading partners.
The revised scheme will be administratively simpler, more certain in application, and focus attention towards more constructive industry developments and trade goals.

The Government recognises that, as a result of the changes, preference margins will be created in some areas and increased in others. Overall this will be offset by significantly reduced margins in other areas of industry.

The Government considers that the application of a five percentage points margin of preference would not be large enough to cause any major difficulties for industry. However, reference to the Industries Assistance Commission remains where an industry is experiencing difficulties competing against imports from any source.
The Government's decision follows a thorough review of the system of granting preferential access to developing countries.

As part of this review Professor Helen Hughes of the Centre for Development Studies at the Australian National University was commissioned to report on the scheme and her recommendations form the substance of the new approach.
In the review the Government rejected such options as abandonment of DC preferences or adoption of trigger mechanisms to automatically graduate countries or products out of the scheme.
The option adopted reaffirms Australia's commitment to the concept of developing country preferences.
Australia was the first country in the world to introduce such preferences, which are now accorded by most developed countries.
The new scheme represents a significant improvement over the existing scheme.
The new scheme provides Australian industry and all Australia's trading partners, both developed and developing, with a settled framework for development of investment and trading plans.
Under the new system the developing country tariff rate and the general tariff rate will be set as a package and industry planning can proceed in this knowledge.
Australian industry seeking to complement local production with external sourcing can plan with greater confidence than exists under the present arrangements.

In discussion most of the developing countries in the Australian region have welcomed the broad thrust of the new system which incorporates important principles endorsed by the developing countries generally.

Some disappointment has been expressed at the reduction that will be entailed in existing margins of preference for some items and a larger margin of preference than five percentage points was generally desired.

The Australian Government considers that any disadvantage arising from margin reductions will be offset in the longer term by the guarantees of margins at any volume of trade in the situation where Australia's tariffs are moving towards lower levels of assistance.
The other initiative in regard to Australia's trading relations contained in Schedule 9 is the new Forum Island Preference Scheme.
Australia undertook a major review of the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement in 1985.

Following this review the Prime Minister announced at the 1985 South Pacific Forum meeting in the Cook Islands that Australia would introduce a new scheme which would expand the duty free access entitlement for Forum Island countries on and from the first of January 1987.
The Prime Minister announced that duty free unrestricted access would be granted for all exports from forum island countries, other than for those goods to which sectoral policies apply.
The goods covered by these sectoral policies are textiles, clothing and footwear, steel, passenger motor vehicles and sugar.
In addition, those products on which excise is levied when they are produced in Australia will be subject to a customs duty at the same rate as the excise duty.

The government has now decided that, with the exception of passionfruit products, the introduction date of the new scheme will be brought forward to the first of July 1986 to coincide with the commencement date of the new developing countries preference scheme. The changes in regard to passionfruit products will take effect from the first of January 1987. The original operative date for passionfruit products is being maintained to allow a transition period for local producers because virtually all imported passionfruit products come from the forum islands and these islands have a penetration of the Australian market in excess of ten per cent.
Schedule 9 also includes those changes to operate from the first of July 1986 which arise from the Government's decision on the IAC's report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts.
Certain modems and multiplexors are to become dutiable at minimum rates and optical fibre preforms are to be dutiable at a general tariff rate of 20%.

An amendment is being made to item 3 in part I of schedule 4 to the principal Act which presently provides duty free entry for goods imported for the personal or official use of the Governor-General, the Governor of a State, a member of the family of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State or a member of the staff of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State, being a member of the staff who is not an Australian citizen.

This concession goes back to the time when governors and their staff were mostly appointed from outside the country. As this is no longer the case there is no justification for continuing concessions in relation to goods for personal use.

The concession is accordingly being restricted to goods for the official use of the Governor-General, the Governor of a State or a member of the family of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State. No concessions will be available for members of the staff of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State.
The final amendment required to implement the Government's decision on the IAC's report on re-import concessions is also contained in schedule 9.

Item 31 in Part I of Schedule 4 is re-drafted to allow the issue of commercial tariff concession orders for goods exported for repair or renovation which cannot be performed in Australia in the normal course of business.
The opportunity has also been taken in this schedule to remove all redundant phasing rates from the various schedules to the principal Act.
The final schedule to the Bill, schedule 10, is to operate seven days after royal assent of the legislation.

This schedule inserts a new legal note, note 12 to chapter 84 in schedule 3 to the principal Act, defining the term ``of the track-laying type'' which is used in connection with tractors and tractor bases.

Special provisions for goods ``of the track-laying type'' at minimum rates of duty have appeared in the customs tariff for many years. The concept of equipment incorporating tractor bases of the track-laying type attracting a separate duty on the tractor base arose out of an IAC report in 1974.
It has always been considered that the provisions only applied to the traditional tracked vehicles that can only operate when their tracks are attached.

A recent ruling by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has applied the term in question to a loader which was imported with tracks which go over the wheels of the vehicle but which can operate as a wheeled vehicle without the tracks.
This extension of the term has had the effect of lowering the level of assistance intended to be accorded the local manufacture of such machines.
The major local manufacturer has made representations to the Government concerning this loss of assistance.
After consideration of this matter, the Government accepts that the intended assistance levels should be restored and, accordingly, an amendment is being made to the Customs Tariff Act.
Financial Impact

The revenues raised by customs duties are incidental to their prime purpose of assistance to industry. With this qualification in mind, it has been possible to make some estimates in regard to changes to customs revenue for some of the changes contained in this Bill.
The removal of the duty on grain harvesters and certain parts is expected to reduce revenue by $4.1m in 1985-86 and $8.25m annually thereafter.

The general reduction in tariffs resulting from the Government's decision on the IAC's report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts is not expected to reduce Government receipts. This conclusion is based on the knowledge that over 70 per cent of imported telecommunications equipment enters under concessional arrangements and that projected increases of dutiable imports of telecommunications equipment will more than compensate for the reductions in tariffs. In the case of outgoings the complementary amendments to the Bounty (Computers) Act in regard to modems and multiplexors is expected to cost $3.5m in 1986-87. This increase in outgoings is expected to be partly or fully compensated by increases in the level of dutiable imports of telecommunications equipment.

The changes made as a result of the Government's decision on the re-import concessions IAC report are basically designed to improve the administration of the concessions rather than vary their scope to any great degree. Thus any financial impact will be minor. Similarly, the Government's decision on the IAC's report on tableware and other goods of ceramics is revenue neutral.
It is difficult at this stage to quantify the financial impact of the revised system of tariff preferences for developing countries.

It has, however, been estimated that, overall, the revised scheme will result in a slight increase in assistance. Estimates of any additional revenue to be gained by such an increase in assistance could only be calculated on existing import trends. In order to speculate on any such increase, an assumption would need to be made that these import trends will continue after the introduction of the revised scheme. The Government is not in a position, at this stage, to so speculate.

The proposed removal of tariffs on imports from the forum island countries is not expected to have a significant impact on revenue. Australian imports from the relevant countries amounted to only $217.5 million in 1984/85 and 98% of these were accorded duty free entry. In addition, the forum island countries have limited capacity to displace third country suppliers to the Australian market.
All the other changes in the Bill are also expected to have minimal financial impact.
There are no significant administrative costs associated with the Bill.
A summary of amendments for each schedule to the Bill has been prepared. Copies are available from the records and tables office.
I commend the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (IMPACT OF PROPOSALS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to improved arrangements for administering the environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and to provide greater emphasis on public involvement in carrying out environmental assessments under the Act.

The object of the Act, which came into force in 1974, is to ensure that to the greatest extent practicable, matters affecting the environment to a significant extent are fully examined and taken into account in relation to actions and decisions of the Commonwealth Government and its authorities. The administrative procedures under the Act provide a means of achieving this objective through a process of environmental assessment which includes, provision for the preparation and public review of environmental impact statements. The Act is a cornerstone of the Government's environment protection legislation. Under its provisions the environmental implications of a wide range of proposals have been examined. These include airports, railways, ports, highways, buildings, and coal, iron ore, uranium and woodchip export projects.

Mr President, the amendments proposed by this Bill are the result of a comprehensive review of the Act by the Government. In carrying out the review, the Government has taken into account key elements in the ALP platform on the environment, and has benefited from several reports from Parliamentary Committees. On 11 October 1984, a statement was tabled in this House which provided a response to 19 recommendations in reports by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, and two recommendations in a report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, all dealing with various aspects of the legislation and related matters. On 17 April 1986 the Government's response to the recommendations of the May 1985 report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation: ``Administration of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, 1974'' was tabled.

I would like to comment on one recommendation in this report that the Government has decided not to adopt. That recommendation calls for an amendment to the Act to enable the Environment Minister to initiate action under the Act. As honourable senators will be aware, the current procedure is for the minister responsible for making the decision on a proposal-known as the ``Action Minister''-to make a decision on the environmental significance of a proposal and, by designating a proponent, formally initiate action under the Act.

After giving this matter long and careful consideration, the Government has decided not to change the current procedure. However, in reaching a decision, the Government took into account two important procedures. The first is that memoranda of understanding are to be agreed between the environment department and other Commonwealth departments and authorities. These memoranda will provide a clear basis for identifying proposals that are environmentally significant. The second is that, in the rare event that there is a difference of opinion between Ministers on the environmental significance of a particular proposal, the matter would be resolved by the normal process of referral to the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

The Act will continue to provide for the preparation, public review and submission, to the Commonwealth environment Minister, of environmental impact statements (EISs) for proposals of major environmental significance. Amendments will provide, however, for the preparation of public environment reports (PERs) for proposals with less complex, or less important environmental implications.

Experience has shown that many proposals, of a localised nature, or involving only one or two issues of environmental significance, arouse considerable public interest. Such proposals may not warrant the preparation of an EIS, which is normally a comprehensive document requiring considerable time and resources to prepare in draft and then final form. However, under current procedures there is no provision for obtaining public comment on the environmental aspects of proposals except through the procedures associated with an EIS. A PER, however, will be a simpler and less costly document than an EIS, but will still provide a sound basis for public comment and Government consideration.

The Act currently places an obligation for a proponent to provide the environment Minister, or his Department, with sufficient information to enable the Minister to decide whether an EIS should be prepared. Experience has shown that this obligation is not sufficiently clearly expressed, so an amendment of the Act will permit the Minister to require the supply of information to enable him to consider the need for an EIS or a PER.

Section 10 of the Act enables any person to write to the Minister asking what action has been taken, or is proposed, to assess a proposal under the provisions of the Act. The Minister is required to respond promptly to such requests. This provision is consistent with Government policy on freedom of information and has been frequently utilised. However, the requirement for the Minister to respond promptly was considered too vague by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation which recommended that a period of three months be specified. The Government accepts this recommendation, and the Act will be amended accordingly.

The Act enables the Minister to direct an inquiry on any environmentally significant matter for which a Commonwealth action or decision will be required. The inquiry process calls for the convening of a Commission to conduct the inquiry and for the Commission to report its findings and recommendations to the Minister. However, there is no provision in the Act for a Commission to report within a specified time. This could lead to practical difficulties. Accordingly, the Act will be amended to enable the Minister to direct a Commission to report its findings and recommendations by a specified date.

The Government's intentions to improve the administration of the environmental assessment process and to provide scope for wider public consultation are largely reflected by amendments which will be made to the administrative procedures under the Act. These amendments respond to many of the recommendations made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, and will be presented to the Governor-General-in-Council for approval in due course.
I would like briefly to touch on the more significant of these amendments.

A number of the amendments will improve the current mechanism for the preparation, public review and reporting on EISs. The amendments include making public the decision of the Minister to direct an EIS on a proposal and, on written request, to require the Minister to make public the reasons for not directing an EIS on a proposal.

Provision will be made, following the direction of an EIS, for consultation between the Department, other governmental authorities and public interest groups on the guidelines for the preparation of the EIS. Provision will also be made for consultation between the Department and the proponent during the preparation of an EIS, to ensure that an adequate response is made to the guidelines.

Other important amendments will provide for ministerial discretion to extend the period of public review beyond the current 28 day minimum, to direct a round-table discussion on a proposal following public review of an EIS, and to make public the Department's assessment report prepared after examination of a final EIS and the Minister's recommendations following such examination.

Two further amendments will relate to Government collaboration with the States and Territories. One will give formal status to the Minister's discretion to take into account any State or Territory environmental assessment action when deciding whether an EIS or a PER is required. The other will provide the Minister with authority to enter into arrangements with the States and Territories to facilitate the operation of the administrative procedures and to require that these arrangements be made public.

Mr President, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 is a major piece of legislation which, since its introduction, has significantly assisted Ministers in taking environmental implications properly into account in government decision making. The amendments to the Act and administrative procedures, which the Government intends to make, will further improve the effectiveness of the process. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill contains measures which will amend the Social Security Act 1947 and the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971.
The main amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 are-
the introduction of the ``young homeless allowance'';
a bar to payment or unemployment, sickness or special benefit to a full-time student who is eligible, in principle, for an education allowance;
a change in the treatment of lump sum compensation payable to sickness beneficiaries; and
a change in the rate of benefit that applies to a legally married but permanently separated unemployment beneficiary to the rate that applies to a single unemployment beneficiary.
The Bill will also provide for the social security amnesty.

In ``Youth Policies in the 1985-86 Budget'' (Budget Paper No. 13), the Government recognised the needs of unsupported young people, whether students or unemployed, and indicated that new provisions would be introduced, under strict conditions, to provide an independent rate of allowance equal to that of the living away from home rate under the tertiary education allowance.

This Bill introduces a new allowance for 16 and 17 year olds who are homeless and without support. It will increase the rate of income support received by 16 and 17 year old unemployment, sickness and special beneficiaries, who currently receive $50 per week. The allowance, called the ``young homeless allowance'', will result in such a beneficiary being eligible for a level of assistance equal to the tertiary education allowance, currently $73.28 per week.

The allowance is available only on strict conditions, which are intended to ensure that only those in genuine need are assisted and that there is no undue incentive for a young beneficiary to leave home.
The current measure will apply from 1 July 1986, and will cost $2m in 1986-87 and $2m in 1987-88, in broad terms.

In conjunction with this development, the Bill also provides that unemployment or sickness benefit (and in consequence, special benefit) is not available to a full-time student who is, in principle, eligible for an education allowance. The policy this reflects is that such persons should look to and be covered by education allowances rather than what are, primarily, work-force related benefits.

There will be some cases where, following recent AAT decisions, a full-time student receiving special benefit also receives an education allowance, typically a Secondary Allowances Scheme (SAS) payment. Since there will be a corresponding ``young homeless allowance'' available separately under the SAS program, most (if not all) of these beneficiaries will be more appropriately assisted by the education allowance, rather than special benefit.
Full-time students not eligible, in principle, for an education allowance may, however, qualify for benefit, as may some part-time students who will not be eligible for education allowances.

Consistent with the ``young homeless allowance'', this measure will apply from 1 July 1986. However, transitional arrangements will ensure that an eligible beneficiary at that date may continue to receive benefit until the end of the academic year.
This ``bar'' will create estimated savings of $10m in 1986-87 and $20m in 1987-88.
The Bill will make new arrangements for the treatment of a lump sum amount of compensation received by a sickness beneficiary.

In many cases there are lengthy delays in the resolution of compensation claims. Accordingly, the Act currently enables sickness benefit to be paid as an interim form of income support where a person qualified for benefit has a compensation claim pending, subject to the benefit being repaid, in whole or in part, where the claim is resolved in favour of the beneficiary.
However, it is currently unclear whether a lump sum should be treated as compensation for the balance of the person's life, the balance of the person's working life, of some lesser period.

The new arrangements would treat all lump sums in the same way by precluding a person from sickness benefit for a period calculated by dividing the lump sum by Average Weekly Earnings, as measured by the Australian Statistician. This means that anyone receiving sickness benefit who is seeking lump sum compensation will be able to be certain as to the consequences for their sickness benefit.
This initiative will apply to all lump sum payments which are paid or become payable on or after 1 July 1986, and will create estimated savings of $20m in 1986-87 and $20m in 1987-88.
The Bill will change the rate of unemployment benefit which is applicable to a beneficiary who is legally married but permanently separated.

Currently, such a person is eligible to the rate of $97.90 per week which is applicable to a single unemployment beneficiary with dependants, rather than the lower rate applicable to a single beneficiary without dependants, which is $91.45 per week.

There is no difference in principle between a legally married but permanently separated person and a person who is not married. The abolition of this unintended anomaly will also mean that where a legally married but permanently separated beneficiary is divorced, the rate of benefit applicable will not thereby drop to the rate applicable to an unmarried person.
This change will create savings of $4.5m in 1986-87 and $5m in 1987-88.

The Bill will also provide a legislative base for the social security amnesty which was announced on 12 February 1986. The amnesty is, of course, one element of the Government's strategy designed to significantly reduce social security overpayments and to further improve the administration of pensions, benefits and allowances.

The amnesty only applies to people who have omitted to do something-that is, they failed to advise a change of financial or other circumstances. It has been specifically designed for people on the ``treadmill''.

In effect, these people want to set the record straight, surrender the payment completely, or have the rate corrected downwards. However, they have been afraid to come forward in the past because they fear prosecution or having to repay the amount overpaid to them.
The amnesty allows these people to get off the ``treadmill'' without fear of repercussions.
The amnesty does not apply to people who have deliberately told lies to increase their payment or commence a new one. It does not cover changes in circumstances which occur after 12 February 1986.
It is worth emphasising that the amnesty is for ``treadmill'' cases-not those deliberately cheating the system.
The amnesty will have two main consequences.

First, future outlays will be reduced because people who come forward between 12 February 1986 and 31 May 1986 under the amnesty will cease to receive payment or will be paid their correct entitlement in the future.
Second, correcting the record in these cases will allow resources to be better targeted on the prevention, detection and recovery of overpayments in deliberate fraud cases.
The Bill will also make a number of less significant changes and make minor or technical amendments which will up-grade the Act.
I turn now to the amendments which this Bill would make to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971.
The principal aim of the amendments is to improve the administration of the Compensation system. The three main reforms proposed by the Government would-
extend the powers of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation so that a claimant may be required to provide certain information;
clarify a provision of the Act which gives rules for the calculation of weekly benefits to partially incapacitated employees; and
remove the six months time limit within which a claim for compensation must be lodged.

The Commissioner has occasionally had difficulties in obtaining information in support of a claim for compensation, particularly where the claimant has sought legal advice before making the claim for compensation.
In the absence of sufficient information to determine a claim in favour of the claimant, the Commissioner must determine that liability to pay compensation does not exist.

The claimant may then ask the Commissioner to reconsider that determination or seek review of the determination in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In general, if the reconsideration or appeal results in a more favourable determination, the claimant becomes entitled to legal costs associated with the reconsideration or appeal. Such costs are not payable in relation to the initial determination.

To overcome some cases where there has been an apparent abuse of the system, the Commissioner's powers would be extended so that the provision of the information relevant to a claim for compensation may be requested where the claimant has the information or can obtain it without unreasonable expense or inconvenience.

If the claimant fails to comply with the request and subsequently seeks a reconsideration of the initial determination, the Commissioner may declare that the claimants costs in relation to the reconsideration are not payable. A decision of this nature will itself be reviewable by the AAT.

The powers of the AAT in relation to the costs of proceedings before it will also be varied by these amendments. The AAT may not make an order in relation to the cost of proceedings in a case where the claimant failed to comply with a request for information if the AAT is satisfied that, had the Commissioner had the information requested, the initial determination would have been more favourable to the claimant.

The second reform proposed by the Government would clarify section 46 of the Compensation Act, which provides rules by which benefits payable to partially incapacitated employees are calculated. In calculating these benefits, the Commissioner is required to take account of the amount that the incapacitated employee is ``able to earn'' in some suitable employment of business.
The phrase ``able to earn'' has been subject to various interpretations, such as ``is actually earning'' or ``would be earning if he could find employment''.

It is desirable to reduce this uncertainty. Accordingly, the Bill would insert a new sub-section 46 (4a) which would set out the factors to be taken into account in determining how much a partially incapacitated employee is able to earn. Those factors include the amount the employee is actually earning, the amount the employee would be earning if he or she had accepted an offer of suitable employment, and the amount that he or she would be earning if the employee had engaged or continued to engage in suitable employment.

Where the employee has failed to seek suitable employment, the amount per week that, having regard to the state of the labour market at the relevant time, the employee could be expected to be earning in suitable employment could be taken into account. Other factors which can be considered are whether the employee's failure to accept an offer of employment, or to seek, engage or continue to engage in suitable employment was reasonable in the circumstances, as well as any other relevant matter.
The third main amendment to the Act would remove a provision imposing a time limit on the lodgment of claims which is of little practical use.

In general, a claim for compensation must be lodged within six months of the employee becoming aware of the injury or disease. However, the Act also provides that a claim for compensation made outside that period shall be deemed to have been made in good time if the Commonwealth would not be prejudiced if the claim were treated as a sufficient claim, or if the failure to lodge the claim within six months was a result of the death or absence from Australia of the claimant, or from ignorance, mistake or any other reasonable cause.

In practice, these qualifications mean that few, if any, claims will fail because of late lodgment. The Bill would remove the prescribed six months period, so that claims need only be made in writing and served on the Commissioner.

These are not all the changes to the Act which would be made by this Bill. Several other minor or technical amendments will be made and are referred to in the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the Bill.
None of the above measures have cost implications, and should produce small administrative savings.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vigor) agreed to:
That Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Vigor be postponed till three sitting days after today.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1985-86[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1985-86APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1985-86]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate are Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1985-86. The purpose of the Bills is to provide the Government with funds to cover essential additional expenditure for 1985-86, and the Opposition does not oppose them. However, as indicated by Senator Michael Baume, the Opposition will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) highlighting the litany of promises broken by the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills provide an opportunity to focus some attention on the current sorry state of the Australian economy and on the Government's contribution to that very sorry state. The first thing I must say is that the outlook is appalling. This is not simple doomsaying by an opposition trying to talk down the economy, nor does it simply reflect the views of those who the Government claims have an ideological axe to grind. Unfortunately, it is an economic fact that our prospects, both in the short and long term, are of great concern to all thinking Australians. After one and a half terms of the Labor Government, despite the heaps of congratulations bestowed by it on its prices and incomes accord, despite a massive devaluation of our currency that was supposed to make us more competitive by providing a fillip to our manufacturing sector, despite the world economic recovery and despite having had the benefit of a wages pause and the breaking of the drought in 1983, Australia today faces the following economic predicaments.

We have a current annual inflation rate of 9.2 per cent. This contrasts with our major trading partners' much lower rates. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average is a mere 3.8 per cent and that figure is inflated by New Zealand's inflation rate, which stands at about 16 per cent. Moreover, the gap is widening, not narrowing, despite the assurances of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the rate of inflation has peaked. He says this every month even though we keep reaching new levels of inflation. Australia's comparative inflation rate is the worst in nearly 30 years. The Government has absolutely no cause for complacency or self-congratulation on this. One can fool some of the people some of the time but not all the people all the time. We are about to award ourselves a 2.5 per cent CPI wage increase on top of the 3.8 per cent awarded in November. In addition, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is being pressured by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to award a 3 per cent so-called productivity award, to be followed by a further 4 per cent in October in wage indexation-and government spokesmen talk about declining labour costs.

In 1986 our unit labour costs are likely to increase by about 6.5 per cent. The projected figure in the seven major industrial countries for the same period is a mere 2.5 per cent. The apologists on the Labor benches, who bury their heads in the sand, miss the point when they continually refer back to the 1981 wages explosion in their defence of the accord. What happened in 1983-85 may have been an improvement. After all, the unions now have no need to try to destroy the Government of the day as they did in 1982. The unions have their Government firmly under the political control of the ACTU, but such comparisons are simply irrelevant. The simple fact is that we should be doing better than we are on the inflation front, and the Government cannot get away from this.

The reason for our inability to compete is our high domestic cost structure-specifically our labour costs. It is not simply that wages are too high-in some industries they are; in some they are not. The problem is that wage rises currently apply across the board. They hit every industry, every producer, and every firm in Australia, irrespective of capacity to pay or capacity to compete effectively overseas. This is why the accord must go. Senator Button knows that the accord, as currently constituted, cannot deliver the competitiveness that has eluded us despite the depreciation. The Government knows it; the financial Press knows it. Charlie Fitzgibbon, described by Bill Kelty as the most impressive union official he has ever dealt with, knows it. The Confederation of Australian Industry knows it.

At the very least, the productivity case must be deferred. The September wage case must be discounted, and industries which cannot pay should not pay. I simply point to our declining terms of trade, our foreign debt of nearly $80 billion which is growing at the rate of approximately $1 billion a month due to our current account problems and our record Budget deficits of the past three years.

It is time that we as a nation faced the fact that we either accept the facts by moderating wage rises, or else we face further reduced living standards by further depreciations of our currency. The choice is ours. It is not a matter of sweated workshops or exploitation of the workers. It is stark economic reality, sheeted home by the exposition of our economic performance by a floating exchange rate.

I turn to some of the other economic indicators that give us cause for great concern. I have mentioned inflation. I have mentioned our overseas debt, which now stands at $70 billion. When Labor came to power it was half what it is today. The last three Budgets have contained deficits totalling $20 billion. They are all records. The current account deficit after nine months of 1985-86 stands at $10.4 billion-greater than the total for 1984-85 and likely to exceed Budget projections this year by about $3 billion. The J curve is looking decidedly droopy. Let me quote the often-quoted comment of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who said:
I don't know who invented the bloody J-curve but I tell you it wasn't an Australian who learnt about the Australian economy.

Despite the depreciation, manufacturing production is not picking up. Import substitution does not appear to be solving our problems on current account. Economic activity, according to Westpac Banking Corporation and others, is declining; retail sales are falling; and new dwelling approvals have dropped, as have motor vehicle registrations. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has expressed doubts about the likelihood of further employment growth. These are all reliable barometers of the economy. They are not doomsaying; they are facts.

There are other facts. Interest rates remain at record levels while rates are falling dramatically overseas. High rates are stifling business investment, hurting rural producers and choking growth. They are placing an inordinate amount of pressure on monetary policy, a fact acknowledged by no less an authority than Mr Bob Johnston, Governor of the Reserve Bank. Interest rates remain high because the Government does not trust the dollar. It will not let the dollar go because it does not have sufficient faith in the economy-and in particular, in the unions-to adjust. What a sad commentary that is.

I turn to the much-vaunted trilogy-the Government's own test of fiscal rectitude. The trilogy fails my test of prudent government spending, but it also fails its own test. The Budget deficit has blown out by about $1.2 billion in 1985-86. This is despite an increase in revenue collections of roughly the same amount over the same period, and despite the Government's fiddling of the books over the oil price reductions. Hence, to come in on target as far as the trilogy is concerned, the Government must make cuts of over $1 billion, and, on the evidence, it is simply unable to do this. It will not have a mini-Budget before the Australian Labor Party's National Conference in July-the Left would not allow that. But I doubt whether the Government will be able to make the required cuts at all. Certainly its pruning efforts of the last two years have been reabsorbed in new spending programs. Yet the Government must act to relieve the burden it now places on monetary policy, otherwise the economy will simply dip into recession. And we cannot afford that. The Government's own revenue requirements cannot afford it either.

I refer to taxation. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) threatens to break yet another promise of his Government-to cancel this year's promised tax cuts-if the Opposition achieves the defeat or amendment of the fringe benefits taxation. The Government, given its present fiscal problems, no doubt would be delighted to have this excuse. The Minister well knows that it is inflation that will largely pay for the promised tax cuts, not the fringe benefits tax. Comparative runaway inflation does have its uses for this Government.

Difficult problems require strong solutions. Earlier this year the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) suggested a six-point plan for immediate actions to restore balance and flexibility to our economic policy mix. Since the Government found the Opposition's ideas on housing interest rate ceilings so helpful in solving its problems a month or so ago, perhaps it will take similar note of the following suggestions: Firstly, there must be expenditure cuts in a mini-Budget. Secondly, the accord must be re-negotiated to provide for further discounting of wages. Thirdly, the productivity case should be abandoned, postponed, or confined to those industries that can afford to pay. Fourthly, monetary policy should be allowed to be eased. If spending cuts and wages changes take place, this will occur. Fifthly, the Government must abandon the anti-business and anti-rural elements of the tax package-negative gearing, capital gains, the foreign tax credit system and the fringe benefits tax. Finally, foreign investment guidelines must be eased.

This package of measures is only a start. Only longer term solutions will reverse our deep-seated problems-in foreign debt, current account and terms of trade, in our currency and in our hyper-regulated labour market. We must become more competitive; governments must allow us to become more competitive. This is not ideological baggage; it is not doomsaying; it is not talking down the economy. It is simply economic realism. The Government at last seems to be recognising that the problems exist and are real. Now it must act to correct the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Siddons, I would point out that the previous speaker used in a quotation a term that is regarded as unparliamentary. I note that it was in a quotation, but I think that senators wherever possible should desist from using such terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86 as it is a money Bill and, as such, we have an obligation to support the Government. The Opposition has circulated an amendment which will be moved when the Bill is called on. The Democrats have circulated an amendment to the Opposition's amendment. This Appropriation Bill covers a wide range of government finance. The debate on it has been wide-ranging, covering such things as the nuclear issue, our overseas debt on so on. I want to speak to the Liberal Party's amendment. The Liberal Party has sought to draw the Government's attention to various matters, some of which we agree with and some of which we do not agree with. For instance, the Liberal amendment states that there should be a reduction in interest rates. We certainly agree that that should be attended to by Government economic man- agers. The Liberal amendment states that the inflation rate should be brought down to 5 per cent. We certainly agree with that. So we will support paragraphs (a) (i) and (b) (ii) of the Liberal amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: We will certainly support paragraph (a) (v) of the Liberal amendment, which draws attention to the failure of the Government to fulfil its promise not to raise the interest rate ceiling on housing loans. That was a very serious about-turn by the Government. It refused to honour a promise it made to the electorate. We believe that the failure of the Government to fulfil that promise should certainly be brought to the Government's attention.

We will not support paragraphs (a) (iii) and (iv) of the Liberal amendment which maintain that taxation as a percentage of gross domestic product should be held down. We are not unduly concerned about the size of the deficit. We believe that the Government has backed itself into a very tight economic corner by making promises such as those in the trilogy. Given the present state of the economy, we fail to see how the Government can honour its trilogy commitment in relation to the size of our overall deficit. We put people before deficits. We will not support the Liberal amendment calling on the Government not to introduce a capital gains tax. I believe that our position on a capital gains tax has been made abundantly clear in this chamber. We support a mild and fair capital gains tax because, without a capital gains tax, there is no way that tax avoidance can be clamped down on.

Paragraph (b) notes the deterioration in the Australian economy as indicated by the continuing balance of payments crisis. We wholeheartedly support that. Later I will spend a few minutes of the Senate's valuable time drawing attention to aspects of the balance of payments problem. We do not support any part of paragraph (c), which relates to the introduction of a mini-Budget, condemns the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearing on the productivity case and asks that the anti-business and anti-rural elements of the tax package be withdrawn and that the Government relax foreign investment controls to encourage job-creating equity investment in Australia. That part of the amendment is in line with the Liberal Party's laissez-faire, free market approach which is precisely the approach to the economy the present Government is pursuing. In other words, we have a coalition of the Opposition and the Government which has a completely deregulated, laissez-faire economy, an economic approach which surrenders control to international financial interests.

If this course is pursued, inevitably Australia will become bankrupt. We already virtually have lost control of most of our wealth-creating enterprises. They are now owned by foreign interests. Essentially we are renting our country to international forces. At the same time we are still living massively beyond our means. We are like a family which rents its home and buys goods on hire purchase but is not earning sufficient income to pay the interest on those purchases. A family which does that is heading for disaster. Likewise, so is our country. We cannot afford to continue to borrow the money to sustain our living standards without changing our economic approach. We have to earn sufficient foreign exchange to pay the interest on the money we borrow. Right now we are not earning that foreign exchange. Between 30 and 40 per cent of our exports go simply to pay the interest payments on the money we have borrowed over the last four or five years. There has been a dramatic increase in our overseas debt and something has to be done about it.
I propose to list one or two areas to which I believe government attention should be directed. In doing so, I will be speaking to paragraph (b) of the Liberal amendment, which reads as follows:

notes the deterioration in the Australian economy as indicated by the continuing balance of payments crisis, an inflation rate twice that of our trading partners, excessively high interest rates, rising unemployment, lagging private investment in new productive capacity and the severe downturn in the housing and motor industries;

The Democrats agree with the Opposition that the Government needs to be criticised on all those points. If we are to pay our way, if we as a nation are like a family deeply in hock, we have only one solution: We have to work; we have to earn income. In terms of our national economy that means that we have to sell more goods and services overseas. We would like to sell more primary products but commodity prices are deeply depressed. We would like to sell more minerals. Again, international prices are very depressed. Therefore we must turn to our manufacturing industries. We must produce goods with a high value added content and sell them overseas. In very simple terms, this means that we have to get our manufacturing industries export-oriented and internationally competitive. They have to become very efficient so that they can sell their goods on world markets. The world must be looked on as our potential market, not the domestic market. The days are gone forever when we could look to import replacement as a solution to our balance of payment problem.

If we pursue this approach, the Government will have to assess every manufacturing industry for its export potential and then, with rifle shot accuracy, direct resources to those industries which will, in turn, earn foreign exchange and will export goods manufactured in Australia. The Government's approach has to be selective, in other words. This approach is always criticised because-in Senator Button's words-`governments should not attempt to pick winners'. We are not saying that the Government has to pick winners. We are saying that the Government has to co-operate with industry. It has to determine which industries have export potential and see what can be done to improve their export performance. That is not picking winners. It is co-operating with industry. It is certainly directing resources with rifle shot accuracy where they need to be directed now-to exports.

During the war we had to produce our armaments or we would have been overrun. How did the Government go about it? It assessed the industries that had the potential to produce armaments and encouraged them. The crisis facing us now is just as great. We have just about lost the economic war. We are just about to be told to get out. We are just about under the control of international forces, international finance institutions. Unless we realise that we have a state of emergency and that we have to do something about it we will be sold out.

If we are to save our country from going bankrupt we must husband our scarce reserves of foreign currency. The financial system must be used to direct investment to export and job-creating areas. By scrapping exchange controls, the Government has given up any powers it had to control the flow of money into and out of the country. Our increasing foreign debt makes it absolutely imperative that foreign borrowings be scrutinised and that those considered unnecessary or undesirable be disallowed. I realise that that is an approach that the Liberal Opposition certainly will not agree with but it is an approach that is now inevitable; it cannot be avoided. We cannot have the luxury of allowing money to flow into this country for any purpose whatsoever and calling on the whole community to earn the export currency to pay the interest on that foreign borrowing. We must reimpose exchange controls simply to stop speculation on the stock exchange in particular and other undesirable non-productive, non-export oriented projects.

The Government and industry must co-operate to establish a long term indicative plan in key industry sectors with world markets as the key criterion. National planning must be undertaken, with the co-operation of industry, by a body similar to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Japan. Priorities can then be set and action taken to encourage development. That is not picking winners. It is co-operating with industry to decide where we should best direct our resources. Japan has been doing it for 40 years and has built an industrial machine that is the envy of the world. It has established a balance of payments surplus that is almost embarrassing.

We must curb speculation on the stock exchange. We cannot afford to allow billions of dollars to be borrowed overseas for non-productive pursuits simply to protect companies from raiders. This means that the whole issue of takeover legislation and company law should be looked at. We should bring in reforms along the lines of ensuring that offers for companies are unconditional, that once made they cannot be varied. Offers should stipulate the closing and settlement dates and these should not be changed. We should ensure that raiding companies comply with section 50 of the Income Tax Assessment Act by first offsetting their interest on the borrowings against related dividend income before any other source of income; in other words, we should eliminate negative gearing. It is simply a matter of enforcing section 50 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Much has been said about the on-cost burden on industry. The Australian Democrats' position is very clear. Industry in Australia probably bears more on-costs than any industry anywhere else in the Western world. We refer to such things as payroll tax. This could be eliminated over a three-year period. It is a tax on labour. It adds enormously to the cost of production in Australia and adversely affects labour intensive industries. Of course, it is a State tax, but it cannot be eliminated in the States until the Federal Government is prepared to finance the States to eliminate payroll tax. While industry has to bear the burden of payroll tax, its costs of production are very high. It tends to make our industries uncompetitive with those in the rest of the world.

We should rationalise workers compensation to spread the cost more evenly across the whole community. It is an enormous additional burden. Workers compensation has very largely become a personal insurance for workers, whether they are on the job or not. As such, it is very much in the nature of a national responsibility rather than a responsibility to be placed entirely at the feet of industry.

We should give serious consideration to a `Buy Australia' Act, along the lines of the `Buy America' legislation in the United States of America, to encourage government purchases of Australian made products in lieu of imports. Most people would be surprised to know that public sector purchasing, both State and Federal, costs approximately $22 billion annually. The Government's overseas deficit is presently $3.4 billion per year or thereabouts. If we could divert even a small percentage of these State and Federal Government purchases to Australian sources, we could very easily reduce the size of our overseas deficit annually by about $1 billion to $2 billion and at the same time give Australian industry a much needed boost.

We should establish guidelines to direct superannuation funds into more productive areas. About 50 per cent of the money invested on the Australian stock exchanges comes from superannuation funds. That is a very large percentage. These funds very largely represent the savings of the Australian work force. They will double once superannuation for all is introduced. Over a period of three or four years we will find the size of the funds to be invested from superannuation will virtually double. They represent Australia's savings. It is important that they be invested to help the Australian economy-invested in productive enterprises in this country to create jobs for Australians.

Although the Government has done something about trying to reduce the marginal rates of personal income tax, we believe that it has not gone anywhere near far enough. There is still a very large disincentive to personal effort in Australia. Unless we fundamentally reform the personal income tax scale this disincentive will continue. The Democrats' position is simply that there should be a tax free threshold amounting to at least $100 per week. From there the primary rate of tax should be 20 per cent and then from 20 per cent the scale should progressively increase in steps of one per cent per $1,000 of income to a maximum of 49 per cent. So, instead of having stairs and sudden changes in the marginal rate of tax, there would be a progressive straight line increase in the marginal rate of tax from 20 per cent to 49 per cent, which level should be the maximum rate of personal income tax. This sort of reform would not cost as much as many people may imagine. In fact the Democrats have carefully costed it and have incorporated the cost of it into an alternative Budget. That is available.

We believe that employee share purchasing offers a middle road between the excesses of socialism and unrestrained capitalism or free enterprise. Share purchasing leads to efficiency in industry. It gives employees an incentive to look at their industry and to try to contribute towards increasing its efficiency. That is a vitally important factor. Up to the present time very little attention has been given to this very important initiative. If we are to build our industries to be internationally competitive, if we are to build an industrial machine in Australia along the lines of that in Japan, we have to get away from confrontation in industry. We have to engage the brain power, the initiative, the leadership and the expertise of the whole work force to improve the efficiency of industry. Until we do that we will not be internationally competitive. I suggest that one of the best ways to do that is to encourage employee share ownership. That gets all people involved in what is happening. It gives them all a vested interest in increasing the size of the reward to be divided between the interests of labour and capital, the two fundamental factors in production. Until we increase the efficiency of industry, the reward to be divided between labour and capital cannot be increased. If it is just not there it cannot be divided.

Lastly, in the interest of increasing the efficiency of industry, we have to give much more attention to worker participation generally, not just employee share ownership. The Japanese have been dramatically successful with their small group activity, that is, having small panels of about 10 people throughout the organisation looking at their particular work responsibilities. These small groups can then assess whether the ideas from individuals should be applied throughout the whole organisation. If that sounds to honourable senators like a very simple idea, let me assure them that it is, but like many simple ideas it has dramatic consequences. In Japan last year there were no fewer than 1.9 million suggestions from employees in the Toyota organisation alone, all of which were processed through this small group activity. The important point is that 90 per cent of those suggestions were acted on by management. The greatest genius of all time may be leading an organisation, but that person is not going to come up with 1.9 million suggestions. It is a completely different ball game when the whole work force is looking at ways and means of improving the efficiency of what they are doing. Then there will be some action. An organisational structure that allows for co-operation and encourages people to try to improve the efficiency of the enterprise has to be a better organisation every time, as the Japanese have proven. That is the way they have built their industrial machine from a heap of rubble 40 years ago to an industrial complex which is the envy of every Western country. Japan now produces more cars than does the United States of America. Whoever would have thought that could happen in 1945?

TALK.START.PARA: —And in the 1950s we produced more than Japan.
