—I was not aware of that. Look at the enormous ground that has been traversed by the Japanese in 40 years. They make 90 per cent of the motor bikes in the world and they are vying for leadership in machine tools, computer technology, and so on. The list goes on ad nauseam. The Japanese are leading the world and they have done that by co-operation between the work force, management and government. They have said: `Right, we were in desperate trouble in 1945. We have to earn our keep in the world. How are we going to do it?'. They did it by building their industrial machine to be internationally efficient, to be world leaders in the various areas. If the Japanese can do that, why cannot Australia?
—They also have a decentralised wage system.

—We have problems with our wage fixing system, I agree, but these problems are not insurmountable. Once we get co-operation between the trade union movement, government and business leaders the whole problem of our wage fixing and industrial relations will disappear, but it will not disappear if we fight each other. That is a fundamental approach, the only approach by which we can possibly succeed. If we think we can hit the unions over the head and get rid of them, we will have chaos. We will have confrontation like nobody has ever seen.

SPEECH.PARA: Unionism is a way of life in Australia. Our whole system of conciliation and arbitration is based on unions. We have a high degree of unionisation in Australia and we have to accept it. It is built into our system of conciliation and arbitration. The only possible approach, short of a revolution, is to get co-operation between the trade union movement, industry and government. The Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government are co-operating pretty well right now; industry has to co-operate as well. The whole three have to get together to build an industrial complex that can export manufactured goods around the world. We cannot do that in every area of manufacture but we can do it in some areas of manufacture. It is up to the Government to assess those areas that can be built to world efficiency and exported around the world, and we have to do it fast.

We have to work our way out of debt. We cannot sit back any longer and see this enormous flow of foreign borrowings coming into Australia without any consideration of how the Australian people will meet the interest commitment on those borrowings. Certainly we cannot sit back any longer and see billions of dollars go into stock market speculation with no productive advance in our industries whatsoever. Billions of dollars are invested in nothing that has any semblance of productivity for development of the country in any way at all.

We support the Appropriation Bill, but it impinges on a whole lot of areas of economic management. We will be supporting some of the areas that are of concern to the Liberal Party. I have spent some time stressing our real concern about the one aspect we have to face up to, namely, the size of our overseas borrowings. That is critical and fundamental. If we agree on that, it can be solved only by a fundamental change in economic direction along the lines of co-operation that I hope I have successfully outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity in speaking on the Appropriation Bills to make some references to the plight of the rural economy. In doing so I want to make it clear that I am not seeking to talk down the economy but rather to put, in as objective a way as possible, the facts relating to the rural industry so that they are understood properly and clearly. The Hawke Government has done more to destroy the Australian agricultural industry than has any other government in recent history. At best it has constantly failed to act where it could have assisted Australian farmers and at worst it has pursued policies in the knowledge that the effect of those policies would be to drive up farm costs and thereby reduce farm incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is either too incompetent to realise the real problems facing Australian farmers or has deliberately chosen to ignore them. I believe that it has deliberately chosen to ignore them, because history has shown that farmers are rated very low in the Government's list of priorities. I think it is a pragmatic judgment it makes in terms of the seats that are likely to be won or lost, or the fate of the Government in respect of that section of the community. The Government has sought also to place the entire blame for rural problems exclusively on overseas factors. I doubt that there is a person in the entire nation who would not agree that the agricultural policies of the European Economic Community have greatly damaged the Australian rural industry. The $1.5 billion United States Farm Bill designed to combat the policies of the EEC, will also further harm Australian farmers.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) believed that he would solve the problems by going to Washington to ask that Australian farmers not be harmed by United States policies. In effect, Mr Hawke went to Mr Reagan and said: `Mr Reagan, will you please lose votes in your rural lobby so that I can gain votes from my rural lobby'? Of course, that is totally unrealistic. However much the Americans may humour Mr Hawke when he is in Washington, the extent of his impact on American policies was shown when he left the United States of America. No sooner had Mr Hawke left the United States than it was reported that 50,000 tonnes of wheat were to be sold at $20 per tonne subsidy to North Yemen. Two days later it was reported that the United States planned to sell 60,000 tonnes of rice to Papua New Guinea at a price 50 per cent less than that which Australia is presently receiving. It ought to be recognised that Papua New Guinea is our single largest market for rice. Obviously Mr Hawke's endeavours overseas, much as the flourishes of the television cameras would give us the opposite impression, have achieved absolutely nothing.

The question that ought to be asked is: What else can the Government do? The answer is that the Government must look at stemming rises in domestic farm costs. This Government has not done so. It has blamed all the problems of the agricultural sector on overseas factors and has persisted with domestic policies which have driven up costs to farmers, which in turn have had a devastating effect on farm incomes. The Government's only other response has been the patch-up Kerin rural policy, which by itself is hopelessly inadequate. The Government has not attempted to deal with the crippling effects of its labour policies, its interest rate policies, tariffs and rising costs-the whole thrust of the burden which has been cast upon farmers. These are the real issues for the farmers. These are the problems with which the Government has to deal if it is serious about dealing with the crisis in the rural economy of Australia. But it has failed to do so. It has come into this place hoping to rectify chronic farm problems with band-aid measures. These measures are, of course, hopelessly inadequate, as any examination of the current state of the Australian rural economy will reveal.

In the three years since the Hawke Government has been in office the incomes received by farmers in the major sectors of agriculture have constantly fallen. At the 1986 National Agricultural Outlook Conference, held by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, it was revealed this year that 50 per cent of all farmers surveyed by the Bureau will earn less than $5,900 a year. Here is the sorry story of three years of Labor Party rule. Income for wheat farmers has fallen from an average $41,425 per annum in 1983-84 to an estimated loss of $7,500 in 1985-86. In the dairy industry income has fallen from $21,259 to $8,800 in the same period while income for livestock farmers has fallen from $26,519 to $4,500.

The fall in farmers' incomes is put in perspective if it is compared with average weekly earnings. Based on the December quarter figure for last year supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, a person on average weekly earnings would have earned $21,554 in a full year. A person on average weekly earnings is something like five times better off than the livestock farmer, two and a half times better off than a dairy farmer and infinitely better off than a wheat farmer, because a worker on average weekly earnings will at least put money into the bank while this year, after three years of the Hawke Government, wheat farmers will make a loss of $7,500. Mr Hawke and his Government are prepared to watch farmers go into bankruptcy because they do not have the courage to tackle the problem of rising farm costs.

In my State of Western Australia and on farms throughout the country both on-farm and off-farm costs have risen astronomically. It is the rise in the farm costs which, in many respects, is the root of the farmers' problems inasmuch as they can be contained within Australia. It is within the grasp of the Australian Government to do something about these matters, if it is prepared to have the courage, the initiative and the will to do so. On wheat farms average costs are expected to rise by 12 per cent. Almost half of the increase in farm costs is as a result of this Government's policy of deliberately increasing the rate of interest charged on loans. Farmers are now paying between 17 and 21 per cent on loans. The amount farmers have had to pay for money has been compared with overseas rates of interest to reveal the true extent of the damage which this Government is causing farmers. In February this year the minimum overdraft rate in the United Kingdom was 13.3 per cent, while in the United States of America the prime rate was 9.1 per cent. Farm payments on interest rose by 17 per cent in 1984 and are expected to rise by 40 per cent in 1985-86. How can our farmers be expected to pay these kinds of interest rates and compete successfully against overseas farmers who are carrying nowhere near the same interest rate burden? The simple answer is one which every farmer knows-they just cannot compete.

Rather then entering this place and attempting to hoodwink the farmers into believing that it is doing something for them, the Government would be better served by looking at introducing policies designed to cause a permanent and sustainable fall in interest rates, down to the levels which are being charged by our international competitors.

Labour rates are another cost which is slowly but surely squeezing the lifeblood out of the Australian farmer. Labour rates on Australian farms rose by 5 per cent in 1985. The BAE expects them to rise by 7 per cent on 1986. If the Government were serious about assisting farmers it would try to restrain to some extent these increasing labour costs. It would abandon the productivity increase which we are about to witness-this dreadful farce which has been inflicted not only upon the rural sector but upon the whole Australian economy. If this Government were in any way fair-and that is all the farmers are really asking for-it would examine the incomes of the Australian farmers. If it were to do so it would find that in my State of Western Australia, for example, the State farm employees' award guarantees employees $234.30 a week, or roughly $12,183 per annum. If the Government were fair it would compare this figure with some of the incomes farmers are expected to earn, such as those I have already mentioned. If it were to do so it would realise that many farm employees earn twice as much as their employers and, in the light of that, perhaps it would impose some constraint upon the head-long rush to satisfy the demands of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to satisfy the demands of the accord and to hell with the economy. The Hawke Government, however, will not moderate its accord until it is finally forced to do so as a result of economic pressures which are about to undo the whole economy. In fact, it has already rejected the notion of considering farmers as a separate case in the light of the current rural malaise. Whether farmers will actually have any money with which to pay this new impost is of no concern to this Government. It has handed over its labour policies to the trade unions through its blind ideological following of the accord. As Professor Richard Blandy, Director of the National Institute of Labour Studies, said:

The Accord seek[s] to orchestrate the relations between people at work from a very great height as a result of the manoeuvres between the very powerful in our society. This is not a good scene for the rural producers in our society, the small people, whose interests cannot be politically orchestrated in the same way.

As 90 per cent of farms surveyed by the BAE are classified as being family farms, among the many people to whom Professor Blandy addressed his remarks and who are suffering because of the accord are Australian family farmers. This situation is not likely to change because, as Professor Blandy went on to say about the accord:
What the unions have done is to trade off a developed capacity to inflict unacceptable damage to the economy and, therefore to the Government of the day, for a direct say in government.

There are many other areas where farm costs have increased under this Government, such as the 22.7 per cent rise in the cost of fertilisers and the 18.5 per cent rise in the cost of chemicals which Australian farmers, particularly Western Australian farmers, have had to suffer since mid-1983.

In the time remaining, I would like to address the issue of off-farm costs. These are the costs which a farmer has to pay for services once his produce has left the farm gate. In a recent publication by the National Australia Bank Ltd it was revealed that up to 50 per cent of the value of rural produce at the farm gate was absorbed by off-farm costs. Let me examine some of the costs in the wheat industry, for example. From a guaranteed minimum price of $149 a tonne for Australian standard white wheat, or fair average quality wheat, farmers have the following costs deducted: Co-operative bulk handling costs, $13.05; tolls, $1.84; wheat research levy, 35c; Ceres House levy, 10c; wharfage costs, 50c; and carry over to port loading costs, $1.53. So, we see that the farmer has lost $17.37 from what he is theoretically paid for his crop before he even receives payment. We find that the farmer is being paid only $131.63 for his crop. From this he has to deduct rail freight charges.

The Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association recently indicated that the average rail freight charges for grain were: Victoria, $21.30 a tonne; New South Wales, $24.80 a tonne; Queensland, $16.20 a tonne; South Australia, $16.70 a tonne; and Western Australia, $16 a tonne. I note that the two States with the longest serving Labor governments are the States which have the highest rail freight rates. Interestingly enough, despite the prices which farmers are being charged in Victoria, the Victorian Minister for Transport, Mr Roper, indicated that Victorian railways would still expect to lose between $5m and $7m on grain cartage.

By comparison, the Canadian Freight Association has indicated that a 300 kilometre wheat haul in Canada would cost $13.24-about the same figure when related to the Australian dollar because the dollars are almost equivalent in value at present. Of course, averages frequently conceal the fact that there are isolated cases where farmers have to pay far higher charges. For instance, in a place such as Marvel Loch, some 260 miles from Perth, Westrail advertises a price of $25.28 per tonne. Therefore, some farmers, including these farmers, are paying 20 per cent of the money they receive for their crops simply for rail freight. These rail freight charges, of course, are increasing dramatically.

The Australian Wheat Board has computed the average price paid for a tonne of wheat in Australia. The Board has indicated that since 1981 the average cost of hauling wheat in Australia has risen by 51 per cent. Grain handling charges are another cost which is destroying our farmers by making them less competitive than farmers overseas. This is also a cost that neither the Federal Government nor the State governments have been prepared to do anything about. In a classic statement by Mr Kerin on 15 January 1985, which might well have been a trial run for the patch up rural policy which was discussed recently by him, he said that the Commonwealth and the State Labor governments were investigating what could be done to reduce off-farm costs to growers. There was and there still is a very great need for something to be done about the spiralling costs of handling grain.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has recently revealed that in the six years to 1984-85, the cost of grain handling from primary receival points to export points free on board has risen by 52 per cent in Australia. When our farmers have to compete with overseas farmers, the figures for comparable charges overseas starkly demonstrate the disadvantageous position of our farmers. Over the same period-the six years to 1984-85-handling costs in Canada rose by only 37 per cent while in the United States they actually fell by 18 per cent.

At the National Agricultural Outlook Conference in 1985, Andy Stoeckel, the Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, indicated that if there was greater competition in the marketing of wheat it could result in savings of somewhere between $60m and $80m annually. Twelve months after Mr Kerin made his statement, what has been the result of his investigations? The answer, it would seem to me, is absolutely nothing. In the recent rural package, Mr Kerin announced that the Commonwealth was prepared to meet the cost of a joint royal commission with the States into off-farm costs. All the Government has done, of course, is to go from an investigation to a royal commission. How has this helped the farmers to pay their bills as they come in? This is something that Mr Kerin just does not seem to understand. The Government has not decided actually to tackle the reasons why our grain handling costs are so much higher than those of our international competitors. In 1986 Andy Stoeckel returned to the Agricultural Outlook Conference to state:

In general, Australian grain handling facilities are characterised by much higher manning levels than those of equivalent facilities in the United States, short shifts, a lack of co-ordination of shift changes, which effectively prevents 24 hour operation and a large number of unions which increases the possibility of demarcation disputes.

While wheat farmers will make a loss this year, grain terminal employees will each earn in the vicinity of $35,000 in wages. In New South Wales, Mr Mick Charles, a member of the Grain Handling Authority Board, said that the New South Wales grain handling system is now based on a 46 per cent labour component compared with 32 per cent in 1979. While Mr Kerin has been confronted with a real issue where he could assist farmers, he has done absolutely nothing. Instead, he has produced this farce he calls a rural package which he hopes will gloss over the very real issues.

There are many other areas where off-farm costs are much too high. Figures I have obtained from the Australian Wool Corporation show that for a 176 kilogram bale of wool, it costs the wool industry $229 to take the wool from the sheep's back to a point where it is ready to be shipped. The Wool Corporation assumes a price of $571 for a 176-kilogram bale. It therefore costs 40 per cent for wool to be sheared, classed, baled, stored, insured, sold, transported, tested and dumped so that it is ready to be loaded on board ship. Whilst a figure of 40 per cent for costs from the sheep to the wharf is alarming enough, it hides the fact that the cost of wool packs-the packaging for bales of wool-has increased in price over the last 12 months by 17 per cent. Transport costs for wool, both from the farm to the store and from the store to a mill or wharf, have increased by between 7 per cent and 9 per cent. The wool tax has increased from $15.16 per bale to $17.15 per bale, while the market support levy has risen from $25.28 per bale to $28.59 per bale. In each case the increase has been approximately 13 per cent. By comparison, increased costs in overseas nations are far lower. Inflation in the European Economic Community was recently reported to be 4.7 per cent compared with our rate of 9.2 per cent annualised on the last figures.

Another example of this Government trying to deliberately mislead farmers has been its portrayal of the exemption it gave farmers from the new fuel excises. Actually, the Government has given them nothing. The Government has not done farmers a favour at all by introducing this measure. Rather, farmers have received the reduction in fuel prices which should have flowed through to all Australians. The Government has robbed non-farming Australians of a fall in fuel prices of $7.95 per litre by increasing fuel excises. It has then tried to tell farmers that because it did not similarly rob them, it has done them a favour. The truth, of course, is that the Government has done farmers no favour at all but has simply robbed the rest of the country of that which it has not robbed them. Indirectly, the Government has still robbed farmers because many farmers, particularly on cattle stations, have to send their stock by truck. By denying road hauliers a reduction in fuel excise, which amounts to something like 36c per gallon of diesel, the Government has kept freight rates at a level which is dangerously higher than they ought to be and higher than what most farmers can afford to pay. As many cattle trucks can manage only approximately five miles for every gallon of fuel consumed, on a journey of 500 miles an additional $36 is paid by the operator because the full reduction in the price of oil has not been passed on.

Had there been full fuel price reductions, it would have been inevitable that in a competitive industry such as road freight, part of the savings would have been passed on to farmers. Given that fuel costs frequently amount to 30 per cent of total operating costs for lorries, the reductions which would have occurred would have been substantial. The Government has done virtually nothing to reduce the burden which high levels of protection for Australian manufacturing industries places on farmers.

The Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research has calculated that manufacturing protection costs farmers between $1 billion and $1.5 billion each year. When this figure is averaged over all Australian farmers, it is calculated that it costs each farmer about $8,800 per annum. The protection given to our industries was estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics to cost the average wheat farmer $134.62 per week in 1981-82. Today the cost is probably somewhere in the vicinity of $200 per week. Such an amount of money means that if protection was removed, most of the wheat farmers who presently will make a loss of $7,500 this year, would be able to make a profit. Again, I point out the unfairness this Government has cast on this issue. As I have said before, it is only a fair deal which Australian farmers are seeking; nothing more and nothing less.

The assistance given by the Government is so greatly weighted in favour of manufacturing compared with that given to agriculture that the situation has no semblance of fairness at all. In its annual report for the year 1984-85 the Industries Assistance Commission indicated that effective assistance to the wheat industry has varied from 10 per cent to minus 3 per cent. In 1984-85 it was at a level of 2 per cent. The 1985 figure for wool was 4 per cent, for beef cattle it was 9 per cent, for pigs it was minus 9 per cent and for poultry it was minus 5 per cent. In 1982-83 the average rate of assistance for manufacturing was 25 per cent. To look at some particular industries makes the comparison all the more awesome. Effective assistance for the production of transport equipment-cars, lorries and the like-was 72 per cent, while for clothing and footwear it was 220 per cent.

In order to protect the inefficient Australian industries the Government raises the price of goods which are imported into Australia by imposing tariffs and quotas upon these imports. While this protects Australian industry it does so by increasing the amount which people who buy imported goods have to pay. Farmers are one of these groups. They are paying for this Government's tariff policy every time they buy such basic items as utility trucks, fertilisers and machinery. Farmers lose again when overseas countries place tariffs on Australian rural exports in retaliation for the tariffs which are imposed by this Government.

In a report entitled `Wheat Marketing in Australia-An Economic Evaluation' which was published in 1983, the BAE made the following statement which I believe applies not only to wheat farmers but to all Australian farmers:
Australia's wheat industry has been growing and performing well internationally without significant assistance and indeed against a significant penalty.
Of course, to the extent that the BAE said that the wheat industry was growing, that comment was made in 1983 before wheat farmers had suffered three years of the Hawke Labor Government.

The neglect of Australia's farmers which has taken place under this Government has taken its toll. If the BAE figures prove correct, Australia is facing the prospect of somewhere near half of its farmers earning just slightly more than one quarter of average weekly earnings. Real returns on farm investment have fallen to the point where they will average minus 6.2 per cent this year. In part this negative return on capital has been due to falling land prices. Should land prices recover under this Government, many farmers will find that when they sell their land they will be subject to capital gains taxes. They will pay almost half-49 per cent-of the benefit accruing by taxation to the Labor Government. After years of working to build up the value of a rural property, farmers may well lose half of its value to the Commissioner of Taxation when it is sold.

Because of time, I have been able to mention only a few of the failings of the Hawke Government in this speech. There are many others which could have been mentioned and discussed. For example, the Government has introduced a sales tax on wine. It has destroyed the intended effect of income equalisation deposits. In this, the world's driest continent, it has removed the immediate tax deductibility for expenditure on water conservation.

As if these matters were not enough by themselves, to destroy the ability of farmers to compete with the farmers of other countries on world markets, the Government proposes to introduce a fringe benefits tax. In addition to the cost of having to pay initially for accommodation for employees in remote areas of the country, the Government's fringe benefits tax will mean that farmers will have to pay a tax of 46 per cent of the difference between what they charge their employees in rent and whatever rate the Commissioner of Taxation assesses the market value of the employee's accommodation to be. Farmers will have to stop providing their employees with accommodation, or raise the rent, or try to absorb yet another cost increase thrust upon them by the Hawke socialist Government.

It is little wonder that Sir Leslie Price, the former Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, was recently reported in the Australian Financial Review as saying that between 4,000 and 5,000 farmers may be forced out of the wheat industry. The National Australia Bank suggested in its April monthly summary that up to 27 per cent of Australian farmers, that is more than one in four, will have difficulty remaining viable in the long term. Already the Country Women's Association of Western Australia has planned for emergency food relief in certain areas, such is the plight of the rural industry in Western Australia.

It is a tragedy that in a land which once rode so proudly upon the sheep's back and where the Australian farming family was the power-house which drove the economy of the nation we find that under this Government the emphasis has changed. Whereas as late as 1953 agriculture still constituted 19 per cent of GDP, in late 1985 it constituted only 5 per cent.

Time prevents me from going through a range of other areas but if one looks at expenditure on social welfare and the part of the Budget which it consumes as a proportion of gross domestic product and compares that with gross rural production one can see that the Hawke Government is clearly seeking to move its priorities from stimulating the rural sector, enabling it to be the power-house which it ought to be and giving it a chance to prosper, survive and increase its share of GDP and to move them to social welfare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the problem of monitoring serious injuries in Australia. A considerable amount of both public appropriations and money from the private purse could be saved by having such a system. I am prompted by general overseas experience and by the absence of medical information on the Dalkon shield with which I have dealt at length in the adjournment debate. Between 1964 and 1983 only a handful of adverse reactions to intra-uterine devices were reported to the Commonwealth Department of Health. There were four mentions of the Copper 7 device, 30 of the Lippes loop and 73 of the Dalkon shield under voluntary reporting procedures which were in force at that time. Last year, the Department of Health cited a 0.05 per cent adverse reaction rate because only 74 problems had been notified from the 147,000 shields imported into Australia. Now we find that 3,000 Australian women have joined in a major American class action in Richmond, Virginia. Many other women have contacted women's health centres and the Public Interest Advocacy Centre to register their experiences with this revolting device. These people have never had any intention of going to the courts but they were glad at last that someone was prepared to listen to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Besides a large number of seriously injured people, there are three cases in which relatives or doctors of women who wore the Dalkon shield and died believe there is a link between the shield and the deaths. It seems quite clear that the voluntary reporting procedures have failed and that the true picture is only now emerging because of the court cases. It is extremely important that we monitor all types of injury. I have been particularly concerned with child injuries in the community. I have tried to get statistics on this area from every possible government instrumentality to use in speeches. Children and women are being injured. People in our society who can least afford it are not having their health monitored properly.

It is the policy of the Australian Democrats that we should have prevention rather than cure in medicine. The whole health system, in appropriations and elsewhere, seems to be geared towards curative instead of preventive medicine. To move our system from curative to preventive medicine we need the information necessary to know what we have to prevent. Many women have suffered needlessly because the many individual experiences with IUDs were not collated and used properly.

The vicious circle was complete because doctors did not know what was happening. This meant that they often failed to associate the symptoms of seriously ill women with the wearing of the Dalkon shield. In some cases, this lack of knowledge caused doctors to completely disbelieve the women who came to them. The stories did not fit with the promotional material that had been distributed by the company concerned. There was no way of knowing about this problem in any place where a decision could be made. It is interesting that the situation in the United States was similarly clouded, but that country at least had some monitoring and now has a compulsory reporting procedure which was set in force as late as 13 December 1984. We are at least two years behind in getting these types of compulsory procedures into place.

All deaths and serious injuries in the United States now have to be reported within five days of the event. On top of that, the Consumer Product Safety Commission has been monitoring a sample of hospital emergency rooms since 1976. This gets danger alerts into the open very quickly. For instance, a United States Federal Court judge last year found that the spermicide, ortho pharmaceutical gel, had caused severe defects in the child of an Atlanta woman who continued to use the product in the first four weeks of her pregnancy. This is the type of information we need to get quickly into medical hands. We need to spend some money on obtaining information. The United States Food and Drug Administration released this quite quickly. In contrast, our Department of Health had to be prodded into action after the National Times reported the American case in 1985.

In my maiden speech I referred to the need to establish a child accident surveillance system. Virtually 50 per cent of children under the age of 14 receive treatment for injury each year. Some 70,000 children are admitted to hospitals. Medical expenses are over $200m each year-that is just the medical expenses associated with these cases. Some 60 per cent of all the injuries to children involve common consumer products. I could not find any real statistics except for these general overall figures. Some 50 per cent of the 700 deaths of children each year are related to the road. That is about as much information as I could gather on this terribly important area. Statistical data about what is happening now is not available. At best, it is available only one or two years after the event and it is far too late to identify new trends and to counter them effectively.

Statistics are currently available only after a considerable amount of time. If we decided to collect data from accident and emergency departments in hospitals we could start an injury control program. Sweden's child injury rates are about half ours, partly because its surveillance procedures make prevention possible. Norway has just started a data collection system on injuries to all in-patients and a group of five accident and emergency centres are now collecting this information. For each dollar spent Norway expects to save $40 in hospitalisation and other expenses. When extra money is being found to set up therapeutic goods and chemical registers we should insist that the data base be widened to make prevention possible. We should be able to get information immediately. These data bases should be open for doctor inquiry. Unfortunately, the Government will need quite a deal of encouragement to go into injury control rather than just saying: `It is an accident. It cannot be prevented'.

I believe that the Dalkon shield episode shows that human suffering can be lessened if we establish proper data collection systems. In the United States, A. H. Robins received reports of spontaneous infected abortions in wearers of the Dalkon shield as early as June 1972. The first known death was in August 1972. By 1973 there had been 400 separate complaints, most listing several people, yet doctors were still given the impression that their observations were quite unprecedented and related only to individual cases. There was no collation of this information. It was only when doctors made contact with one another that the scope of the problem was appreciated. At the same time, sales were suspended in July 1974. However, by then seven deaths and 103 spontaneous life-threatening abortions had been reported. The number of these deaths could have been cut down in the United States. The United States now has a system of injury control and reporting. The death toll had risen to 43 last year, with 313 non-fatal septic abortions. That was because it was not possible to quickly contact people who were fitted with the shield because there was no register of who had been fitted.

The reason I am giving American figures here is that Australia's data collection system does not give us a hope of making even a reasonable guess at what has happened here and I believe that that is an utter disgrace.

Let me take one example which was mentioned in the Good Weekend magazine of 22 March. The person concerned developed minor discomfort after a Dalkon shield was inserted in April 1972. She had it removed in February 1975 and another was inserted. Five months later the doctor told her that the United States Food and Drug Administration had cleared the Dalkon shield. That was certainly not the case. Terrible abdominal pains beset the woman. Her body became stiff, her temperature fluctuated wildly, and she could not walk or move without suffering agonising pain. I could go on describing those symptoms, but basically this suffering went on with a number of women. There were 3,000 Australian women in this type of situation and the statistics were not there to bring all this together.

It is quite difficult to make connections between a recurrent illness and a particular type of device or product, such as the Dalkon shield. The only way this can happen is by collating material. For example, the symptoms of the Dalkon shield problems sometimes resembles flu and include feverishness, vomiting and dizziness. Major life-threatening complications can develop within a matter of hours. There is no routine description of the syndrome. Text books do not include any details of this. It is very important that we have a collection of data. If data had been collected as a matter of course, doctors would have had the relevant information, a timely diagnosis could have been made, and many people could have been saved.

There is also the problem that many women did not even know that the IUD which had been inserted was a Dalkon shield. A lot of women did not know because there was no registration of wearers. When a new product comes onto the market there should be some system of registering those people who are using the particular drug or product so that it is possible to monitor that group if it comes under risk. I inquired from the Department of Health what systems are in place in Australia for such monitoring and I am appalled to see that there are very few. Individual hospitals keep statistics but they hold them jealously to themselves. The Family Planning Association in New South Wales did keep some records of the Dalkon shield but these were destroyed in a major flood which hit inner-city Sydney late in 1984. Hence it is rather difficult to know what women have been fitted with the Dalkon shield in Sydney. It may even be that some women are still wearing this lethal device.

In the United States the Food and Drug Administration gave approval for a modified monofilament Dalkon shield only on condition that patients registered when they had that device inserted. We do not have a similar system on any of the IUDs we are currently distributing. We have had problems with a variety of medical devices in recent years but, because adequate records were not kept, those involved and at risk could not get any type of early warning. In the case of the Dalkon shield the risk was twofold but basically related to the fact that bacteria travelled up the multifilament plastic strands to a double knot where the plastic device was attached. It took a long time for the effects of the bacteria to show up and they showed up much later as general systemic infections. Unless we record who uses a device and the relationship between disease and devices we will never be able to fix the problem. A microbiologist established that a vastly increased number of bacteria accumulated on the string after the Dalkon shield had been worn for about two years. This is why long-term wearers were at risk. Most of the early monitoring programs in the United States were over just six months. Many of the devices which are potentially dangerous-not only medical devices but also children's toys and electrical devices, although our electrical monitoring system is reasonable-are on the market. It is important that we record information on this matter. Currently this is not happening. I put it to the Government that we should establish proper patient registry and accident surveillance mechanisms as soon as possible.

I also want to raise a largely unreported aspect of the Dalkon shield; it concerns access to medical records. There are individual State and Federal jurisdictions, so the matter should be put on the agenda of the next Health Ministers conference. Currently we have enough problems because under the Trade Practices Act only three years are given in which to seek relief from loss or damage caused by defective products. This is made worse because there is no legal right of access to medical records, which makes it rather difficult for people who have been treated at a hospital by other than their own doctor to get access to their own medical records, especially if there is any suspected problem with a product that the hospital has fitted. Consequently, those who discover their cause for action under the Trade Practices Act within the three-year period may face very serious obstacles when they prepare their case. If all the States had the freedom of information legislation that exists in Victoria people would at least have access to public hospital records. With the development of computing, data base and microchip technology and the increasing problems with particular diseases being latent for many years-we have solved the problems of a lot of short term diseases-it is more important that we carry out national surveys and make a lot more diseases and accident-type situations compulsory notifiable. We should keep that information and the statistics on it and monitor changes which can give us early warning of problems that are developing.

We will have to look at ways in which the private sector will also be able to retrieve information from these types of data bases. At the moment, patients have no legal right of access to their medical records held by their own doctor. We need to give them this legal right. In the Dalkon shield investigations doctors have refused access to information on the grounds that either they did not want to be involved or that somehow the doctor-patient relationship would be ruined if they gave in to a particular request. I believe that those doctors ought to re-examine their commitment to the healing profession. It is not for them to exercise God-like powers in this direction. However, even where doctors have co-operated, there has been a major financial impediment to people getting this information. Some doctors have sought to charge people for providing the material sought. This should be stopped. Medical information can save lives and it should be available to people at all times.

In other cases State regulations have been at fault. For instance, in Western Australia patients have no direct access to their own hospital records. The patients need to be accompanied by the doctor who admitted them to hospital and by their lawyer and they must pay for the time of these professionals. There is a further burden for plaintiffs because they cannot get photocopies of records. Naturally, the cost of such antiquated processes becomes prohibitive for many ordinary Australians. There are enough obstacles on the road to justice without these mazes being put in their way. I hope that the State and Federal Ministers for health will act promptly to give the injured some encouragement in their pursuit of justice and that we will set up a system of monitoring and injury prevention.

At this stage I briefly turn to another subject which is of great concern. We have not had any answers from the Government on certain aspects associated with giving to people information on the Chernobyl disaster. I would like to know what steps governments are taking to ensure the safety of Australian people overseas. We tried to get this information in a debate when Standing Orders were suspended. What is the Government currently doing to monitor this type of situation? Without information it is rather difficult to do anything. The fact that the Russians withheld information from their neighbours meant that it was rather difficult to save people from possible radiation hazards at an early stage. It is extremely important that we should not have that problem in Australia. There is the question of whether we have instituted a monitoring system to check for contaminated foods or objects we are importing from that area and the question of getting a register of at least goods that may have come from areas where the level of radiation has severely increased. I would like to know what steps have been taken, or what measures are being set up to monitor radioactivity on products imported into Australia.

We know that Chernobyl was not the first such accident. Vast areas of land in the Urals have been affected. When I was in Great Britain in the 1960s all babies were fed with South American dried milk rather than with British cows milk because of the Windscale disaster. People tend to export products which they do not want on their market, and we should be monitoring this closely. It is worth having moneys appropriated for these purposes and I recommend that to the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
The speech read as follows-

I present Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86 which, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprises the additional estimates for 1985-86. In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoid- able expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1985-86 under Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act. These additional appropriations are required to meet commitments that have been approved by the Government since the Budget or foisted upon it by courts and tribunals which have no responsibility for the fiscal consequences of their decisions. Also provided for are additional requirements of an ongoing nature and the reappropriation of certain amounts necessitated by transfers of functions which are unable to be effected under existing legal authorities.

The principal factors underlying the requirements are certain unavoidable cost and price increases and exchange rate fluctuations since the Budget was prepared. Although the Budget figuring contained allowances for prospective wage and salary increases, those amounts were not then appropriated, and funds are now required to meet the costs of awards and determinations made since that time and to meet the cost of other factors affecting wages and salaries, such as staffing increases. No provision is made in these Bills in anticipation of a wage and salary increase that might arise out of the current national wage case hearings. Any such increase will be met under the separate appropriation provisions in section 5 of the Appropriation Act (No. 1) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1985-86.

Of the additional appropriations in the three additional estimates Bills totalling $940.3 million, $755.7 million is sought in Appropriation Bill No. 3, $183.6 million in Appropriation Bill No. 4 and $1.1 million in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill No. 2. These amounts are offset in part by savings in the appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1985-86 reflecting the Government's continued determination to achieve savings in expenditure for ongoing programs wherever possible. These savings, amounting to $264.0 million, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document ``Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations'', which has been distributed to senators. After allowing for prospective savings, the appropriations now sought represent a net increase of $696.3 million in expenditures financed from annual appropriations. As a proportion of total estimated outlays-encompassing both annual and standing appropriations-this increase amounts to 1.0 per cent.

I now outline some of the main areas in respect of which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) to meet expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

An estimated $297.8 million is for wages and salaries, of which $173.3 million is for defence and $124.5 million for non-defence purposes, to meet increases in award rates, other wage and salary costs and a small increase of 0.2 per cent in budget-approved average staffing levels. These provisions do not include the wage and salary components of additional funds being provided to certain statutory authorities funded under one line appropriations.

A sum of $10.7 million is provided for the Attorney-General's Department by way of the reappropriation of funds to the Australian Legal Aid Office following delays in the merger of that office with the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales. This amount has been fully offset from savings in amounts which were to be paid direct to the New South Wales Government in 1985-86 had the merger proceeded.

A sum of $16.9 million is included under the Department of Community Services to implement revised subsidy arrangements for childcare services. Under the new arrangements, subsidy is paid on the basis of the number of places centres have for children and varies according to the number aged under or over 3 years. This replaces subsidies previously based on the ratio of qualified staff to children.

A sum of $95.9 million is sought for the Department of Defence to meet the effect on the purchase of new equipment and stores of exchange rate variations and other cost and price increases since the Budget. The effect of these increases has been partially offset by reduced requirements for certain naval refit projects and the effect of the Government's decision on oil prices.

A sum of $14.9 million is included under the Education portfolio reflecting the reappropriation to the Department of Education of funds originally appropriated to the Commonwealth Schools Commission following the transfer to the Department of program administration for general recurrent grants to schools. Cost supplementation of those grants is also provided for. A sum of $70 million is included within the Trade portfolio to enable the Australian Trade Commission to help eliminate the backlog of eligible claims under the export market development grants scheme. This represents significant additional support to the export sector over the level provided in the 1985-86 Budget. A sum of $16.2 million is sought for the Department of Veterans' Affairs for payments to specialists and local medical officers in respect of medical services provided to veterans and their dependants. The rise is mainly due to the short-term transfer of the payments function from the Health Insurance Commission to the Department of Veterans' Affairs to provide for the manual payment of a backlog in accounts, and is fully offset from savings in amounts appropriated to the Health Insurance Commission in the Budget. A relatively small component-around $2.5 million-of the increase is provided for increased demand for services and increases in rates and costs. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION BILL 1985AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1985ATOMIC ENERGY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 November, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In leading for the Opposition I make it clear that the Opposition will not oppose the Australian Nuclear Science Technology Organisation Bill 1985, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1985, or the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill 1985. In the latter part of the debate we will be seeking, through amendment, to make these Bills a little more useful and constructive for Australia's national interest. At the outset of this debate I reaffirm the recognition by the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia that anything dealing with atomic energy is a highly emotionally charged subject. We approach the subject with due sensitivity and caution. But we do live in a nuclear age. We have done so for 40 years. A large part of the power that is used in the world is generated by nuclear sources. These Bills are concerned in a broad sense with the peaceful uses of nuclear power. There is no involvement at all with nuclear weapons or anything like that.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in this debate we will be the victims of some extreme, emotional fear-raising statements by the Australian Democrats which will serve only to muddle what is a very important argument. We cannot unlearn nuclear physics. Human nature is creative and inventive. Mankind split the atom. We are probing the limits of nuclear physics and particle physics. We will go on until ultimately we unlock their secrets. Whilst there are great dangers in nuclear power, there are certainly enormous possibilities for mankind. Those possibilities will be attained in the fullness of time. Regrettably we will have incidents such as the Chernobyl reactor incident last week. As I made it clear in speaking on that subject, that accident could have been avoided had the Russians consulted other nuclear physicists and engineers around the world and had they acted in a more responsible and cautious way. The disastrous consequences of that accident should never been inflicted on the Ukrainian people.

I regard it as a tragedy that Australia has not taken a much larger position in the field of nuclear physics and nuclear engineering. We are 40 years into the nuclear age yet we have virtually no nuclear industry, no nuclear design or engineering capability. The decision in 1969 to build a nuclear reactor at Jervis Bay was correct. It was wrong not to proceed with that reactor, either at another site or at Jervis Bay so that we could achieve the design and manufacturing capability in this country to take us into the nuclear age. One reason that is advanced as to why we cannot buy nuclear submarines is the fact that we do not have any of the support engineering facilities in this country. That is only one application.

The whole field of nuclear engineering is developing. Because we have no base in this country other than the vestigial research facilities at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, Australia cannot be part of it. The governments of Australia have been unduly influenced by the shrill cries of the Luddites and the people of that nature. The hagiography-ridden left wing of the Australian Labor Party is stridently opposed to anything to do with nuclear engineering. Whilst the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill will give to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation the powers to carry out research, clause 5 (3) of the Bill provides:
In undertaking its functions the Organisation shall have regard to the national science and energy policy objectives of the Commonwealth Government.

That clause will mean that under a Labor Government there will be no research and development in nuclear fields, particularly the nuclear generation of power. Australia will be very much the poorer for that.

I said a little while ago that there is a great confusion, intentionally created in the minds of the public by people such as the Democrats, between nuclear power and nuclear armaments. They are quite different things. The peaceful uses of nuclear power have brought very great benefits for mankind.

I was in Japan last year and I was very interested to visit one of the Japanese nuclear power installations. That country has suffered the horrors of a nuclear attack on two occasions, at Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The Japanese, above all other races, have reason to be opposed to nuclear physics, nuclear generation and nuclear power if any country has. But there is a ready acceptance and an expanding employment of nuclear generation of power in Japan. They do not have the confusion that exists in the muddled minds of the Australian Democrats between nuclear power and nuclear generation.

Of course, as well as generating electrical energy, nuclear power has a great application in propulsion, particularly in ships. The ability of ships to operate for years without refuelling and to operate in absolute safety, provided accepted engineering practices are followed, brings great commercial benefits.

The world uses energy. When we became industrialised we faced an increasing demand. First came fire-wood, then coal and oil. But anything that we burn results in the production of carbon dioxide and water. While the water does not hurt in the atmosphere, the cumulative effect of carbon dioxide does have a very severe effect. Most of the hydrocarbons that we burn, whether they are solid or liquid, contain some sulphur. Those that do not contain sulphur attract a premium in the market-place. But the burning of those sulphur containing compounds leads to the production of sulphur dioxide. When released into the atmosphere this produces sul- phurous acid, which is the cause of the acid rain which is now having such a devastating effect on the forests of Europe. But not only the forests are affected; acid rain is precipitated into the lakes and the aquatic life in those lakes is killed off as the acidity level in the lakes rises.

It is inevitable, if we go on burning more and more fuels, that we will just swelter in the garbage of the products of those combustions. Seventy-seven per cent of the world's energy is consumed by 28 per cent of its population. As standards rise, that 72 per cent of the population not currently using the 77 per cent energy will need more and more electrical energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe they are smarter than we are.

—They would not have to be smart to be smarter than Senator Sanders. Some countries do not have oil and coal-countries such as Japan. They have to maintain a highly complex society and they have turned to nuclear energy as their source. Because we do not have nuclear generation in Australia, the degree of power generation that comes from nuclear sources around the world is not widely known. There are well over 200 nuclear power-houses in existence. Some European countries, such as France and Belgium, develop 50 per cent of their electrical energy from nuclear power. The application of those power-houses has been of great benefit to the communities. In short, there will be a place in the world scheme-it will be a minor place but a significant place-for the generation of electrical energy by nuclear power in the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.PARA: That fact leads me to the place of Australia in the scheme of things. Australia has great reserves of uranium oxide. Under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons we have a legal obligation to supply that yellowcake under very stringent safeguards to those countries that need it for peaceful purposes. Because of the dogma of the Australian Labor Party those Australian deposits of uranium oxide are not being exploited and developed in the way that they should be. This leads to some interesting things. Apparently one can have good uranium in Roxby Downs but not at Jabiluka, Koongarra, Yeelirrie, Beverley or Honeymoon. In fact, the Labor Party has licensed production only at Ranger and Roxby. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, first of all may I acknowledge the generosity of Senator Bjelke-Petersen in letting me change places with her on today's speakers list. I want to raise a matter as a result of two Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions that were made with regard to Department of Social Security decisions in October and November of last year. They are rather extraordinary decisions and they have some rather extraordinary ramifications. I would be interested in some response from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) at some stage.

SPEECH.PARA: One case deals with the case of Kingston v. the Secretary to the Department of Social Security, which occurred in October 1985. Mr Kingston was 80 years old and shared a flat with a woman who was 75 years old. They had been cohabiting since 1965. Since 1971 the Department of Social Security had treated Kingston and the woman concerned as if they were married, and accordingly paid them their pensions at the married rate. In October 1984 Mr Kingston applied to the Department of Social Security for a full pension-as distinct from him and the lady concerned getting a married pension which, as everybody would know, is not twice the full single pension. The Department of Social Security rejected this application but the Administrative Appeals Tribunal set aside the decision. The Department had argued that Kingston was living with another person of the opposite sex as the spouse of that person on a bona fide domestic basis, although not legally married to that person. The evidence presented by the Department included, firstly a statement signed by the woman concerned in 1977 that she had lived with Kingston as `man and wife' since 1965; secondly, Kingston had not objected to letters received fromthe Department of Social Security in 1975--

TALK.START.PARA: —He also claimed the dependent spouse rebate in 1969.

—I thank the Minister; I am about to get to that. Kingston had not objected to letters received from the Department of Social Security in 1975 referring to the woman concerned as his spouse. Thirdly, in 1969 Kingston applied for a spouse rebate in respect of the lady concerned. The evidence the Tribunal accepted `without hesitation' was Kingston's statement that they were not in a quasi-marriage relationship. The AAT commented-I would alert honourable senators to this because it is worth listening to:

SPEECH.PARA: Before such a relationship is converted (ie, housekeeping relationship) into a man and wife relationship there must be some kind of spark to ignite the tinder of cohabitation to the fire of a quasi-marriage relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quasi-poetic.
—I would have said purple prose, but quasi-poetic will do.
—You would wonder how anybody with an IQ above 65 could have come out with the conclusion that the AAT did.

—I will accept the Minister's interjection but not comment on it because I want to go on to a second AAT decision, a month or so later, on a similar matter. This one occurred in 1982 and it concerned a man by the name of Kennison who was in receipt of the unemployment benefit at the married person rate as a result of his cohabitation with a woman then aged 16 years. In 1983 the Department of Community Services decided to pay Kennison the single rate of unemployment benefit because the woman concerned was under 17 years of age-the legal age of consent in South Australia. The AAT set aside the DSS decision. It was argued by the DSS that because it was a criminal offence for a person to have sexual intercourse with a person under 17, it could not administer the social security system so as to allow any person to benefit from the commission of a criminal offence. I would say that seems a reasonable sort of assessment to make.

SPEECH.PARA: This argument was rejected by the AAT because in this case there was no direct evidence of a sexual relationship. I just draw the Senate's attention back to the previous decision in which the fact that there was no evidence of a direct sexual relationship meant that one of the people was able to get a single pension-that is a full single pension-rather than a married pension. The AAT stated that neither the AAT nor the DSS was obliged to investigate the existence of any such relationship, although it might be proper for the Department of Social Security to refuse to pay a benefit to a person whose entitlement rested on facts which amounted to a criminal offence under State law.

Having received that information I thought that surely since these two cases contradict each other, and are extraordinary within themselves anyway from the attitudes and the assumptions made-assuming that there is no other evidence that I am not aware of-the Department of Social Security would appeal on either or both of those decisions. My staff member who made the contact with the officer concerned was informed that it was not going to appeal. This, then, raises a number of questions. First, why did the Department not appeal to the Federal Court of Australia-as it can, of course, under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977?

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is there is no guarantee, based on its record, that the Federal Court would be any more sane than the AAT.
—Again I accept the Minister's interjection without any additional comment. Nevertheless, the two cases are contradictory and they are internally odd.
—Agreed-scandalously so.

—I thank the Minister for his assistance, but I did suggest to Senator Bjelke-Petersen that I would be quick. There are, I would suggest, some rather interesting possible consequences of the precedents set out in these two decisions. First of all, if the fire goes out of a legal marriage tinder box, can each of the partners concerned then claim the full single pension-apparently they can-in a relationship that used to be defined by the couple concerned as de facto but about which they have now changed their minds? Secondly, is a sexual relationship essential to eligibility for receipt of a married pension if people are over the age of 75, but not if one of the parties is under the age of 17? I would like some explanation about that question, and whether the answer is yes or no. Finally, as far as the Kennison case is concerned, does it mean that any couple, providing they are of opposite sexes, one to the other, can receive married unemployment benefits no matter what their age or the legality of the relationship, or whether any criminal element is involved? Does that mean, for example, that if the AAT is going to ignore the possibility of a criminal offence-as it did for this case, where sexual intercourse was quite clearly an offence since the person was under the age of consent as far as the South Australian system was concerned-incest, or the possibility of it, will be ignored so that a sole supporting parent, for instance, can claim married unemployment benefits as long as he or she has under the same roof a person, of whatever age, apparently, who is of the opposite sex? Or do we not worry about the sex of the person? Are we going to take this right down the track so that that does not matter at all?

SPEECH.PARA: I find it extraordinary, Mr Deputy President, that the Department itself did not appeal in either of these cases. If the information that I have is correct, the Tribunal made those decisions without thinking about the internal inconsistencies and about the potential problems that they have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity today to pay a special tribute to a great Australian who, regrettably, passed away very suddenly last week. I speak of course of the former Governor of Queensland, Commodore Sir James Ramsay, KCMG, KCVO, CBE, DSC-a man who distinguished himself by his tremendous service to his country and his great love for his fellow man. Commodore Sir James Ramsay was born in Tasmania in 1916 and joined the Royal Australian Navy in 1930. He served through World War II on various ships in the areas of the Indian Ocean, the Red Sea, the Atlantic Ocean, Singapore, the Persian Gulf, Burma and the South West Pacific, and he also served in the Korean War later on.

SPEECH.PARA: After the war this distinguished Australian assumed the duties of operations officer and fleet navigating officer, and Commanding Officer of HMAS Warramunga, HMAS Arunta and HMAS Vendetta. Commodore Sir James Ramsay's shore appointments included being Captain of the RAN College, naval representative in the United Kingdom, Director of Plans, Director-General of Fighting Equipment and naval officer commanding the Western Australian area-a position from which he retired in 1972. In 1974 Commodore Sir James was appointed Lieutenant-Governor of Western Australia, an appointment which lasted until 1977.
On 22 April 1977 Sir James was sworn in as Governor of Queensland, an appointment which saw his great love for the people and his dedication to the monarchy exemplified.

He was blessed with a wonderful wife, Janet, Lady Ramsay, who together with the Governor travelled Queensland widely. I know of many occasions when he went out to Longreach at the time of the endurance ride. The endurance ride went day and night and he was always there, interested in that. In times of drought, in times of flood, the Governor was there. He used to travel by train a lot and he would call in at all the small towns along the way, on whichever route he was taking, in whichever part of the State he was going to. People everywhere spoke very well of our late Governor and his wife. In fact, I am sure we could say he was certainly a man of the people. As the Queen has brought the monarchy to people throughout the Commonwealth, so Sir James represented her very well throughout the State of Queensland as her vice-regal representative.

I have been to many occasions when he has presented honours to people. Twice a year he used to present them, at Government House. He was well decorated for the service that he gave to Queen and country. As I said earlier, he was a Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George, a Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order and a Commander of the Order of the British Empire, and had been awarded the Distinguished Service Cross. The DSC, of course, was for services rendered during the wars. The Governor retired on 22 July 1985 after giving eight years of magnificent service to the State and the people of Queensland and, in all, some 56 years of service to his country. A senior Governor before he retired, he relieved the Governor-General at Government House in Canberra on a number of occasions.

Commodore Sir James Ramsay is survived by his wife, Lady Ramsay, three daughters and a son. I was very honoured to attend Commodore Sir James Ramsay's funeral in Brisbane yesterday, together with almost 1,000 people, including the Premier and Deputy Premier, Cabinet Ministers, members of parliament and distinguished people from all walks of life, to pay my tribute to him and his service to the Commonwealth, to Australia and to Queensland. The service conducted at St John's Cathedral was a very fine one. It was conducted by the Dean of Brisbane, the Reverend Arthur Grimshaw, and the panegyric was preached by the Archbishop of Brisbane, His Grace the Most Reverend Sir John Grinrod. I felt he took a very appropriate text from psalm 107, verses 23 and 24:
They that go down to the sea in ships, that do business in great waters; these see the works of the Lord, and his wonders in the deep.

During the funeral service the Archbishop said that the late Sir James's joy of life and sense of humour jumped the bridge of protocol in his role as Governor. He said that Sir James was a religious man with a reserve and respect for the convictions of others; he and Lady Ramsay drew people of diverse occupations and background together. I think that that was a very fine tribute to the late Governor. The Navy paid him the highest accolade possible. Six able seamen from HMAS Vampire carried his flag-draped coffin, bearing the ceremonial sword and his cap, from the Cathedral out to the gun carriage where the 124 strong Royal Australian Navy guard saluted and reversed arms as a mark of respect. Hundreds of people lined Ann Street as sailors slow marched Sir James's casket along Ann Street to King George Square.

Sir James was indeed an officer and a gentleman. He was truly a remarkable man and a great Australian who will be sorely missed, and I wish to convey to Lady Ramsay and her family my sincerest sympathy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I use this opportunity this afternoon to outline to the Senate an incident in Queensland which occurred after I was maliciously maligned by a State Government Minister. The Queensland Minister for Education, Mr Powell, made the attack in the State Parliament and later issued a Press statement in which he repeated some of the things he had said in the Parliament. So far there is nothing unusual about that story, but the story does not end there. A State high school on the south side of Brisbane included the Minister's full Press statement in its February newsletter. In that Press statement Mr Powell accused me and the Australian Labor Party of `attempting to mischievously ferment trouble and rebellion in Queensland's schools'.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Powell's parliamentary comments were made and his subsequent Press statement was issued last November after I publicly defended a State high school student who was forced to wear a dirty school uniform from the school's lost property office because she had not been attired in full school uniform. The student, who had to change in an empty classroom, said she had been humiliated by the incident and developed a rash as a consequence of wearing the filthy garments. I pointed out at the time, as I have done so on many other occasions, that State school teachers in Queensland have no authority to insist that school uniforms be worn. Under the Queensland State Education Act and its regulations there are no provisions whatsoever covering the wearing, compulsory or otherwise, of school uniforms. Thus the wearing of uniforms cannot be legally enforced in Queensland State schools, and students who do not wear them should not be excluded from school activities on that basis.

In Mr Powell's Press statement, which was reprinted in the newsletter of the State high school to which I have referred, he said I had `engaged in a disgraceful display, symptomatic of the Left Wing's trends to undermine traditional values of authority and responsibility'. Presumably that was due to my desire to see the law upheld. In Queensland most members of my Party have become immune to the idiotic vitriol expressed by members of the National Party, but I did take exception to a State high school giving prominence and wide circulation to Mr Powell's unsubstantiated and vicious personal attack. Having a State high school become so blatantly enmeshed in the politics of the National Party is frightening.

I should mention that the principal of this high school had not informed me that these defamatory remarks would be published in his school's newsletter and had not offered me the right of any reply. Indeed, I became aware of the newsletter only when an anonymous person contacted my office-someone who I assume was a parent who objected to her school's newsletter being politicised in such a fashion. After speaking on the telephone to the high school principal about this matter I wrote to him outlining my position on the issue of school uniforms. I now quote the letter which I forwarded to the principal:
Dear Sir,

In your newsletter of 5 February you included a media release in relation to school uniforms by Mr Lin Powell, Minister for Education. Mr Powell's release was highly critical of me and it made aspersions which I consider to have no foundation. I have made my position clear on the issue of school uniforms in State schools on a number of occasions. Personally, I do not care if students choose to wear a uniform or not. What I do object to is a coercion to wear uniforms where there is no legal basis for such coercion.
Some teachers and Parents and Citizens Associations may prefer to have students wear a school uniform, but in Queensland State schools they do not have the legal right to enforce that preference.
I am mystified at the Minister for Education in Queensland suggesting that because I like to see the law upheld, I am guilty of fermenting trouble and rebellion in Queensland schools.
Because you gave wide circulation to Mr Powell's comments I trust that you will include my letter in a forthcoming issue of your newsletter.
Yours sincerely,
Mal Colston,
Senator for Queensland.

In a subsequent telephone conversation, however, the high school principal made it clear to me that my letter would not be published and I would thus not be given that opportunity to put my case to the students and parents who had seen the Minister's scurrilous Press statement in the school's newsletter.

Naturally, I was deeply concerned by the highly political stance taken by a State high school. More importantly, however, this incident raises a number of pertinent questions about the sorry state of Queensland under the present State Government Administration. How can a Queensland Government Minister encourage State school teachers to ignore the law and malign those who would stand up for correct legal processes? Mr Powell promised in his statement to support schools which coerced students into wearing school uniforms. In true National Party style, Mr Powell is happy to take the law into his own hands when the law as it stands does not suit him.

The incident I have described must also raise questions about the relationship between the Queensland State Government and its bureaucracy. I can see no valid justification for this particular high school reproducing a Press statement which amounts to no more than blatant politicking, and distributing that statement to all the families represented at that school. That high school cannot claim to offer a sound education in the values of independent thinking when its principal allows the school newsletter to become a vehicle for the propaganda of its political master. Has bureaucratic integrity sunk to such a low ebb under the Bjelke-Petersen Government that a school principal will allow politics in his school in order to curry favour with his Minister; or, in a more sinister light, was the principal fearful that his career and school would suffer if he dared to circulate any reply from me?

I am sure honourable senators are aware of the Queensland Premier's attitude to freedom of expression in that State.
