Recently he was quoted widely as saying that Queensland would be a much better State when it got rid of the media. I suppose the Queensland Government would carry on quite well without the media. It could use State-funded institutions to carry and spread its propaganda.

I have many personal friends in the teaching profession in Queensland, not all of whom share my political persuasion. It bothers me that an incident such as the one I have described could reflect on them, as I know that they would regard what happened as a despicable event. Although it is now a long time since I taught in Queensland I still have fond memories of the schools in which I worked, my former colleagues and many of my former students whom I still remember and occasionally meet. It is my hope that those memories will not be spoilt by another incident of this nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak briefly about a new form of alcoholic drink being marketed aggressively for young people. The drinks are called coolers and, as many honourable senators will know, coolers burst onto the American market in the summer of 1981 and the Australian market at the end of 1984. These drinks known as coolers have been sensationally successful. Sales in the United States boomed to the point where it was claimed recently that some seven million cases of coolers were sold in 1985 alone. In Australia the distribution of coolers during last summer far exceeded the wine industry's expectations. It is claimed that one million cases of a leading brand, West Coast, have been sold after only eight months on the market. There has been a proliferation of brands. As well as West Coast cooler, we have Island cooler, Hula cooler, Castaway cooler, Surf cooler, Berry Estates tropical cooler, Capricorn cooler, SL cooler and Cin Cin cooler.

SPEECH.PARA: These coolers are a combination of white wine and fruit or imitation fruit juice. They are essentially very sweet drinks, and some have a very high alcohol content, the highest I could discover being on one on sale at Hardy's winery, which had an alcoholic content of 9 per cent. I hasten to say here that I am not objecting to the sale of alcoholic drinks or to the sale of high alcohol drinks. That is no problem; they are available anyhow. I am concerned about the marketing of these products and the market at which they are being directed-new drinkers. A random sample taken in some of Canberra's supermarkets and liquor stores shows that the following coolers had an alcoholic content of between 4 and 6 per cent: West Coast cooler; 4 per cent; Island cooler, 6 per cent; Hula cooler, 5 per cent; and Castaway cooler, 5 per cent. So they are not without a significant alcohol content.

I am concerned about this mushrooming market not because these drinks contain alcohol, not because I do not drink-I certainly do-but because of the increasing number of problems associated with the abuse of alcohol in the community and the recruitment of very young people into alcohol use. An analysis of the cooler market shows it to be directed towards new drinkers, or new business. It is aimed particularly at young drinkers or occasional drinkers feeling their way into the use of wine, or being introduced to wine.

The packaging of many coolers in small bottles, which makes them look like soft drinks, is important for it serves to distinguish in the minds of customers the coolers from what are called starter wines, such as Barossa Pearl, Ben Ean and Cold Duck. Each of those forms of wine is marketed in a wine bottle and people know that they are drinking wine, but these coolers are marketed as if they were soft drinks. Whereas it is not socially acceptable to swig away at a wine bottle in public, it is certainly socially acceptable to toss back a cooler in a public place. Because of its packaging it looks as if one is just tossing back a soft drink. Some supermarkets display alcoholic drinks like coolers in the same refrigerated compartment as they sell their soft drinks. Advertising by cooler companies, including television advertising, has been extensive. These television advertisements do not appear during the viewing time for small children-I am not suggesting that at all-but the advertisements which do appear are quite unlike beer advertisements or other wine advertisements. They are more similar, perhaps, to advertisements for Coca Cola or other accepted soft drinks than they are to the usual kinds of wine or beer advertisements. They have been tantalisingly and inaccurately described as having `plenty of flavour', and being `crisp' and `refreshing'. They are quite crudely associated with sexual success in one of the articles which appeared in a weekend magazine in Sydney. So they are being marketed and directed towards young drinkers.

Most experienced wine drinkers-that would include, I imagine, most senators-would find coolers quite horrible. They certainly would not find them equivalent in taste to any kind of good dry white. They are, in fact, some form of white wine mixed with fruit juice. They are intended for a young, unsophisticated market which is inexperienced at handling alcohol. Or, they may be directed towards people who just want a drink for the alcohol content, just to be affected by drink. Presumably they use fairly low grade wine-I have no objection to that-but they combine these with a variety of real or synthetic fruit juices and cordials. They are drunk like beer, yet most coolers have a higher alcoholic content and are drunk by young and inexperienced drinkers. They often knock the coolers back without realising the amount of alcohol that is contained in them or the dangers which this poses for them as drinkers.

It is not surprising that I recently received a letter expressing concern about the effect of coolers on young drinkers. This criticism came from a long-time defender of the alcohol industry, a long time defender of people's right to drink-and to drink with minimum government taxation, I might add-and a person who defended alcohol producers and distributors from what he saw as often unnecessary government interference. I am making the point that he is in no way a wowser. He wrote saying that I should focus my concern on what he called the soaring growth of soft drinks containing up to 6 per cent alcohol, volume for volume-so-called coolers-which are sold to the very young without significant indication by brand name or warning label that they are alcohol-content drinks. He went on to say:

When you drink beer you know it is alcoholic; so with wine; and with gin and whisky but not so with coolers. Coolers volume sales are enormous, tax on 6 per cent alcohol is 10 per cent of the wholesale price.

He makes the comment: `Scandalous'. Whether or not the excise is appropriate is another issue. Following that letter I undertook some investigations to see what I could learn about the expanding cooler market, and I really do not like what I found. First of all, the drinks do have an alcohol content higher than that of most beers and they are being confused with soft drinks. Marketing campaigns are being undertaken which will lead young Australians to think that they are drinking a soft drink. There are no special controls or monitoring of this new alcoholic starter drink, and there is evidence that the drink is aimed directly at a young audience.

I suppose this is my concern-not that the drink should exist, not that it should be on the market, as that is a matter for the manufacturers and for the consumers, but that it is being directed without full disclosure of what it contains at a young drinking market. That seems to me to be unreasonable. It is not good enough. I ask the Labor Government what it is doing to examine the marketing practices of some of these drinks and what it is doing to ensure that adequate information is placed in the hands of those who will buy and use the drinks. I hope the Government is not so pre-occupied with economic matters with economic statistics, that it does not have time to concern itself with the relationship between this alcoholic drink and young Australians.

I draw only three conclusions from what I have said. Firstly, we really need to examine the marketing of coolers to try to prevent them being offered as soft drinks when they are clearly alcoholic drinks. That is just a matter of proper consumer information. Secondly, we should look at setting a maximum limit on the alcohol content of coolers, and I suggest that that limit should be towards the lower rather than the higher end of the coolers already available. Thirdly, the Government should try to make sure that young Australians are not being targeted in a deceptive way-are not being deceived, in effect-by cooler advertising campaigns and understand that they are being asked to buy a drink with a very considerable alcohol content which in turn could cause many young Australians to get into trouble with drink driving and with other matters without them having realised that they were exposing themselves to these dangers. Although my children are out of this age group now, it was not so long ago that they were on provisional driving licences and all the talk at that stage was of the great danger they faced of losing their licences following any infringement at all. The inappropriate marketing of these particular alcoholic drinks may, in fact, lead them towards just such problems.
Sitting suspended from 1.20 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney- General. Is it true that the Government has decided that judges from New South Wales will not be considered for appointment to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry into matters concerning the alleged conduct of Mr Justice Murphy? If that is so, what is the basis of this exclusion of members of the New South Wales judiciary?

—It is not true that any absolute decision of that kind has been reached. The only consideration was that a number of New South Wales judges had clearly excluded themselves from consideration by virtue of having made some public comments in the matter bearing upon the Flannery and Briese trials. There are also obvious considerations of personal contact and familiarity that arise when one is dealing with a person who comes from a particular jurisdiction. Beyond that, there is, I believe, no foundation for any belief that there is any generalised veto applicable in that respect.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the release today of the April labour force figures. I ask the Minister: Firstly, how does employment growth in the latest figures line up with the Government's commitment to employment targets set in 1983? Secondly, what has the effect of the participation rate had on the unemployment rate and job growth? Thirdly, what would the unemployment rate be if the participation rate had remained static since 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The third part of the question requires some research and I happen to have done that. In relation to the earlier part of the question, let me say this: The latest figures represent an important stage of the recovery of the labour market under this Government. Since April 1983, in our first three years in office, over 669,000 new jobs have been created, compared with our job target of 500,000 new jobs. The target was reached five months ahead of schedule. Job growth has increased by over 10 per cent for this period and is now at a 20-year record. Unemployment has fallen by over 100,000, or 14.5 per cent, and the unemployment rate has declined to 7.9 per cent. It was, of course, around that level in an earlier quarter. When the Government took office, full time employment had declined in the previous year by 243,000, while unemployment had soared by 254,000. There is almost an inverse ratio between those figures. The unemployment rate was then above 10 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Ray asked me about the participation rate. It is an important point because the seasonally adjusted participation rate increased by 0.5 percentage points in April to 62.4 per cent, the highest since the commencement of monthly labour force surveys. If the participation rate had remained at the April 1983 level, unemployment would be 200,000 less and the unemployment rate now would be down to 5.2 per cent. The rise in the participation rate has meant that hidden unemployment has been drastically reduced, as is revealed in the aggregate figures. I might say that all groups have benefited from the recovery in the labour market, including teenagers. The youth unemployment rate has been reduced from 26.6 per cent in April 1983 to 22.6 per cent in April 1986. That is still not a satisfactory result, but it is a vast improvement. Employment growth in the past 12 months has increased by 358,000, or 5.4 per cent, and is now far above the Budget financial year forecast of 180,000 for that period.

The Government had made commitments about this matter of employment prior to being elected. Those commitments have been more than fully discharged in terms of what was promised, although they were derided in some circles at the time. Senator Crichton-Browne makes a sotto voce interjection which he may like to make louder-I did not hear it. What was it?

TALK.START.PARA: —I said: `I doubt your statistics'.

—He did not say that at all. If he is ashamed of his interjections, he should not make them. The point I make is that in terms of the commitments the Government made the figures are very encouraging. All honourable senators ought to be encouraged, even Senator Crichton-Browne. Let me say that, as always, one must approach figures with caution. The fact of the matter is that the record of achievement in respect of the labour market is good, but it is not one which should induce satisfaction or complacency about the general condition of the labour market. I thank Senator Ray for his question because it has a number of important sub-points in it. It is appropriate that the figures be seen in the perspective which was embodied in Senator Ray's very lucid and important question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education. I am sure that she is aware that recipients of unemployment benefits are denied those benefits as soon as they apply to enrol at a tertiary institution because they are regarded as no longer searching for fulltime employment. As that may mean a loss of the applicant's only source of income, can the Minister explain why it is taking her Department anything up to three months in Western Australia for tertiary education assistance scheme forms to be processed and for money to be paid? I have a case history of a delay of more than three months in the Department, and the Department by its own admission says that it will be two months or more. Does the Minister consider that this period without income is acceptable? What will she do about it and how does she suggest that those people should maintain body and soul during that period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to Senator Crichton-Brown's question and it seemed to me that at one point he was suggesting that unemployment benefits should continue to be paid to students. I know that Mr Howard, grappling around for some way to make himself a little attractive to young people, has suggested that unemployed people should be put into education.
—What about late payment? Come on! Deal with the question. What about late payment of students? Do you want them to starve? Come to the substance of the question.

—It is not surprising that Senator Chaney has to start shouting interjections whenever I mention Mr Howard and particularly when I mention the absolute lack of anything like a coherent education policy coming from the other side. I realise that these matters are a great embarrassment to Senator Chaney because he can see daily that support is growing for the Australian Labor Party and is falling away from the Liberal Party of Australia. The Liberal Party tries to conceal its lack of policies, and we get rather disjointed and confused questions such as the one Senator Crichton-Browne has just asked.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course it is the case that unemployment benefits are paid to people who are unemployed; that is, people who are looking for full time employment. They are not paid to students, who are eligible for tertiary assistance if they fulfil certain eligible criteria. I am concerned at Senator Crichton-Browne's claim that there has been a three-month delay in the case of one student, because it is the custom in many Commonwealth Department of Education offices administering TEAS to pay TEAS to students once they notify the Department of enrolment, even if that means later making a deduction, so that students will not be left without income to which they are entitled.

I would be very happy to have investigated the case about which Senator Crichton-Browne has asked a question. I spend a lot of time investigating these claims. I suggest that he would be assisting his constituent better if he were to bring this difficulty to my office straight away, instead of sitting on it for a while to ask a question about it at Question Time. I am not aware that there are delays of that kind in Western Australia. I will have the matter investigated and I will report to the Senate on the current state of time taken between notification of enrolment in a course and the first TEAS payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question just so that I understand the Minister. Is she in fact saying that it is not the norm for her Department to take two months from when the unemployment benefit ceases to make the first payment under TEAS, which is what her Department has clearly advised me? I can give the Minister the name of the departmental officer and I have his advice in writing.

—Senator Crichton-Browne did not listen to what I said. I did not say that it is not the norm for a period to elapse between payment of the unemployment benefit and payment under TEAS. What I did say was that it is not the norm for three months to elapse between notification of enrolment and the first TEAS payment. My Department has the responsibility for TEAS payments not for unemployment benefit. I will certainly report to the Senate on the time that does elapse-of course, there is some time that necessarily will elapse-between a student providing evidence of enrolment and eligibility for TEAS and the first TEAS payment being made.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. I refer to the excellent and enviable public housing records of the South Australian and the Western Australian State governments which significantly are the result of those States nominating 100 per cent of their low interest Loan Council borrowings for housing trust and housing commission purposes. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's new funding program for public housing, in particular the arrangements covering the Loan Council public housing funds for South Australia and Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Maguire is very well aware, public housing is a major priority for our Government and that area was not ignored in the recent 2 April housing package announcement. That announcement included the following commitment: That the direct grant funding for public housing via the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement will be at the same level in real terms this year as last year's very high level, which will result in about $700m in direct grants to the States for public housing. Of course, that compares more than favourably with the $406m that was available for public housing in the last year of the Liberal Administration. The 2 April package also included the commitment that all States will be allowed to allocate up to 60 per cent of their Loan Council funds to public housing, and so receive these funds at the highly concessional 4.5 per cent interest rate. If this change had not been made all States, other than South Australia and Western Australia, would have been limited to allocating only 30 per cent of their Loan Council funds for public housing.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning to South Australia and Western Australia, these States were allowed last year to allocate 100 per cent of their Loan Council funds to public housing. They had done so for a number of years in the past. In the next financial year, under current arrangements, this will fall back to 60 per cent, which could involve up to $85m less being available for public housing in those States despite the increases in other States. The housing Ministers of South Australia and Western Australia put their views to the Commonwealth Minister for Housing and Construction at the recent housing Ministers meeting in Adelaide. The Minister for Housing and Construction has informed the Government of the situation of these States and the issue will be examined in the Budget context.

In conclusion, the Government has every reason to be proud of its public housing record. The total funding, Commonwealth and State, in 1985-86 is $1.8 billion, the highest ever in real terms, and our funding for 1986-87 of at least $700m in direct grants, and up to $700m in concessional loans-that is, a total of up to $1,400m available from the Commonwealth-will lead to up to 21,500 new housing commencements. Of course, that is a dramatic improvement on the public housing record of our predecessors.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Resources and Energy follows the Government's acknowledgement that Australian uranium tails, U238, is sent to France and can be used in the Super Phenix reactor, and that Sweden and Finland send their uranium to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics for enrichment. Is the Government aware of a statement made by Georges Benedett, then French Deputy President of the Assemblee Nationale, on 3 November 1983 that `the fast breeder reactor is the only one actually capable of providing plutonium in sufficient quantities to supply the development of our tactical nuclear force'? Can the Minister state categorically that Australian U238 has never been used in the Super Phenix? If so, on what facts does he base his assurance? Is there not an equivalent risk associated with the Australian U238 which has been sent to the United Kingdom? Finally, will the Minister now also acknowledge that Australian origin nuclear material is sent to the USSR from West Germany and the United Kingdom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particular statement Senator Vigor referred to about fast breeders providing plutonium for tactical nuclear forces, but I think it is worth noting that the Super Phenix fast breeder reactor is clearly used only for nuclear power production and is part of a European program of co-operation in breeder development for peaceful purposes. The reactor is owned and operated by a consortium comprising French, the Federal Republic of Germany, Italian, the Netherlands and Belgian utilities. As the reactor is subject to IAEA, International Atomic Energy Agency, and European Atomic Energy Community, Euratom, safeguards, France simply could not legitimately remove nuclear material in Super Phenix from safeguards for military purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: The Phenix fast breeder is an entirely different reactor. It is not safeguarded and there would be no legal impediment to the use of this facility for the production of nuclear weapons material. That is the difference between the Phenix and the Super Phenix. Depleted uranium is, as I described, a by-product of the uranium enrichment process. France, being the world's second largest enrichment supplier, has in storage very substantial quantities of depleted uranium of various origins. The depleted uranium of Australian origin to which I referred the other day would comprise only a very small proportion of the total amount in storage. In these circumstances there is no reason to believe that France would wish to use Australian uranium in Super Phenix.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that they have not?

—I am getting to that. Can Senator Sanders curb his racing hormones and listen for a while? The reports received by the Australian Safeguards Office confirm that Australian origin depleted uranium has not been so used. I repeat for Senator Sanders: Has not been so used. From a non-proliferation perspective, use of Australian origin nuclear material in a safeguarded facility in accordance with an Australian bilateral safeguards agreement, whether a fast breeder reactor used for power production or some other type of civil nuclear facility, does not represent any kind of risk of diversion into weapons production.

ANSWER.PARA: What I can say about the last part of the question about AONM being sent to the USSR from West Germany and Britain is that the fast breeder reactor operated by the United Kingdom-the prototype one at Dounreay-is a safeguarded facility and is not used for the production of weapons material. No Australian depleted uranium has been used in this reactor. Under the Euratom-Australia nuclear safeguards agreement, West Germany and the United Kingdom may send Australian origin nuclear material to the USSR for enrichment on an all-in all-out basis. But to date, for commercial reasons of their own, neither country has used this provision of the Australia-Euratom agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate not agree that, whilst work force participation rates have increased, a disconcerting aspect of the employment figures released today is the increase in youth unemployment to its highest level since this time last year? Is it a fact that youth are not getting their fair share of the additional jobs created by this Government? What, in the view of the Government, are the factors which give rise to this position and, apart from the traineeship scheme, what can be done about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite able to deal with the first aspect of the question because the figures I gave in respect of youth unemployment were the figures for the period of this Government and I have not seen the month by month figures. I accept what Senator Harradine has said about that, but I just have not seen the figures and I cannot comment on them on the basis of the last few months. I do not know that Senator Harradine can say there is a Government view about this issue. In terms of the youth traineeships and elsewhere, we have attempted to recognise the particular problem of youth unemployment. But let me say that there are many instances of widespread job vacancies in Australian industry today which are not being filled. I think we have to face the fact that there are a number of significant cultural changes which have led to a reluctance on the part of some young people to take available jobs and to a preference to take alternative courses of action, whether it be in lifestyle or in seeking other levels of employment. I do not want at Question Time to get into a dissertation upon this issue, which I think is highly controversial. Speaking for myself, I doubt that the aggregate unemployment level in Australia really represents the situation of unemployment if one compares today's aggregate unemployment levels with those of 20 years ago. I suspect that full employment in this country is probably at a slightly higher level of unemployment than it was in years gone by. I think that is very much replicated or true of youth unemployment in Australia, for a variety of reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: I think this is a matter about which it is more appropriate to have a lengthy discussion than to have me speculating at Question Time on the basis of my own views about these matters. In answer to the question, as I indicated in my earlier answer, the question of youth unemployment is of continuing concern to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I ask: Because of the extraordinary wide application of workers compensation Acts, giving rise to a dramatic escalation in costs borne by industry, would the Minister not agree that something must be done to ease these additional costs to employers, and that there is now a definite social security element enshrined in workers compensation? Since the present treatment of injured workers on workers compensation contrasts sharply with the injured unemployed looking for work, will the Government give consideration to discussing with State Attorneys-General the introduction of a more equitable compensation package for injury?

—Workers compensation has been regarded hitherto as essentially a matter for the State governments but there is a case for rationalising the compensation system as part of an overall assault on some of the inequities and uncertainties associated with accident compensation generally. It is probably a long haul so far as this or any other government is concerned to be able to bring workers compensation into some more rational framework of compensation systems on an appropriate no fault basis, but it is an exercise upon which this Government has embarked, starting with efforts, in co-operation with the States, to develop no fault compensation systems in the transport area and so on. I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Attorney-General for such further comment as he wishes to make.

—Has the Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women seen comments in yesterday's Tasmanian Mercury in which the Convenor of the National Women's Consultative Council, Ms Edith Hall, stated that women in Queensland and Tasmania are being denied access to relevant information and are unaware of their rights to benefits and equal opportunities? Whilst I am sure the Minister would not be surprised at that statement, would she care to comment on it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I am aware of the disadvantage suffered by women living in Queensland and Tasmania because of the continuing refusal of both of the conservative governments of those States either to provide any sort of anti-discrimination legislation for women in those States or to provide any sort of special programs or information services for them. While it is true that Tasmanian women and Queensland women have benefited from a number of Commonwealth initiatives such as the Sex Discrimination Act and the various programs that we fund, there are some areas of legislation which only States can act on. In particular, of course--
—We have equality in our State for women.

—I hear Senator Newman interjecting. I think she, as someone who has taken an interest in women's affairs, should be ashamed of the record of the Tasmanian Government, which refuses to give its own employees in the State Public Service the same sort of protection against discrimination and sexual harassment as that which every Labor State has provided and as, indeed, was provided in Victoria under a Liberal government and as has been provided by us to Commonwealth employees.

ANSWER.PARA: Women in Tasmania, despite having female representation on the other side of the chamber, have no protection and it seems to me that there is no move to give them any protection by Tasmanian Liberals, be they Federal or State. Similarly, women in Queensland are seriously disadvantaged because of that Government's refusal to carry out its responsibilities to women-although it must be said that that State does have the benefit of a very strong advocate in our Government for Queensland women, namely, Senator Margaret Reynolds, who is certainly able to compensate to a large extent for the deficiencies of the Queensland Government.

We have taken the step of establishing women's information services in Brisbane and Hobart in order to help overcome the disadvantages suffered by Tasmanian and Queensland women. Speaking of disadvantages suffered by Tasmanian women--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Obviously the Minister does not know what she is talking about. Tasmania is the only State that has sent two women to the Senate.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the Minister's well-known attitude towards a more flexible wages system, does the Minister believe there are grounds for looking at a system which would represent more the American-type position where employers and the trade unions negotiate and bargain, and finish up with a contract, within which they may agree upon a certain enforcement procedure, which would then be a legally binding document and would thus allow the processes of the law to apply on that basis?

—I am glad that Senator Parer referred to my well-known approach to flexibility in the wages system. It is becoming increasingly well known because of his questions; I am not going to answer them any more if I can avoid it. I think this is a good achievement on the part of the Opposition. It has brought up an important issue and I congratulate it on that. It has not done that in relation to anything else. I am asked whether my flexibility, as it has been called, would extend to the American position. I resist all temptations, particularly in respect of the American position. In all these questions Senator Parer has asked me, I think he has to grapple with the fact that, whether he likes it or not, we have a 60 per cent unionised labour force in Australia and that in America the unionised labour force is something now in order of 17 per cent.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator Withers should be on the record as saying `hear, hear' to that because that is the sort of simple solution which he might like. It is not a solution to wage policy issues in the context of the history and environment in which we operate in this country. I am not even sure that the implications of what Senator Parer said about the United States in his question are even right. He identified the American position, as he calls it, as being plant by plant negotiations. I think that the honourable senator will find that that is not true if he considers the American automotive industry at the moment, even though it has a relatively poorly unionised labour force. One difficulty which the American automotive companies will complain about is the very fact that they negotiate industry by industry agreements, not plant by plant agreements. The American situation cannot be clearly identified in the way in which the honourable senator would like to identify it in the assumptions which seem to underlie his question. My answer is that I do not regard the American experience as being relevant or useful in the Australian context. I do regard the European experience in countries such as Germany, Austria, Sweden and so on as being very relevant and useful in our context because their economies have been marked by continuing and steady success over the last 25 years.
—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that the statement that I made was a direct quotation from a statement by Mr Hawke in 1980?
—Order! That is not a supplementary question. The honourable senator is adding new matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Last Friday, Senator Michael Baume read out in the Senate a letter which he had written to the Minister claiming that the Government had produced `a record balance of payments deficit'. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether this is a fact and whether he has replied to Senator Baume's letter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a fact that a record balance of payments deficit is looming, because by definition a balance of payments deficit is always zero, a fact of which Senator Baume's colleague Senator Messner was made aware at Estimates Committee C when he said to the Treasury Deputy Secretary, Mr Moore:

ANSWER.PARA: What would you expect the overall deficit on our balance of payments to be this financial year, in the light of current figures?
Mr Moore said:
`Zero'.
Senator Messner said:
I am sorry. That was a very clever answer.
Mr Moore said:
Do you mean current account?
I have replied to Senator Michael Baume. Since he has set the precedent of making public in the Senate the correspondence which passes between the two of us, I will read my reply. It states:
Dear Senator Baume,

I write regarding your letter to me dated 25 April 1986. I note that in that letter you seek to make a number of judgments regarding the present Government's economic policies. As in areas such as fine wine, good music and debenture issue prospectuses, an appropriate level of expertise is normally regarded as a prerequisite to being able to distinguish the good from the bad. Your letter suggests that in the area of economics, you lack such expertise. The balance of payments deficit in 1985-86 will be zero, as it was in 1984-85, 1983-84 and in every other year for which data exists. It is difficult to see how this constitutes a ``record''. In Estimates Committee C on 17 April your colleague, Senator Messner, demonstrated that he understood this fact. I suggest you seek assistance from Senator Messner in order to commence developing a better grasp of economics.

I hardly need to point out that under the former Government of this country, the type of intellectual sloth which your letter displays towards matters of economics produced the worst depression experienced by Australia since the 1930s.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he is aware that, because of the duty free importation of 100,000 litres of passion-fruit pulp from the South Pacific Forum islands group, the Westland Food Packers processing plant at Cleveland in south-east Queensland has ceased operations. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether this pulp is being dumped or is being allowed in under some preferential agreement? If the latter is the case, can the Minister tell the Senate what steps are being taken to ensure that farmers and workers will not continue to be disadvantaged by this action? If the importation is a normal commercial transaction, can the Minister inform the Senate when the Government will reverse its present discriminatory policies and allow the costs of all farmers, including passion-fruit growers, to fall so that they can be competitive on all markets?
—I thought that the honourable senator would have welcomed something entering Australia duty free. She has argued for that for superphosphate for a long time.
—This affects my passion-fruit growers.

—There it is. The honourable senator said: `This affects my passion-fruit growers'. She puts passion-fruit in the scones too, I suppose. As far as her passion-fruit growers are concerned, I do not know the precise circumstances of this matter. I will certainly inquire for the honourable senator but I think she will find that this Government has agreed-it is now in operation-that imports from so-called Forum island countries, the countries of the South Pacific region, should be at duty free levels now or are being reduced to duty free levels. The Government has agreed on that to assist those economies. It is part of a proper trade approach to countries in this region. I will find out about the circumstances of the honourable senator's passion-fruit growers as requested but I think that she will find that that is the answer. I think that this policy would be approved by most Australians. I hope that the answer which commends itself to passion-fruit processors or growers is that they should get about the task of improving their competitiveness in the Australian market. Perhaps they can then find a market for their product overseas as well. That would be highly commendable.
—Three per cent for this and 3.8 per cent for that and you talk about competitiveness.

—I cannot deal with Sen- ator Archer's incoherent interjection at this stage. If he likes to make it clearer, I will do so. That is the general answer to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. I will certainly investigate the particular circumstances and give her a further answer.

—I refer the Minister for Community Services to today's reports that the Mitchell royal commission into the Greek social security conspiracy case is about to report. Can the Minister indicate whether this is true and whether the Australian taxpayer will have to foot a bill running into millions of dollars because of the scandalous conduct of Senior Detective Don Thomas, who was found by the presiding magistrate--

—Mr President, you can see why those opposite are nervous. He was found by the presiding magistrate to have contrived evidence and concocted his whole sordid investigation, which came to be known as `Don's Party'.

—I take a point of order. I think it is well known by most honourable senators that this question goes to likely criminal proceedings, if not criminal proceedings that have been commenced. Mr President, I ask you to watch the question and any answer given by the Minister.
—Order! I will allow the question but I ask the Minister to bear in mind the point that has been taken by the Leader of the Opposition when he replies to the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The commission of inquiry into compensation arising from the so-called social security conspiracy case was established by this Government in 1984. Its terms of reference were that it make recommendations, as Senator Bolkus said, on the levels of compensation which may be payable to people involved in this case to cover out of pocket expenses, et cetera, and also to cover the loss of benefits that some people-very few-received while they were being investigated. The commission under Dame Roma Mitchell has presented its report to the Governor-General. The report is in two volumes: A general part which deals with the commission's procedures and general recommendations; and volume 2, which will make particular recommendations in respect of each of the 173 individuals who submitted claims. Cabinet will shortly consider this report along with the recommendations on those adversely affected by the conspiracy allegations but who were not actually charged. There were a considerable number of people in that class.

ANSWER.PARA: The latter group has been considered administratively with the assistance of the Greek- Australian welfare association in Sydney. The Government is pleased that these recommendations are now to become available so that appropriate compensation can be paid, ending this sorry episode, which Senator Bolkus described, in the history of the Australian social security system and in the history of Australian justice. When the Cabinet has considered the matter and has considered the report we will report to the Parliament. I think that would be the appropriate time to deal with the matter of how much is involved and how it should be paid-under proper circumstances, unlike the circumstances surrounding the case when it occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Government noted that, since the Repco company was taken over by the New Zealand firm, Ariadne, it has had many of its automotive parts manufacturing divisions sold off? Is the Government concerned that this may result in local content requirements, on which its car plan is based, being impossible to meet for any car manufacturer because parts will no longer be produced in this country? Finally, how can the Government maintain the position that takeover laws do not need reform when before its very eyes an important Australian manufacturer has been taken over and split up, resulting in a loss of industrial capacity to the country and a large speculative gain to the successful raider?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been very aware of the position of the Repco company since it was taken over by Ariadne. I have had a number of discussions with the Chairman and Managing Director of the company. Of course, I was very aware of Repco before it was taken over by Ariadne. It has not led an entirely charmed life in the last few years, if I can put in it those terms. We as a Government are concerned that the integrity of the motor vehicle component sector be retained as far as possible. There have been discussions about possible alternative sources of manufacture within Australia in respect of Repco functions. I expect that there may be further announcements, but on looking at what has happened to date, the brake function of Repco has been taken over by a British company, the BBA group, which is reputedly a company of good technology that is expanding successfully into world markets, with substantial interests in America.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not sure what other matters Senator Siddons had in mind, but certainly there have been discussions about other parts of Repco. Again the same sorts of considerations apply. That is to say, it is important that a successor manufacturer be found to continue the manufacturing function previously performed by a particular division of Repco. So the answer to that part of the question really is that we have been concerned about this. We have been monitoring very closely what has been happening and we will continue to do so. In my speech to the Federated Automotive Component Manufacturers last year I made the point that if there were not competent manufacturers in the Australian component industry who could supply efficiently and competitively to the industry, the Government would not hesitate to invite other contributors into the industry. We will do that if that becomes necessary.

On the final part of the question Senator Siddons asks: `How can the Government maintain the position that takeover laws do not need reform in the light of these circumstances?'. I do not think the Government maintains that position. The question of takeover laws is being examined by the Government and by a whole range of people because it is important that we have the best contemporary takeover laws we could have. There are disagreements, of course, about the adequacy or otherwise of existing takeover laws. Senator Siddons may have been referring to some of the tax aspects of takeovers in respect of which clearly a different position was adopted by him from the position adopted by the Government in a particular set of circumstances. Those matters are not excluded from examination by the Government and are subject to current review.

Senator Siddons referred, in the last part of his question, to a loss of industrial capacity to the country as a result of the Repco takeover. I think I have answered that. We will be very concerned to see that there is not a loss of industrial capacity. It may be that some of the changes that are taking place in relation to Repco represent an improvement in management and industrial capacity subject to the fluctuations of that change. I think it is quite possible that that will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In Question Time on Monday Senator Maguire asked the Minister for information on the employment levels in the restaurant industry in the wake of the Government's crackdown last year on taxpayer-subsidised lunches. The figures the Minister gave the Senate were described by Senator Michael Baume in yesterday's matter of public importance debate as `deceptive and misleading'. Were those figures deceptive and misleading? What is the relationship between the figures the Minister quoted and the figures quoted by Senator Baume-figures indicating a fall in employment in the industry concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures I used on Monday were taken from the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of employment and earnings series and the figures Senator Baume quoted yesterday were taken from the ABS labour force survey series. There is a note by the ABS-this is another indication of the sort of intellectual sloth that members of the Liberal Party, and this member in particular, apply to economic questions-in its catalogue 6263.0 entitled `Comparison of Employment Estimates from the Labour Force Survey and the Survey of Employment and Earnings' which states:

ANSWER.PARA: The SEE covers only wage and salary earners.
That is the source of my figures. It continues:
Its strength lies in the capacity to provide industry/State estimates which are more reliable than those from the MLFS.

That is the monthly labour force survey which Senator Baume used. More importantly, however, the figures Senator Baume used were highly selective. They constituted a highly selective misuse of the series which he used to support a shonky conclusion. They were unquestionably deceptive and misleading, and I will give the Senate the details. The figures I used were a comparison of August 1985 and December 1985 employment. The reasons for choosing the August base is obvious, and December was taken because that is the most recent available month for that series. If Senator Baume examines the survey of employment and earnings figures for September, October and November, he will also find a picture of steady growth. Therefore, for him to speak of the December figures, as he did, as being distorted by the Christmas trade is absolute nonsense-more intellectual sloth. He quoted figures from November 1985 and February 1986-

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the numbers you used in order-
—Order! I have repeatedly asked Senator Messner at Question Time to keep silent. I give him a warning.

—Senator Baume quoted figures for November 1985 and February 1986 which showed a decline of less than 1,000, which of course is statistically insignificant. It is interesting to note that he did not give the August 1985 figure-this is where the deceptive an misleading bit comes in-from the ABS series he was using. In August 1985 the figure was 214,000. The increase from 214,000 in August to 230,000 in November is statistically significant-an increase of 7 1/2 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, there is the question of industry groups. Senator Baume suggested that I was pulling a fast one by quoting figures for restaurants, hotels and personal services; that is, the group to which the SEE data applies. The labour force survey data which was so selectively, deceptively and misleadingly quoted by Senator Baume is available on a finer level of subdivision-in fact, on a finer level than the level used by Senator Baume. For the restaurants, cafes and accommodation subdivision, which is the closest approximation to the restaurant industry which is available from the labour force survey statistics-Senator Baume's source-employment in August 1985 was 176,000, employment in November was 189,000 and employment in February 1986 was 190,000. This shows that there was no fall between November and February, the very time which Senator Baume chose to rely on, but for a less accurately targeted definition. Between August 1985 and February 1986, according to the survey data, employment rose by 14,600 or 8.3 per cent.

There is absolutely no doubt that the figures used by Senator Baume were deceptive and misleading. Whether that should be attributed to an intention to be deceptive or misleading or just to intellectual sloth in application of economic matters is a matter for others to judge.

I also note in today's Australian that one Henry Rose of Howarth and Howarth, an accountancy firm, said that the figures I had used related to restaurants, hotels and personal services. I said this at the time, of course. He claimed that 20,00 jobs had been lost in restaurants. Restaurants are believed to comprise about one- third of the total numbers in the category restaurants, hotels and personal services. Therefore, if restaurants lost 20,000 jobs the other two categories-this is, personal services and hotels-must have gained 40,000 jobs in that period, or had about a 20 per cent growth in employment in four months. This is even higher than the actual growth rate of employment across the economy on which Senator Button commented earlier in Question Time. The point I want to make is that any accountant as creative as Mr Rose obviously he would at one time have got a job writing prospectuses for Patrick Partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister pass that information on to Senator Baume so that Senator Baume has no excuse for being deceptive and misleading in the future?
—Order! There is no supplementary question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and refer to an answer that he gave earlier today to Senator Robert Ray's question with regard to employment figures for Australia. For clarification I ask: Were the figures quoted by him for employment growth and employment based on full time employment, or is there an element of part time employment that can be disclosed in the figures that he has provided? Has the Government undertaken any investigation in order to give an explanation of the apparent disparity between those receiving unemployment benefit and those who are seeking employment at present?

—In answer to the first part of the question, I gave total employment figures. However, on previous occasions when answering questions about the labour market I have drawn attention to the very high levels of full time employment within those aggregate figures. If the honourable senator wishes I will again obtain the percentage. I think last time these figures were available I drew attention to the high component of full time employment in the figures. I am asked whether the Government has had any work done or whatever on the discrepancy between the number receiving unemployment benefit and the number seeking work. I will direct that question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and obtain an answer. I made the point that the participation rate was abnormally high. There are always explanations for that which--
—It might be part time employment.
—I know; the explanation might fall on any side of the political debate, but I will seek to get an answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is it a fact that a French company is currently leach mining for uranium at Manyingee near Onslow in Western Australia? Does the Manyingee ore go to Yeelirrie? If not, where does it go? If it does go to Yeelirrie, where is it earmarked to go after that? Is it leaving the country under the guise of an official export licence from another mine-for example, Roxby Downs or Ranger-via Yeelirrie? Considering that no uranium mines are officially operating in Western Australia, how much uranium has been produced for test purposes at Manyingee, Yeelirrie, Cunderlee, Officer Basin, Robinson Range, Jailore Bore, Mundon Well, Mooloo Downs, Lakeway, Mt Joel, Lake Raeside, Lake Marmion, Thatcher's Soak, Kintyre-all in Western Australia? How much uranium has been extracted from the French operated explorations at Allamber and Burnside in the Northern Territory and Ben Lomond and Lagoon Creek in Queensland? Where does the ore go once it is extracted from these exploration sites?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the kind of question that encourages an unco-operative answer but, Senator Vallentine and I having a very warm and workable professional relationship on these matters these days, I am only too happy to help her to the extent that I can. Total Mining Australia, a French-owned company, holds a valid exploration licence at Manyingee. Exploration licences are of course solely a State responsibility. There has been no mining at Manyingee this year, the honourable senator will no doubt be pleased to find out. However, solution mining trials have been carried out to assess this technique for exploiting the deposit. The trials, which were approved and monitored by State authorities, have now finished. Work carried out this year has involved site rehabilitation and this work is now virtually complete.

ANSWER.PARA: Less than 500 kilos of uranium oxide was extracted during the trials. It is stored in drums at the site with the approval of the Australian Safeguards Office. The material is not being exported from Australia. Regarding the various other exploration prospects that Senator Vallentine mentioned, ore has been mined at some locations and samples taken at others. However, as far as I am aware, apart from in testtubes in laboratories, uranium oxide has been extracted only from ore at Manyingee and Yeelirrie on a trial basis. About 11,000 kilos were produced at Yeelirrie and that is now simply in store. This Government, in adhering to its policy on uranium mining, has not approved the export of any ore samples or uranium oxide for testing or any other reason from other than the approved mines at Nabarlek, Ranger and Olympic Dam. All uranium oxide produced during various tests is stored in a manner approved by the Australian Safeguards Office.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of the news item in yesterday's Australian Financial Review in which the New South Wales Local Government and Shires Association claimed that proposals to allow the transport industry to operate heavier trucks on Australian roads would add $85m a year to road maintenance bills? If so, what action is the Government taking to ensure that if heavier trucks are introduced to Australian roads it will be in a safe, economic and responsible manner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the implications of heavier trucks on our road system. As a result of that awareness, the Government commissioned a report in 1984, called the Review of Road Vehicle Limits, for the purpose of establishing areas of responsibility and the action that should be taken to protect our road system-whether Commonwealth, State of local government. That report was circulated for public comment in January this year. I assume that the response from the Local Government and Shires Association was as a result of the invitation of the Government. The Association's view is that a great more needs to be done to arrest the problem of damage to roads as a result of increased load content on heavy vehicles as well as quantity of traffic usage in recent years.

ANSWER.PARA: The review was required to report on the efficiency, uniformity and economy of the Australian road freight industry with a view to benefiting all Australians. Therefore, it would be premature for the Government to make any response to the Local Government and Shires Association's views other than to invite all other persons interested to make some comment-which is required by 30 June 1986. So therefore, they have only six or seven weeks to indicate their interest in the issue raised by Senator Sibraa.

The Government recognises the need for discussions between the Commonwealth Government and State and local governments about problems of freight usage with the truck manufacturers as well as transport operators. We are anxious to respond to the problem by inviting public comment and by involvement in widespread consultation with all interested parties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Lewis asked me a question without notice in respect of the home nursing service in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister for Territories has provided me with the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: A workload monitoring committee was set up in December 1985 in the community nursing area as part of the dispute-settling arrangements following last year's nursing strike. This committee consists of an equal number of representatives of management and of nurses employed by the Authority, the latter drawn from nominations by the Royal Australian Nursing Federation. The committee is provided with data relative to nurse staffing and workloads and is empowered to make recommendations to management concerning these matters. In this instance the workload management committee took successive decisions to close its books on palliative care and domiciliary patients. Both these decisions were made without the involvement of senior Community Health Services Division management.

The overall resources in community nursing are limited and the response to our recruitment campaign for community nurses has been poor. The difficulty is that the nurses and the RANF are apparently refusing to consider transferring existing resources to areas of need or to consider allocating priorities to patients on a clinical needs basis.

At a meeting with the committee and the RANF yesterday, the committee agreed that it will only make recommendations in the future. Management undertook to examine ways of increasing the supply of nurses but within existing resources, with the aim of opening the books for new patients.

Community health management will be providing the RANF and the workload monitoring committee with its suggestions for allowing a more efficient deployment of existing nursing resources and for improving the quality of the committee's recommendations. It is hoped that the suggestions will be accepted at tomorrow's meeting of the committee, and that the service will revert to normal operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I draw the attention of the Senate to a tribute paid to the late Senator Alan Missen on Tuesday, 22 April 1986, in the Canadian Senate by Senator the Hon. John M. Godfrey, Chairman of the Canadian Parliamentary Joint Committee on Regulations and Other Statutory Instruments. I will not read the tribute in its entirety but the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances this morning thought it fitting that I should draw it to the attention of honourable senators. Part of Senator Godfrey's statement was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators, news of the death on March 29 of a senator of the Commonwealth of Australia, Alan Missen, reached me on Friday. I rise to pay him tribute.

Honourable senators may well ask: What had this Australian senator to do with us? The answer, honourable senators, is that he had much to do with the successful establishment of the review of delegated legislation in this Parliament and throughout the Commonwealth. It is fitting that he be remembered here.

Senator Missen was one of a long line of forceful, independent chairmen of the Australian Senate's Regulations and Ordinances Committee, the counterpart of our Joint Committee on Regulations and Other Statutory Instruments. He was a member of the committee from 1974, and chairman in the years 1978 to 1980. The Australian Senate, armed with a statutory power of disallowance over delegated legislation, is the most effective chamber in the Commonwealth in preventing executive abuse of delegated powers. Together, the Australian Senate and its committee are Commonwealth pathfinders in the Parliamentary control of executive actions under delegated authority. Senator Missen should be remembered in Canada primarily for his personal contribution to the establishing of effective parliamentary scrutiny of delegated legislation in this Parliament, and for his bringing together of all those involved in this critical, though unsung, task throughout the Commonwealth. It was in his role as a Commonwealth elder statesman, that I first met Senator Missen and thereby came to appreciate the signal contribution he had already made to Canada, quietly and generously. I learned much from him and I admired his independence of mind.

I seek leave to have the text of the whole tribute incorporated in Hansard along with the Committee's letter of thanks to Senator Godfrey. The letter and tribute will be sent to Senator Missen's widow Mollie.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
CANADA
THE SENATE
Tuesday, April 22, 1986
The Senate met at 2 p.m., the Speaker in the Chair.
Prayers.
COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
THE LATE SENATOR ALAN MISSEN-
TRIBUTE
Hon. John M. Godfrey: Honourable senators, news of the death on March 29 of a senator of the Commonwealth of Australia, Alan Missen, reached me on Friday. I rise to pay him tribute.

Honourable senators may well ask: What had this Australian senator to do with us? The answer, honourable senators, is that he had much to do with the successful establishment of the review of delegated legislation in this Parliament and throughout the Commonwealth. It is fitting that he be remembered here.

Senator Missen was one of a long line of forceful, independent chairmen of the Australian Senate's Regulations and Ordinances Committee, the counterpart of our Joint Committee on Regulations and other Statutory Instruments. He was a member of the committee from 1974, and chairman in the years 1978 to 1980. The Australian Senate, armed with a statutory power of disallowance over delegated legislation, is the most effective chamber in the Commonwealth in preventing executive abuse of delegated powers. Together, the Australian Senate and its committee are Commonwealth pathfinders in the parliamentary control of executive actions under delegated authority. Senator Missen should be remembered here primarily for his personal contribution to the establishing of effective parliamentary scrutiny of delegated legislation in this Parliament, and for his bringing together of all those involved in this critical, though unsung, task throughout the Commonwealth. It was in his role as a Commonwealth elder statesman, that I first met Senator Missen and thereby came to appreciate the signal contribution he had already made to Canada, quietly and generously. I learned much from him and I admired his independence of mind.
A Liberal senator from the State of Victoria, Alan Missen stood on the progressive wing of his party and never hesitated to vote against it when he considered it to be wrong.

In the late 1970s, the idea was floated that the parliamentary committees set up to scrutinize delegated legislation from around the Commonwealth should get together to share their experience, and to pool their knowledge, and, just as importantly, to encourage the establishment of parliamentary scrutiny where it did not exist. Senator Missen took this idea up enthusiastically and put on the brilliantly conceived and managed First Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation in Canberra in October, 1980. It was an outstanding occasion.

Out of this conference grew the Commonwealth Delegated Legislation Committee, a Secretariat, and the Commonwealth Delegated Legislation Bulletin. Senator Missen secured the funds to set up and maintain the Secretariat and to publish the Bulletin, thus ensuring that the impetus of the Canberra Conference was not lost and that its benefits were not wasted. Today, scrutiny committees in all Commonwealth jurisdictions are kept up to date with the abuses of executive power uncovered throughout the Commonwealth, and with the principles used by scrutiny committees to expose and correct those abuses. Even the failures reported in the Bulletin are instructive as revealing the pitfalls to be avoided by others.

The energy flowing from the First Commonwealth Conference was channelled by Senator Missen as Chairman of the Commonwealth Delegated Legislation Committee and led to a second conference being held in this chamber in April, 1983. Representatives of more jurisdictions attended and the event was a signal success. Again, Senator Missen played a leading role.

A further contribution of this outstanding man should be noted, honourable senators. He was very much involved in setting up the Australian Senate's Scrutiny of Bills Committee whose task is to spy out and alert the appropriate Senate committee to oppressive and unjust provisions and dangerously drawn enabling powers in bills before the Australian Senate.

The powers of this Australian Senate committee were the inspiration for my own motions to endow our own Joint Committee on Regulations and other Statutory Instruments with some of these powers. As senators will remember, after some years of fruitless effort, I was able to get the approval of the Senate for these in February last year, and I am hopeful that the House of Commons will soon concur.

Recently, the House of Commons adopted rule changes that will greatly increase the powers of the Joint Committee on Regulations and other Statutory Instruments with respect to disallowance of regulations. These together with my motions when they are concurred in will be Senator Missen's memorial amongst us.
Hon. Senators: Hear, hear.
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
THE SENATE
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
May 1986
The Honourable John M. Godfrey Q.C.
The Senate
OTTAWA Ontario KIAOA4
Dear Senator Godfrey,
At its meeting on 8 May 1986, the Committee resolved to take special note of the very fine tribute you paid in the Canadian Senate on 22 April 1986 to the late Senator Alan Missen.

As you of course know, Senator Missen was a former Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. His record of diligence, independence and bi-partisanship in pursuit of the Committee's objectives in scrutinising delegated legislation, and in advancing the cause of parliamentary control of executive power are an example to us all and will be hard to equal.

His stature in the network of Commonwealth delegated legislation committees was very clearly demonstrated by the fact that, although he was a life long back bench Senator in Australia, his untimely passing was the subject of such a sincere valediction spoken in the Canadian Senate.

The Committee asked me to write to you acknowledging your tribute to a former Chairman and encouraging you, and indeed all of our colleagues on delegated legislation committees, to keep alive and bright the vital flame of diligent bi-partisan scrutiny of subordinate laws, in the interests of parliamentary supremacy and for the protection of personal rights and liberties.

Courageous and combative as he was in defence of parliamentary and personal freedoms, Senator Missen has shown us how to perform our task as legislative scrutineers. We have much to learn from his strength of personality and commitment to principle.
The Committee resolved that your statement should be incorporated in the Australian Senate Hansard.
With best wishes from the Committee.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Northern Territory Superannuation Arrangements

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present the report on Northern Territory superannuation arrangements, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report concludes the Committee's inquiry into the superannuation arrangements for Northern Territory Government employees. Following the granting of self-government to the Northern Territory, a joint task group was established by the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory in 1979 to make recommendations concerning Northern Territory employer superannuation contributions. This was pursuant to the Memorandum of Understanding signed at self-government. The joint task group reported in mid-1984. The then Minister for Finance, Mr John Dawkins, and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Ian Tuxworth, agreed to the arrangements proposed by the joint task group. On 4 April 1985 the Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, informed the Chief Minister that the arrangements had been reviewed. This led to our inquiry.

The Committee has considered matters raised by the Northern Territory Government, the unions and the evidence of the Minister for Finance and has come to conclusions about them. Several other issues are dealt with in our report but the central matters are as follows: The Committee does not consider that an agreement in the terms proposed by the joint task group necessarily was required. The phrase in the Memorandum of Understanding `being placed in a position' does not necessarily mean being placed in a financial position, as asserted by the Northern Territory Government. The Committee does not consider that the Dawkins-Tuxworth exchange of letters in October and November 1984 constituted a legally binding agreement.

The Committee considers that the Commonwealth Government legally could determine conditions of the type contained in the 4 April 1985 letter from the Minister for Finance, although it might have been preferable for the Minister to have discussed any changes with the Northern Territory Government prior to their implementation.

The Committee draws attention to the variation to the proposed action of the Minister for Finance revealed by him at the public hearing held on 11 September 1985 and the developments which have occurred since its public hearings. It welcomes these developments.

The Committee emphasises that there are proper mechanisms such as the Commonwealth Grants Commission available for the Northern Territory, as for the States, to claim an increase in Commonwealth grants because of changed circumstances or because of extra or special financial responsibilities, and for such a claim to be assessed taking into account the Territory's disabilities and its own taxing efforts. No doubt the cost of employer superannuation contributions will be a factor when the Grants Commission next recommends an adjustment for the Northern Territory.

The Committee's terms of reference required it to study the joint task group report and to recommend on its implementation. The report proposed effectively institutionalising, by a method involving the exchange between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory of almost identical cheques, the then existing temporary situation of the Commonwealth's paying the employer superannuation liability for Northern Territory Government employees. The Committee believes such an arrangement to be unsatisfactory and does not recommend the implementation of the report. The Committee believes that it is inappropriate for the Commonwealth to continue to shoulder the burden of employer superannuation contributions for a self-governing Territory when the Commonwealth has no control or even influence over the numbers or salary levels of the Northern Territory public servants involved. Now that the Minister for Finance has modified the terms of the new arrangements, the Committee is satisfied that the conditions applying to Northern Territory Government employees, being members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, are appropriate to the Northern Territory as a self-governing Territory which values its independence and its ability to set its own spending priorities.

I should draw attention to the fact that Senator Short and Senator Vanstone have expressed, in an addendum to the report, some reservations in about five sentences or phrases in the report. Three of those are matters of judgment or opinion, with one degree of political judgment or another. But two of the reservations relate to the conduct of the inquiry. As Chairman of the Committee, I think I need to respond to them. With regard to paragraph 3.6 of our conclusions, the comment has been made that we did not seek a legal opinion about the Dawkins-Tuxworth exchange of letters. With regard to paragraph 3.13, the comment is made that the Committee did not seek expert evidence on the report of the joint task group. I wish to point out that, during all the time that we were dealing with this matter, no member of the Committee suggested that a legal opinion should be obtained on the first matter or that expert evidence should be sought on the second matter. I do not believe that such a legal opinion is necessary; nor do I believe that expert evidence was needed on the report of the joint task group. But in any case the main point is that we have studied the joint task group report. We have had it for over a year. I have certainly studied it, although it must be said that the Committee did not as a committee debate it for a long period, if that is what was expected. The general decision of the Committee at the end of last year was to draft a report. The draft, in various versions, containing such conclusions has been around since February or March. There has been no suggestion from any member of the Committee that further evidence should have been sought about either of those matters until a few days ago. I merely point out that this inquiry was initiated by the Opposition. If the Opposition wanted that additional evidence, Opposition members on the Committee could have suggested that. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Debate resumed from 20 March, on motion by Senator Archer:
That the Senate condemns the Hawke Labor Government for-
(a) plunging the housing of Australian families into the worst position in 50 years by doctrinaire and unbalanced policies;
(b) creating and maintaining a high interest, high tax economy that makes home ownership an unattainable goal for many young Australian families;
(c) presiding over and causing a rapid decline in the availability of rental housing, causing extreme hardship to low income families in particular;
(d) creating uncertainty by not releasing after 6 months, details concerning taxation policy on investment property; and
(e) destabilising the finance market by artificial and sectoral constraints which will have long-term detrimental effects on home ownership funding.
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was last being debated, the Government was persisting with the fiction that it was possible to provide money for housing despite the fact that lending bodies were being offered rates that were simply not competitive. Since this debate started the Government has partly resolved this problem, in a belated and distressing way, by easing the maximum limit of 13.5 per cent that had applied to interest rates for savings bank loans. Of course, this will serve to increase the volume of money available for those people who can afford to borrow. But it also involves an absurd situation in that the people who already had loans through the savings bank system are protected against the impact of that increase. I am not protesting about that; what I am protesting about is that that protection extended only to people with savings bank loans and not those with loans from other bodies such as the building societies, which will now be obliged to increase the rate of interest to their depositors.

SPEECH.PARA: Coincidentally there has been a continuation of a problem that we have pointed to over a long period. We have been pointing out to the Government that its high interest rate policy has made it very difficult for home owners to be able to afford to repay the loans, let alone to obtain them.
