We have been pointing out that this high interest rate policy would inevitably have a disastrous impact on the building industry. Of course, that has taken place. It is disheartening to us that, if only the Government had acted when we first suggested, the impact would not have been nearly so serious. I suppose one can say that, if the Government had done what has been suggested about economic policy for the past 18 months or two years, there would not have been this enormous level of high interest rates, because high interest rates are the result of deliberate Government policy. The Government cannot get out of it by saying that there is a free market and it is that free market which has created these high interest rates. In fact, the Government has depended entirely on monetary policy as its only instrument in controlling the economy.

We have seen only recently that major advisers to the Government, such as the Reserve Bank, and the Governor of the Reserve Bank in particular, have criticised strongly the Government's heavy dependence on a high interest rate policy. The Governor of the Reserve Bank only last week made a speech in which he outlined the serious consequences for growth-and, as a result, employment-of maintaining this high interest rate policy as the only weapon of Government economic policy, or at least carrying the brunt of Government economic policy. He said that it would result in interest rates which were higher than he would prefer to see and that this would also be a consequence of the Government's attitude in relation to the balance of payments current account. I have to say `current account', even though everyone knows what the balance of payments problem is, because Senator Walsh is in one of his fastidious moods at the moment and requires it to be called `the balance of payments current account'. As a result of the Government's deliberate high interest rate policy we have seen this extraordinary reduction in housing activity, which the Government now says belatedly that it will try to do something about. It will be solving a problem that it has created itself.

Let me outline how big the problem is. There was a substantial decline in housing activity in the second half of 1985 after two years of recovery. New housing starts declined in the September quarter by one per cent and in the December quarter by 5.3 per cent. The forward indicators of activity in the housing sector suggest that there will be a further decline in activity all through this year. Already we have seen that local government building approvals declined by 26 per cent-over a quarter-between August last year and March this year. The March figure is the lowest monthly level for three years. Housing loans by the major lending institutions declined for the seventh consecutive month in February 1986 to a level about 31 per cent lower than in July 1985.

These forward indications of activity this year cannot and will not suddenly be reversed by the Government's belated action in the area of releasing interest rate controls over one part of the housing lending market. Of course, a change in the major thrust of the Government's economic policy is required. Some more regulation of its own activities and less regulation of the activities of the commercial areas is needed. The Government needs to cut its own spending so that there will be greater reliance on fiscal policy than on monetary policy. Of course, we will not get that because we have already seen from the leaked Government document that the Forward Estimates figure is $6.4 billion. The demand by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that $1.4 billion be cut off Government spending in prospect for next year is being stoutly resisted by all the spending Ministers involved. So our chances of getting a Government deficit of around $5 billion, which is still far too high, are very slight indeed unless something dramatic happens after the upcoming biennial Australian Labor Party Conference. Obviously nothing will be done before then in case the rank and file try to take control of their own Party. The real policies of the Labor Party bear little relationship to the policies being pursued or attempting to be pursued by Messrs Hawke and Keating.

The Government's own advisory body, the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry, has confirmed that a downturn is under way, and industry and forecasting groups such as the Housing Industry Association, the Master Builders Federation of Australia and BIS- Shrapnel Pty Ltd have also forecast a downturn. As a result of this Government's deliberate and determined policy and activities the housing industry has been forced back into a boom-bust cycle, with all that means for cost additions, uncertainty of employment, and disappointment and natural resentment from those people, particularly young people, who seek to be able to buy a home. The impact on all those industries, as a result of this boom-bust approach that the Government appears to favour in the housing industry, is one that we were told would not take place. This Government was going to be a rational, new, exciting, dynamic government that knew what it was doing. I do not know that a 26 per cent fall in building approvals between August and March gives any indication of a government that knows what it is doing. I do not think that getting the lowest monthly level of approvals for three years is any indication of a government that knows what it is doing. If the Government knows what it should be doing and has deliberately decided not to do it, it is culpable; so in this area it faces the charge of either culpability or incompetence.

There is no doubt that these high interest rate policies have reduced the supply of cheap housing funds and have put housing finance beyond the means of many Australians. To make matters worse, the Government's tax policies, including the abolition of negative gearing provisions and a capital gains tax, have reduced investment in residential properties. Let us get this very clear indeed. Because of the tax situation that had existed, it was worth while for people to build homes and units for letting purposes at rents that were far below the sort of return that could be got by putting money into Commonwealth bonds. So most people would not have got anything like a 14 per cent return by building a flat or a house and letting it to someone, particularly to people in lower income groups who cannot afford to buy their own homes.

We had a situation where there was an incentive for people to build homes and units, even though they were going to get a return of only 6 per cent in rental terms from that investment. That was because, if or when they ultimately sold that property, they would be entitled to gain a tax-free return. In other words, they would get the total benefit of selling that property, if or when they chose to do so, which would make up for the fact that they were getting such a low return from the rent. The taxation situation created an environment in which rents were generally able to be far lower than would otherwise have applied and, in a sense, provided provided a degree of subsidy to people who wanted to rent. One may say that that is ridiculous-why would people want to do that; why not do it directly?

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that many people were looking at the total rate of return when they ultimately came to sell the property and therefore were prepared to take a lower than economic rent. The fact is that they were providing a competitive market, so that even those property owners who did not intend to sell their properties-the people who would not be looking to get an ultimate return of that nature-nonetheless had to compete, as owners of rental properties, with the other owners who were looking at a total rate of return, including the tax-free capital gain, when they ultimately sold their properties. So, in a sense, the market price for rents was created by what could well have been a small minority-who knows what size the minority was-of people who owned properties and nonetheless rented them out. As a result of this system, the people who rented in Australia received a far better deal; they ended up paying rents worth something like 6 per cent on average of the value of the property instead of having to pay a rate of something like 14 per cent, which would have been needed to provide an adequate and equal return to the owner of that property if that owner had decided, instead of building a property, to put the money into Commonwealth bonds.

By changing the tax arrangements now the Government will ensure either that there will be massively higher rents-because of these negative gearing and capital gains tax arrangements-or that people will cease to build properties for rent. That, in itself, will have an impact on pushing rents up for those properties which do exist. There will be a scarcity, and when there is a scarcity the market price will naturally rise. The Government has, through its tax package, increased the cost of rents. We must recognise that the great bulk of people renting properties are those who do not have the resources to buy them. This particularly applies to young married couples and those in the society who have at some stage suffered financially or have not been able to accumulate the amount of money necessary to build a house. We have had government policy directly putting up the price of buying homes in the first place, because of the huge interest cost, and then putting up the price of renting homes because of the change in the taxation arrangements.

At the time of the last election, home loan interest rates were 11.5 per cent. They are now 15.5 per cent from a government which said that it would reduce interest rates. The monthly repayments on a 25-year $50,000 home loan are now $150 a month higher than they were 18 months ago. This is just overwhelming and disastrous for those people who have been struggling to save in order to buy a home. Is it any wonder that we have had this 26 per cent fall in building approvals between August last year and March this year? It is no wonder at all. People simply cannot afford it any more.

I made the point that the rental market will no doubt tighten, with housing rents increasing as new home construction falls. Many Australians will be forced into the rental market. Not only will there be a reduction in the volume of properties available for rent, but also more and more Australians who cannot afford to buy homes, because of this Government's high interest rate policy and the other matters of which I have spoken, will be forced into the rental market. Already, the Real Estate Institute of Australia has shown that there is a very low and declining level of vacancies. Already we have seen the market being squeezed. Private housing rents have risen by 10.1 per cent over the past year. That is above the consumer price index increase of 9.2 per cent. Increases in some cities, particularly in Sydney but also as I understand it in Perth, have been far greater than this. So we have a situation in which rents are already going up faster than the CPI. As the Government's taxation policies bite more deeply we will see a massive increase in rents relative to the overall increase in the CPI. That is bad enough because that affects those people who are in the earlier period of their lives and struggling to find somewhere to live.

On the other hand, what about the impact on the building industry? Increased unemployment in both the housing industry and related industries-including building supplies, household goods, real estate and finance-obviously are in line. Employment in the construction industry has already fallen over the year to February after strong growth in the previous year. Reduced investment in private housing will increase demands on public housing, leading to further lengthening in already long waiting lists. It is all very well for us to hear, at Question Time, a Minister in this place talking about the increased contribution to public housing. There will be a far greater increase in the demand for public housing as a result of this Government's belting of the private sector, of the ordinary people trying to get their own homes. Naturally, there will be an enormous increase in the demand for public housing. The attempts the Government is making now to cope with an increased demand for public housing will, of course, be totally inadequate to meet the enormously increased demand for public housing that it, by its own actions, will have generated.

The housing package that the Government announced on 2 April, after this debate originally started, was a clear acknowledgment of the crisis situation facing the housing industry and the need for government action. As I have mentioned, this package included the removal of the 13.5 per cent ceiling on home loan mortgage interest rates for new bank loans after that date, but the ceiling is to be maintained on existing home loans. There is enormous disagreement about what will be the impact lifting the ceiling on new home loans. The Government claims that the package will ensure that savings banks lend $6 billion for housing in 1986-87, which it says is sufficient to raise the level of housing starts to 135,000. That is up from the 100,000 starts or fewer that the Government claims would have occurred without its intervention. In other words, if the Government had not moved to fix up the total chaotic mess that it created in the housing industry there would have been only about 100,000 housing starts, according to the Government. The Government is picking it up, it says, as a result of this package, by 35,000. I think we should remember the enormity of this admission by the Government that its own incompetence was going to push housing starts down to 100,000. It now says that housing starts will go up to 135,000 because of these new arrangements.

As building societies will not receive any government subsidy they will be relatively disadvantaged compared to savings banks under the new arrangements. Any increase in loans by the savings banks is, therefore, likely to be partially offset by reduced lending by the building societies. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), and the Chairman of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry, Professor Gruen, have both conceded that the achievement of the 135,000 figure is crucially dependent on sustained falls in interest rates through the next year or so, and that without such falls the number of housing starts will be considerably fewer. I must say, I do not expect any Minister in this Government to make any more promises about falling interest rates because their prospect of success is in inverse proportion of the vehemence of assertion. The more the Government has said in the past that interest rates will fall, the worse the rise has been.

I am unnerved that the Government seems to be operating on an assumption that there will be a fall in interest rates and that the target of 135,000 cannot be achieved unless interest rates fall through the next year or so. Homeseekers who are depending on getting a home would be very unwise, it would seem to me, to build up their hopes too much on being rescued by this Government's gesture in this area if the Government depends so heavily on interest rates falling. So the 135,000 figure is, therefore, very optimistic indeed. The industry estimates put the likely figure at between 120,000 and 135,000 starts. Of course, even if 135,000 new housing starts are achieved, it will be below the Indicative Planning Council estimate of underlying demand for housing of 147,000; so there is no doubt that the Government will not, even if it is successful, reach the level of underlying demand. I state again that the basic reason for that is that the Government has relied far too heavily on a high interest rate policy.

The interesting thing is that there remains conflict over the Government's precise requirements of the savings banks before it passes over the interest rate subsidy. There has been a fair amount of disagreement on that score which I have not got time to go into at this stage. But the Budget implications of the housing package are also interesting because the cost to the Government Budget of the housing package in the coming financial year could be as high as $150m, although it is difficult to estimate. This is primarily accounted for by the interest rate subsidy because, depending on financial developments, the sum could be considerably less if the final subsidy instalments are not required; in other words, if interest rates fall. This additional outlay will further aggravate an already difficult Budget process. The required expenditure cuts necessary to achieve the trilogy constraints-if anyone seriously believes in the trilogy any more-by sufficiently tightening fiscal policy to allow an easing of monetary policy, are now greater because of the housing package.

We have the irony that the housing package, which depends for its success on getting interest rates down, will itself be a factor in pushing interest rates up because this will increase the Government's deficit and, therefore, its demands on the market for money. The additional cost of the housing package, taken together with the rural package, the oil refiners compensation package and the decision not to have a May mini-Budget this year, casts great doubt on the Government's ability to deliver a credible Budget this year. In contrast to this, the Opposition's approach to housing, I believe, is eminently sensible. The high level of interest rates remains the fundamental problem for the housing industry and this can be corrected only through a more balanced economic strategy. The Opposition says that it has that strategy.

Further wage discounting for the effects of the depreciation of the consumer price index are required. The 3 per cent productivity increase should be delayed for at least a year. The Government should make a major economic statement detailing significant expenditure cuts to take effect from 1 July. The decision to abolish negative gearing provisions and to introduce a capital gains tax should be reversed. This will revive investment in dwellings, particularly multi-unit dwellings such as town houses, units and flats. If such action were taken there would be no need for the band-aid measures contained in the Government's housing package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a motion moved some time ago by Senator Archer dealing with the problems of housing in Australia. Housing, of course, is the most fundamental need and the biggest single investment most Australians will make during their lifetime. When looking at housing we have to look at four different aspects of it. We cannot look at a single problem. There is the question of the costs of new loans to acquire housing; there is the question of what happens to people who have existing loans, what happens about welfare housing and, finally, the availability of rental accommodation. We have to keep all these problems in mind whenever we look at the problems of housing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer's motion contained five points which I will go through in turn. The first point was that the Hawke Government should be condemned for plunging the housing of Australian families into the worst position in 50 years by doctrinaire and unbalanced policies. Certainly we were heading for a crisis in accommodation and in housing loans. The number of new building approvals fell by 9.7 per cent in the three months to February to be 13.9 per cent below the level of a year earlier. The number of new dwelling finance approvals fell by 17 per cent in the three months to February to be 23 per cent below the level of a year before.

This country needs about 135,000 new houses a year to meet its needs. Under the Government's policies, before the abrupt and most peculiar change I will come to in a moment, we were heading for a production of under 100,000 which would have created not only a real housing crisis but also a crisis right throughout the housing construction industry and for the people who make facilities for houses and equipment for houses. It would have had major economic repercussions. There is no doubt at all that it was the policies of the Hawke Labor Government that created these problems.

The main reason it created these problems is the second leg of Senator Archer's motion-that the Hawke Labor Government should be condemned for creating and maintaining a high interest, high tax economy that makes home ownership an unattainable goal for many young Australian families. We have to look at what is happening to the Australian economy. People do not yet seem to have grasped the seriousness of what is going on in the Australian economy. All too many people think if they have a job: `Things seem to be going fairly well for me, I have a job. The economy seems to be all right as far as I am concerned'. What they do not grasp is that we are borrowing $1,000m a month to support our current standard of living. No country can go on doing that. It is South American-style finance. The net overseas debt has doubled in the three years since the Hawke Government came to power. It is an impending financial catastrophe and this Government just does not seem to have grasped the problem. Those members of the Government who have grasped it are trying to wish it away in some peculiar way.

Look at what has happened to our balance of payments. The current account deficit in February was $979m. In March it was $1,023m. It has gone up substantially from the year before. We keep on hearing about the J curve. I am glad that Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, has some sensible views about the absurdity of the J curve. Nevertheless, we keep on hearing from the Treasurer, Mr Keating, how the J curve will solve all our problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has become an L curve.

—It has become an L curve. I think he needs `L' plates. Certainly he is not up to `P' plates yet. The J curve, after we devalued and had an inflow of imports for a while, was supposed to worsen our current account deficit, then with our exports becoming more competitive and with us exporting more, we were suddenly supposed to become more competitive an go up on the long stroke of the J curve. That just has not happened. It has not happened because of other aspects of government policy. One would think that a country that was borrowing $1,000m a month for its current standard of living would at least try to keep its costs down in order to make itself competitive so it could get more exports. No one in this world owes us a living. If we are going to export on world trade markets we have to be competitive. But what are we doing? We are giving ourselves three pay rises this year. One is going on now, about 2.4 per cent, then probably in the middle of the year there will be a totally phoney 3 per cent productivity bonus and there will be another pay rise, probably 4 per cent or more, at the end of the year. This is economic insanity.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only repeat over and over again that a country which borrows $1,000m a month-and has to do so because it is not competitive on world markets-and which continues to grant itself pay rises loses its competitiveness on world markets. We have enough problems being competitive as it is with our problems of shipping and the waterfront, quite apart from pricing ourselves out of world markets by absurd wages policies. This Government is showing no sign whatever of even remotely grasping that this is the core problem of what is going on.

The Government reminds me irresistibly of the attitude of the Neville Chamberlain Conservative Government in Britain when faced with the rise of Hitler. It pretended the situation was not serious. It believed it could negotiate the problem away. It even went to Munich and got `peace in our time'-an accord with Hitler. I think our so-called accord should have been drafted in Munich. What this Government is doing is a catastrophe. It is causing great harm to the Australian economy and great harm to future generations of Australians. In this particular context we have to look at its effect on housing because our interest rates are very high indeed. Interest rates are high because the Government has to keep them high in order to prop up the dollar because the dollar still is set, despite the agreement in Tokyo, freely on international markets. World assessment of our performance is reflected in the value of our dollar, which has gone down by 30 per cent since the Hawke Government came to power. That is a 30 per cent decline in the way the world views the Australian economy since the Hawke Government came to power. That 30 per cent decline is only against the US dollar, which has itself declined by about 25 per cent against currencies such as the German Deutsche mark and the Japanese yen. We are viewed by world markets and world financiers as a very poor risk indeed. We have to examine ourselves and see why this is so.

The Government has to try to prop up the dollar because it cannot let the dollar sink forever-for the very simple reason that we already have an overseas debt of $70 billion and every time our dollar declines or depreciates further the cost in Australian dollars of servicing international debts goes up. Instead of propping it up by improved performance, by organised work, by holding our wages to reasonable levels and not granting ourselves pay rises that we have not earned. The Government is trying to do this by holding interest rates at a high level. The effect of these high interest rates spins off into housing. Let us look at comparative figures for prime interest rates. At the moment, our interest rate is just under 18 per cent. In Japan it is 6.9 per cent; West Germany, 9.1 per cent; France, 10.6 per cent; the United Kingdom, 12.5 per cent; and the US, 9.5 per cent; and Australia, 18 per cent. That is done, as I said, to prop up the dollar rather than tackle the fundamental problems of the economy. The effect spins off into housing. The reason that our housing interest rates are so high is that that is an inevitable consequence of this Government's policies. The third leg of Senator Archer's motion was that the Hawke Government should be condemned for:
. . . presiding over and causing a rapid decline in the availability of rental housing, causing extreme hardship to low income families in particular.

The Hawke Government has caused this in two ways; in a third way the State Labor governments are making the situation even worse. We will not have rental housing unless people are prepared to provide it-unless they regard it as a reasonable investment. The Hawke Labor Government's proposed capital gains tax is a direct disincentive for people to invest in rental housing. Even worse is the elimination of negative gearing, whereby if a person made a loss on acquiring and renting property, he could offset that against other income. That has been stopped and that is another very strong disincentive for investment in rental property. As night follows day, it is an inevitable result that there will be a rapidly increasing scarcity of rental accommodation. That situation will be made even worse by new tenancy laws. This is not universal. Wherever there are Labor governments there seem to be attempts to make the provision of rental accommodation as difficult, as dangerous, as unpleasant and as unworkable an investment as possible.

A new tenancy Bill going through the Victorian State Parliament will make it extremely unattractive to invest in rental property. The consequence will be a drying up of the availability of rental property and people will be paying higher rents. Once there is a scarcity demand will push up rents. All this is being done in the name of socialist equality. As with all the Government's proposals, this looks superficially attractive but in the long run it will be disastrous.
I have to admit that the fourth leg of Senator Archer's motion is now out of date. The Government has actually done something. Senator Archer said that the Hawke Government should be condemned for:
. . . creating uncertainty by not releasing after 6 months, details concerning taxation policy on investment property.

At last something has been done-but after an inordinate delay. It is disgraceful the way that this Government announces policies that will have very severe effects on investment and confidence and then leaves it for months, in some cases years, before the Government makes it clear exactly what the legislation is. It is gross incompetence to announce a policy and not to introduce detailed legislation promptly after announcing the policy. This Government is guilty of that type of slack administration over and over again. At least in this area it has now announced details of its policy eight months after it announced its broad intention.
The final leg of Senator Archer's motion was that the Hawke Labor Government should be condemned for:
. . . destabilising the finance market by artificial and sectoral constraints which will have long-term detrimental effects on home ownership funding.

The Government was faced with the problem that the number of houses being built in Australia would fall to under 100,000 because of very high interest rates and the Government, as a consequence of its policies, had to do something. It could not tackle fundamentals so it subsidised the savings banks to the tune of $120m, with a further $25m being set aside, provided the banks kept interest rates on existing housing loans pegged at 13.5 per cent, well below the market level. For new mortgage loans the sky is the limit; there are no controls. Savings bank loans are currently in the rage of 14.7 to 15.5 per cent, about the same as building society loans. Why did the Government do this? The Government declared that economic circumstances-for which we should read `Hawke Government economic mismanagement'-forced it to take this step because there was a very real risk that housing commencements would fall below 100,000. Housing construction is a significant part of our gross domestic product-about 0.3 per cent-and is also a very important means of employment.

The four major savings banks tried to get a deal of $180m to hold the lending rate on existing loans to 13.5 per cent. The Government showed at least some sense and refused that and reduced it to $120m on the basis that the savings banks continued to lend for new housing at $6 billion a year. That agreement has a life of one year and is reviewable quarterly. There are a few questions I want to ask about that. First, savings banks provide about 50 per cent of housing loan finance. Building societies provide about 29 per cent. I should admit to the Senate before I go any further that I am a director of a building society but I have no financial interest in any of these matters. However, it gives me an insight into some of the problems. I inform the Senate of the basis for some of my remarks.

The Government has given the subsidy to one group of people with housing loans, those who have a mortgage with a savings bank. Why does this apply just to savings banks? On the whole, building societies have been dealing with younger and less affluent groups in the community than have savings banks. Why does the Government do this deal with savings banks and not deal with other groups of lending? Surely it is just as important that their mortgage rates be kept down. Why is the Government advantaging people who borrow from a savings bank and disadvantaging those who borrow from a building society, a trading bank or another organisation? There is absolutely no rationale for this. If it is a matter of efficiency; I point out that a very detailed analysis has shown that as providers of home finance building societies are markedly more efficient than are savings banks. What we have to look at with an organisation like that is the difference between the average cost of its funds and the average return it gets from mortgage and other investments. Savings banks work on a margin of about 4 per cent. Building societies generally-of course, in each case there are variations-work on an average difference of about 2.8 per cent. The building societies are quite significantly more efficient. One of the reasons for this, of course, is that the savings banks are locked into a very archaic and old-fashioned form of branch structure. They are locked into some staff practices which are very inefficient. Nevertheless, as far as we should look at who should be helped, I would have thought that we should help the efficient rather than the less efficient.

The Government is being completely irrational in what it is doing. If it wishes to try to help people who have existing loans one can see the argument for that. People enter into a major investment and, because of absurd government policies, interest rates go through the roof. It is very unfair for people who have their major savings tied up in housing investment. If we do not hold down interest rates, of course, people might have to sell their houses and pay out their mortgages. However this measure should surely apply to all people who have housing loans, not a particular group. Half of these people happen to have loans from savings banks. Finally, of course, the problem the Government is causing is that the rate for new housing loans will be over 15 per cent. It is probable that, because of the increased competition the savings banks can now provide for the pool of investment money, building society rates will also have to go up. Unless there is a subsidy from the Government-there is no sign of there being one-the building society rates will apply not only to new borrowers but also to people with existing mortgages.

What we have from this Government is a thoroughly muddled economic policy which is having consequences right through the economy. The consequence that hits home most to the Australian public, I suppose, is the effect on their mortgage payments. People can see immediately what damage the Government is doing to the economy. But that is only a symptom. The cause of the problem is the Government's unwillingness to recognise the economic situation we are in, its unwillingness to recognise that no other country owes us a living. If we want to be competitive on world markets-if we are to maintain our standard of living-we must take strong and decisive steps to improve the efficiency of the economy, improve our work practices, and improve our export performance. Without that, the high interest rate on housing loans under the Hawke Labor Government is only a beginning. Where it will end I do not know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to close the debate on this motion, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Hawke Labor Government for-
(a) plunging the housing of Australian families into the worst position in 50 years by doctrinaire and unbalanced policies;
(b) creating and maintaining high interest, high tax economy that makes home ownership an attainable goal for many young Australian families;
(c) presiding over and causing a rapid decline in the availability of rental housing, causing extreme hardship to low income families in particular;
(d) creating uncertainty by not releasing after 6 months, details concerning taxation policy on investment property; and
(e) destabilising the finance market by artificial and sectoral constraints which will have long-term detrimental effects on home ownership funding.

Several honourable senators have spoken in this debate. Debate started towards the end of March and we are now closing it on 8 May. It is interesting to see what has happened during that period. The debate has highlighted the housing situation. The date on which the debate commenced-20 March-seems years away now because of the changes that have occurred. That was the stage when we were getting promises from everybody, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and various members of the Australian Labor Party through to the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) and others, that there would be no increase to the interest rate limit of 13.5 per cent. That promise was made by various people on numerous occasions. I was never of the opinion that that 13.5 per cent was a magical figure but I always believed that while there was uncertainty about housing funds it would be very difficult to make decisions on housing in the market-place.

In that period the State Council of the Queensland Labor Party attacked the Government very strongly and Mr Wran attacked the Government very strongly about its intervention when that was not what he had in mind. We then had the building societies and their problems and we had the bank handout. Frankly, as we were saying in the debate in March, those were not the real problems. The problems were that the costs were too high, there was economic uncertainty, and monthly mortgage repayments were getting to the stage where people were unable to meet them. All those points still remain. Nothing that has happened since then has made this any different. Ultimately, the Government decided that it had to listen to some of the advice that was being tendered and some of the complaints that were being made and have a better look at where it stood on the housing question. All that happened as a result is that, instead of housing problems being created by one lot of artificial situations, they have now been replaced with a few more artificial situations. One problem has been replaced by another. I noticed in the Melbourne Age of 4 April a headline `Home loan moves end of great Australian dream'. That was after we had decided what was going to happen. That was after the Government had decided that changes needed to be made, certainly not before.

Going back to about September last year, various members of the Opposition-the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), myself and others-were raising the question of the problems of the housing industry, the inevitability of a major decline in building, a great fall-off in home ownership, and considerable losses of tradesmen in various aspects of the industry, flowing through to the supply industries as well. We waited so long that the crunch came and the decline was in full flight before anything was done. It was another of those cases, like the case of Mr Justice Murphy, where the Government held off. We went past the stage where it may have been possible to get some remedies going had action been taken at the right time. When action had been taken Professor Gruen, Chairman of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry said: `It has been done but I still have grave doubts that it is likely to make the housing position what we would like it to be. We do not think that, even with these band-aids, we will be able to restore the figures we have been promised'.

The 135,000 new houses certainly will not be achieved for a variety of reasons. I am one of those who says that 135,000 houses is an artificial figure in the first place. I do not believe that there is a market for that number anyway. The history of the last five or six years confirms that in relatively good housing years the average has been only about 129,000. So to talk about getting that figure up to 135,000 in difficult times, whether or not money is available, is really not on. We are now in the position where this $6 billion has been guaranteed by the banks. I believe the problem that will show up in the housing industry is that there will not be a demand for $6 billion from the banks. They have been put over a barrel and have had to promise to lend this amount of money, but I do not think it will be required. I will be very interested to find out what will happen if, because of lack of demand, they are unable to fulfil the stand-over promise as to the benefits that will flow as a result.

I think the house building market will be slack. I believe that the imported commodities that are going into houses are starting to get terribly expensive. Anyway, we have lost so many tradesmen to other areas that it would now be very difficult to get together a proper work force. It has always been the same: Whenever there is a severe downturn in the housing industry people leave and very seldom come back. We train a lot of tradesmen in a variety of trades. They stay until they finish their apprenticeship and they stay while the market is quite active, but if they have to leave because of an economic problem they very seldom come back.

In the rental market the situation is probably even worse. The great bulk of rental housing in many towns and cities in Australia is owned by people who do not really want to be rental home owners. They own property only because it has happened more or less accidentally or incidentally. A lot of people own a spare house that they have had left to them. They may own a house that they purchased for the use of an aged parent or student children. They may have owned a house and built a new one but retained the old one and decided to let it. There are other things that they could do with their money. It is not a matter of rental housing being a top investment. A lot of people like to feel that they own a little property.

This Government has traditionally been anti-landlord. There has always been a stigma attached to owning a rental property. This fails to acknowledge the great number of people who depend on being able to rent reasonably priced accommodation in the private market in a reasonable location. Government housing will never be able to fill the needs of the rental market. The Government should provide housing for those who are unable to get it otherwise-people who are in a critical situation, people who are unable to afford housing in the private market, or people who have special reasons for needing such accommodation. It will never be possible for the Government to fill the need. It will always require the private sector very largely to fill the gap. In the course of my business before I became a senator I handled a lot of rental property. I know how important it is and how much the market depends on it.

Of the rental stock around Australia, thousands of units have been sold off in the last six months. Even more have been sold off in the last, say, 18 months as the returns on capital invested in other areas have been much greater. It has become apparent that, due to various other disincentives, people are shedding rental properties that they do not need to own and are putting their money into management trusts, stocks and shares, and other areas. That too has taken away a lot of potential new housing sales for the next year or so, and this trend will certainly continue. More and more people are now finding out the undesirability of a house investment as against other investments. As the opportunity arises to do so, people will be selling off. Many of these houses will be available at prices that are considerably lower than new house prices. With the very high cost of interest and repayments it will suit more and more people to take advantage of being able to buy lower priced houses. What will the Government do about that? I do not expect it to replace this loss with Government housing because it is just not possible. Of course, this has not stopped the Government from bringing in various changes to the taxation system which are definitely and specifically against the rental housing market.

The March figures have just been confirmed. On 20 March I predicted that the figures for March would be even lower than they were last year and, as I understand it, this is the case. The figures are now down by about 60 per cent on last year's figures. This is a very severe drop. It will take a tremendous amount of work to get this figure back to a reasonable level.

I feel sorry for the Indicative Planning Council because one of the disadvantages it has had is that it is instructed as to the method it is to use in its projections. For instance, it must use the information on economic circumstances that is provided by the government of the day. If the government of the day gives the Indicative Planning Council a list of incorrect instructions, it is very hard for it to come up with figures that are right. I am not criticising this Government; I am criticising the system. We should not appoint a body of the nature and weight of the Indicative Planning Council and then tell it what information we want it to base its base projections on. I would like us to look at freeing it up, giving it an opportunity to be a part of the development process, enabling it to give us, much earlier than in the past, figures on what it sees will happen, instead of giving it the parameters that it has had recently based on productivity, inflation rates, the value of the dollar and various other things, all of which have turned out to be at variance with the facts.

The next problem we have is that, because of high interest rates and the increasing bureaucracy at local, State and Federal levels, the price of land is continuing to go up. The cost at that end also of getting into a house now is more difficult. One only has to look at the figures which are now the norm in Canberra to see that that is so. At the end of last month the mean average price of houses sold was of the order of $100,000. That is not the sort of price that any new home buyer could possibly contemplate when we are talking of interest rates which may be as low as 13 1/2 per cent for some of the money but may be as high as 18 or 19 per cent for the majority of the money.

Newspapers have given a lot of coverage to the problems of the housing industry since the debate started on 20 March. I hope that the Government is looking very carefully at this matter. Mr West has not made any comment on the problems that have developed since the changes were made and he has given no indication of what those changes may do to improve the situation. Frankly, I do not think that the changes that were made will result in any improvement. I certainly do not go along with the problems that were created by interfering with the differences between the banks and the building societies. There are much cleaner ways of doing it. To now shuffle what happens in the race for investment funds will not help the situation at all. The only thing that has happened since the matter was debated on 20 March is that the tax package has now been brought down. We now have the details of negative gearing propositions; we can now take into account the anti-housing bias that this provides. People will be less likely than ever to invest in new housing for rental. As a result of the Government's having achieved that, one can be sure that it is only the tip of the iceberg and that in the longer term the Government will proceed in an anti-housing direction.

We have the problem of inflation and Australia is far against the world trend. People who are trying to build new houses are finding costs getting greater and greater. A great deal of imported material is used by the housing industry and this is making the job more difficult. The Government must face up to the problem. It must decide not only whether it wants to see more people in better housing but also what it intends to do to maintain the levels of employment allied with the various factors related to the provision of new housing. Housing is absolutely fundamental-it is the most fundamental thing in our society. Nothing is more essential than a proper, regular housing industry. Its continuity is essential, but housing has always suffered from the ups and downs of government policy. There has always been a tendency for governments either to slap some money into housing to try to build up the economy in a hurry or to take it out, to cool it down, and then the industry is unable to cope with such variations in the way they are inflicted.

The Government must even out the housing market and introduce some predictability. In the last year or two we have seen a considerable loss of housing funds. We have also a loss of tradesmen and suppliers. I refer to items such as furnishings even down to gardening equipment, instant lawn or anything else-curtains, furniture and many other industries are being affected by the sudden downturn. This will flow back through other industries and will produce a long list of bankruptcies and financial difficulties. I raised this matter in March because it was serious; it was serious then and is more serious now. The problems are very clear and we fully understand them. The industry requires predictability the whole way through. I thank honourable senators who have participated in the debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Senator Boswell:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Conciliation and Arbitration (Amendment) Bill 1986 which seeks to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 in relation to industrial matters, I commend Senator Boswell for providing a vehicle that will serve yet again to highlight the concern of the majority of Australians about the implications of accord mark II. If anyone thinks that there are not real concerns, I would refer him to the gallup poll survey in the Bulletin of 6 May. It was pointed out that in regard to union-controlled superannuation 53 per cent of trade union members said that the funds should be industry based run by employers and fund members; 23 per cent said that it should be company based jointly; and 10 per cent said that it should be industry based run by trade unions. Among non-unionists 41 per cent said that the funds should be industry based run by employers and fund members; 29 per cent said company based; 4 per cent said it should be industry based run by trade unions; and 26 per cent could not say.

SPEECH.PARA: The important aspect of it was that fewer than one in 12 Australians believe that superannuation funds should be run or controlled by trade unions. Accord mark II is a well-contrived and devious agreement between this government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions to hand over economic control of Australia to the ACTU. It is well recognised that the ACTU has political control of the Government and is now in the business of handing over economic control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get some facts if you want to put out this nonsense.

—The honourable senator asks for facts. An interesting insight emerges from a paper by Brue Hartnett, who was with the ACTU at the time. He delivered it to the Australian Labor Party Special National Conference in 1981. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of issues raised by the extension of union involvement in superannuation schemes. Ultimately these questions include an examination of the investment strategies of those funds and their implication for industrial relations employment and structural changes in the economy. What we must recognise at this early stage of union involvement in the superannuation issue is that the control over the funds will provide unions and governments with considerable financial leverage. That leverage will be used to advance the cause of socialism in Australia.

If there were any doubts before, now we know the real purpose of the accord mark II. The coalition is not opposed to legitimate superannuation as a means of people during their working lives providing for their own retirement. We are totally supportive of such a concept provided that there is absolute freedom of choice. Let me trace the history so far of the schemes we have seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the guidelines.

—The guidelines do not reflect what is happening in practice and I think the senator is aware of that fact. One has only to look at some of the disputations of the last few months. I think Senator Robert Ray might have been stopped from leaving Canberra airport because of a Transport Workers Union strike trying to force union members into joining the TWU superannuation scheme. Let us look at the schemes. Let me discuss briefly the basis of superannuation. As we all know, there are two types of superannuation: One is the benefit promise scheme where the pay-out at the end of the period is a multiplier of final average salary. Generally those schemes involve a degree of employer and employee contribution. There is a requirement every now and then to have an actuarial review. If the scheme is found to be actuarially unsound, it is generally up to the employer to make up the balance to get the scheme back on track.

SPEECH.PARA: The other type of scheme-this is the one referred to in the accord and is the basis of the current claim before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-is the accumulation type scheme or a contribution promise. It is understandable that that sort of scheme would be introduced for itinerant workers. In other words, funds are invested and the pay-out at the end of the period on retirement or prior death would be related to the investment performance of those funds. It is also important for itinerant workers that those sorts of schemes include portability provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't your mob bring it in?

—I will come to that. Schemes were available and there was encouragement to join them for taxation advantages. What has happened to date? We have had a plethora of union schemes which originated from the Australian Council of Trade Unions in Melbourne. Most of them have companies as trustees. Generally the office of the trustee company is care of the ACTU in Melbourne. Examples of those schemes include the building unions superannuation scheme, the Allied Unions Superannuation Trust, the Metal Union Superannuation Trust and the Transport Workers Union and Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia schemes. They all had very similar characteristics. Their trustees were companies. I will take BUSS as an example because the schemes are all much the same. They are the mirror image of one another. I believe that the architect of the schemes was Gary Weaven, who made some very interesting comments about these schemes.
—He was not the architect of all of them.
—He was not the architect?
—Not of all of them.

—Going back to the Transport Workers Union scheme, there is no doubt in my mind that one Mr R. J. Hawke was involved in that scheme. There was Bill Landeryou and, I think, Simon Crean. It has been said to me on a few occasions that they never expected the plans that were formulated back in 1972 or 1974 to reach fruition so quickly.
—It just shows their talent.

—It shows the control they have over the Government. Let me quote from comments made by Gary Weaven in Superfunds in September 1985. There are a couple of good quotations. He said that the ACTU would seek to achieve the `endorsement' of government, which it now has, the Arbitration Commission and employer organisations. Mind you, it did not seek to achieve the endorsement of employer organisations; it browbeat them into it. It is now working on the Arbitration Commission, trying to browbeat that organisation as well. Mr Weaven said that ACTU was seeking the endorsement for guidelines to include `broad criteria' as to the development of occupational superannuation schemes. Mr Weaven then went through a list of items, the last of which was `establishing union control' or, presumably in brackets, failing that, partnership in the administration and investment of funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Absolute control is the aim. It is said that the building unions superannuation scheme and Allied Unions Superannuation Trust have been dramatically successful because they were designed by the ACTU and unions for the interests of workers. What absolute garbage! Those schemes have an identical background. Representatives of the schemes went to the various insurance companies and fund managers and negotiated. There is nothing wrong with negotiation. One gets a good deal. But what they negotiated was not absolutely in the interests of the members of the schemes. In this instance a deal was negotiated whereby the company BUSS Pty Ltd would receive a management fee. I believe that the fee was a dollar a man a week. A fee is a nice word for a commission. Those people will argue-I have discussed it with them: What is the difference between their receiving the commission and paying it to someone such as a life underwriter? My argument is that doing so is absolutely wrong. They should have paid a fund manager and every cent that was available should have gone into the fund for the employees. That did not happen. They were interested in two things. The first was the size of the commission which, if extrapolated across the whole area of people not covered by superannuation, would have amounted to $3m a week going into their coffers. That would have amounted to $3 billion a year being available for investment.

These schemes were what I would term dirty schemes because they included the element of commission, which they should never have done. The ACTU is not stupid. It realised that if this practice was allowed to continue it would find itself on the rocks, so it decided to negotiate a couple of clean schemes. I call them clean schemes because their end is to control a large volume of money. I will get to why they want to do that, in a minute. The idea behind the clean schemes was: `Let us make an arrangement. We will form a company between the ACTU and one of the tame employers groups and employ an outside fund manager'. That particular scheme is called ARF-I do not know whether it is short for `Arfur' in Minder-and it is ready to go. One may ask the fund manager how sure he is that one year, two years, or three years down the track, when the scheme is in place, the ACTU or ARF will not say: `Why are we employing a fund manager?'. It is easy to sell. One says: `We can employ four or five of those characters and pay them double the amount they are getting already. We will have absolute control of those funds'. People have said that that is pretty nasty, and that what the ACTU will do is concentrate the investment of those moneys, which might run at $3 billion a year, in sensitive industrial areas and put the heat on employers to make industrial settlements. Frankly, I do not believe that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not happened yet.
—They do not have the money yet but they are lining up.
—The storemen and packers have $20m.

—Have they got $20m? They will be doing it. They are just going easy at this stage. Mind you, it has not gone through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The schemes will zero in on the key industries.
—Do not judge others by yourself.

—Just wait and see. It is not that I have not had discussions with some of the honourable senator's people about this. I will tell the honourable senator what their answer was. They will zero in on the key industries--
—For reasons of profitability.

—If profitability were the only hallmark in their decisions I do not think too many people would worry. But the rest of Australia is concerned. That is why only 7 per cent of people are prepared to trust these schemes to handle their money. As I said, they will zero in in the same way as in the case of political coups in other countries, people zero in on the media, the radio stations, television stations and newspapers.
—Take it out of the hands of the Establishment.
—That is exactly what they will do. When I have charged them with that-
—Do you mean take it away from Murdoch and Packer?

—I am delighted that Senator Robertson has agreed with me because that is exactly what I have been told-that they will do that. That is their No. 1 target. I am delighted to get that admission from Senator Robertson-
—Do not misuse what I have said. I said it would be a wonderful idea.
—The honourable senator said that it would be a wonderful idea for the trade unions, through the superannuation funds, to zero in on the radio stations, the newspapers and the television stations.
—Is that what he said?

—That is exactly what he said. I mentioned earlier Mr Gary Weaven, the same gentleman, incidentally, who recently in industrial discussions, when he was told that a certain agreement was not in keeping with the accord, said: `Don't you realise, Mr X, that we are the Government?' We in the ACTU are the Government. Haven't you woken up to that?' That is the same Mr Weaven. Mr Weaven has made the remark that BUSS and AUST were so darned successful because they were set up by the ACTU. I will tell honourable senators why they were successful. They were successful because of standover tactics, coercion, and blackmail that was no different from that employed by the Chicago Mafia. They forced employers and employees to join schemes against their will, irrespective of the fact that schemes were already in existence, irrespective of the fact that alternative schemes offered better returns to the members of that very union.

SPEECH.PARA: The last time this matter was debated here as a matter of public importance I produced 40 documented cases of standover tactics used by the people behind the BUSS scheme to force employers and employees to join the scheme. Black bans were imposed upon building premises. People were told that, if they did not get their BUSS ticket-that is the term used-they would never work in the industry again. There were examples of threats of physical abuse. That is why the BUSS and AUST schemes have got where they are.

As to competing schemes, some employers have hung out. When one investigates this one finds, oddly enough, that the union people are only too happy to talk about it. They are prepared to tell us what they are doing, what their aims are and, as confirmed by Senator Robertson, what their final aims are. Regrettably, employers will tell us that, yes, they were stood over and, yes, they were blackmailed and, yes, they were told that if they did not join a BUSS scheme they would never work again. However, in the main they were not prepared to come forward and give hard evidence because of their fear of retribution. That is something that I do not believe we can tolerate in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is provable, you are right.

—Even Senator Ray agrees with me on that. Mind you, Victoria can be a rough place too. I wish to commend Senator Boswell for providing this vehicle. The whole of Australia must realise what this is all about. It is an attempt to hand over economic control of this country to the ACTU. It will change the whole direction. The ACTU already has political control, as I have said.

SPEECH.PARA: In the coalition we believe in and strongly support occupational superannuation. The record of previous coalition governments, as well as the increase in superannuation coverage recorded over the period from 1974 to 1983, can be used to demonstrate our commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you vote for this Bill?

—I am just telling honourable senators what we believe. The coalition supports universal access to superannuation. It is in line with out self-provision principle, which was also the ground used for opposing the assets test. The coalition is committed to supporting the extension of occupational superannuation through the taxation system. We strongly support both employer and employee contributions to superannuation and will encourage those. We believe that superannuation funds should be controlled by the trustees for the benefit of the members.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition does not support the use of superannuation as a weapon to extend unionisation throughout the work force. While on that point, I mention that under the BUS and AUST schemes, the fund manager acts as the policeman for those schemes. if a person is found on site without a BUS ticket, it is reported back to the union, which promptly declares the site black. When the BUS ticket is taken out, the black ban is lifted, but more importantly, the fund manager gives the union a computer printout of every person on that site. There is no doubt that this is also a real attempt to increase the level of trade unionism in this country from 55 per cent to 100 per cent. We do not support the use of superannuation as a weapon to extend unionism throughout the work force. When we get back into power-which will not be very long, by the look of the figures-we will not tolerate the use of coercion or blackmail to advantage union funds.

We also oppose the bias in the guidelines in favour of union funds and against existing enterprise based schemes. Employers who have already taken action to cater for the retirement needs of their employees should be encouraged and not penalised. We also favour the development of a diversity of genuine superannuation schemes in a competitive climate to provide employees with a choice of which scheme best suits their needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course! That is common sense.

—If Senator Ray can assure me that the way those six funds have operated until now will change, he may have something to talk about. The way that they operate at the moment is no different from the stand over tactics used by the Mafia fellows in Chicago. They have been very successful.
—That is garbage and you know it.
—That is unbelievably bad logic from Senator Ray. He is usually pretty good at this sort of thing.
—Name me one that we have rubbed out!
—What about the Transport Workers Union? Is that the next one to be rubbed out?
—Are you saying that that is a Mafia-run organisation? Don't talk rot.
—From what it has done, it appears to be a Mafia organisation. It certainly stoops to blackmail and standover tactics to force people into superannuation schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude my remarks by again complimenting Senator Boswell for providing this vehicle to highlight again the real aim of the accord mark 2, so that the people of Australia can see that the country is being sold out to the ACTU, and to reiterate that we support superannuation and occupational superannuation but provided there is absolute freedom of choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this private member's Bill, the Conciliation and Arbitration (Amendment) Bill 1986, brought in by Senator Boswell to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 with respect to the definition of an industrial matter and to clarify and entrench it in law. By way of a opening statement I say that, as has been said earlier in the debate, the Opposition is not opposed to superannuation schemes for employees, employers or self-employed people. Indeed, we encourage people to prepare for their retirement, but we want to see the schemes properly organised and properly run so that there is safety for the contributors. Headlines in today's newspapers illustrate the concern of people for union-run schemes. When they have before them the evidence of what has happened to other businesses and industries that have been run by unions, they have a very just concern that the unions should not run superannuation schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is important. The matter is under consideration by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission at the moment, but that Commission is under some degree of coercion by the unions because--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an insult to the Commission.

—It has been threatened with serious and severe industrial action if it does not find in favour of the unions. Senator Ray should read the front pages of today's newspapers. Because the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has delayed its consideration, it has been threatened with further union action. Senator Ray is saying that this is not coercion against the Commission.
—I am saying that it would never give in to coercion.
—Then why is it being used?
—I am saying that it would never give in.

—They are hoping that it will. Initially the Government was aiding and abetting the unions in their approach to the Commission. Now the Government is most relieved that the Commission has decided to defer its decision for a little while.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is not altering the law, it is merely entrenching the law as it exists. It has no retrospective element at all. When the matter of pensions was previously put to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in the case of R v. Hamilton Knight; ex parte Commonwealth Steamship Owners' Association in 1952, it was referred to the High Court of Australia, which clearly ruled that the provision of superannuation and pension benefits was not the province of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Yet here we have the Government aiding and abetting the unions to apply to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to provide superannuation benefits. This is clearly a back-door approach to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to provide superannuation benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —You whinged like mad when you didn't get your superannuation payments.

—Senator Ray is way off track there. The Government has encouraged the unions to approach the Commission on a matter that is not its province. In fact, the unions are using the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to behave in a legislative manner. It is properly the province of this Parliament to make laws about superannuation and pensions, yet the unions want to do it through the back door, using the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
—Have you never heard of a productivity case? It is a productivity rise.

—Senator Ray calls it a productivity rise. It is 3 per cent across the board. That is an absolutely ridiculous submission. Nobody can decide which industry is having a productivity rise of 3 per cent and which is having a rise of 30 per cent. In fact, a coal industry ruckus is going on at the moment because the union is claiming a 30 per cent superannuation productivity wage rise. The unions are trying to confuse the words. I think it was Norm Gallagher who said: `Make no mistake, this is a wage rise'. Of course, it is a wage rise on which no tax will be paid.
—It is a tax rort.

—It is a tax rort. Not only that, but there is also no employee contribution; yet the unions want to call it superannuation. How can they do that? That makes it not a superannuation scheme. So the unions are playing with words, playing with the facts as they exist and going by the back door to bypass the proper role of the Parliament in getting the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to perform a legislative function because the Government is not game to do it. Senator Parer cited the examples a few minutes ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the competitiveness of Australian industry and how it will be affected should this kind of superannuation productivity bonus scheme be put under the control of the unions. Firstly, the unions would have a considerable income from the money to manage the superannuation funds. A lot of that money, it is feared-I think justifiably-could be used to fund industrial action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your evidence for that? That is a ridiculous statement.

—I am saying that that is the fear, which is very real. I have that fear, which is why I am opposed to the scheme. Not only that, but the superannuation fund would have a lot of money to invest. This would give the unions the power to invest in different industries and therefore would affect the way in which those industries are run.
—The one thing in common between the unions and you is that you both like profitability. They will not invest in non-profitable enterprises.

—That is right. The unions follow the old proverb that he who pays the piper calls the tune. All of a sudden we will have the unions running businesses. On past experience all businesses run by the unions have been failures-one hundred per cent of them. Yet Senator Ray wants people to take it on face value and to let the unions run some of the biggest businesses in Australia. That would be foolhardy and stupid, which is one of the reasons why I am opposed to it. If the unions have the money to fund industrial action, as well as investing in and taking over the running of businesses, imagine what that would do to overseas investment confidence in Australia. I cannot imagine that anyone from overseas would want to put money into the country knowing that the unions were running the whole shebang, because already Australia has a bad reputation, both as a supplier and as a deliverer on time.
—They invest in Queensland-what is the difference? They are silly enough to invest there.
—They know the right place when they see it.

—Yes. Because of all those things, we are opposed to the legislation. That is just my opening statement. I will go on to the details of what the Bill will do. The Bill clarifies the definition of an industrial matter. It states, quite simply and plainly:

SPEECH.PARA: A reference in this Act to industrial matters does not include a reference to any matter affecting or relating to superannuation or pension schemes or any provision or proposed provision which directly or indirectly provides that an employer shall contribute to a superannuation or pension scheme.

It is as simple as that. It is a three-clause Bill which maintains the existing law. There has been a query about retrospectivity, but retrospectivity applies only when a law passed today is made to apply to something in the past. Until the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has made a ruling, nothing is retrospective, so this Bill has no retrospective element at all. It is certainly not a radical move; it is entrenching the decision of the High Court of 1952 which clearly stated that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had no role to play in superannuation and pension matters.

I want to stress particularly that the Government has aided and abetted the unions to approach the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to get it to make a decision on a superannuation matter. I have already stated that that is using the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a legislative function that is properly the function of the Houses of Parliament.

We can find no reason to support what is going on. The National and Liberal parties stand firmly behind the private member's Bill. We thank Senator Boswell for bringing it to our attention. If this Bill had not been brought forward there would have been no opportunity to debate a matter as important as this. He has given us the vehicle on which we can at least bring it to light. I have mentioned that it is not a true pension scheme. I would call it a type of work compensation scheme, because the amount of money involved in it, the 3 per cent productivity increase, would not be sufficient to provide superannuation for anybody. In fact, if people collected that when they were 55 years of age, they would have only sufficient money for a trip around the world or some minor expense, but certainly would not have sufficient for their retirement. They would blow that lot and go on the ordinary pension, so there is no question that it is a pension or superannuation scheme in its own right. It is just a deferred wage rise on which no tax will be paid and which will put a lot of money into the hands of the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is taxable at the end, though.
—Is it? We do not know about that. It has not been mentioned.
—Have a look at the tax changes brought down in May. Of course it is taxable.

—Senator Ray can say that, but I think it should be pointed out to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that it does not have a role in superannuation or pensions, which are not industrial matters as are wages and conditions. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Conciliation and Arbitration (Amendment) Bill 1986 introduced as a private member's Bill by my National Party of Australia colleague, Senator Boswell. It aims to amend the definition of `industrial matters' in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act by excluding from the Commission's jurisdiction superannuation and pension schemes. I believe in superannuation. When I worked before I got married, I belonged to a superannuation scheme. When I left work-I cannot say that I received a very large amount-I received a small percentage of interest with the money that I had paid in. Nevertheless, I think that superannuation schemes, properly run, are very good for employers, employees and self-employed people. I believe that I am speaking for the majority of Australians today in registering my strongest protest against the Australian Council of Trade Union productivity superannuation deal. It is blatantly obvious to all but the ACTU and this Australian Labor Party Government that Australia cannot afford this push for so-called productivity gain-in reality wage rises.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has 600,000 unemployed. Our inflation rate is running at 9.2 per cent. Interest rates have gone completely out of control and, I regret to say, are among the highest in the world. Our producers are struggling to be competitive on world markets with the result that our farm sector is in serious decline. We have an enormous balance of payments deficit. Australian employers simply cannot sustain additional labour costs. If they are forced to do so by this ACTU superannuation push we may rest assured that more jobs will be lost. As far as I am concerned, the Bill should be supported by all concerned Australians who feel that the ACTU superannuation push is nothing more than a blatant attempt to by-pass the parliamentary process in securing wage rises for the ACTU membership. It is as simple as that.

The ACTU is saying to this Government and to the whole of the Federal Parliament: `We do not need you; we are more powerful than you. What the ACTU wants, the ACTU will get, whether you like it or not'. The whole issue of this productivity push is, as far as I am concerned, the last straw. Just how long do Australians have to put up with the bully boy tactics of the unions in this country? When will the Government realise that it has an obligation to say to Mr Simon Crean and the rest of the union cronies that they have gone too far? Queenslanders are fed up. In Queensland we are used to seeing courage and determination in our leadership. We are not used to the weakness being displayed at the helm of this Labor Government, especially at this time, when the country needs leadership. Unfortunately, I fear that our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has begun to believe his own publicity machine-that is, that he is everybody's good mate and a great arbiter. Actions speak louder than words, and speak louder than advertising campaigns. As far as Australians are concerned, the Prime Minister does not do enough of the right sort of acting.

The great superannuation debate is a complex one. It is not simply a matter of posing the notion because it is being advanced by the ACTU. This question goes beyond party political bias. Australia could be catapulted into a major economic recession if this superannuation push is successful.
