The Confederation of Australian Industry has forecast that the payment of a 3 per cent productivity based increase, paid as superannuation-it is quite possible that it will be more than 3 per cent because the unions are on record as saying that that is their portion and that the employers have to put in another 3 per cent or even more-would turn the mild slow-down which we are presently experiencing in economic activity into a real recession.

Another major employer group, the Business Council of Australia, has suggested that business profits are not adequate to cover this pay increase. Mr Bryan Noakes, the Director-General of the CAI, has been quoted in the Australian as saying that it was difficult to believe that the Government was treating the nation's economic problems seriously when it was supporting the unions' productivity claim. He said:
The granting of the superannuation payment will make the coming downturn more prolonged and far deeper than it would otherwise have been.

The unemployment rate in this country grew from 7.8 per cent to 8 per cent in February. Our balance of payments deficit jumped to $1.33 billion. Similar Australian Bureau of Statistics information has revealed a downturn in manufactured output during the December quarter, and continuing declines in housing approvals and savings banks deposits. We heard quite a deal about the housing industry in a previous debate.

If these ACTU attempts to use productivity as the basis for yet another cost increase on industry are successful we can be sure that the consequences will be borne, not just by employers, but by everyone in the form of higher prices, interest rates and unemployment. I am not opposed to the concept of superannuation where individuals put in their share and the employers add theirs. I agree that individuals should make provision for their future-a future, I might add, which should be independent of government support. To this end I agree with the individual's pursuit of a superannuation scheme, whether that scheme be a company or a private one. After all, it is the individual's money. In the long term this can result only in healthy competition between various superannuation schemes.

If the ACTU superannuation push is successful, we will see something like $1 of every $11 that the employer puts into the scheme going to the union coffers as administrative costs. Supposing that this is an accurate figure, we would see about $3 billion annually finding its way into strike funds and into the Australian Labor Party. I find it hard to imagine what sort of havoc the unions would wreak if they had $3 billion a year to play around with. If it were not so dangerously serious it could almost be a joke, but I am not laughing and there are millions of earnest, hard working Australians out there who also are not laughing. We are deadly serious and very worried.

In the words of the editorial of the Australian of yesterday, 7 May, is it in the interests of Australia to have giant union superannuation funds which could have even an indirect influence on the investment decisions of the institution managing a fund for a union? I think not. We simply must not allow this deal to go through. The unions have far too much power in this country as it is. I urge concerned fellow senators to support this private member's Bill and to ensure that this country is not put in jeopardy by the selfish actions of the unions hierarchy, which wants nothing more than to bring this country to economic disaster by stealth and by force. We who have the power to do something about this today must join together and act responsibly for the sake of millions of Australians who want no part of it. I support Senator Boswell's Bill and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to speak on the Conciliation and Arbitration (Amendment) Bill 1986 introduced by Senator Boswell, which gives honourable senators an opportunity to bring to the notice of the Parliament the considerable disquiet which is felt not only by Opposition senators, but also widely throughout the community at the proposed productivity award, in terms of superannuation, which is now before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Without going into the complexities of whether in fact the Commission has the power to deal with the provision of superannuation for the Australian work force, whether in fact it is being threatened or cajoled into dealing with a subject which the courts have previously held was not with its general purview and is seeking to get around those court decisions by some sleight of hand whereby superannuation replaces wage increases, is a debate of considerable importance but is not the central issue to be addressed in dealing with this particular piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want, however, to start with some remarks about the case currently scheduled to go before the Commission. The proposals currently before the Commission have been analysed in detail by the firm Morrow Australia Pty Ltd which I think is generally recognised as the most outstanding private consultancy firm in this area. That firm has identified five particular concerns about the case currently proposed to be heard. Those concerns are as follows: First, that the choice as to whether any productivity award is to be directed towards an employer, union or industry fund be on the basis of an individual election by each employee rather than the so-called consensus view of any group of employees as reflected through a decision by their union. In other words, employees should have truly individual freedom of choice. I do not believe anybody would dissent from that particular point of view. Certainly nobody on this side of the chamber would dissent from that point of view.

Secondly, that other than in the case of death or serious ill health, any benefits preserved as a result of any productivity award should be unavailable to the individual until the statutory retirement age. That is again a significant matter to which I wish to return later. Thirdly, that provision be made for at least some existing superannuation benefits, which have to date been provided outside the industrial negotiation process, to be offset against any productivity award Fourthly, that the trusteeship requirements for approved funds be such as to ensure that there is not an undue concentration of power in any one individual or group of interests. Again, that is a matter to which I wish to return later.

Finally, that the Commission ought to make it clear to all parties that, if superannuation is to be brought into the conciliation and arbitration scheme, it must be accepted that any industrial action in support of superannuation benefits beyond those required to be provided under any productivity award ought to be regarded as a breach of the accord or any other agreement entered into, and ought to be dealt with accordingly. Even those who have some sympathy for the case which is currently before the Commission recognise that that particular case is already substantially flawed.

However, there are issues which are of far greater moment and which go to the whole question of the way in which superannuation ought to be looked at and dealt with in Australia. I believe that the provision of superannuation for employees in Australia is a desirable objective but it ought to be based fundamentally upon the question of the free and independent choice of the individuals concerned. One has to be aware, for instance, of the enormous rise in expenditure which is taking place within the welfare system in Australia. If one looks, for instance, at the annual report 1984-85 of the Department of Social Security and one simply turns to the question of the number of persons in receipt of the age pension, in 1966 there were some 636,984 persons in receipt of payments of $442m. By 1985-only just under two decades later-the number of persons in receipt of the age pension was 1,331,782 at a cost of $5,638m.

Quite clearly the welfare system in Australia cannot go on providing unlimited amounts of money for the payment of pensions and other benefits. It is, therefore, axiomatic that at some stage a major shift in the way in which we provide for our retirement and security must take place towards superannuation. I put to honourable senators that that must be done only within the context of a completely voluntary arrangement entered into by individuals themselves. We are already facing an additional pressure on all of this by the enormous changes which are taking place in work patterns in Australia and the decisions progressively being made, including by tribunals in New South Wales, for a balancing of the retirement age. People are being allowed, indeed encouraged, to retire at earlier ages and there is a considerable amount of debate as to whether the retirement age for both males and females should be brought into line.

The Senate will shortly be debating a piece of legislation to amend the Sex Discrimination Act. I do not want to anticipate debate on that matter other than to say that that legislation provides inter alia for a reduction to the age of 60 of the eligibility of males to receive certain welfare benefits, including those provided in terms of aged persons accommodation and delivered meal subsidy arrangements. In other words, the Parliament is shortly to be confronted with legislation bringing down the age of eligibility of males to 60 in order not to provide a situation of discrimination between the way in which males and females are dealt with in terms of welfare payments and welfare matters.

I come back, however, to the point that I believe is essential to the debate, and that is freedom of choice for individuals and resistance to the encroaching power of the trade union movement. I say firstly that in terms of dealing with the position of the unions it is interesting to quote what the unions have said about the use of superannuation. In an article by Max Ogden, education officer with the then Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, in its monthly journal of May 1979, this was said:
Whatever the figures, it is now clear that superannuation funds which are workers' money,--
I interpolate there to say that it is not exclusively the workers' money, there is a great deal of the employers' money involved there too--
make up such a considerable proportion of investment funds now, that control of these would be tantamount to either complete control, or certainly a major influence in directing the economy.
He goes on:
I suggest that democratic control--

again I interpolate to say that to hear the word `democratic' used by an officer of the then Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union must be one of the most gross perversions of the English language that anybody could possibly imagine--
of pension funds should mean not necessarily that the money is used for the purpose of the highest interest rate, but that it should be seen in a much broader social context . . .

In other words, being told by the unions that they would use the money not as they ought in order to get maximum return on the investment funds of their members and contributors, but rather to be used for what the then AMWSU regarded as social purposes, clearly indicates that it is not the preservation and promotion of the rights of the individual workers that is at stake in terms of many of these union officials, but rather a back door method by which they can increase their control of the Australian economy. Today, of all days, in the Australian Financial Review, appeared an article by Gerard Noonan under the heading `Super funds will begin to control markets, says study'. I quote from that article:

A superannuation study commissioned by the Metal Trades Industry Association has suggested that 50 per cent of the Australian stock market will be controlled by superannuation fund managers by the year 2000, tripling the current level of involvement.
This is a study commissioned from Noble Lowndes, one of Australia's most distinguished firms of consulting actuaries. The articles goes on:
Noble Lowndes raised a series of doubts about the economic effects of what it termed `this proposed measure for compulsory saving',--
that is the case currently before the Commission--
arguing that no proper economic survey had been undertaken.
Nevertheless, it estimated that a 3 per cent contribution level would add conservatively $3 billion to total present funds of $35 billion.

It suggested that where funds now held some $17 billion worth of stocks (about 17 per cent of total market capitalisation) by 1991 they would hold $36 billion (31 per cent) and by the year 2001 $79 billion (52 per cent).

That is, 52 per cent of the total market capitalisation of the Australian economy would be in the hands of superannuation funds. Under the scheme of arrangement which the Government favours those funds will be brought progressively under the control of a limited number of trade union heavyweights. We have had debates in this Parliament about the Commonwealth Employees Superannuation Fund and about the structure of the board that was to be responsible for dealing with its superannuation. With the assistance of the Australian Democrats we amended that legislation to ensure that control was not vested in the hands of a narrow sectional group within the trade union movement which did not accurately reflect the contributors to that fund.

That was a matter of debate here some months ago. When one considers what is being advanced under the aegis of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission one can see that unless some sort of discipline such as that proposed in Senator Boswell's legislation is imposed we will allow ourselves to become hostages to fortune as far as this is concerned. Instead of people being able to choose their superannuation arrangements freely we will find the unions in control of the superannuation funds, and through the superannuation funds, in a commanding position in our free economy and our free market. As I have already said, the union leaders clearly indicated years ago that they sought that, not for the purposes of advancing their members' interests in a financial sense or for protecting them in their retirement but to use the financial power to make the sorts of social and political changes to which unions such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union are committed. There should not be doubt in anybody's mind that the Liberal and National parties are committed to developing rational, responsible and available superannuation schemes throughout Australia. Our shadow Minister for Finance, Senator Messner, when he was the shadow Minister for Community Services, gave an address on 15 August 1985 to a luncheon meeting of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia. I will cite two of the points he made. First, he noted that there had been a substantial increase in the percentage of the work force covered by superannuation schemes-from 28.7 per cent in 1974 to 45.5 per cent in 1983. He said that that `must, in the view of the Liberal and National parties be continued'. We all support that. Senator Messner concluded his address in these words:
Let me draw together the strands of my argument and outline several general criteria for a cost effective system of retirement income.
The time has come when the facts need to be addressed:
that costs cutting in retirement income can only flow from decisions which take a long run perspective and which promote self-provision;

that those who argue for restraint in social welfare expenditure should recognise that, in the long run, only the promotion of independence through integration of the tax and social security system can achieve this; and
that short-term savings in expenditure on other categories of income support can only be made by examining eligibility to ensure assistance is being effectively directed to those in need.
These matters are the real politic which the Liberal and National Parties are facing. They represent the fundamentals of our policy review and development.

That is a very accurate statement of exactly what we as the Opposition parties are seeking to bring into the superannuation debate. It is really quite simple to put this down in a number of very precise and clear points. First, as the Opposition parties we are committed to the expansion of the use of superannuation, not only because we believe it to be in the best interests of individuals to be covered by superannuation but also because we believe that we cannot afford the burgeoning welfare bill which is the only alternative. Secondly, the key element in the expansion of the superannuation system must lie in the element of free choice and not be part of some coercive attempt, whether made directly by the unions in the way in which Senator Parer outlined or whether it be through the aegis of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The principle of free choice must be maintained.

Thirdly, we are opposed to the unions being put into a position from which, by using some of their members' money but also the substantial contributions provided by employers, governments or whatever, they are allowed to take control of a substantial part of the Australian economy and turn it not to the advantage of their members but to the promotion and advancement of their social and political aims. On that basis Senator Boswell has put legislation before the Parliament to draw attention to these matters. The Liberal and National parties believe that superannuation is being grossly mishandled at the moment by the Government. It is again an example of the extent to which the Government is prepared to kowtow to the trade union movement in a quite outrageous and unjustified fashion. The issues before the Parliament are most important and are ones which the Liberal and National parties take very seriously.
Debate (on motion by Senator Archer) adjourned.

That Government Business take precedence of General Business for the remainder of this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION BILL 1985AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1985ATOMIC ENERGY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the adjournment of the debate earlier in the day I had been talking about the nuclear generation of power and the peaceful uses of nuclear energy on the world scene. I made the observation that there are well over 200 nuclear power generators in the world. In fact, the figure is in excess of 300. The nuclear generation of power is a fact of life and will be an important supplemental source of power into the forseeable future-until such time as nuclear power generation turns to nuclear fission. That is at least 30 years away, and probably 50 years away. I made a personal observation that I regret that we have no nuclear power houses in Australia because we have been in the nuclear age for 40 years and we have no development of nuclear engineering design capability as a consequence of not having that source of power. I hasten to add that I recognise clearly that this is not an economic proposition in Australia. It would cost us a great deal to build a nuclear power-house, as we have a cheap source of coal. I believe that the educational benefits to the scientific and academic world are such that it would be worth a subsidy of hundreds of millions of dollars a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Nuclear power houses use uranium, of course. I was about to consider the supply of uranium from Australian sources to the world market. I observed that under the Australian Labor Party, Ranger and Roxby Downs are the only two sites at which it is allowed to be mined. I should have added Nabarlek, the Queensland Mines Ltd operation, which I have visited several times. Australia's potential is massive for the mining of low cost, high grade and readily accessible uranium ore. We have at least 30 per cent of the world's known reasonably assured sources of uranium. Australia is a stable country politically and, as a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, monitors very carefully the safeguards of those people to whom we supply uranium. In March 1984 the Australian Science and Technology Council reported on the nuclear cycle in Australia and it made some observations on the world consumption of uranium. The ASTEC report concluded:
. . . the present free world consumption of 34,000 tonnes of uranium will increase to 50,000 tonnes by 1990 and possibly 65,000 tonnes by 2000.
The report added:

. . . there will be a requirement for between 130,000 and 170,000 tonnes of uranium in the period 1984 to 1986 for which no contracts have as yet been signed. In addition, the existing contracts may not all be firm and there may be opportunities for some utilities to substitute lower cost supplies if these become available. Australian uranium would fall into this category.
Further on, at paragraph 4.3.32, the report stated:

The market provides opportunities for Australian uranium producers to gain additional contracts and to increase exports beyond present levels. If Australia were to secure one third of the uncommitted share of the market, a reasonable assumption on the evidence available, that would lead to a doubling of the amount contracted for delivery between 1984 and 1996. Most of the new exports would occur in the 1990s.

In recent years, uranium has become a major export item for Australia, with sales comparable in value to some other important mineral and agricultural products. The annual value of urannium exports increased from $70 million in 1978 to over $360 million in 1982. If sales were to increase in future to the extent suggested in the preceding paragraph, and if the price of uranium were to remain at $A77 per kilogram for uranium oxide (a reasonable expectation of long term contracts, which generally fluctuate less than the spot price), the annual value of Australian uranium exports would rise to over $1000 million by 1993. The total value of exports in the decade 1984 to 1993 could exceed $6000 million.

For a country which is starved of export earnings and which has the biggest debt position it has ever had-a third of our overseas earnings are needed to pay interest on Federal borrowings alone-that is a very important consideration that we cannot afford to be negligent about.

Australia's involvement in the nuclear cycle is restricted at the moment; it is restricted to the mining and milling of uranium. We operate a very old research reactor. We have had research into Synroc and the waste disposal cycle. We have had some very limited research into the enrichment of uranium and we transport radioactive material and handle low and medium waste.

The next stage in the uranium cycle is the enrichment process. Enrichment has very great economic benefits for Australia because the price of enriched uranium is many times that of the raw uranium oxide-the yellowcake that we sell. Up until the present time, uranium enrichment has been done by either a gaseous diffusion technique or a centrifuge technique. Both of those techniques require huge capital investments. They require very big factories and big capital expenditure to set them up and they use a very great amount of electricity. The output of one big electrical generating station is needed to supply one factory. The process involves increasing the natural percentage of uranium 235 in yellowcake by 0.7 of a percentage point. The enrichment process takes it to between 3 and 4 per cent so that it is a fuel for nuclear power stations.

There is often a misconception between the production of fuel for nuclear power stations and weapons grade nuclear fuel. The difference is enormous. The difference is that the power-house requires fuel of a concentration of 3 to 4 per cent of uranium 235, whereas the nuclear fuel, the weapons grade national, is around 90 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lucas Heights has 80 per cent enriched uranium.

—It is simply misleading for the emptyheads in the Australian Democrats and other fools in the community to suggest that we can take a power-house generating electrical power and use that to develop nuclear weapons. It is uneconomic and it is not done at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The technologies that are used, the gaseous diffusion technique and the centrifuge technique are both very capital intensive. For quite a few years now research has been going on on laser enrichment techniques and this can successfully be done in a laboratory. The great advantage of the laser enrichment technique is that it can be made in very small units. The size of the pro-cessing facility can be increased in increments as required from it at a relatively low capital cost. The other great advantage of it is that it is very moderate in its demands for electrical power. So the cost of making this fuel for nuclear reactors is very modest compared with the gaseous diffusion or the centrifuge techniques. The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia would like to see research taking place in Australia on the laser enrichment techniques so that we could process our yellowcake, which we are selling overseas, to a stage suitable for use in nuclear generating stations.

The next point I want to talk about is the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty because there seems to be a great deal of ignorance as to Australia's involvement in it. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has been one of the most successful international agreements of the nuclear age. It is designed to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons around the world. Its articles provide:
Article I: Nuclear weapon States undertake not to transfer nuclear weapons to the control of another country or to assist a non-nuclear weapon State to acquire them.
Article II: Non-nuclear weapon States undertake not to manufacture or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or nuclear explosive devices.

Article III: Non-nuclear weapon States agree to accept IAEA safeguards on all nuclear activities in their territories for the purpose of verifying the terms of Article II. Each member country to require IAEA safeguards on exports of nuclear items to non-nuclear weapon States which are not a party to the NPT.
Article IV-
Australia does not observe this Article-

This affirms the rights of all countries to use nuclear energy for peaceful purposes and requires countries in a position to do so to contribute to the development of nuclear energy in member countries.

Article V: Each party undertakes to ensure that potential benefits from peaceful applications of nuclear explosions will be made to non-nuclear weapon member States on a non-discriminatory basis and the charge shall be as low as possible and to exclude research costs.
Article VI: All parties to the Treaty undertake to work for a cessation of the nuclear arms race, for nuclear disarmament and ultimately for general and complete disarmament.

Australia is one of the original signatories of that Treaty, along with 122 other countries. We support the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Both this Government and the preceding Government have honoured that Treaty to the letter of the law. Some of the questions that have been raised in this place in the last couple of weeks about the end point of Australian uranium are utterly without foundation. Neither this Government nor the previous Government has had the slightest difficulty in establishing the end-use of our uranium.

The three Bills before us-the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Transitional Provisions) Bill and the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill-repeal the outmoded provisions of the Atomic Energy Act 1953 and replace the Australian Atomic Energy Commission with a new organisation to be known as the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. I would like to pay tribute to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. I do not think it has had a fair run in recent years. It has been short of the funding it needed but it has had very dedicated staff working for it-it has had very competent professionals on its staff. I think they have done a marvellous job for Australia with the very limited resources that have been devoted to them and they have been exposed to some very unfair and unjust criticisms at times throughout their career. What they have done in the field of nuclear physics and in the biological field has been of enormous service to the Australian public and the Australian health professions. If we did not have Lucas Heights today to provide some of the short life radio isotopes for the treatment of many medical conditions many more people would be suffering in Australia. On that ground alone the work they have done in the medical field more than justifies their cost.

The Atomic Energy Amendment Bill will repeal most of the Act because it is out of date. It was set up in the early 1950s when defence implications were involved. The Bill will abolish the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. It is no longer envisaged that the AAEC will be involved in power generation. Its research and development functions will be carried on under ANSTO. The existing provisions for the control of uranium mining were set up with an emphasis on defence implications. They are no longer considered necessary and are to be repealed. Since ANSTO does not need this power, the power will not be in the Acts. The new legislation will restrict Commonwealth powers to matters of international and interstate trade and commerce and prescribe substances in connection with a range of projects or in relation to a territory not related to defence. All external obligations under the International Atomic Energy Agency and other international agreements will be repealed; such obligations will be transferred to the Australian Safeguards Office. The Australian Safeguards Office is to receive legislative backing through the proposed nuclear non-proliferation safeguards Bill which will come before the Parliament soon.

The second Bill-the ANSTO Bill-creates a new authority to replace the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The functions of the new organisation are described in very broad terms but essentially ANSTO will be restricted to nuclear science and technology research and development.

As I said in my introduction, the Opposition will support these Bills. We regret that the policies of the Australian Labor Party are such that Australia will not be able to fulfil the role it should in the world, of being able to influence the nuclear fuel cycles and the nuclear generation of power by being actively involved in research and development in these most important fields. The more development we put into this field the more authority we will have in the international councils of the world for the safeguards of humanity which were so important to us when the Fraser Government signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comments on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill 1985, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1985 and the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill 1985. I do not wish to elaborate extensively on them but there are some points that I would certainly like to draw to the Senate's attention. In the last 12 months I took the opportunity of visiting Lucas Heights. I am pleased to join Senator MacGibbon in acknowledging the contribution of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to Australia and to the whole scientific and research area. In particular I place on record my appreciation of the hospitality that the Atomic Energy Commission afforded me and one of my staff members that afternoon. Further I thank Dr Max Brennan, who is not only a colleague but also a friend. I will come back to some of the things that I discovered on my visit to Lucas Heights that are addressed in the aims and objectives of the legislation and its new provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator MacGibbon has spelt out, the Government has decided to introduce three Bills, although Senator MacGibbon referred to only two. The third Bill relates merely to transitional provisions in the changeover from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to the new Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. That is more an organisational or administrative piece of legislation. The substantive Bills replace the Atomic Energy Commission with the new Organisation and, importantly, repeal the outmoded and offensive provisions of the Atomic Energy Act 1953. The intention of these new Bills is to reflect the Government's policy on nuclear activities; that is, the Organisation will emphasise the research and development of peaceful applications of radio isotopes and radiation and it will concentrate on research and development under both of these headings. It will particularly look at all nuclear science and technology research and development that is in line with the Government's policy. It will look at the production and use of radio isotopes and radiation for medicine, science, industry, commerce and agriculture. Perhaps some time in the future that list will be added to as our research and development discovers new ways of peacefully using radioactivity and radio isotopes.

As the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill states, the new Organisation will have a seven-member executive, the majority of members coming from outside ANSTO. The Organisation will be further assisted by an advisory council of up to 11 members. Again the majority of those members will come from outside ANSTO so as to provide independent advice to the Executive of the Organisation and to the Minister for Resources and Energy.

The Bill also establishes a Nuclear Safety Bureau which will be responsible directly to the Minister for the monitoring of the safety of the two reactors at Lucas Heights. Currently the Safety Review Committee reports to the Atomic Energy Commission. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech stated that it is very likely that the Safety Review Committee, which reviews independently health and safety matters of significance to staff and the public, will be re-established under ANSTO as the Nuclear Safety Bureau. It is significant that it will report to the Minister on the matters I mentioned. Further, the Joint Consultative Committee, which provides for consultation between management and staff, will also be given legislative recognition and this is entirely consistent with the Government's industrial democracy objectives.

The changes both to the aims of this new Organisation and to the structure of the Executive in council go towards ensuring that ANSTO carries out its functions with an emphasis on the needs of Australian industry in as commercial a way as possible. The expectation is that the Government, in encouraging the commercial development of the research and discoveries at ANSTO, could go some way to recouping the cost of some of the outlays required by this Organisation. Although we might aim to develop along the lines of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority's Research Establishment at Harwell, the Government-Senator Gareth Evans noted this in his second reading speech-does not presume that what happens in Australia would reach anything like the same dimensions in significant part because in the United Kingdom there is a much larger industrial base for activities in this area. However, in retaining the commercial revenue it will be possible to develop under this legislation, the prospects for Australia's commercial and industrial development will be furthered.

Senator MacGibbon emphasised the second Bill, which repeals the offensive and outmoded provisions of the Atomic Energy Act 1953. That Act was established at a time when Australia was very aware, if not a part, of a world which appreciated a Cold War mentality and many of the sections under that legislation were very serious, particularly the penalties sections. They applied to restrictions on information that people could pass. There were enormous penalties for people who were found guilty of offences under that Act. The world has changed and, more importantly, the emphasis of change in this new legislation moves away from that approach to the development and research that may be happening at Lucas Heights. Therefore, the Government is pleased to seek a repeal of those very offensive provisions. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON AN AUSTRALIA CARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order, I present the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, together with a transcript of evidence and written replies to questions asked during the Committee's examination of departmental witnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In doing so I wish to make some consequential remarks as Chairman of that Committee. By a resolution of the House of Representatives and the Senate, a Joint Select Committee of eight members representing each of the four main political parties was established on 29 November 1985 to examine the Government's proposal for an Australia Card to combat tax evasion, social security fraud and illegal immigration. The Committee fulfilled this task within what has been a very tight time schedule. We have held public hearings in every State and have taken 5,000 pages of oral and written evidence. We have heard 168 witnesses and held 18 public hearings. The Committee believes it has served an important function in encouraging a systematic and widespread debate about the related issues of privacy, civil liberties, prevention of tax and social welfare fraud and the question of illegal immigration.

In addressing those issues, the Committee was able to come to a series of unanimous recommendations which we believe will be of value to the Government and Parliament and the Australian community at large. These recommendations are contained in chapter 2 of the report. For the interest of members and senators it is worth briefly listing these areas of agreed concern. I refer to the computerisation of births, deaths and marriages registers; the introduction of a data protection agency; the introduction of privacy legislation; the implementation of the banking controls recommended by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union; the implementation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure recommendations on illegal immigrants; the transfer of responsibility for payments under education assistance schemes from the Department of Education to the Department of Social Security; and administrative reforms within the Department of Social Security relating to proof of identity procedures.

However, when the major issue of whether or not there should be an Australia Card was addressed, the Committee split in a five-three decision. A majority of the Committee, Senators Puplick and Haines, and Messrs Porter, Blunt and Saunderson, favoured an upgraded tax file number system in preference to the Government's Australia Card proposal. The proposed high integrity tax file number would be used in a wide range of financial transactions and in the reporting of information to the Australian Taxation Office. The majority viewpoint left open the question of whether or not a card should be issued with the tax file number.

A minority-myself, Mr Brown and Mr Brumby-supported a modified version of the Australia Card proposal. The main modifications of the minority report were recommendations supporting the inclusion of a photograph on the card and limitation of its use to four departments: The Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security, the Health Insurance Commission and, on a more limited basis, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Thus, the report contains unanimous recommendations, a majority viewpoint, a minority dissenting viewpoint and a personal addendum by Senator Puplick. I wish at this stage to express the Committee's gratitude for the dedicated work of the Committee secretariat. Tim Dodson, Judy Ryan, Brett Levy and Janice Paull must be mentioned individually, but there are many other members of the Senate committee office who offered their ready assistance and without whose help this report would not be tabled today.

As a member of the group which brought down a minority report, I wish to point out a number of issues which were at the heart of the reasons why we as a minority group were prepared not to accept the major recommendations of this report relating to the implementation of an Australia Card proposal. First, we need to get back to the basics-that is, whether we have an identity system to combat tax evasion, social security fraud, illegal immigration and other problems relating to the use of false identities within the community. We believe that the proposal put forward by the majority of the Committee in favour of an upgraded tax file number system has a number of major flaws. Those flaws relate to the fact that they have given the Department of Social Security and in particular the Australian Taxation Office the responsibility to run the system. We believe that the Australian Taxation Office is not equipped or presently capable of gearing itself up to handle the immense task of organising this upgraded tax file number system. There are a number of issues I shall want to talk about at a later date, but most of the major flaws relate to what one does with those people who currently hold a tax file number and how they will be brought into the system as proposed by the Committee.

The Australia Card proposal, on the other hand, as advanced by the Government and supported for the most part by the minority group on the Committee, encompasses a number of positives that I shall mention in the next three or four minutes. Basically, we are prepared to put, in opposition to the majority viewpoint that the Taxation Office should run the system, the proposition that the Health Insurance Commission is the most appropriate body to handle the identity system, and that the Health Insurance Commission's experience in this area will be invaluable and has not been taken seriously enough by the majority viewpoint on the Committee. It has had experience in bringing in what is basically a universal identity system, coupled with benefits, in the implementation of Medicare. That experience has been of immense value. It has made mistakes here and there from time to time; it is aware of those mistakes, as indicated in the evidence given to the Committee; and we believe that the people in the Commission would be experienced enough to move into a totally new system such as this without the sorts of problems that are inherent in giving the Australian Taxation Office the responsibility-a department which we all know has no experience in this matter and which, we believe, would be incapable of involving itself in the setting up of a national identification system.

The major problem we feel that would occur with the Australian Taxation Office having control of this operation, in conjunction with the Department of Social Security, is the qualification written into the majority viewpoint that all taxpayers who have a tax file number, or have had a tax file number for five years or more, would automatically be allowed into the system without any major check of their security, their integrity, and without the validity of their identity being checked. In other words, we believe that as that system has been set up it will contain a fatal flaw which revolves around the fact that there would be a significant number of false identities, false tax file numbers currently in the system which would be allowed to go into the new system.

At the heart of any proposal to have a proper identification system, whether to combat tax evasion, social security fraud or whatever, is the need for everyone in the community to feel confident that at all times, and as much as is possible, the identity claimed by people, whether claiming benefits or involving themselves in banking transactions, should under no circumstances be capable of being questioned. We believe that the tax file number system has that flaw of a dearth of proper integrity arrangements, to use the term that went through the Committee on a number of occasions.

I was personally disappointed, as I think were other members of the minority group, that we moved to unanimous support for a number of major recommendations. At the same time, when it got down to the major question of whether or not there should be a national identification system, there appeared to be a caucusing which at times pulled people back from accepting the logical conclusions one would come to, having judged all the evidence. I indicated the problem about tax file numbers, which currently lack integrity and which would simply be allowed to go into the system proposed by the majority Committee.

The revenue implications are another matter of extreme importance. Obviously, there is no point in a government going into this type of operation, whether it is a tax file number system or an Australia Card system, unless it is sure that the expenditure it is involved in will be less than the revenue which is to be returned from the implementation of the system. We consider the evidence given to us by the Australian Taxation Office to be extremely conservative in terms of revenue implications of an Australia Card proposal. The Taxation Office admitted that in evidence. When we considered some of the techniques for the investigation of forgone revenue we were assured that the Australian Taxation Office had not, for example, taken into account a number of areas of extra revenue, such as the penalties for people who had evaded tax and the back payment of tax that was rightly due but had not been picked up under the current system. Those are just two of the areas where the current arrangement is inappropriate and where we think the Taxation Office was extremely conservative.

It is our view as a minority group that $8 billion over 10 years would be the real revenue, or the likely revenue, to be gained from the implementation of a full Australia Card with photograph. I stress that the minority group clearly came down in favour of a photograph being attached to any Australia Card brought into use. We believe that without that photograph the whole question of identity verification would go back into the melting pot. In practical terms, I guess, it is fair to say that that $8 billion would work out roughly to $8 in each taxpayer's pocket every payday. That is a very crude rule of thumb but it is sustainable, given the evidence that came before us.

There is one other major area about which all Committee members were concerned. Under no circumstances do I question the integrity of the people who raised these issues. I believe that the whole community has to be aware of them. I refer to the question of the invasion of privacy and matters relating to civil liberties in this country. As we considered the evidence which came before us, as we questioned banks and government departments, as we sought information from commissioners such as Mr Costigan, as we read reports such as the Stewart report, on the whole we were of the view that there is already significant concern about invasions of privacy in our community and that any proposal which was put forward by the Government or the Committee, whether it be the majority or minority, would have to address the whole question of privacy and civil liberties in a very direct way.

In common with the majority of members of the Committee, we believe that the data protection agency concept advanced by the Government, the appropriate privacy legislation and the logging of people who have access to any file system so that a record is kept of who has been at one's file and for what purpose they have been at one's file, are protective measures which will, at the end of the day, give us as a community much greater protection of our privacy and civil liberties than would have been the case if nothing had been done and would be preferable to what we have now.

I mention, for example, a point that was raised by the banks. People who believe that they can walk into a bank, apply for a loan, give information in seeking that loan to the bank and think that information will remain discreet and within the bank might be under a misapprehension. One major banker who appeared before us indicated quite clearly that, as a matter of course, without telling the loan applicant the bank checks with other banks that all information contained in the loan application is correct. That is an example of the sort of ad hoc invasion of privacy which is now occurring in the community. The unanimous view of the Committee in relation to the civil libertarian arguments and the protective devices that have to be built into the system ought to be taken up very seriously by the Parliament before we advance with any system, regardless of whether it is a tax file number system or the Australia Card proposal.

I thank those officers who worked so hard on this report. They have been up night after night in the last week trying to put together the evidence and ensure that the debate that begins tonight is an appropriate public debate. To summarise in one paragraph-not a reportable one, of course-it is fair to say that the Government had the courage to bring before the Parliament a proposal which did not pretend to be anything other than a national identification system. We have seen examples in other countries of national identification systems coming in by the back door, whether they are in the guise of drivers licences, social security cards or whatever. This Government said: `We are bringing in a national identification system to combat that tax evasion, social welfare fraud, illegal immigration and other matters relating to the misuse of identities'. The Government ought to be commended for that.

When we begin this debate on whether or not we have an Australia Card or the alternative, put by the majority of the Committee, it should be kept in mind that the debate so far has been open. I believe our Committee has helped a great deal towards opening up the debate and raising the issues. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's Australia Card proposal has as many holes in it as Caesar's corpse and, like that body, I come to bury it, not to praise it. The report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card concludes clearly and by majority decision that the Australia Card proposal should not be proceeded with. The majority of members who make this recommendation consist of myself and Mr Porter from the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Blunt from the National Party of Australia, Senator Haines from the Australian Democrats, and Mr Saunderson from the Australian Labor Party, who represent all the major parties which are represented in this Parliament. We say in our majority report:

SPEECH.PARA: Having considered the Government's proposal for a national identification system, as well as alternatives, such as the use of photographic cards and the extension of the use of the current tax file system, the majority of the Committee rejects all proposals for the issuing of identity cards with or without a photograph.

The report, which runs to almost 300 pages, takes in in very considerable detail all the arguments which have been advanced for and against the proposal. They were all heard in open session over a prolonged period. It was very difficult for the Committee to report within its short time framework. I pay tribute to the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Aulich, for the way in which the Committee's proceedings were conducted. I pay a particular compliment to the staff of the Joint Select Committee, who worked under enormous pressure in completing the report and who responded to all the demands, reasonable and unreasonable, which were placed upon them by the members of the Committee and by the time constraints.

It is unfortunate that in Senator Aulich's tabling statement he has seen fit to make a number of comments which I believe are not supportable by the facts. The first and most unfortunate comment is the implication, clearly directed against the integrity of members of the Committee, that for some reason, resulting from caucusing or pressure, they were not prepared to act in a way which, according to their consciences and as a matter of mature judgment, they thought was correct, that they were pressured to resile from what was supposed to be a reasonable point of view. That is a personal reflection. It is incorrect. Frankly, I resent it. Secondly, one ought to look clearly at a number of matters arising from the minority report. The minority report is written with a degree of personal animus and a degree of slur cast upon the intelligence and integrity of members of the majority. It says, for instance:
We are surprised that the opponents of a national identification card system who sat on the Joint Select Committee did not pursue this matter further.
This relates to evidence that in fact the Health Insurance Commission has already assigned numbers to every member of the community. It also states:

We believe it is likely that they chose to ignore the existence of such a numbering system because widespread knowledge of its existence might serve to strengthen public acceptance of the Australia Card.

That is not only untrue; it is also unfair and a reflection on the personal integrity of members of the Committee. It implies that they were not seeking the truth and not seeking to come to a fair, reasoned and rational decision. I say that in that sense the report of the minority stands condemned out of its own mouth.

I give two examples. It is alleged that the benefit of the card proposal is to be some $8 billion over a 10-year period. That includes a figure of $1.2 billion, as is indicated at page 249 of the report dealing with the minority opinion, as the saving alleged by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. However, at paragraph 1.53 of the body of the report, the unanimous part of the report, which deals with the evidence of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Committee as a whole dismisses that evidence as next to worthless. It notes that Mr McKinnon, the Secretary of the Department, in describing to the Committee the basis upon which that calculation was made, said at one stage that the figures were presumed, at another stage that they were a rough estimate, at another stage that they were guesswork, at another stage that they were a guesstimate and, finally, that they had been arrived at using a crystal ball. Those words `presumed', `rough estimate', `guesswork', `guesstimate' and `crystal ball' are in fact the exact words used by the Secretary of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to describe the quality of his evidence, which the Committee as a whole dismisses and which the minority report then seeks to resurrect and make part of its calculations.

Finally, the minority report talks about the majority decision being `cobbled together' and attacks the majority opinion for failing to endorse the issue of a tax card, a matter which we neither endorsed nor rejected but in fact left open, if the truth be told. It states that the absence of such an examination is plainly evident in the failure of the majority to endorse the issuing of a tax card. Again, that is a reflection on the integrity and capability of the members in the majority.
It is interesting to note that the minority relies very heavily on the evidence, for instance, of Professor Whalan. Paragraph 2.10 of the minority report states:
Professor Whalan is a key figure in the debate.
If one looks at Professor Whalan's evidence, which is to be found in particular on page 3825 of the transcript, one sees that Professor Whalan said:
On balance-I emphasise `on balance'-I suggest that if we do have a card there is probably now no need for a photograph.

But that piece of evidence from Professor Whalan is dismissed by the minority, who say that there must be a photograph, despite the fact that Professor Whalan is described as the key witness. Yet on this his advice is ignored. Looking further at Professor Whalan's evidence, he says that the reason that we ought to accept this is that we should not be like King Canute-that the revolution is coming, that we will all be turned into numbers in a system and therefore we should not resist it. His talk about King Canute can be found at page 3826 of the transcript. So, in terms of the evidence relied upon, the authority relied upon, the figures relied upon, the arguments relied upon and indeed the personal reflections against the majority relied upon by the minority report, it will become evident why the minority is the minority.

I turn to matters addressed in what is the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card which recommends that we should reject the Government's proposals. We were asked to test this essentially on four criteria: First, whether the card proposal would be useful for cutting down taxation fraud; secondly, whether it would be useful for cutting down welfare fraud; thirdly, whether it would have any impact on the level of illegal immigration; and, fourthly, whether it would have any impact on organised crime and criminal behaviour. The Committee reaches the conclusion, after testing each of those proposals, that the Government's proposals as put forward fail.

The Committee then goes on to examine each of those matters and to make recommendations that it believes will be more effective in dealing with these matters. It raises the issue of the use of the taxation file number for certain financial transactions. It makes recommendations about the procedures in the Department of Social Security. It makes recommendations about the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs putting into effect the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled `Who Calls Australia Home?'.

In terms of organised crime, the Committee advocates the introduction of a number of the measures originally recommended to the Government by Royal Commissioner Costigan. Therefore we have addressed in the Committee all of the critical tests. We have put forward recommendations which we believe will protect the revenue and help to combat fraud within departments such as the Department of Social Security and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Perhaps one of the useful things to come out of the hearings in relation to social security fraud was the clear evidence that the overwhelming majority of social security fraud takes place by the misstatement of the financial circumstances of the applicants and that only 0.6 per cent of the fraud relates to the establishment of false identity. It is not false identity that is the problem with social security fraud; it is that legitimate identities misstate, either deliberately or inadvertently, their level of income in order to make the assessment of what payment they are entitled to receive.

The evidence from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs demonstrated a complete lack of control within the Department and a complete lack of statistical data available. The Department was pressed on three or four occasions to respond in detail to specific inquiries from the Committee. The responses were generally tardy. When they did arrive they were generally uninformative.

The cost implications of the recommendation need to be looked at. In a personal addendum to the report I have sought to identify what I believe to be the deliberate failure of the Government to include costs which are important in establishing the cost-benefit analysis. For instance, the proposal by the Government includes no cost for the replacement of any computer equipment over a 10-year period. Anybody involved in the computer industry will know that that is nonsense. It understates the number of changes that will need to be made to the roll, taken against the experience and the evidence on address changes given to us by the Australian Electoral Commission. It gives no cost for the storing of material by the Australian Archives. It gives no cost for compliance by State and local government. It gives no cost for the compliance required by the private sector, estimated conservatively to be in the vicinity of $377m. It gives no cost for the burden that will be placed on the banking system. It gives no cost for the burden that will be placed on the banking system. It gives no attention to other matters that were raised by bodies such as the Law Council of Australia in its very strong opposition to the introduction of the proposal.

I turn next to organised crime. It is interesting that of all the experts who came before us who were competent to deal with the issue of organised crime, in particular Mr Costigan and the senior counsel assisting his Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, Mr Meagher, and the Australian Federal Police, all not only opposed the introduction of the Australia Card but also drew our attention to the overwhelming weight of evidence in the United States of America that the existence of a national identity system is positively beneficial to organised crime. We were told that studies by the United States Department of Justice, by the Comptroller-General of the United States, by the United States Senate in a number of its inquiries and by the commission which was established to look at the use of false identity cards in the United States, all clearly concluded that there was substantial benefit to organised crime-I repeat, benefit-in the introduction of a national identification system.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next point I address in terms of the matters arising in relation to the Government's proposal for the Australia Card touches on the issue of protection of privacy. Here we have without doubt the most Alice in Wonderland proposal that has ever been put before the Parliament. The Government's proposal says: `Let us first introduce the Australia Card; let us secondly think about introducing a data protection agency; and let us thirdly think about introducing privacy legislation'. In other words, we do it this way: Instead of establishing privacy legislation, then having a body which can monitor privacy legislation and the threats to personal liberties and privacy and then introducing the Australia Card and seeing whether that stands the test of the legislation and the operation of the data protection agency which is proposed, like Alice in Wonderland we will approach this on the basis of the verdict first and then the trial. The Committee is at pains to point out that this is an absolute nonsense in terms of the way in which privacy ought to be protected in Australia and the Committee recommends that both privacy legislation and a data protection agency be put in place before the Australia Card proposal is introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The minority members, in their report at paragraph 1.3, have been at pains to indicate the sorts of people who have come before the Committee to support the introduction of the Australia Card. They list the following: The Returned Services League, the Australian Taxpayers Association, the Australian Retailers Association, the Australian Hotels Association, the Salvation Army and the Sydney City Mission. This is one of the more disingenuous parts of the minority report, because when one looks at their recommendations one will see that the latter three of those organisations-the Australian Hotels Association, the Salvation Army and the Sydney City Mission-would all be excluded by law from access to the use of the Australia Card under their proposals.

The Australian Retailers Association made the point that it wanted the card because it would do something about the black economy, or cash economy, yet both the minority and the majority are at one in saying that the Australia Card proposal will do absolutely nothing to combat tax evasion through the cash economy. The Returned Services League came along and said that it thought there was really no reason why everybody should not carry an Australia Card because, after all, during the war everybody had to have a number and it was basically good for everybody to have a number. Undoubtedly there are some people who actually believe that to be the case.

Most interesting is the Australian Taxpayers Association. Mr Risstrom was our first witness. I say with the greatest degree of objectivity that he was one of the least impressive witnesses the Committee was forced to listen to. The nature of his argument was tendentious and the claims he made were, frankly, racist in terms of describing the way in which a large number of Italians and others were ripping off the system by working in restaurants and not declaring their tax. The whole approach he brought to the Committee was entirely reprehensible. I note that yesterday Australia Associated Press reported that Mr Risstrom had put out a statement in which he said, basically: `It does not matter what the Joint Select Committee says, the Government will of course go ahead and introduce the card. After all, we cannot have the matter of tax cheating decided by a handful of people making decisions for political reasons'. Of course, it would never cross Mr Risstrom's mind that it was possible to do anything for political reasons. He was presumably referring to Senator Haines, who gave him a particularly rough trot at the Committee hearing, when he said that the Committee contained `emotional diehards who had voted against introducing the national identity card, including Australian Democrats' Deputy Leader, Senator Janine Haines'. I cannot speak for Senator Haines, but I am sure that she resents greatly being described as an emotional diehard.

I should indicate that, while groups such as the Returned Services League, the Taxpayers Association, the Retailers Association and the Australian Hotels Association thought the card was a good idea, the overwhelming number of people who came before us thought that it was an appalling idea. For instance, the Victorian, New South Wales, Queensland, South Australian and Tasmanian Councils of Civil Liberties, the Law Institute of Victoria, the Queensland Law Society, the Law Council of Australia, the International Commission of Jurists, the New South Wales Privacy Committee, the Australian Computer Society at the national, South Australian and Western Australian branch levels, the Bar Association of Queensland, Professor Walker from the law faculty of the University of Queensland, Professor Barter from the computer faculty of the University of Adelaide, Professor Webster from the community medicine faculty of the University of New South Wales, Dr Emberson from the University of Western Australia, Mr Butler from the law faculty of the University of Queensland, Dr Walsh from the anthropology department of the Sydney University and Professor Johnson of the University of Wollongong all said that the card was an awful idea. The Anglican Diocese of Perth came before us to say that it was an awful idea; the Catholic Social Welfare Commission gave us a submission saying it was an awful idea; the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Federated Clerks Union and the Victorian Teachers Union said it was awful; the Confederation of Australian Industry said it was awful; the South Australian Chamber of Commerce said it was awful--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did anyone want it? Who wanted it?

—We will come to that in a moment. The Australian Labor Party was interesting on this matter. We had a formal submission from the National Legal Policy Committee of the Australian Labor Party telling us that it was against it. We received Senator Bolkus's worthy paper saying that he was against it. We received letters from a number of branches of the Australian Labor Party saying that they were against it. The National Conference of Labor Women passed a resolution saying that it was against it. Most of the divisions of the Liberal Party of Australia indicated that they were against it. Senator Sheil, speaking on behalf of the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia, indicated that that organisation was against it. Yet all of that evidence can be tossed aside by the minority members in their determination to rescue what was left of the Government's proposal after the evidence was in.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of incrementalism is interesting. When the Government first advanced this proposal at the National Taxation Summit, we were told that only seven Commonwealth departments would have access to this Australia Card and its register. By the time we got the final proposals from the Health Insurance Commission, one of the seven departments, namely, the Australian Electoral Office, had withdrawn; nevertheless, there were by then 13 departments which suddenly thought they needed access to the whole thing. That frightened even the minority members of the Committee, who in their report have whittled it back down to four departments. Nevertheless, I think we ought to be particularly conscious of the fact that this proposal, of which the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) seems to be the principal advocate within the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not alone.

—I understand indeed that he is not alone. Perhaps he is not alone in being responsible for having introduced the Health Insurance Regulation made under Statutory Rule No. 290 of 1985, which this Senate disallowed. If Senator Crowley bothers to look at the excellent statement made by her party colleague Senator Cooney, indicating why that Health Insurance Regulation should be disallowed, she will see how Dr Blewett, as Minister for Health, by introducing a regulation which consists of only eight words, had nevertheless trampled upon the rights of privacy of every person in Australia. Senator Cooney, in noting the disallowance of that regulation, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the potential invasion of privacy represented by the power to circulate medical details is much more serious since our state of physical and mental health is a source of our most intimate weaknesses.
Improper revelation of medical information exposes us to humiliation, ridicule, contempt, embarrassment, blackmail and great stress.

He went on to say that the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett-the great advocate of the Australia Card and the person who wants us to believe that he is actually concerned about our civil liberties and the protection of privacy-is the Minister who introduced an eight-word regulation which the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and this Senate saw fit to bring to the attention of the Parliament in order to have it disallowed because of the enormous implication it had in trampling upon the civil liberties and personal privacy of every person for whom there is a Medicare file and Medicare number. The Minister was aware of the Committee's concern because the Committee on Regulations and Ordinances wrote to him and drew his attention to the fact and to its concerns. Nevertheless, he persisted with the making of the regulation which fortunately the Senate caused to be disallowed.

We are now to believe that the Minister who was prepared to do that with our medical records is to be trusted to run an enlarged system based upon the computerisation and centralisation of personal details about every man, woman and child in Australia. I say `child' because another thing that has grown in terms of its incremental use about this card, which was originally proposed at the Tax Summit to be introduced only for all adults, is that it is now required under the Government proposal to be introduced for every child. Every child is to be registered, and a card is to be issued which parents have to accept and hold and keep responsible control over for their child from the point of birth.

The most important comments made to us were that this proposal would make some very fundamental changes in the nature of Australian society. That point was made to us in the submission to which I have previously referred by the Catholic Social Welfare Commission. It was made perhaps in its most eloquent fashion by His Grace the Right Reverend Michael Challen, Bishop of the Anglican Diocese of Perth and Chairman of the Social Responsibilities Commission of that diocese. His Grace came before us as a witness and made the point at some length. He said in part:

Certainly it is imperative upon us all to try to order our society on the basis of commonly accepted moral values primarily, rather than through legislation, through insistence. The more we have taken the second route, the more we minimise the moral imperative. I think we get into a downward spiral.
In describing what he meant by that, His Grace was an eloquent and formidable critic of the Australia Card proposal. The same might be said about Mr Costigan, who said in part:

. . . you ultimately have to prove that the computer is wrong and you can just imagine the problems if something has gone wrong and you have to persuade the person across the counter that you are right and the computer is wrong.

He went on, as did Mr Meagher, counsel who assisted him in the Royal Commission, saying that he opposed the card because it would help organised crime rather than hinder it and because it would change the nature of our society. His Honour Mr Justice Michael Kirby, in a paper which was taken as evidence by the Committee, concluded:
What is at stake is nothing less than the nature of our society and the power and authority of the state in relation to the individual.
He said that in his very eloquent opposition to the introduction of the Australia Card proposal.

When people have had a chance to study this report, which runs to some 300-odd pages, I believe that they will see that the evidence is overwhelming. It would be, I suppose, very difficult to find any proposition-particularly one sponsored by a government, which would bring together people as politically diverse as myself, Mr Porter, Mr Blunt, Senator Haines and Mr Saunderson-on which we could conclude that this card proposal should be rejected. I go back to the words we used in the report:

Having considered the Government's proposal for a national identification system as well as alternatives such as the use of photographic cards and the extension of the use of the current tax file system, the majority of the Committee rejects all proposals for the issuing of identity cards with or without a photograph.

I conclude by saying that perhaps the one satisfying thing in this whole exercise has been that this was not a piece of legislation which was brought into the Parliament and attempted to be rushed through the Parliament. That occurred because I think the Government understood that it would be unable at that time to secure the support of the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats to get it passed by this chamber. The compromise that was agreed upon was that there should be a joint select committee of the Parliament to investigate all aspects of this proposal. That joint select committee was formed with four Labor Party members, two Liberal Party members, a National Party member and an Australian Democrat. It met on numerous occasions. It held public hearings in every capital city except Darwin. It took some 5,000-odd pages of evidence in transcript. It heard evidence from 100-odd witnesses. It has received nearly 200 written submissions. At the end of the day, discharging what I think to be its proper parliamentary purpose, it has come to a conclusion that the Government's proposal should be un-equivocally rejected, and it has addressed itself to the alternatives required to deal with the pro-blems properly identified of tax evasion, welfare cheating, illegal immigration and organised crime. I hope the Government will be guided by the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee. I am encouraged in my belief that if it does not and it persists with its recommendations in the form that the Joint Committee has clearly rejected, the Opposition parties in this chamber and the Australian Democrats will ensure that such an unjustified and dangerous proposal is never given legislative effect.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION BILL 1985AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1985ATOMIC ENERGY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I proceed with my remarks on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill 1985, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1985 and the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill 1985, I take the opportunity to correct what I may have said in error in my earlier remarks. It was not my intention to mislead either the people or this Parliament, but on examining further what I said it may be that I have done so. I take the opportunity to make it quite clear, first, that the Nuclear Safety Bureau that will be established by this new name under this legislation will be established and given statutory recognition. It will be, if you like, a replacement of the present regulatory bureau of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The comments I made about the Safety Review Committee that might have suggested that it was to be established under the Nuclear Safety Bureau are the points of confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: To be clear, the Safety Review Committee will be established under a separate clause of the new Bill. There is currently a Safety Review Committee, established under the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, with the brief to review health and safety matters of significance to the staff and the public. These functions will continue under the new legislation. Further, if I could go into it, the structure of the Review Committee is important. The legislation mentions specifically that not only will there be the Nuclear Safety Bureau but a Safety Review Committee will also be established. It is interesting to note that the Minister for Resources and Energy shall establish this Committee and that, unlike the new Nuclear Safety Bureau, it will not necessarily comprise members of the staff of the organisation but very likely will comprise people from outside the organisation, as is currently the case in large part.

The functions of the Safety Review Committee under the new legislation are very much to the same principal point, that is, to preserve and look after and review the health and safety matters of significance to the staff and the public.
