That is spelt out in clause 24a (1) of the legislation. Further to that, under clause 4 the Safety Review Committee shall be required to report to the Minister each year, and its report must also go to the Executive. Associated with that is clause 6, which requires the Minister to lay the report before the Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days after the report is received by the Minister. But even further to that, under sub-clause (5) of 24A of the legislation there is a clause that allows the Committee to submit to the Minister and to the Executive such other reports relating to the operations of the Committee as the Committee considers appropriate. In other words, the legislation allows that the Committee may review or report on matters outside of the annual report. If for whatever reason and from time to time it saw fit to prepare a report outside of the annual report under the legislation, it is able to do so. Under clause 7 the Minister may cause a copy of that report received by him under sub-clause (5) to be laid before each House of the Parliament.

Those are very clear elaborations of some of the functions of the Safety Review Committee. Further, I think very importantly, sub-clause (8) describes that the Committee may, in the carrying out of its functions, obtain advice or assistance from any member of the staff of the organisation, which I think describes and avows the understanding of the significance of the Safety Review Committee. The Committee, in fact, can avail itself of any member of the staff or the executive of the organisation to inform it or to provide it with information to allow it to most satisfactorily and fully do what it sees as its task. In fact, I think that is a very significant clause in the Safety Review Committee section of the Bill and I think we should remark that clause because it does convey the significance that the Government, in this legislation, places on the whole question of safety and the importance of the thoroughness and the comprehensiveness of that safety review function. This is no slight clause tacked on. The Government is very concerned that the safety function, and the safety review function in particular, be very clearly spelled out, and so it has done in clause 24a.

It is interesting to compare the functions of the Safety Review Committee with the functions of the Nuclear Safety Bureau. It would seem from a reading of the legislation that the Nuclear Safety Bureau has a responsibility to review and monitor the safety of the nuclear plant whereas the Safety Review Committee has the much broader task involving the standards, practices and procedures adopted by the organisation. I think the Safety Review Committee is of considerable significance in this legislation and it has a very comprehensive range of specified tasks. I hope that in elaborating in that way I have corrected any misapprehension I may have given earlier.

In summary of my comments at this point I would simply like to make clear that the Bill gives a very clear legislative direction for the future of the research program in this whole area of nuclear science and technology. I would be surprised if the people involved in the area do not welcome this clear legislation and direction by the Government of what it sees as appropriate functions for this new organisation.

I would like now to make a few other comments. I understand that some people would argue that we may, in fact, do away with the whole nuclear process, do away with the medical supplies-the medical radioisotopes that are produced currently at Lucas Heights-and close that whole show down if we ever import, buy or establish a cyclotron. I think this is to misunderstand what happens with a cyclotron and a nuclear reactor. In fact, each produces a different range of radioisotopes. They have different functions and different applications. If and when a cyclotron is established in Australia, it would be an additive to what is available from Lucas Heights, not instead of, and that is most important. In supporting the establishment of a cyclotron it would certainly not be my intention to argue a cyclotron as a replacement for the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights. It is important to be clear that the two would be providing different medical radioisotopes, even if we only confine ourselves to the medical radioisotope area. It is important to know that it would be an additive and not a replacement. I understand that the cyclotron, if and when it is established, could well be included under the provisions of this legislation. I do not wish to pre-empt how that might happen, but as it goes very much to matters of similar sort, that would seem to me to be appropriate and I understand it could so be considered.

I would like to make a brief comment, too, about some negative comments, particularly by the Australian Democrats, about the hazards that might be attributed to Lucas Heights because of the age of the reactor. I think it is important to recall to the Senate the answer given by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, in answer to questions earlier in this session, when he said the age of the reactor is about 25 to 27 years. I am not precise on that. In fact, that is of no serious concern to us in this country precisely because of the safety requirements, the maintenance and the care that has been provided at Lucas Heights. In fact, as I remember Senator Gareth Evans saying, one could probably say that the reactor is safer now than it was in the early days of its establishment. More importantly, this reactor is a particular sort that is not similar to the electrical energy provisions of, for instance, the Chernobyl reactor. It is quite different. Senator Gareth Evans has elaborated that difference and I sincerely hope that Senator Sanders has read his answers and understood them and will not give us yet another serve on misrepresentation of what is in fact the case at Lucas Heights.

I would like to conclude my remarks by turning to comments made by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, of which I am a member, about this piece of legislation. In the sixteenth report of 1985 of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, dated 27 November 1985, at page 3, the Committee drew the attention of the Senate to clause 40 under the heading `Delegation', and the Committee made the comment:

Clause 40 permits the Minister to delegate to `a person' all or any of the Minister's powers under the Act other than the power of delegation and the powers of the Minister to appoint deputies for members of the Executive and to give directions to the Executive.

The Committee has, on a number of occasions, and again in this piece of legislation, expressed concern in relation to unrestricted powers of delegation. The Committee noted that some steps had been taken in the present piece of legislation-this particular Bill-to restrict those powers by going some way to defining what restrictions there would be, but still the Committee felt it was important to draw the clause to the attention of the Senate because it felt that `by permitting such unrestricted delegation it may be considered to make rights, liberties and/ or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers'.
We were pleased in the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to receive a reply from the Minister, whose Senior Private Secretary responded in the following terms:

In preparing this Bill it was not envisaged that the powers referred to by the Committee in clauses 17, 26, 29, 38 and 43 would have been delegated. The Minister has therefore agreed that sub-clause 40 (1) (b) should be amended during the Committee Stage of consideration of this Bill, to include these powers in those that may not be delegated. In addition to the powers noted by the Committee, it is proposed that the power to give directions, contained in sub-clause 5 (1) (a) (iii), will also be included in those that may not be delegated.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee reported our thanks to the Minister for his agreement to amend the Bill in this fashion. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee drew the attention of the Senate and/or the Minister to those delegations of powers that cause it concern under the terms of reference of that Committee. I think it is very satisfying when they are noted. The Minister in this case has noted those comments and has taken them into account, to the point where he is proposing amendments in the Committee stage of this legislation. I think that is a point worthy of comment in the debate on this legislation. I am pleased to be able to speak on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill. It goes to a very clear statement by the Government of its proposed changes and intentions for what shall happen with the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, what shall be done there and what shall be encouraged. The Senate should be pleased to support this legislation precisely because of the clarification and reordering of priorities it gives to that structure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has come up with its usual reliance on gee whiz technology and its other preoccupation with making a quick buck no matter what the consequences. It has been apologising for nuclear technology ever since I have been in this place. I do not think Opposition senators really understand the full ramifications of their apologies-if, in fact, anybody listens to them. In bringing on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill and allied Bills the Government is to be congratulated for trying to break the monopoly that the Australian Atomic Energy Commission has held in the atomic energy field. However, the announcement on the Bills by Senator Gareth Evans came at the time that the Nuclear Weapons Prohibitions Bill brought in by the Australian Democrats was debated. The timing of this announcement of ANSTO was no doubt influenced by the desire to counter unfavourable publicity about the Government policy to oppose the Democrats' Nuclear Weapons Prohibitions Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes have a legitimate basis but they are basically of a housekeeping nature. I urge Senator Crowley to stay in the chamber so that she can listen to the replies to her questions which were directed to me. She is staying. I thank her very much. The Government is being extremely dishonest in promoting the ANSTO Bills as being a positive anti-nuclear initiative. The removal of the draconian penalties in the Atomic Energy Act which would ensue for anyone publishing information on uranium deposits and the nuclear fuel cycle, while necessary, is an attempt to show the dismantling of the nuclear state. Meanwhile, our democratic process is being undermined by the official secrecy surrounding the functions of nuclear-related bases in Australia and on the entry of nuclear weapons into our ports, secrecy which is directed solely at Australians. The nuclear state is thriving in this country through our nuclear links with the United States of America. The lack of parliamentary control over the bases agreements illustrates this further.

The replacement of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission with ANSTO is supposed to indicate a trend away from nuclear fuel cycle research. This trend existed irrespective of legislation. ANSTO's functions, as defined in the Bill, include no prohibition on such research. ANSTO is merely supposed to have regard for Government policy. The Government is yet again guilty of refusing to put its alleged anti-nuclear commitment into law, as was the case with the Democrats' Nuclear Weapons Prohibition Bill. The establishment of a nuclear safety bureau to monitor the Lucas Heights reactor is prima facie a good move but in reality is woefully inadequate when compared with nuclear watch-dog agencies overseas. It would simply not be tenable in the United States to appoint such a body from the nuclear industry; in this case ANSTO. ANSTO will have undue control over the NSB, which could be crippled by ANSTO's executive interference and by an inherent conflict of interest. The Government has responded to Democrats' criticism in this area and has changed the Bill, as we shall see later.

ANSTO is prohibited from conducting nuclear weapons research. This is laudable and indicates that as a principle Australia has no desire to use nuclear weapons. Clearly, the Government sees a distinction between Australian nuclear weapons and those of the United States, which it fully supports in ever increasing numbers and degrees of overkill, including support for the United States nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed ships which stay in our harbours. The same principle is behind the banning of any defence-related uses of Australian uranium by Australia through the AEA amendments. Yet we do not seem to be concerned about exporting uranium to the West German firm RWE, which may contribute to the French nuclear weapons program by supplying fuel for the Super Phenix fast breeder reactor.

The Bills will not change the nature and level of Australian nuclear-related activities. At best, they represent an exercise in housekeeping with some gains for civil liberties. At worst, they are a pathetic attempt to create a false impression that the Government supports the passage of anti-nuclear legislation. Australian Democrats' support for these Bills is highly qualified. We oppose the continued export of uranium. We wish to see the explicit prohibition of most mining and nuclear fuel cycle-related activites. We wish to see cyclotron produced isotopes investigated as an eventual replacement for reactor produced isotopes to rid Australia of any need for the further operation of a nuclear reactor. If we need these isotopes we can readily obtain them from overseas where there is an abundant supply of nuclear reactors. I have been told that a cyclotron would give us access to isotopes which we do not have at present.

The Atomic Energy Amendment Bill will allow the continuing function of the Ranger uranium mine. Ranger should be shut down for two reasons: The first is that it supplies uranium which, as I shall point out later, is used in weapons production overseas; the other is that it simply cannot be operated in an environmentally sound manner. Ranger has a water problem. It is inundated by water. It was the company's mistake to begin with and the Australian people are being asked to pay for it. When Ranger was first built water was actually impounded. The engineers thought that they would need to keep some water over the dry season. Apparently they were from more arid parts of the country and did not realise that during the wet the rain literally pours down on the area. They impounded too much water and that has been the problem ever since. Now the mining company is applying to release contaminated water into the environment. It should not be allowed to do so. It has distinct environmental problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen them? Have you been up there?

—Yes, I have been there. I have seen the water problems. They have been explained to me by the Ranger people. I have been through the supervising scientists' offices and have become fully aware of the problems. They admit that they have problems. If they cannot release the water they will have to shut the mine. That would be a fine thing.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the end use of the uranium? After much questioning of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) we find that this uranium that is shipped from Australia to a country such as Finland is first shipped to France, where it is converted into uranium hexafluoride, that is shipped to Russia, where it is enriched into reactor-grade uranium for use in Finnish nuclear reactors. An equivalent amount of enriched uranium, uranium minus the tails-I will speak about that later-goes from Russia to West Germany or Sweden where it is transformed or processed into fuel rods. This brings up two issues. The Australian uranium or uranium hexafluoride that goes to Russia stays in Russia in large part. It would be like pouring a teacup full of water into a swimming pool of water. Australian uranium is sent to Russia and is poured into the Russian uranium enrichment pool. We get back by a paper work accounting method some uranium. By necessity the uranium that we get back is 99.999 ad infinitum per cent Russian uranium. The uranium which went into Russia as Australian uranium stays around and dilutes the Russian pool. This is irrefutable. Senator Evans has said in answers to my questions that we cannot account for the Australian uranium molecule by molecule as we would with olives on a stick. This means that Australian uranium is staying in Russia, where it is undoubtedly used in the Russian nuclear weapons program.

We have been told over and over that we have a moral obligation to supply uranium under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. I put it to this Senate that it is immoral to send Australian uranium which we know will be used in Russian nuclear weapons. It is highly immoral either under that Treaty or under any normal definitions of morality. The other thing that happens with Australian uranium which leaves Russia after the processing phase is that the tails-which are U238-are sent back to France. We have been trying to track this down. We got an answer today, a very convoluted answer, from the Minister. We will really have to wait to analyse Hansard before we can figure out what he said because I do not think he really has a knowledge of the operation himself and he has to rely on pieces of paper which are given to him.

The tails, of which we now have 159,991 kilograms, are apparently used in the French fast breeder program. This U238 is used as a blanket around breeder reactors. Why is it used as a blanket? It is used as a blanket to retain plutonium. The uranium tails left over from the Russian enrichment plant would be almost pure U238-a uranium isotope which is not fissionable and cannot be used as a fuel. The U238 is placed in a blanket around the core in a fast breeder reactor to produce plutonium PU239. Ostensibly, it will then be reused as a fuel for the Super Phenix fast breeder reactor. In this way, 330 kilograms of plutonium will be produced per year. PU239 is also used in nuclear weapons and 330 kilograms is sufficient for up to 60 bombs a year.

Several statements made by prominent French politicians and officials reinforce the suggestion that France will make use of the Super Phenix military applications. In 1979, General Jean Thuy, previously director of France's military centre for nuclear testing and subsequently an adviser to the head of the Atomic Energy Commission of France, wrote that France was able to make large quantities of nuclear bombs `since fast breeders will provide ample supplies of the necessary plutonium'. Bertrand Goldschmidt, an official with the French External Relations Department, is on record as saying that, while he could no longer speak for the French Government, he was certain that the Super Phenix would be used for weapons production purposes. To be sure, France has not hesitated in using `civil facilities' for military application in the past. The well respected Nucleonics Week journal notes:

The French public electricity utility, EDF, reactors at Chignon were used to produce weapons grade plutonium for the military while simultaneously producing electricity, and, more significantly, that the Super Phenix predecessor, Phenix, has provided plutonium to the military branch of the CEA.

Today the Minister said that there was a difference between the Phenix and the Super Phenix. One would produce plutonium and the other would not. The French seem to differ with our Minister for Resources and Energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anything else to say?
—Sit down. We have had enough.

—It is interesting to listen to the interjections from the gaggle of Opposition know-it-alls on my right. In fact, they have very little technical knowledge and can only resort to personal vilification. Their interjections otherwise have no substance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill will have a great deal to do with the operation of Lucas Heights. Lucas Heights runs two reactors. The one of most concern is the HIFAR reactor, which first went critical on Australia Day 1958. This reactor was built by the same arrogant British and Australian nuclear technocrats who gave us the debacles of Maralinga and Monte Bello Islands. These were the people who said that the nuclear age was dawning; they could do no wrong, nuclear power was safe; it was the way of the future. (Quorum formed) I am grateful to the Opposition for calling that quorum because I think more people should listen to this debate. It also gave me a chance to have a drink of water. As I was saying, the HIFAR reactor was built by the same arrogant British and Australian nuclear technocrats who gave us the debacles at Maralinga and Monte Bello Islands. They thought there was an infinite future for nuclear power. They thought that their technology could never fail. In fact, what they did was build an old reactor at the time. It was an obsolete design at the time and now it is geriatric. This reactor is now almost 30 years old. In 1979, they had to close it for four months because of a leak in their heavy water system. Let me quote from an article in the Age of 29 October 1979:
The main nuclear reactor at the Lucas Heights research establishment has been put out of action for at least four months while leaking parts in its heavy water system are replaced.
Here is an interesting statement about people in the Atomic Energy Commission:
. . . a senior Commission official has pointed to the failure in the bellows as a sign of the reactor's age.
Remember, this is 1979. The article continues:
Dr G. L. Miles, deputy director for operations at Lucas Heights, said . . . If you fly a DC3 in the 1980s, it is going to be more expensive, less efficient and less safe.
The reactor was commissioned in 1958, he said, which made it `relatively venerable' as a piece of `fairly complex equipment'.
`HIFAR belongs really to the design philosophy of the mid-1950s,' Dr Miles said.
The Commission was saying this. The article continues:
He said he did not mean that HIFAR was not a good, well-maintained or safe reactor, but it had to be realised that it would need replacing.

It is interesting to note that the Commission now says that it will keep it running for ever but we will get into that at a later time. On 31 August 1979, an article in the Australian headed `Tighter Security for Atomic Plant' stated:
The Federal Government is taking urgent action to overcome health and security problems at the Atomic Energy Commission's Lucas Heights Reactor in Sydney.
The Department of National Development has admitted to the Senate that present security at the plant is not up to international standards.
The AEC has conceded that there is a `significant hazard' to workers at the reactor.
The Department also said there had been several industrial disputes because maintenance staff were reluctant to do their jobs, fearing health risk.
That was in 1979. What does the Atomic Energy Commission have in mind for the reactor at Lucas Heights? I have an article from the Age dated 24 October 1985 which states:

The chief executive of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, Dr David Walker, says it is still working safely and well, producing commercial radio-isotopes and serving as an important scientific research tool.
He says that with proper upgrading it can be kept operating effectively until at least the year 2005, perhaps indefinitely.

Anyone who is at all familiar with metallurgy knows that a plant which suffers these types of thermal stresses, pressure stresses, can simply not be operated for that length of time. There is a huge accident potential here. This can be illustrated by a careful reading of the Atomic Energy Commission's thirtieth annual report, that for 1981-82. On page 53 the report states:

Although HIFAR has now been operating for more than 20 years it has been well maintained. However, standards for safety and reliability have been developed since HIFAR was built and some of its systems do not comply with these new criteria.
Here is a piece of bureaucratese; this is real newspeak stuff:
Non-compliance with a standard does not imply that the system is unsafe, but on the other hand compliance is an indication that a system is more demonstratively safe.
This is real gobbledegook. The document continues:
If HIFAR is to continue operation until 1990-
much less the year 2005-
it was thought necessary to upgrade those systems which have a public safety connotation to a level at which compliance with criteria can be demonstrated.
It continues:
The present emergency core cooling system which is manual in operation will be converted to automatic and its layout, piping and testing will be upgraded.

I sincerely hope so because there have been a terrible number of problems with that. Another problem with the Lucas Heights reactor is the fact that it contains a wall of graphite some two feet thick surrounding the fuel assembly. This is a neutron reflector and it causes neutrons to be bounced back into the fission process in sustaining the reaction. After the Chernobyl disaster there was publicity about what nuclear engineers always knew-that graphite anywhere in a reactor would cause a problem and be dangerous. The Age stated that James Landis, a senior vice- president of Stone and Webster, which is a firm that builds nuclear power plants in Boston, said that the Chernobyl accident is the worst kind of nuclear accident and any reactor that uses or contains graphite is susceptible. We have an old reactor at Lucas Heights surrounded by graphite which has already had problems with its cooling system and a Chernobyl disaster could easily result. The graphite in the reactor is also referred to in a publication by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission on the HIFAR reactor, which points out:

Great care was necessary during construction to keep the material as clean as possible because extraneous material absorbs neutrons. Graphite block clearances near the core had to be suitably proportioned to allow for growth in the volume of the graphite due to fast neutron bombardment . . .

The Minister for Resources and Energy said in this place that the reactor would not be bombarded by neutrons. The HIFAR reactor people say that it is. We have also been told in this place that the HIFAR reactor is no problem because it is 1.6 kilometres away from the nearest habitation. This is no protection at all, given the Chernobyl disaster, where radiation extended from Chernobyl to Spain and Japan and is now reaching the west coast of the United States. A 1.6 kilometre buffer zone is ludicrous.

If those people in Sydney who trust Senator Evans and his reassurances and trust the Atomic Energy Commission ever suffer any radiation damage, I urge them to look at the back of any insurance policy they have. They will find that insurance companies `will not cover any damage directly or indirectly caused by, or contributed to, or by, or arising from, ionising radiations or contamination by radioactivity from any nuclear fuel or from any nuclear waste from the combustion of nuclear fuel'. So insurance companies do not think it is safe, but our Minister for Resources and Energy apparently does and so do members of the Opposition.

The problem with the Bill as it exists is that the bureaucrats have had too much to say in the operation of the atomic energy system in the Lucas Heights area. The Lucas Heights reactor has emitted a number of low level discharges and radioactive waste into the Woronora River which has accounted for a number of fish contamination episodes. It has always denied this or played it down. It says that there is no danger. However, Professor Ernest Sternglass, who is from the University of Pittsburgh and is an expert in low level radiation, after studying the Australian Atomic Energy Commission records, stated:
The same pattern of high localised levels of radio- activity in the milk, seems to be existing around the Australian test reactor, that we have found around a series of nuclear reactors in U.S.

We find that the Atomic Energy Commission in Australia, in company with its brethren around the world, simply does not like to talk about any spills or anything that happens at the Australian test reactor. A headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 October 1985 read `Lucas Heights Leak Report Conflict'. The article stated:

The Sydney Water Board and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission have given differing accounts of a delay last month in notifying the Commission about a leak in a vandalised effluent pipe from the Lucas Heights research laboratories.
The board insists that the Commission was first notified four or five days after the leak was discovered by a board employee on September 7.
In other words the Sydney Water Board had to find out about the leak; the Atomic Energy Commission did not tell it. The article continued:
It has admitted that the Commission was not told sooner because of an internal ``misunderstanding''.
The Commission is equally emphatic that it was not notified for nine days, when it logged a telephone call from a Board employee at 8.40 a.m. on Monday, September 16.

The Board was not notified when there was a leak and it allowed the leak to continue until the civil authorities in the area actually discovered it. This is a reprehensible action and I hope that the ANSTO Bill, in its reconstituted form and with a new clause, will solve this problem. ANSTO shows the inbred, incestuous nature of scientific bureaucracies and their elitist approach. Hopefully in this day and age we can do better than this. I hope that we can bring our technology under control, put technology back under the control of people rather than under the control of technocrats, because they have their own vested interests in all of this. They will delay the reporting of a spill in order to protect their jobs and their prestige. The people must have more of a say.

We now have a chance to start afresh if we have the guts to do so. I do not think we have at present; certainly the Senate does not. The people are far ahead of the Senate in their awareness of the problem and their willingness to do something about it. Obviously the Opposition's mind is completely closed. The Government has people in its Party who are very concerned about this matter. At the moment they are in the minority but only slightly. I hope that sooner or later they will gain the ascendancy and see what the people of Australia want. What the people of Australia want is protection from this most deadly threat to themselves and their children that is posed by nuclear technology, nuclear reactors and, of course, nuclear weapons. We believe, as I believe do most of the people in Australia, that all uranium mining should cease, Lucas Heights should be shut down and ANSTO, which is responsible to the people of Australia rather than to the nuclear industry, should oversee the dismantling of our present dangerous nuclear program. I am foreshadowing that I will move some amendments to both of the major Bills which will bring them more into line with the thinking of the Democrats and the Australian people. However, I will go into that in more detail at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my privilege tonight to speak on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill 1985, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1985 and the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill 1985.
—It is indeed your privilege.

—Thank you very much. It is because of the Government, which has kept us here tonight, that I have been given this opportunity and I thank it very much. This legislation replaces the Australian Atomic Energy Commission with a new organisation which will be known as the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, or ANSTO, and it repeals certain provisions of the Atomic Energy Act 1953.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner we heard Senator Crowley make a speech. I must say that I regarded what she said as very sensible. She spoke about the cyclotron, which some people believe should be brought in to replace the HIFAR reactor that is operating in Sydney. She pointed out that it is not a replacement. It makes medical isotopes that are an addition to rather than a replacement of those now made in Sydney. Some people say `Get rid of the reactor', but I wonder what would happen if those people needed some kind of medical isotope. About 100,000 radioactive units of isotopes of different kinds used in Australia each year are produced in Sydney.

Senator Sanders, for the first few minutes of his speech, criticised the attitude of the United States of America to the nuclear situation. However, it was remarkable that he did not very much criticise the Russian situation or the technology used there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just as bad.
—It is not just as bad; it is a lot worse.
—You did not listen to my other contributions.

—I do not need to listen to many of them. I listened to the one Senator Sanders gave a few moments ago, and he did not criticise Russia at all or the way the Russians make their reactors. Senator Sanders was most one-sided, and I begin to think that he is an apologist for Russia. I would hate to say that about him but I would not be the first to say it.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask the Chair to apply standing order 422. Senator Sanders has just had unbridled access to this chamber but is now denying Senator Townley his right to speak.
—Order! I was about to ask Senator Sanders to cease interjecting because Senator Townley has the floor.
—May I speak to the point of order? My point is that this is personal abuse. Do I get no chance to defend myself?
—If the honourable senator thinks that way, he can take a point of order.
—If Senator Sanders thinks that this is personal abuse he can either reply when I finish my speech or meet me outside afterwards. I do not care which.
—We will not have any quarrels in this place. I call Senator Townley.

—The Australian Atomic Energy Act gave the Australian Atomic Energy Commission the right to be an active participant in the development of all phases of the peaceful uses of atomic energy. Unfortunately, governments over the last few years have been scared of the development of nuclear power in Australia and have opted for the use of fossil fuels. It may be that that is sensible on the Australian mainland, but I do not believe it is. I would much rather live downwind of a nuclear power plant than I would of a fossil fuel power plant. The amount of radioactivity that drops out of the smoke stacks in such plants, even with the scrubbing that can be done-at tremendous cost of course-is frightening. Anybody who thinks that their health and the health of those who live nearby a fossil fuel plant is good or is likely not to be impaired by living there has not studied the situation. Tasmanians have been used to having clean hydro-power but, because of certain reasons, they are now not able to develop the amount of hydro-power they wanted to develop.
—Does Tasmania really need the energy?

—Senator Sanders again interjects. I am asked whether Tasmania needs the energy. I suggest that Senator Sanders go back and study his mathematics. If he were to study the use of energy in most parts of the world, including Tasmania, he would see that it is increasing. No matter what the honourable senator says, there will come a time in Tasmania when we will need more power. No matter whether he switches off his electric blanket or does not use his plug-in torch or whatever, that time will come.
—He might sell more wood heaters.
—We shall not talk about wood heaters here.
—Comalco is leaving.

—Senator Sanders does not know that Comalco is leaving. Show me a bit of paper to prove that Comalco is leaving. Here we have a senator trying to justify not building things in Tasmania that sometimes have a ten-year lead by saying that Comalco is leaving. When it leaves we will have plenty of power and we will be able to sell it for other people to use. Maybe the honourable senator will be able to plug in his electric blanket again. In the meantime, if Senator Sanders wants to save power, let him go ahead and do it. When it was proposed in Tasmania that we build a fossil fuel plant in one area there was a local uproar, and rightly so. For those of use who prize the clean air in Tasmania--
—The cleanest in the world.

—One can understand their worries because, as Senator Tate says, it is the cleanest in the world. Cape Grim, on the north-west side of Tasmania, has a base line station for testing the world's air. I disagree with the establishment of fossil fuel plants in Tasmania. I think that the world will continue to use nuclear power, and I will get on to that in a moment. Former Senator Peter Rae, whom some of us honoured last night in this building, said for a long time that Tasmania should go nuclear. In the future it may well be that that option will be followed.
—What a time to say it, after Chernobyl.

—A former senator, Peter Rae, has been saying that for many years, I am sure well before Senator Sanders came to this country. I certainly support leaving nuclear power as an option-not only for Tasmania, which has very little in the way of fossil fuel of a suitable type, but for this entire country. Therefore, I am sorry that over the last few years nuclear power research at the Atomic Energy Commission has been curtailed. I believe that that Commission should have remained involved in all aspects of the peaceful use of uranium mining, and what goes on after it. We should be involved in enrichment to power production level, not of course to weapons grade.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for people who speak about this and who are against nuclear power stations to say that materials for the production of atomic weapons can be obtained from power plants. Those who want to make atomic weapons realise that if a country decides to make atomic weapons it does not go through the normal process of making nuclear power plants. It has a dedicated system designed specifically to make the very rich uranium that is needed. When I talk of enriching uranium to the standard used for nuclear power plants, I mean raising the amount of uranium 235, which is usually at about 0.7 per cent in yellowcake, to four or five times that level. That means that it is still safe to carry in one's hands.

When somebody says that there has been a spill of yellowcake, it does not mean that it is terribly dangerous. It is only four or five times what it would be if it were in soil. It should not happen because in all areas of nuclear technology one has to take a great deal of care. If one does not take care all the way along the line, one runs into trouble. In the United States Navy, which has operated nuclear power plants for many years, care in every area is one matter that is stressed most.

I believe that we should have been sensibly involved in the enrichment of uranium, but the Government has decided even to curtail experimentation in that area. The Government seems to have given in to what I call the ratbag element that says that all nuclear use is bad. I ask again: What would those people say if they needed some kind of radioactive medical product that could perhaps save their lives? I am sure it would be an entirely different story as to whether that nuclear plant at Lucas Heights, which produces about 100,000 doses a year, should be allowed to continue.

The Government has decided to move away from nuclear fuel cycle activities. So, in line with government policy, Australia is not involved in the cycle, except for the mining and milling of uranium and for the disposal of wastes. As an engineer I made it my business to visit Lucas Heights and examine the way waste disposal in Synroc is developing. I am very pleased that the Government intends to continue in that area. Just for the record, when uranium is irradiated in a light water nuclear reactor it is usually in there for three years. The initial 1,000 kilograms of fuel is composed of about 967 kilograms of uranium 238 and 33 kilograms of uranium 235. After three years the spent fuel still weighs the same-it is all contained inside the reactor-but of that 1,000 kilograms of fuel, the uranium 238 has dropped to 943 kilograms and the uranium 235, which is the radioactive part that is useful, has dropped to eight kilograms.

That leaves 49 kilograms of assorted fission products that are dangerous. Some of them are very dangerous. Some of them are dangerous in the long term and some in the short term. They are usually contained in storage chambers for an initial period prior to either reprocessing or final disposal. If reprocessing is the chosen option, the various chemicals within the assorted fission products are chemically extracted and the useful elements returned to the fuel cycle because they are very valuable. The remainder of the highly radioactive elements are stored in cooled containers. The safety and feasibility of the storage of these elements are well demonstrated. I think it was Senator Sanders who said that the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights has been in operation since 1958. That shows how reliable it is. Nuclear reactors have been operating in other areas of the world for a full 25 years.

It is not wise for people in Senator Sanders's situation to use scare tactics on people who sometimes are scared of the unknown. Many people do not quite understand how a nuclear reactor works. If one sits down and studies it, it is quite straightforward. It is an engineering problem. The problem with the Russian engineering was that they did not follow the usual containment policies that worked so well at Three Mile Island. The operation at Three Mile Island eventually closed down automatically by itself, which proved that the engineering was of the right design. Admittedly, there was some leakage but let us make a comparison. If one calls Three Mile Island a disaster, what would one have to call the accident in Russia? The Russian accident is certainly of much greater magnitude. I hope that people, and particularly scientists, in Russia will now reappraise their whole situation and realise just how important it is to take the care that has been recognised in other areas of the world-not only in the United States, but also in Germany, France and England-that must be taken in engineering projects that are as large as any nuclear power plant.

I was talking a moment ago about the Synroc experimentation that is going on at Lucas Heights. I believe that it will provide a very useful second generation storage system. At the moment, for the purposes of long term storage, resistant glass blocks encased in stainless steel are used. At present several such facilities are under commission or construction in Europe. I believe that Synroc will be more useful in the second generation because in some ways it will be better than glass. It will be more difficult, but there is a high degree of confidence that the Synroc system will be a much better storage system. Glass is good, but Synroc will be better still.

Last year the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, announced that Australia and Italy had agreed to co-operate in a research program dealing with high level radioactive wastes. There is to be an exchange of information. The two countries will collaborate in developing technology in the area I have just mentioned. Synroc, which is synthetic rock, was developed by Professor Ringwood of the Australian National University in Canberra. It is based upon incorporating radioactive elements into the very stable crystal structure of a particular type of synthetic rock. We also have agreements with the United Kingdom and Japan. Those agreements are a positive way that Australia can assist in radioactive waste management, something that is of interest to a great number of people in the world and certainly to the many countries that now operate nuclear power stations.

Just in case some people do not realise how many nuclear power stations there are, because in Australia we do not have many, I note that at the end of 1984 there were 318 nuclear power stations operating in some 26 countries, 200 under construction and a further 26 on order. As we all know, they are not all in the Western bloc. It is to be hoped that the stations in the Eastern bloc are following the designs and exchanging the information they should be exchanging with the scientists and engineers in the Western bloc who, I believe, have very nearly solved all the problems associated with nuclear power reactors.

I commend to those interested in nuclear power and the fuel cycle a reading of the status report 1985 of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. It is a very good document. It is removed from the hysteria that so often accompanies any mention of uranium or nuclear power. I instance the accident in Russia, which still has not been scientifically analysed. It has been analysed by the Press but not scientifically analysed. The report deserves wide reading, particularly by young people who have an open mind, as opposed to so many people in the world who seem to have closed minds.

My reading of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill is that, although it will change the name of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, it will not destroy the work at Lucas Heights in the very important areas I have already mentioned. It will encourage the important contribution that nuclear technology can make in the areas of medicine, science, industry and agriculture. The Atomic Energy Commission already does a great deal in the nuclear medical area. It supplies some 50 hospitals with a wide range of radiopharmaceuticals. For someone to say that a cyclotron will be able to replace that range of pharmaceuticals shows how little that person understands cyclotrons. Of course most of us here understand everything that a cyclotron does! I have made it my business to read a little about it, which obviously some people have not done. Senator Crowley, too, obviously understands that if a cyclotron were built in this country it would help add to the number of available radioactive pharmaceutical isotopes. A cyclotron by itself is not sufficient.

I wish ANSTO well. I will watch its progress in the future. I hope to visit the set-up at Lucas Heights again in the near future. I suggest to the Government that it should look at bringing in legislation to include the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region under the umbrella of ANSTO. At this stage I see absolutely no reason why the Supervising Scientist, who deals very much with the kinds of things that are studied by the high level scientists at Lucas Heights, could not be under the umbrella of ANSTO. It may well save this country a considerable amount of money if that is done. I believe that their aims and their expertise would mix very well and that the amalgamation of those two bodies could result in a significant saving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak for no more than about 10 minutes, under the Whip's instructions, and commend the Government on the introduction of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill 1985, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1985 and the Atomic Energy Amendment Bill 1985. I believe the legislation marks a very mature stage in this Government's grappling with the problem of the harnessing of the tremendous power of the uranium resources that we have in Australia in a way that is directed to peaceful uses for the benefit of humanity. In that regard, the orientation of the new Organisation, as set out in the functions listed in clause 5 of the principal Bill, are entirely proper and bear reading into the record. The Bill states that the major functions of the Organisation are:

SPEECH.PARA: To undertake research and development in relation to-
(i) nuclear science and nuclear technology;
(ii) the production and use of radioisotopes, and the use of isotopic techniques and nuclear radiation, for medicine, science, industry, commerce and agriculture;
and
(iii) such other matters as the Minister directs.

Before I stress those beneficial aspects of the harnessing of the atom, it is very important that it be noted that the Bill expressly places a prohibition on the Organisation undertaking research or development into the design or production of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. Of course, that prohibition is in total harmony with this Government's efforts over many years to secure a comprehensive test ban treaty in relation to nuclear explosive devices, not merely nuclear weapons. It brings to mind the international aspects of the importance of getting this Organisation to undertake activities within Australia that are in harmony with our international obligations.

One must recall that Australia is a party to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, which recognises the right of other countries to either commercial or peaceful exploitation of atomic energy. Therefore, we have an obligation, in supplying uranium to service that right of other nations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, to keep abreast of the latest science and technology involved in the production of such nuclear energy, and indeed an obligation to deal with the waste products of such endeavours. I will come to that shortly. What I want to emphasise is that the Government has taken this Organisation in hand and oriented its program in particular to the production and use of radioisotopes for medicine, science, industry, commerce and agriculture. I believe it is very significant that the Australian Democrats are not opposing this legislation. Even within the Democrats there has been a maturing of their attitude to nuclear matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really?

—Senator Walsh has shown some surprise and I know that, if Senator Townley were not in the chair, he would also have expressed an ejaculation of surprise from his normal seat. However, I recall that back in 1983, when the Democrats introduced into this place the Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware) Prohibition Bill 1983, it contained an absolute prohibition on the importation of hardware which would have allowed the reconstruction, refurbishing and continual development of the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights and associated facilities. It was pointed out in debate by honourable senators from this side of the House that that would have had a disastrous effect on the capacity of Lucas Heights to produce, for example, those medical radioisotopes that are so essential for the treatment and the alleviation of suffering and, in some cases, illness which would otherwise be fatal. In that respect their obsessive concern for the bad aspects of the harnessing of the atom, as expressed in the legislation that they brought in, would have done great harm, had the legislation been passed, to the health of the people of Australia. A year or so later, when they tried to introduce a similar Bill into this place for passage, they placed an amendment in the Bill which allowed for and recognised that the use of radioisotopes in particular for medicine, commerce and agriculture was a legitimate use. So even the Democrats have recognised that the processing of uranium in order to release some of its beneficial aspects for the service of humanity ought to be encouraged. This Bill would take that into proper practical application within this new Organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad that Senator Townley mentioned the thirty-third annual report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, which covers its activities during 1984-85. There one can read many pages of calmly presented programs which, on any reading, are undoubtedly of great benefit to Australia's hospitals, to those in pursuit of agriculture and to those involved in various industrial endeavours. In particular, it is to be noted that the Synroc project involves many research and development projects which, as I have already indicated in my opening remarks, are really part of Australia's obligation to the world. If we are to supply uranium, we have a moral obligation to use our best scientific endeavours to devise a scheme to trap the wastes in a way that will not be harmful to mankind over succeeding generations. Insofar as we have the scientific, engineering and technological expertise that could be of service to the world in this regard, I believe the Government is quite right to maintain an organisation that can carry through with international collaboration the further refinement and development of that process.

I wish to pass to another aspect of the Bill which finally removes from this body of legislation many legislative provisions which were quite obnoxious from a civil liberties point of view. When I first entered the Senate in 1978 I think the second or third speech I made was on the Atomic Energy Act, as it then was, when the Liberal Government was attempting to amend it in some way. I recall very vividly that the late Senator Alan Missen and I complained about the fact that the Act still contained provisions which were designed for the 1950s use of Australia's uranium resources, particularly the Rum Jungle resources, for the nuclear weapons developments of our allies, particularly, of course, the United Kingdom.

In that regard the legislation was littered with provisions that were explicable only if one was thinking of the development of uranium mining projects destined for a defence purpose. I need not reiterate the sorts of legislative provisions that were embodied in that legislation. But I am delighted to see that those particular provisions have been deleted from the Act; that is as it should be. In fact it may be remarked in passing that it was the common concern of Senator Missen and I, and some others around the chamber, that led to the conclusion that a scrutiny of Bills committee was required. Back in 1978, when the then Liberal Government was introducing legislation to deal with the commercial development of the Ranger deposits, it could have taken the opportunity to deal with these provisions, which, as I have said, were really conceived in a different era, but it did not. But had the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills been in operation at that time, it would have picked that up and helped debate to get under way in the chamber which would have led to deletion of those provisions before now. Insofar as the Government at this stage has brought in legislation which overcomes those obnoxious and tyrannical provisions, it makes this body of legislation a package which is worth commending to the Senate.

Finally, I note that the Government expresses in the second reading speech of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) an intention to bring into the Parliament legislation which will help to carry through our obligations under the South Pacific nuclear free zone agreement and the nuclear non-proliferation arrangements, to make it very clear that Australia will neither possess nor station on its soil nuclear weapons or nuclear explosive devices. It is essential that that legislation be brought in before the end of this session. I hope that the Ministers and the Caucus committee concerned can bring that to pass. Insofar as this legislation before us provides a sound legislative basis for the operations of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, I commend it to the Senate.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill is to establish the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation as a successor to the existing Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The Bill will provide a new organisation with functions which support current Government policy towards nuclear research and development. These will reflect the realignment of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission activities away from the present work on the nuclear fuel cycle towards a greater emphasis on the applications of radioisotopes and radiation in medicine, science, industry and agriculture.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides that ANSTO shall undertake research and development in relation to other matters not outlined in what I have already said, as the Minister in charge may direct. Further, the Minister shall give such a direction only if he is satisfied that the work would make effective use of the staff of the organisation and would not duplicate any activity being performed by other Commonwealth bodies. Other clauses prohibit ANSTO from undertaking any research or development into the design or production of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices and for the organisation to have regard to national science and energy policy objectives.

The general powers of the Organisation are given in a way which complements the work of other statutory authorities and replicates the general approach which is being taken to statutory authorities to allow them to enter into contracts; to hold or dispose of real or personal property; to occupy, use and control land or buildings; to undertake construction; to form or participate in companies; to appoint agents and attorneys or to act as agents; to engage persons to perform services; to design, produce, construct and operate equipment and facilities; and undertakings of that nature. The restrictions placed on ANSTO are similar to those placed on other statutory authorities in that ministerial approval is needed for the formation of subsidiary companies or taking shares in companies. Parliamentary oversight of the activities of ANSTO is, I believe, adequately catered for in this new piece of legislation.

The Atomic Energy Commission, as it has operated, has served Australia extremely well over two decades. I believe that the work of the Commission has established Australia as a leading participant in a large number of those activities related to the development of atomic energy and to the peaceful use of uranium and radioactive material. The Commission and the whole operation of the nuclear fuel cycle in Australia have been subject to a number of inquiries, the most significant of which was the inquiry undertaken by Professor Slatyer in his report on Australia's participation in the nuclear fuel cycle. I also draw attention to a report of the Australian Science and Technology Council, dated 4 November 1985, entitled `Nuclear Science and Technology in Australia'. ASTEC undertook a major review of the legislation and facilities for development of atomic energy in Australia. While I do not want to rehearse in detail the recommendations of that ASTEC report, I draw attention to the comments made in the report about the HIFAR reactor at the Atomic Energy Commission establishment at Lucas Heights, south of Sydney.

We heard today from Senator Sanders what I thought was a most scurrilous piece of fearmongering about the condition of the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights. That, I believe, not only does no credit in advancing the cause Senator Sanders seeks to advance, but also is very irresponsible and quite improper. The statements that were made about the status of the HIFAR reactor, its safety and the way in which it operates were entirely unjustified. If one looks at the report, one will see that certainly the HIFAR reactor is old; it is about 25 years old. Nevertheless, it has an impeccable record of safety and operation. It has provided, particularly in terms of radio- isotopes for use in medical technology, life-saving materials of considerable benefit to the whole Australian community. To make allegations about its unsafety or the extent to which it is a threat to the life, security and wellbeing of the people who live adjacent to the reactor is grossly improper.

I refer to a number of the activities currently undertaken by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission which will now be undertaken by ANSTO. I mention the sorts of things which rarely get much attention. For instance, the Commission is involved in projects such as undertaking major flow studies. These sound very exciting and perhaps a little pedestrian, but when one considers that work has been done for organisations such as the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd on the operation of its blast furnaces to improve the efficiency of its operation, one can see the very considerable industrial benefits that flow from the work the Commission has undertaken.

The Commission has done a great deal of work on the environment in studying things such as solar effect, the operation of sewage treatment works, and the disposal of wastes using material which is radioactive and can be monitored and traced. The Commission has made a very valuable contribution to the examination of environmental issues and the improvement of environmental conditions. It has done coastal engineering work in areas such as Port Brisbane on the question of how the port might avoid the problems of silt. It has done valuable work in the St Vincent Gulf in much the same fashion. It has looked at things as unromantic as termites, studying the way in which they have affected rural areas and destroyed historic buildings, and it has allowed steps to be taken for the conservation of the natural and man-made environment.

The Commission has played a role in assisting Australia's overseas aid program. Advice has been given to countries in the region, such as Malaysia, which has been of very considerable benefit to their national and scientific development. That has been done through the Atomic Energy Commission and has made a significant contribution to improving our relations and assisting in the development of less developed economies within the region.

A topic which undoubtedly will come before the Parliament from time to time and on which I have already asked a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Health, the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), is food irradiation. I happen to believe that the work which the Commission has been undertaking to identify correct procedures and standards for the irradiation of food in order to allow the preservation of food, to increase the shelf life of food, to avoid the financial losses which have occurred to producers and marketers because of the destruction and spoilage of food, has been a very valuable contribution. For instance, assistance has been provided to less developed countries as far as this is concerned. There has been a study of the meat trade with the Middle East-whether it will be possible to provide a system whereby meat can be treated in such a way as to preserve it for transport so as to help reduce our dependence on live sheep exports to the Middle East. It has looked at the fact that mushroom producers in Australia lose probably $1m a year because of wastage and spoilage of food which could be overcome by a proper program of food irradiation.

Lastly, I mention one of the important things that the Commission has done in terms of the study of water and soil problems in Australia. A study has been done of the Great Artesian Basin, tracing the element caesium 137 throughout the water table. It has been demonstrated that it may, in fact, take a million years for water to travel from its entry point to the west of the Great Dividing Range or from the Gulf of Carpentaria to the Centre. It is a distance of perhaps only 1,000 kilometres, but the study has made people conscious of the fact that in effect a mining of water takes place, that the artesian wells and bores represent a mining of water and that the water may not be as easily replaced, as plentiful, or as renewable a resource as people have previously thought to be the case. Elsewhere the caesium 137 studies have demonstrated that for every one tonne of wheat harvested in Australia something like 40 tonnes of topsoil has been lost. As honourable senators will know, we have had many debates in here about soil conservation and soil management programs. We have identified soil degradation and the loss of topsoil as one of the major areas which need to be attended to in the conservation of natural resources and the environment. That information has been largely provided by the studies undertaken by the Atomic Energy Commission.

Looking forward, one would hope that in the bids that Senator Evans might be making in Cabinet on the forthcoming Budget perhaps he will be in a position to advance the cause of the Atomic Energy Commission in terms of the provision of a cyclotron for that facility. As honourable senators will know, there has been a great deal of interest in that matter. There was an article in the Age on 13 April this year indicating that ASTEC, the Australian Science and Technology Council, the National Health Technology Advisory Panel and a medical cyclotron committee chaired by Dr Keith Lokan, a Melbourne physicist, have made recommendations about the location and siting of a cyclotron facility in Australia. At the moment we are not able to produce the full range of medical isotopes that we would like to be able to produce because of the absence of this very expensive state of the art piece of technology. I believe that the Atomic Energy Commission has an extremely strong case for that facility to be located at Lucas Heights, to make use of the existing technology and of the very high level of skill which is certainly available at that facility.

The production of stable isotopes is another area of activity which the Commission, and shortly the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, undoubtedly would want to be involved in. The production of molybdenum 98 for technetium production, which yields no fission products, could establish a world market which could be used as part of the promotion of a science and technology effort in the so-called sunrise industries which commend themselves very much to this Government. We know that the Atomic Energy Commission has been involved in working on ceramics and processes involving ceramics. There have been attempts to improve the quality of what is called PSZ, partially stabilised zirconia products, that have been a by-product of the development of the Synroc process in which the Commission has played a leading role. The Commission is clearly facing a number of problems which ANSTO will now face. In view of the important legislation about to be introduced, I seek leave to continue my remarks later, Mr Deputy President.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is to establish a Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry into the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy.

The Commission is to consist of 3 persons who are or have been Judges of a superior court. The terms of reference are set out in clause 5 and are to inquire and advise the Parliament whether any conduct of Mr Justice Murphy has been such as to amount to proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution.

It will be noted that the terms of reference provide for a potentially wide-ranging inquiry. This has been necessary because, notwithstanding his acquittals of criminal charges, allegations continue to be made against his Honour. It is necessary for the standing of the Judge and of the High Court that all allegations be dealt with one way or the other.

The width of the terms of reference is to be read in the light of clause 5(2), under which in carrying out its inquiry the Commission is to consider only specific allegations made in precise terms. Mr Justice Murphy is not to be required to give evidence before the Commission on a matter unless it is of the opinion that there is before the Commission evidence of misbehaviour sufficient to require an answer and the Commission has given the Judge particulars in writing of that evidence. These important requirements are intended to limit the inquiry to specific allegations, and also vexatious or irrelevant complaints to be summarily rejected by the Commission.

In addition, clause 5 (4) requires the Commission not to reopen issues dealt with in the trials leading to the acquittal of Mr Justice Murphy except to the extent it is necessary to do so in order to examine other issues in the performance of its inquiry. This includes in particular the issue of guilt or innocence of the charges laid, and whether the conduct the subject of the charges was such as to constitute proved misbehaviour in any other way.

The Commission is required by clause 6 (2) to base its findings on evidence admissable in a court of Law. It is to have all the normal powers of a Royal Commission, including the power to subpoena witnesses and call for documents and other material. This will include Mr Justice Murphy, where the Commission decides that there is a case to answer on the matter in question. As is normal for Royal Commissions, self-incrimination is no excuse for failing to answer, but the evidence cannot be used in any court proceedings other than for perjury. See clauses 16 and 27.

In order to enable the fullest possible consideration of the matters in issue, but in such a way as not to unduly prejudice the rights and reputations of individuals, the presumption is to be (subject to any decision to the contrary by the Commission) that the proceedings of the Commission will be conducted in private. (clause 7 (1)).

The Commission is to have access to documents and other materials of the Stewart Royal Commission, including tapes and tape transcripts and summaries, now held by the National Crime Authority. (clause 13 (1)). In considering any allegation it is to have regard to the outcome of any previous official inquiry into the allegation, and only consider it to the extent that the Commission considers it necessary or desirable to do so. (clause 5 (3)).

Under clause 8, the report of the Commission is to be furnished on or by 30 September 1986 unless both Houses extend that date. The Commission is to report to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives-
(a) its findings of fact; and
(b) its conclusions whether any conduct of Mr Justice Murphy has been such as to amount, in its opinion, to proved misbehaviour within the meaning of Section 72 of the Constitution.

As members appreciate, if it so reports it will still be for each House of Parliament to decide whether a case of proved misbehaviour within the meaning of Section 72 of the Constitution has been established. If the report is that there is no conduct that amounts to proved misbehaviour it will, I trust, be accepted by all members as putting the matters dealt with finally to rest.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, for the purpose of debating the second reading of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill 1986 and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing and Sessional Orders, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Durack) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) shall not speak for more than 20 minutes each and other senators shall not speak for more than 15 minutes.
I think the motion is self-explanatory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill 1986 into the Senate is an historic occasion and one of very great significance for the Parliament, and indeed for the appropriate operation of our Constitution. It is a Bill to establish a parliamentary commission of inquiry to inquire into certain matters and to advise the Parliament-I read from the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether any conduct of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy has been such as to amount, in its opinion, to proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution.

Why do I say that this is as an historic occasion? Surely, many people would say, establishing commissions of inquiries to inquire into numerous questions and to report on them is a very familiar aspect of the political landscape. These commissions are royal commissions or inquiries established by the Executive. They report to the Executive and, of course, in most cases the Executive tables the reports in the Parliament and action can be taken by the Executive, by the Parliament or by both.

In this case we are establishing, I believe for the first time, a commission of inquiry by the Parliament itself. The commission is to consist of three members appointed by resolution of the Senate and by resolution of the House of Representatives. Of course, the report will be to the Parliament. The reason for that is that the question on which this Commission is to inquire and to advise is a responsibility of the Parliament and of the Parliament alone; namely, the determination of whether a judge of a Federal court-in this case, the High Court of Australia-is guilty of proved misbehaviour. That is what the Constitution requires under section 72-proved misbehaviour which would justify an address by both Houses of Parliament to the Governor-General in Council for the removal of that judge from office. That is the only way in which a judge of a court created by this Parliament can be removed from office. Otherwise he or she has full protection under the Constitution until reaching the retirement age of 70 years.

It is important to note from the terms of this Bill that the Commission will inquire into and advise the Parliament whether any conduct of the judge, in its opinion, amounts to misbehaviour. I think that is also a very proper exercise of the constitutional power of this Parliament and of the functions of this Commission. It is being established by this Parliament to make those inquiries and to give that advice to the Parliament, certainly to make findings of fact, but only in a form which ultimately does not trespass upon the power and, indeed, upon the obligation of the Parliament to make those findings.

There are also, no doubt, questions about the standard of proof that would be required. The nature of the conduct which should or could amount to misbehaviour is another matter that this Commission will, no doubt, have to consider and advise the Parliament on. Those matters are not specifically dealt with in this Bill. They were dealt with in this Senate when it established the second committee, the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge. They were spelt out in the terms of reference of that Committee but I do not see any requirement for that and, indeed, I believe that the functions set out in this clause of the Bill appropriately express the constitutional position. The Parliament is establishing this Commission and is delegating to this Commission powers of inquiry, which the Parliament undoubtedly has-it may delegate those powers to its own Commission-and then ultimately it will have to deal with whatever the findings of fact and the advice of the Commission may be.

The Opposition will support this Bill, although we have some concerns about some aspects of it which I will deal with in a moment. It has been quite clear for a long time, probably for more than two years, that a number of grave concerns-certainly less than allegations, but concerns-about the behaviour of this particular judge required an investigation of this kind. When these matters surfaced a couple of years ago the Opposition took the view that an investigation was necessary. We debated it here at great length during the early part of 1984, which ultimately led to the establishment of a Senate select committee of inquiry into the authenticity of the Age tapes and whether there was anything in those tapes which might lead to findings of misbehaviour. As far as the Opposition was concerned, that was an unsatisfactory way of dealing with it.

The Opposition was very concerned that the Government was not prepared to co-operate in any way in conducting an inquiry of that kind and when that Committee reported it was even clearer that some independent persons should be appointed to make findings of fact and, indeed, to give advice to the Parliament on these matters. Again the Government would not co-operate. Indeed, we had calls from the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, for the matter to be dealt with in the criminal courts. We even had calls from the judge himself that criminal proceedings were the most satisfactory way of dealing with this matter. We always took the view that these matters were matters for the Parliament to resolve; they were not matters for the courts, they certainly were not matters for the Executive and they would have to be resolved in this Parliament in one way or another.

We know the history from then on, and I do not want to dwell on it at any great length. Undoubtedly, in the long run, it became obvious and necessary that this was the only path which would lead to these very grave, serious and disturbing questions being resolved. We on this side of the House resent suggestions that have been made that this has been a political witch hunt or indeed that there was a political trial, because that is far from the truth. We have, at all times, wanted this matter to be investigated and advice given to us by completely independent persons so that we could in a calm, sober and rational way exercise our responsibilities in relation to it.

Some of the concerns that the Opposition has with this Bill are whether or not the Commission as constituted under the terms of this legislation will perform this task to our satisfaction and to the requirements, indeed, that we have or should have as members of the Parliament charged with this responsibility. Certainly, I have praised the first sub-clause of the functions of the Commission. I will not go over that again. The second sub-clause talks about the Commission, in carrying out its inquiry, considering only specific allegations made in precise terms. We are somewhat concerned about this. We propose to ask some questions about it and maybe seek to amend it because we do not believe that, when a Commission is inquiring into something, it has to have some specific allegation at that inquiry stage.

Certainly the Commission should deal in the end, in the sense of making findings and advising us, only with specific allegations. Clearly misbehaviour cannot be proved by suspicion or what amounts to suspicion. There must be specific allegations of misbehaviour and specific charges.
