We are concerned whether at the inquiry stage this sub-clause may cut off the proper role of inquiry by the Commission virtually at its birth, thus rendering this whole exercise impotent in many respects. That arises particularly in relation to the Age tapes. This Bill gives the Commission access to all the material which was dealt with by Mr Justice Stewart and which was the subject of his report tabled in Parliament last week. It will be of little use to the Commission having that material made available if it cannot make full inquiries into the matters and what they may reveal and if it is to be cut off by saying that there are no specific allegations. In other cases there may well be specific allegations at the very beginning of the inquiry stage.

We are also concerned about sub-clause (4), in which it seems that the Commission is very limited in the inquiries that it can make into matters before the trials of Mr Justice Murphy. We prefer and will move an amendment to adopt the original provision in the Bill that was shown to us this morning. We think that it better expressed the Commission's need to make inquiries into those aspects of matters which will be before it. The Opposition is also concerned about the very strict provision that, in the conduct of its inquiry, the Commission shall not make a finding except upon evidence that would be admissible in proceedings in a court. We accept that in making its findings of fact upon which ultimately its advice will be given to the Parliament the Commission will require adequate evidence to make those findings. I cannot imagine judges doing otherwise when finding facts upon which a person may be deprived of his status, rights and entitlements as a judge. But the legislation again, the way it is worded, seems to cut off at a very early stage by the prefacing phrase `In the conduct of its inquiry'. That must be further examined.

The deepest concerns of the Opposition are in respect of two other provisions, one which requires that the Commission conduct its whole inquiry in private and the other that says that in its report to the Parliament it has to provide a record of only so much of the evidence as the Commission thinks is necessary to substantiate its findings and gives the Commission the power in submitting its report to the President or the Speaker of the House to require that some aspects of the report in certain circumstances shall not be reported but shall be the subject of a separate report to only the President and the Speaker. These two provisions seem to be quite at odds with the responsibility of this Parliament. In the end, to discharge our responsibilities, we must have access to all the material that was available to the Commission because ultimately we have to make the judgment whether the Commission's findings are justified and whether its advice is justified. Therefore, why do we have a commission of inquiry of this sort, all of which is to remain in private, on one of the most important questions which could arise under our Constitution and which has to be determined by this Parliament? There may be some circumstances in which it may be justified to sit in private but in accordance with all the traditions of the courts of this land and all the traditions of this Parliament an open and public inquiry for all to see and judge is a fundamental principle. To provide that it has to conduct its inquiry in private is absolutely contrary to that principle. As I said, the Opposition will move amendments and make some inquiries of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) about other aspects of this Bill. I hope that those have been circulated or will be circulated as soon as possible. The matters that I have canvassed are embraced in those amendments. I conclude by saying that we have had many debates in the Senate, particularly during 1984, about this matter. We hope that this Bill will be passed this evening and that the Commission will be established as soon as possible. We hope that it will be able to report as soon as possible and perhaps earlier than the reporting date in the legislation and that this will put an end to the matter. Whether that will place a further burden on us to make further decisions is another question. This is clearly the right way to go and the only way in which these grave questions touching the highest court in the land and devolving on us a very heavy responsibility can be properly and constitutionally determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate earlier approved special speaking times for this debate. There has been a request for rearrangement. Is there any objection to Senator Haines speaking for 20 minutes and Senator Chipp for 15?
—I want to speak on this matter. Have you limited my time, Mr Deputy President?
—Your time is limited to 15 minutes.
—I do not doubt that I can say what I need in 15 minutes but I object to the truncation of this time by arrangement.

—Order! The Senate earlier passed a motion on this matter. That is not in dispute. The question is whether we have a rearrangement to allow Senator Haines to speak for 20 minutes and Senator Chipp for 15 minutes. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its co-operation. The Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill 1986 we are debating in the Senate tonight establishes in an unprecedented manner a parliamentary commission of inquiry. After the second Senate select committee had met, considered various allegations, called and cross-examined witnesses and put forward its report, the Australian Democrats stated that, as far as we were concerned, the matter rested with the courts and that whatever the outcome of any full judiciary inquiry the matter would thus have been dealt with accordingly. I do not want to canvass details of events over the past few years but we have had two Senate inquiries and two court cases, and the last of those court cases resulted in Mr Justice Murphy being found not guilty of the charges laid against him. As far as we were concerned at that stage, that acquittal meant the end of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: However, other people felt differently and for a variety of reasons that I do not particularly want to canvass here, continued to agitate. Senator Durack said in his speech that what we had to do was to approach this matter in a calm and rational manner. Without wishing to attribute any motives whatsoever to anybody in this chamber, I would suggest that there is certainly in the public mind a distinct hint of a witch hunt. I do not think witch hunts can really be held in a calm and rational manner, not even when they are disguised under the terms of a parliamentary commission of inquiry.

We have a number of concerns about this Bill. We have those concerns partly because we do not believe that any additional inquiry of this or any other sort is necessary following the acquittal of Mr Justice Murphy at his last trial. However, part of the concerns deals with the contents of the legislation before us. I have raised these concerns with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), and with the Attorney-General's representative in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. I acknowledge that some of these concerns have been picked up-I thank the Government for this-and have been included in the legislation before us tonight. However, one which concerns me and which concerns my Party considerably is the frequent reference within this Bill to the words relating to the meaning of proved misbehaviour under section 72 of the Constitution.

One of our problems from the beginning has been that there is no definition of proved misconduct in the Constitution. It is extremely difficult to work out just what the meaning of section 72 (ii) is. We know that it relates to the need for an address from both Houses of Parliament to the Governor-General on proved misbehaviour or incapacity before a judge of the High Court of Australia can be removed. But there is no definition of that, despite the fact that the 1897 debates canvassed this whole question quite considerably. This means that we are left with something which unfortunately is particularly subjective. As a result, views will differ about what proved misbehaviour is and the criteria used to prove that misbehaviour.

During the debates in 1897 the question of the American situation was raised and the problems that that country had. I think it is worth while for us to look back at what the founding fathers intended for section 72 and why they included the words `misbehaviour' and `incapacity' in the first place. Speaking on 20 April, Mr Glynn pointed out in relation to the United States Congress:

. . . even went to the length of endeavouring to deprive the Supreme Court of a portion of its jurisdiction when they found the judges did not fall in with the views of some of the representatives of Congress. In the United States . . . there is power to interfere with the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
In America attempts have been made to take away the jurisdiction of the judges where the judges were not complacent to Parliament.

I do not think it is going too far to suggest that, if we are not very careful indeed, we will lead ourselves into the situation where proved misbehaviour is defined as something caused by judges who are not complaisant to Parliament. At the stage this debate had reached when that comment was made, the original section 72 contained no reference at all to what criteria were going to be used to remove a judge of the High Court, other than that an address by two Houses of Parliament was required. Mr Glynn went on, however, to question the integrity of members of parliament by saying:
You-
that is, the other speakers-
leave it to the discretion of the two Houses of Parliament to remove a judge, but that power should be put in their hands.
Sir William Zeal interjected:
Is it dangerous to be connected with politics?
Mr Glynn went on:

It should not be regarded as a danger to have the matter connected with politics; but there is the fear of having a repetition of what has occurred in America, and the likelihood is greater here that under the inception of the system there, because with the larger franchise, we are so subject to being swayed by popular opinion.

I think that is something we all ought to remember. A very grave miscarriage of justice is likely if what we do in this place is subject to the pressures coming from popular opinion. As a consequence of those comments and some others, Mr Kingston moved to amend the proposal. He said:

I think we should be at great pains to secure the absolute independence of the Judges of the Federal Court, particularly of the Judges of the High Court of Australia, who are intended to adjudicate on matters which may affect the Federal Executive and the Federal Parliament. To my mind we shall be committing a glaring mistake if we do not protect these judges from ill-considered action either by the Federal Executive or by the Federal Parliament.
He went on:
Besides the first declaration that he shall hold office during good behaviour,-
that is, the judge shall hold office during good behaviour-
we have also this:
May be removed by the Governor in Council upon Address from both Houses of Parliament in the same Session, praying for such removal.
He continued:
It strikes me that if you pass that the effect will be that on the address of both Houses a Judge can be removed independently of whether or not he has been guilty, and that should not be so.

He went on to say that the clause should be amended to include the words `misconduct', `unfitness' or `incapacity'. As usual in debates of this kind, and this was no different from our own, there was some discussion about this. The word `unfitness' was left out and the word `misbehaviour' was substituted for the word `misconduct'. The founding fathers had no doubt at all about the fact that the Parliament had to have something other than its own beliefs about the behaviour of a particular judge when it came to the extremely serious matter of removing a judge from his position. The people involved in this debate clearly believed, as Mr Isaacs went on to point out a little later, that the issues mentioned in Todd in his book On Parliamentary Government in England should obtain. On page 191 Todd says:
Misbehaviour included, first, the improper exercise of judicial functions;

While we are on that point I wonder whether the reported-I stress that it was only reported-suggestion by a number of High Court judges that they would not sit with Mr Justice Murphy constitutes an improper exercise of judicial functions. Todd went on:

second, wilful neglect of duty, or non-attendance; and, third, a conviction of any infamous offence, by which, although it be not connected with the duties of his office, the offender is rendered unfit to exercise any office or public franchise.
He went on to stress:
In the case of misconduct outside the duties of his office the misbehaviour must be established by a previous conviction of a jury.

There was no question that when the founding fathers amended section 72 they were intending that misbehaviour would be judged according to whether a previous conviction of a jury had been determined. We are concerned too that the Bill allows the three judges-assuming the Government can find three judges to sit-to determine what, in their opinion, is proved misconduct under the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. I would suggest that this is leaving the whole thing wide open to a High Court challenge from whoever has standing in this case with regard to exactly what the word meaning in the Bill means.

Given that the Australian Democrats are opposed to the inquiry in the first place and will oppose the Bill at the second reading stage, we are nonetheless concerned that since it is a fait accompli-because the Opposition is supporting, indeed it is enthusiastically encouraging, the Government in establishing the inquiry-the terms be as fair as possible. Therefore we believe it is appropriate that only specific allegations made in precise terms should be considered. The presumption that the inquiry should be held in private, while itself presenting some problems, we acknowledge, avoids the airing of all sorts of scuttlebutt that a public inquiry would necessarily entail. Therefore we cannot accede to the Opposition's amendment that the inquiry be public unless the Commission wishes it to be held in camera. Having in camera hearings might leave us open to suggestions that this a star chamber, that there are secret hearings and that there may be cover-ups. I suggest that to a very large extent we absolve ourselves of any of those sorts of allegations through clause 8 (1) (3), which insists:
The Commission shall submit with its report-
that is a public report which it is obliged to make to the Parliament-
a record of so much of the evidence before the Commission as the Commission thinks necessary to substantiate its findings of fact and its conclusions.

In other words, the Commission is obliged to provide the Parliament with evidence that has led it to make findings of fact and not simply to strew around the place all sorts of allegations and scuttlebutt which may or may not turn out to have any grounds for belief at all. What we have to remember when we talk about the value of having a public inquiry is that unfortunately no rules of evidence exist in the public forum; that allegations are frequently regarded as facts by those people who would like to believe them; that the media, whether it does it deliberately or not, frequently places selective emphasis on those things that it publishes and in doing so can distort, in the public's mind, the issues that are before the inquiry or the Parliament.

We do not believe that the inquiry will necessarily resolve the issue. If proved misbehaviour-whatever that means in the opinion of the three judges-is found, is the Government going to be prepared to accept that and to act under section 72? I stress that the initiative must come from the Government, and that means that the first move, if misbehaviour is found, must come as an address from the House of Representatives. If no proved misbehaviour is found, will the Opposition parties accept that or will they continue to pursue the matter? I would have hoped that they would accept it, but this morning I listened to the Opposition spokesperson on this matter, Mr Spender, saying on Channel 9 that it was quite within the powers of the Parliament to disagree with the judges and to go ahead as it saw fit, notwithstanding any decisions or reports made by those three judges.

I repeat: This inquiry will not necessarily resolve the issue. We have over our heads the spectre of a High Court challenge with regard to the meaning of proved misbehaviour. We have the possibility that if some is found the Government will not act and if some is not found the Opposition parties will continue on their merry little way in their intent to get Mr Justice Murphy no matter what else happens as a consequence.

What worries us a great deal is something that I alluded to early in my speech: The Government may well have taken the action it has taken in bringing this Bill before us as a result of actions that other High Court judges have purported to have taken in refusing to work with Mr Justice Murphy. The real danger in this situation, if it has been accurately reported, is that the other High Court judges, without any constitutional power to do so, are effectively setting a precedent whereby they can indirectly determine who their fellow judges will be. It opens the way for some future new appointment, perhaps, to be objected to by a number of other High Court judges who do not like something about that judge.

TALK.START.PARA: —A self-assumed right of veto.

—As Senator Chipp says, it is a self-assumed right of veto if the judges' actions have been accurately reported. I find that at least as great a slur on the High Court as anything that people allege Mr Justice Murphy could have done to that high judicial office. We oppose this piece of legislation because we oppose the establishment of the inquiry. We do not consider it necessary, given past events. We hope that, since the Opposition is joining the Government in this extension of what can only be termed a witch hunt, at the end of it all the matter will rest on the findings of the three judges and we can get on with what I believe are far more important pieces of legislation than we have to deal with in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose there is one slight advantage in being in political limbo; I can assume the right to speak, having no other forum in which to express my views. You might recall, Mr Deputy President, that from the very start I was opposed to the inquiries that were set up. I said that the first inquiry would create precedents and lead to situations over which we have little control. That has proved to be correct. The inevitable result of those early inquiries was to bring us to this point. We are now faced with a continuation of the exercise which, if it were merely a political exercise, would be of continuing interest to us. However, as we continue and extend this inquiry we continue the agony of a person who, for two years, has been placed on a pillory, has been scrutinised and examined and has had his personal life brought under close examination. I would have thought that once he was acquitted that would have been the end of the matter. I believe that the inquiries held two years ago should never have been commenced.

SPEECH.PARA: We now find ourselves going through another unnecessary exercise, but to the person concerned it is an extension of an experience that should never be the experience of any citizen in this country. What I find abhorrent is that at the very time that we are debating this matter-during the day and even at night-the home of the person concerned is under the closest scrutiny by the media, which have determined that they should work not at the highest levels but at the meanest levels. We are really engaged in a process which has been thrust upon us by a certain section of the Press which has determined that a particular individual, by innuendo and secondary means, shall be exposed and shall be destroyed. I believe that we are party to that destruction. If it had not been for the tremendous courage and tenacity of the person concerned, Mr Justice Lionel Murphy, they would have achieved that result earlier by way of resignation.

I am surprised that the Opposition, in spite of the soft words of Senator Durack, continues to approach this with what can only be described as political savagery. When one examines it, that is exactly what it is about, and it has been revealed by Mr Spender in his remarks in the other place and by Senator Durack, more quietly and perhaps more politely, that the examination will go on. The exercise of this Commission will come up with the same result-an exoneration of Mr Justice Murphy. But in spite of that, we will go through the exercise that we should be going through right now if the Opposition were determined to succeed.

At last the Democrats have seen the light. In spite of two Senate inquiries, they have seen that there was nothing else to find-nothing to find, in fact. The jury in less than three hours, given the right advice from the bench-and that is critical of the previous advice, and perhaps I should not be critical of a judgment-was able in a short time to come to a conclusion which we in this Parliament should have accepted. But that is not the purpose of the whole exercise. The purpose of the exercise is to discredit and destroy a justice of the High Court. In so doing we destroy not only that person but the court itself. The damage to that institution about which I warned at the time, as did other people, is beyond repair.

I believe in political appointments to the High Court. I believe that a person who has served in this Parliament on either side of the House and who has the legal qualifications should be appointed to the High Court. Eventually we shall extend the High Court's numbers to enable it to carry out its responsibilities. It is necessary to appoint to the High Court people with political experience. They will have to assess legislation which comes from the Parliament. They will be aware of the format of that legislation but they will have to give it a human face. My view is that political appointments are a necessary process of achieving that result. The High Court will do as much to change the attitudes in our society as we do in this place.

The appointments we have made politically have been sound, but what have we endeavoured to do by our Standing Orders, which we have breached so remarkably on both sides of the House in the past two or three years? The Standing Orders say that once we make the appointment that judge should be free, without criticism from this place, to carry out his duties and his responsibilities. We had sufficient faith in the integrity of the people appointed to believe that they would carry out their legal function fairly. There may have been one or two breakdowns, nonetheless in the long run it has been a success.

My view is that, once we attempted to scrutinise the personal behaviour of a justice of the High Court, we were engaging in a dangerous exercise. In this case it has been an unfair exercise which should never have been initiated, because many of us knew the reputation of this person. We also knew his weaknesses, which we should have considered to be his strength. But we continue to pillory the person and we continue to do damage to the institution. We do things in haste. If we had reflected on what was being said even by High Court judges-and I agree with Senator Haines that it ought not to have been said-we might have discovered that the advice was not as it appeared in the first place.

If we had discovered that, we could have resiled a little, moved away. But it seems to me, looking at the matter, having come coldly back from a different environment into this political madhouse which seems to have developed, that the advice given to the Attorney-General may have been the opinion of one judge and one judge alone. If it was the opinion of one judge and one judge alone, that judge has allowed himself to fall into error. But it is an error that we forced him into because we created the situation in which that judge became involved. Again, the Standing Orders prevent my canvassing this; but, in the long run, the truth will be revealed. If one is seeking the truth, one should not proceed in haste. What are we doing now? A Bill to set up a commission and to create a precedent was dealt with by the other place in an hour. We are here now, held back from our normal program, to determine the matter here tonight and here also we are truncating the debate on the issue.

My view is-and this is the view of the Democrats-that there should be an end to this. But since the determination has been otherwise, I suggest that we expedite this exercise, get it over, and then reflect on the whole process when the report of the Commission comes back. I am certain, given the wisdom of the terms of reference, which the Opposition for some reason seeks to amend, that there can be only one conclusion to this inquiry-that there is no case, and never has been, for Mr Justice Murphy to answer. Then we should leave it at that. I am beginning to believe that that might not be the case, having viewed the process that we have followed.

There has been a political motivation to all this; there has been error after error on both sides; there has been error on the part of those who have become involved. Do not let us become an instrument of those who in secret listen to communications between people. In many cases they obtain information illegally, information that is moved around by rumour, that surfaces in the Parliament under privilege, forces us to an inquiry and gets us involved in this mess in which we now find ourselves. We could have completed the matter after the first inquiry. I remember Senator Chipp agonising. It could have gone either way. He wanted more information, as was his right. But if he had gone the other way, there would have been an end to the matter.

When we came to the second inquiry and we went through that exercise appointing some sort of commission to assist us, and the four senators we appointed went through that traumatic exercise, at one stage it was possible that the whole matter could have been brought to an end if the individual who was under stress had been differently advised. I remember the conversation and the advice I sought from Senator Tate and Senator Haines on that afternoon as to whether it was too late for the judge to appear. They said: `No, it is not too late; it would extend the inquiry by a week, but we do not really believe that it is necessary'. Upon that basis perhaps the person concerned did not appear before that Senate Committee. Now when I look at that decision, I believe that it was the wrong decision and the wrong advice.

All these situations which are created in this way depend on minor incidents, minor decisions, unexpected situations. I would have thought that when the acquittal came down we should have put the National Times to one side, we should have put the rumour to one side. We should then have proceeded to bring the matter to an end. If the Opposition had decided otherwise, it could have put a substantive motion before the House which we could have determined. My view, based on the Democrats' attitude, is that that would have brought the whole matter to an end. We have now extended it unnecessarily. I regret that. The Senate ought now to proceed to pass this legislation, get the Commission appointed, seek an early result by 1 September and hope that the matter then is at an end.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Senate passed a motion changing the time of adjournment from 6.30 p.m. to 10.30 p.m. It is obviously the wish of the Senate to continue sitting. I did not interrupt Senator Georges while he was speaking. In order to formalise proceedings, I now put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This is certainly an historic but certainly not a happy day for the Parliament, nor is it a happy day for the nation. I say very clearly to the Senate that there is no glee and no witch-hunt on this side of the Parliament. Any suggestion that there is or has been a witch-hunt would have to be directed towards me because I was on both the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge and the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge. I wish to give a brief resume of what I did in relation to both Senate committees. In the first Committee report in August 1984, Senator Durack and I put down a joint report in which we said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a prima facie case of misbehaviour against the judge.
We then made it very clear that that was very much a preliminary finding. In paragraph 19 of our report we said:
We stress that we are not finding that misbehaviour has been proved. It would not accord with the principles of natural justice to make such a finding at this stage.

So that was very much a preliminary finding. We made it clear at that stage that there would be a need for a proper hearing. We asked-indeed, we begged-the Government to set up a proper hearing. I say to honourable senators opposite who are unhappy about what is happening tonight that we did not have a proper hearing because of Senator Gareth Evans. If Senator Gareth Evans had been giving the Government the advice it should have been getting at that stage we would have had a proper hearing then and it would have been all over.

We asked the Government to establish a parliamentary commission of inquiry, which is what we are in the process of establishing now. The Government would not do so. So we set up the second committee, the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge. In that Committee, I found that a prima facie case had been established. That prima facie case was also, I might say, held by Senators Tate and Haines, but they held that it was on the balance of probabilities. My view was that the evidence was uncontradicted by sworn evidence of His Honour. The inevitable conclusion of that was that the case had to be held to be proven beyond reasonable doubt. I still say that my decision was right, notwithstanding the criticisms which have been made about my decision.

I say that my decision was right because subsequently my decision was supported-I draw the attention of honourable senators to this-firstly by the magistrate who committed His Honour for trial and then by the judge of the first trial, who was strongly pressed to say that there was no case to answer but who allowed the case to go to the jury. My decision was then supported by the first jury. Then, after the first jury, five judges of the New South Wales Court of Appeal, having heard all the evidence and argument and having had it strongly represented to them that the case ought not to have been allowed to go to the jury, held that the case should have gone to the jury and that there was evidence which could convict. They ordered a retrial. I believe that that establishes beyond any shadow of doubt that the decision I came to in the second Senate inquiry was a proper and valid decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —What result?

—I will finish the story by saying that the fact that the second jury acquitted His Honour in no way detracts from my conclusion, which was that there was a case to answer. I deny that anyone on this side of the chamber is out to get His Honour. I draw Senator Georges's attention to the fact that this Bill is the Government's Bill; it is not the Opposition's Bill. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber are absolutely determined to face up to the responsibility imposed on us by section 72 of the Constitution. Where a Federal judge is impeached, the Constitution imposes on each one of us in this chamber and each member of the other chamber ultimately to determine where there has been proved misbehaviour. That will be the decision ultimately of each honourable senator and of me. We can seek assistance, as we are doing in this Bill, but ultimately it will be our decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the second Senate Committee report. In that report, I raised four other matters for consideration, one of which has been dealt with. I raised in the report-I was the only one to do so-the evidence of His Honour Judge Flannery, which has now been dealt with, as have the criminal allegations. I raised three other matters in that report which have not been dealt with. They are set out on pages 5 and 6 of my report. I refer to one matter in particular because I hope that when the commissioners are considering the allegations in this matter they will consider the following allegation. I quote what I said:

There is evidence before the Committee of comments made by Mr Justice Murphy to the Chief Magistrate about what is colloquially referred to as `the Social Security Conspiracy Case'. There are two points about the comments:

(i) they were made at a time when the charges were being heard by a magistrate so that they may have been improperly made and with an intention to pervert the course of justice or may have been a contempt of the court, and

(ii) they were made by a judge of the High Court who subsequently was called upon to make findings on appeal about some aspects of the case and who may reasonably have supposed that he would be required to do so.

As I said, I hope that the commissioners will apply their minds to that evidence and also to the other two matters which I have raised and which are substantiated by the reports of Mr Xavier Connor and Mr John Wickham to the Committee.

Turning to the Bill that is before the Senate, there are two absolutely crucial points in this matter. The first is: What is the definition of proved misbehaviour? The second is the standard of proof to be adopted. When the Senate Committee met it had before it two definitions of misbehaviour, one by the Solicitor-General and the other by Mr Pincus. The Senate Committee was required by the Senate to apply its mind to those two definitions. This Bill does not contain either of those definitions. So one is led to believe that in due course the commissioners will determine for themselves the proper definition of proved misbehaviour. They will ultimately advise the Parliament of what is the proper definition of proved misbehaviour in their view.

The other definition is the standard of proof to be adopted-whether it will be on the balance of probabilities or beyond reasonable doubt. That undoubtedly will be a matter to which the commissioners will have to apply their minds. The simple matter is that the Commission will need to determine the facts and advise us of the facts as they have so determined them. It will also advise us as to the law to be applied in a section 72 case. The terms of reference set out for the second Senate Committee, in my view, probably were much better than the terms of reference set out in the Bill. Nevertheless, we are stuck with the Bill. We need an assurance that all the evidence available to both Senate committees, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions and the National Crime Authority will be made available to the commissioners. It seems that that has been covered in the second reading speech, although I will be pleased to hear Senator Evans repeat more or less what he said on television tonight, when I thought he made it perfectly clear that there would be no attempt to restrict that evidence.

There are a couple of other matters to which I wish to refer. The first is my concern about the hearing being kept in secret. The truth of the matter is that, unfortunately, the material will leak. Journalists will make their investigations and their inquiries and undoubtedly there will be people who will believe that they have something to gain by telling the journalists some aspects of the story. The inevitable result of that is that some aspects will be leaked for specific purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the judges?

—Not at all by the judges. So many people will be involved in the inquiry that someone will undoubtedly leak material for their own purposes. Senator Chipp was on one of the committees and he saw material being leaked daily from that committee, so he ought to be well aware of the truth of what I have just said.
—Not by the staff.

—If Senator Chipp is volunteering that it was he who leaked the material, that is his business. I am just saying that the truth is that material will be leaked for specific purposes. That is a tragedy. Ultimately, when the commissioners bring down their report, because the hearings have been secret people will have some doubts about what happened. They will have some doubts about the nature of the inquiry. The result will be that there will be doubts in the minds of some people about the decisions of the commissioners, whichever way they find. That is one of the tragedies of the Government's decision to have the hearing in secret.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I wish to raise is that of specific allegations referred to in clause 5 (2) of the Bill, which states:
In carrying out its inquiry the Commission shall consider only specific allegations made in precise terms.

I would like Senator Evans to tell the Senate what he believes clause 5 (2) of the Bill means. I presume that, as with the second Senate inquiry, what will happen is that counsel advising the commissioners will consider all the evidence to the commissioners and will draw up a series of allegations on the basis of that evidence. Then in due course His Honour will be given an opportunity to respond to those allegations. Unfortunately, I see that Senator Gareth Evans is so involved in discussion with Senator Haines that he is not listening to what I say. I hope that his advisers will ultimately tell him what I have said so that he can respond.

I wish to draw to the Senate's attention the difficulty created for us on the second Senate Committee when that procedure was adopted. Ultimately, when we got around to the closing address, counsel assisting the Senate inquiry pointed out to us that the evidence had raised a fresh allegation. The allegations having been drawn at the beginning and all of the evidence having been considered, by the time we got to the end of the evidence a fresh allegation had arisen out of that evidence. Counsel pointed out that it was probably too late to deal with that fresh allegation because that would have meant that the judge would have to be given an opportunity to respond to that allegation. That is one of the difficulties with having undefined allegations. It is not that I disapprove of it; I simply ask Senator Evans to tell the Senate how he believes that it will work.

Finally, I wish to say that everyone on this side of the chamber hopes that this Commission will ultimately be the end of this disastrous affair so far as the High Court of Australia is concerned. We wish the Commission well. We hope that it will be able to get on with this business quickly, come to a decision, and help us to solve the problems we face under section 72 of the Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would not be an honourable senator here who would not say hear, hear, to the last sentence of Senator Lewis's speech, but I very much doubt whether this Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry will solve the problem. In fact, I am almost certain in my mind that this inquiry will solve absolutely nothing; that after it is over, notwithstanding its findings, we will be back exactly where we are today. The country will probably be $3m to $4m poorer, the time of three valuable judges will have been spent for six months, and the work of the High Court of Australia will have been clogged up in the meantime.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight people have talked about tragedy, and I share that view, but in my mind one of the greatest tragedies of the whole saga that now goes back over two and a half years is that, in the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge, the first Senate inquiry to investigate the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, evidence given against him was given not by some fruitcake or some lightweight in the community but by a chief stipendiary magistrate in New South Wales, a highly respected man who I believe associated with the Australian Labor Party, who made the most grave accusations against Mr Justice Murphy. His evidence was tested on two occasions under the most savage cross-examination-as savage as politicians can be-for about a day. As I understand it, the majority of senators on that Committee could not shake Mr Briese in his testimony that he believed Mr Justice Murphy intended to pervert the course of justice. I have always held the view that an accusation made against another human being is one thing; that no matter how honourable the person making the accusation is, the person who is accused must have the right to respond; and that if the respondent is as convincing or as honest as the accuser, every time I would find no result. I would find in favour of the accused. I expect that every honourable senator would share that view. That is the basis of Australian fair play.

However, on the advice, I assume, of some people-to this day I do not know whether it was the highly paid legal advisers to Mr Justice Murphy, whether it was any of his parliamentary colleagues or a senator on the Committee-but in any case for some reason Mr Justice Murphy chose not to come to that Senate Committee and be cross-examined on the accusations. I believe that from that moment on the position has got worse. I say with great sincerity that if persons did advise him not to appear at that Committee, and indeed at the hearings of the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge, the second Committee, those people today carry an enormous responsibility for what has happened and what is happening to Mr Justice Murphy.

I have come to the view, as have my colleagues-the Australian Democrats are unanimous on this-that this inquiry should not be held, for the simple reason enunciated by Senator Haines. We have now had two exhaustive and efficiently performed Senate inquiries into the alleged misconduct of Mr Justice Murphy and, out of those inquiries, two court cases. Maybe this is shorthand, but the net result of those two Senate inquiries and the two court cases is that a jury has acquitted Mr Justice Murphy on all or any charges against him. That was a few weeks ago. So I would have thought that, in terms of Australian fair play, at that point the slate was clean.

Since then there have been two events. The first was accusations by a former policeman about the Greek conspiracy case. That was properly referred by the prosecutor at the trial, Mr Callinan, to the Director of Public Prosecutions, who examined the accusations. The Director of Public Prosecutions then made a determination that the evidence was of such a character that no prosecution could or should be made.

The other event was the production, fortuitously so soon after the acquittal, of the second, confidential part of the report of Mr Justice Stewart's Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions of which I was privileged to receive a copy in confidence. While one cannot breach that confidence, I believe it is proper for me to say that my reading of that second part of the report would not lead me to the view that Mr Justice Stewart had recommended a prosecution against Mr Justice Murphy on any matters associated with that report.

Where does that leave us? It leaves us with a human being and his family who have gone through 2 1/2 years of hell. Nobody here would know the kind of hell Mr Justice Murphy has been through and is going through. He has suffered four savage examinations of his conduct or alleged misconduct and at the present time his slate is absolutely clean except for certain information-if one could put it that high-rumours or innuendo that go around the place. To investigate those matters, the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill asks the Parliament to authorise God knows how much money-I am putting it at $3m or $4m and six months time, conservatively. Therefore, the Australian Democrats will vote against the second reading. Our vote will be virtually irrelevant because I take it that the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party will be voting for it.

When we get to the Committee stage we will argue that the terms of reference by and large are fair and reasonable. We are deeply worried about the implications of some of them, particularly that we as a parliament are giving to a group of three judges the responsibility that we cannot or are not game to handle here; that is, of defining what is proven misbehaviour. I have come to the view, after closely examining all of this material about Mr Justice Murphy, that we ought to grasp the nettle and try to come up with a definition. At first I was against the proposal of Dr Gavan Griffith, which I am not capable of describing, but at least it is something, and the core of that is that we have to have some measurement of what is proven misbehaviour. The Griffith point essentially is that misbehaviour is only criminal misbehaviour of such a nature which would interfere with the performance of his duties as found in a criminal court of law. I know that it is not perfect-I know that judges, policemen and politicians can engage in misbehaviour of another kind that is not necessarily criminal-but at least it is a test. It is not a subjective judgment. The way we have it now, it must be subjective.

I am terrified of subjective judgments because I spent three years as the Minister for Customs and Excise when I was the Chief Censor of this country and had to make subjective judgments as to what was moral or immoral. One thing I learned very savagely in those years was that the judgment about what is moral or not is very subjective and it differs from person to person. If we took two decent, honourable people and let them examine the same behaviour, the chances are that one would say `that is immoral' and the other one would say `that is moral'. The interesting thing is that the subjective judgment of morality changes even in one person from year to year. If we examine our own attitudes, all of us will see that today we think of an act differently from the way in which we thought of it 10 or 15 years ago. People's subjective judgment varies after they have had children, et cetera. Not only are we not defining `proven misbehaviour'; we are allowing three judges to advise us, after receiving learned advice from the Solicitor-General's Office, et cetera. That worries me.

The thing that also worries me is the matter properly referred to by Senator Lewis; that is, the standard of proof. On what standard of proof are we asking or directing the judges to come to a judgment about misconduct? When the judges get their commission, will they determine whether Mr Justice Murphy is guilty of proven misbehaviour on the test of beyond reasonable doubt or will they come to a judgment on the balance of probabilities? It is quite possible or probable that the judges will have to bring down two judgments, because the strength of the two tests varies and we have given them no lead.

We believe that the proposition that all of the inquiry be held in public is outrageous. I hope that the Opposition has thought this through. The Opposition knows that any royal commission or commission of this kind flushes every fruit-cake in Australia out of the woodwork. Royal commissions about scandal attract people who have a grudge, who want to come out and be a sensation or who want to allege misconduct of some kind. Is the Opposition saying that, if some person wants to make the most outrageous accusation about Mr Justice Murphy, which perchance is totally untrue, absolutely baseless and incapable of corroboration, that should be allowed to be stated in public? That would give licence to the media to put it on page one. What happens to the poor devil whose character and reputation is blackened?

We have had in Sydney recently a version of this, in a different sense, involving a certain lady of unfortunate repute-the notorious Love Boat scandal. It is now obvious that that was a total fabrication. If such allegations were made to this Commission in public, they would be splattered across the front pages of the newspapers and every television station under privilege. It might be said that the next day or the next week counsel for Mr Justice Murphy could wipe clean the slate; but the slate can never be wiped clean on a thing like that, as everybody knows. I believe that there is adequate protection in this Bill for that, because if the Commission finds a proven act of misbehaviour on the evidence given in secret and if the Commission wants every member of parliament to believe it and accept its recommendations it will have to publish the evidence upon which it came to that conclusion. I believe that is the protection we get from having some of these matters heard in secret.

I conclude, because Senator Haines has adequately covered most of the points, on something which disturbs me. Today I spoke at length with a well-known professor of constitutional law. I put to him a question about certain reported actions of the six High Court judges last weekend. I said: `Is it arguable that if one or more of the six judges threatened not to sit with Mr Justice Murphy this could be evidence of proved misconduct?'. His reply was: `It could provide evidence of the judge's proved misconduct'. He said that the fact that the judges would not sit with Murphy, if indeed that was the case, means that they are suggesting Mr Justice Murphy's guilt by implicit suggestion. What bothers me even more is outlined in paragraphs 1106 and 1107, at page 680 of volume eight, on constitutional law, of Halsbury's Laws of England:
``Misbehaviour''--
he is specifically referring to a judge--
as to the office itself means improper exercise of the functions appertaining to the office, or non-attendance, or neglect of or refusal to perform the duties of the office.
I believe it is pertinent tonight to ask ourselves as politicians: Did one or more of the judges refuse to sit, and what sort of position does that put the High Court in today?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am grateful to honourable senators for their speedy and, by and large, dignified consideration of this momentous Bill, the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill 1986. However, I think we could have done without some of the selective recall and crocodile tears of Senator Lewis in his contribution. To the extent that there were criticisms of particular aspects of this Bill, or questions raised about it, I think it is more appropriate to pick those up at the Committee stage rather than endeavour to reply to them in any global way at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators Haines, Chipp and Georges were critical, of course not so much of particular aspects of this Bill but of its very existence, taking the view that a commission of inquiry of this kind is simply not necessary. Let me say that there is much in their speeches and the opinions which they expressed with which I agree.

I personally have fought very long and hard-and have endured much criticism myself in the process, much of which has been of a kind which makes Senator Lewis's criticism tonight seem by comparison a mere bagatelle-to ensure that each allegation, as it has arisen during the whole course of this matter, and there have been many of them, has been considered squarely on its own merits, and that we in the Government and in the Parliament as a whole were not stampeded by considerations of political expediency or perceived political popularity into hasty and unjustifiable action, particularly when we have all known that the consequences of such actions, inquiries and investigations, and so on, have been the cause of massive hurt and distress to a particular individual, to his family, his young family, and to the institution of which he is a part. It is important that we have acted as we have until now, and it is quite defensible to have acted as we in the Government and in this Parliament have acted until now. But there comes a point when there can only be an end to all this by an essentially open-ended inquiry, expensive as it may be, protracted as it may be, of the kind that is here involved. I simply share the hope of every honourable senator who has spoken in this debate that this inquiry and our subsequent consideration of the results of that inquiry in this Parliament will be the end of this matter and that it will not just be an end to the matter; it will be an end which is just and fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the debate this evening Senator Georges indicated that it was his belief that Senator Haines and I had given him a prior indication of our assessment of the evidence against Mr Justice Murphy during the hearing of the second committee, the Senate Select Committee on the Allegations Concerning a Judge, such that he claims that we stated in as many words that there was no need for Mr Justice Murphy to present evidence to that second Select Committee. I have to say that I have a very imperfect recollection of that conversation. I do recall that very late in the hearing, some time in October, Senator Georges, in a very flustered state on the staircase outside my office, came across Senator Haines and me and asked whether it was too late for the judge to appear before the inquiry. I have recollection of indicating that no, it was not too late and that it would only make our already-I do not say that I am using the exact words-arduous examination of the matters that much longer. I have no recollection of saying that there was no need for Mr Justice Murphy to appear, leaving as it would an inference that there was nothing of sufficient weight, substance or credibility for him to answer. At that stage of the inquiry it was my opinion that there was something which ought to be answered and that it would be best answered from the judge's own lips by way of him giving evidence to the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding at the time was that Mr Justice Murphy was not required to appear either by terms of the resolution of the Senate or by his common law right, on which it built, not to appear before a tribunal of that nature which was doing its best to apply the rules of evidence as used in criminal proceedings. I had done the reading on this to ensure that I had the law correctly in mind: If he were not to appear I should not draw any adverse inference against him for not appearing. If I used any form of words which were meant to convey those points, and Senator Georges drew a wrong inference that I was saying that Mr Justice Murphy need not appear because there was nothing for him to answer, I cannot be blamed for the drawing of the wrong inference by Senator Georges, but I do not recollect that I stated those words and I do not believe that I did. It would have been totally to the contrary of my frame of mind at the time. It had always been my expectation that he would appear. I was astonished when he did not and offered the reasons which he did for not appearing.

I say that it was also my attitude-and I would like to put this on record-that in the course of the first Senate inquiry and, in fact, late at night on the very last possible occasion, at the instruction of the Committee, I phoned the solicitor instructing the counsel for Mr Justice Murphy and pleaded to him to ensure that the message got through to Mr Justice Murphy that he come and appear before us because we had a genuine belief that if he did it could settle the manner. I always felt that if the judge did make an appearance before the committees of inquiry which I chaired it would greatly aid his case. I just want to make that very clear and I want to reject any implication in what Senator Georges has alleged against me and Senator Haines that we would have tried to indicate to him the state of our minds in relation to the evidence at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the comments made by Senator Tate. I share his recollection inasmuch as 18-month old memories can be imperfect. Nevertheless, I share his belief of what happened. Certainly, I share his regret that Senator Georges may have got an impression that we felt that there was no need for the judge to appear before us. We pointed out to him that it was not too late. I feel that perhaps in an attempt to calm Senator Georges, who was quite justifiably agitated at the time, we may have perhaps not emphasised sufficiently that it was not too late for the judge to appear. I only say in addition to what Senator Tate has said that I shared all along Senator Chipp's belief that he expressed quite firmly and often that the appearance of the judge at either of the two inquiries would have been extremely useful to the committees--
—And to the judge.

—It would have been extremely useful not only to the Committee but also to the judge. I cannot understand how any impression could have been given that either I or Senator Tate believed that it was neither useful nor necessary for the judge to appear. Having said that, I would like to add that I do not doubt at all that Senator Georges quite genuinely believes that we gave him that impression and I certainly regret it if that is the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—Before I seek leave for you, Senator Georges, do you understand that under Standing Orders personal explanations are not meant to become subjects of debate? We do not want debate to and fro. It has to be a personal explanation from you.

—I could also claim to have been misunderstood. I remember that day clearly. In listening to the summing up, I did speak to the counsel of Justice Murphy and say that in my view it would be prejudicial to him if he did not appear. I knew at that time that Justice Murphy would have liked to have appeared to contest the evidence and that his advice to that point had been different. It was then suggested by counsel that they would contact Justice Murphy and in the meantime I would question whether or not it was possible for Justice Murphy to appear at that late stage. It must be appreciated that counsel-Mr Gleeson, if I recall correctly-had wound up his case.

SPEECH.PARA: I deny being flustered because the matter was extremely serious. The question I was seeking to ascertain was whether or not Justice Murphy at that late stage could appear. I think I approached the matter with Senator Tate as we walked along the corridor from the refreshment room. Senator Haines sought to disengage-she was there at the time-from the conversation. I said: `No, you will be interested in this'. I asked whether or not it was possible at that late stage for Justice Murphy to appear and Senator Tate said `No'; that it would prolong the inquiry for a week and that it would be necessary-if I could refresh Senator Tate's memory-for Mr Gleeson to be called back as he had already completed his case. The tone of the conversation was to the effect that it was not really necessary. From that I suppose I took the inference that it was not necessary for Justice Murphy to be advised that he should seek to appear at that late stage.

In the debate I merely indicated that that is the sort of situation that can arise in this sort of inquiry. Just a slight change of emphasis or a slight change of advice can lead to an entirely different result. I am not being critical of Senator Tate or Senator Haines. They had a very arduous task to perform and the advice I got, of course, was that it could continue on, that there were difficulties and that, of course, perhaps it was not really necessary. I remember those words distinctly because I wrote them down. I wrote them down because I was in the town of Moranbah when the decision of the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge was announced. I watched a certain television program and I was astonished to hear comments made by members of the Committee that it would have been different had Justice Murphy appeared. At that stage perhaps I got flustered but not on any previous occasion. I wrote down a statement pointing out the whole of that conversation and I have that statement.

I have a clear recollection of the day that the Senate Committee's decision was announced and those comments were made. I have that written down. I put it aside because I decided at that stage it was not useful, and I held it. My recollection is clear. The only comment I make is that at that stage I was coldly concerned about this matter. I was not flustered. I may have misunderstood the intention of the words. Nevertheless, on that misunderstanding of those intentions, perhaps advice was given that should not have been given.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, definition of `Judge', leave out `a court created by the Parliament', insert `the Federal Court'.

This simply raises the question of why a judge who is eligible to sit on the Court should be defined in such broad terms as `a Judge of a court created by the Parliament or of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory'. It seems that the appropriate Federal court would be the Federal Court of Australia rather than simply any court created by the Parliament. Although I do not press this, perhaps the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) could clear up this matter by indicating whether the Government would propose anybody other than a member of the Federal Court or of a Supreme Court of a State or Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Government would have anyone in mind other than a member of the Federal Court or of a Supreme Court of a Territory or State. The drafting is wider. That simply reflects the draftsman picking up a precedent from elsewhere. To the extent that the Opposition moves this amendment, if I were in a more churlish mood I would suggest that it reflects once again the Opposition's prejudice against the Family Court of Australia, but I will not generate churlishness in this chamber by pursuing that point. This does not need to be amended. The Government will bear in mind the Opposition's expression of view.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Clause 5 (Functions).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before moving any amendment to clause 5, as I said in the second reading debate, the Opposition believes the Government has got sub-clause (1) absolutely right. Sub-clause (2) seems to contain some confusion of thought in the conjunction of the phrases in `carrying out its inquiry the Commission shall consider only specific allegations made in precise terms'. The Commission is broadly a commission of inquiry, but the word `inquiry' has a very extensive meaning in law or, indeed, in ordinary English usage. When somebody embarks upon an inquiry that person seeks documents, asks questions of people and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems strange that an inquiry would be limited only to specific allegations that somebody has made. For example, under clause 13 the Commission has all the material that was dealt with by Mr Justice Stewart and was the subject of his report last week. The sub-clause says that the Commission will have access to all material before the Senate committees, as I understand it. When the Commission gets possession of this it may have other material in a documentary form submitted to it which may lead it to make and believe that it should make further inquiries. On that aspect of its role, I do not understand the limitation to specific allegations made in precise terms. Clearly, when the Commission comes to make findings it will have to formulate them in specific allegations. It may also want to reduce a lot of information into this form. Before it makes any findings that there is evidence sufficient to establish misbehaviour it would be necessary to have regard to specificity in the matters that are the subject of the inquiry.

At the beginning of an inquiry it seems to me to be very limiting to expect it to have regard only to specific allegations. We have suggested an amendment that has been circulated to remove the words `made in precise terms', but have a broader concern about this clause. Before I move the amendment, will the Minister deal with the point I have raised so that I can assess whether we need to oppose the clause as a whole or whether we may be able simply to confine ourselves to the amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue that has been raised by Senator Durack which goes to the nub of the kind of inquiry we envisage as being properly here carried out. It is not a bizarre kind of `Lionel Murphy, this is your life' exercise in which the Commission feels free to range at large down any highway or byway along which some avenue of investigative activity suggests itself, or suggests itself to the Commission's staff. It is a matter of creating an opportunity for those allegations to be made, many of which are well known because they are in the public domain already, or allegations which people may have been saving up to make at a future stage. It is a forum in which those specific charges, allegations or claims can be tested.

SPEECH.PARA: The mechanism by which we envisage this will occur is essentially through the filtering agency of the counsel assisting the Commission. Whether the Commission would want to advertise I do not know, but we envisage that maybe an initial time limit would be set within which material on which the Commission would base its inquiry would have to be submitted, subject to supplementation perhaps at a later stage if further material emerged. If there is to be an end to this matter the processes of the Commission have to somehow be confined, not in a way to artificially circumscribe the process so that at the end of it there is still more material floating around which has not been answered. It is terribly important and in everyone's interests that any further allegation or claim that anyone might want to make is dealt with by the Commission. But it is a desire to confine it in that kind of way-it must be allegations that are being dealt with rather than open-ended investigation into topics or lines of inquiry that might appeal to the Commission. That is the first point and that goes to the expression `specific allegations'.

As to the language `specific allegations made in precise terms', this is not a term of art and I do not think there is any precedent for this clause that anyone could think of. It was again an attempt to convey the flavour of what really seems to be required by these circumstances. There might be allegations that in a sense are specific but are nonetheless imprecise, that are vague. There might be allegations that someone is biased towards unionists, that someone is a friend or an associate of persons of ill repute, that someone is a man of unconventional or maybe even unsober habits, and so on. Claims of this kind of a generally, I suppose one might say, defamatory kind are being made, purporting perhaps to reflect some particular piece of prevailing popular wisdom or prejudice, and it might be thought that the Commission would somehow be obliged to consider allegations of that general kind. But they would not have about them that degree of specificity as to time and place, or as to particularity, as to make them susceptible to effective investigation. That is what we are trying to convey. Of course, much will depend simply upon the common sense of the Commission in responding to the kinds of concerns.

I add just one further thing. I think the way in which one could easily have couched these terms of reference would have been by retaining all the matters that are lying around at the moment and specifically referring to them in the text of the Bill-the Thomas allegations and such allegations as may appear or it may be possible to construe from the text of volume 2 of the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions and so on-and perhaps also retailing some of those matters which have been the subject of previous inquiries. But we thought, on balance, it was better simply to have an open-ended expression of the Commission's frame of reference in clause 5 (1) but then, to convey in clause 5 (2), something of the narrowing flavour that was necessary if the inquiry was not to get completely out of hand. Two narrowing requirements are contained in the Bill. Clause 5 (2) is the first of them and the other one is the requirement that there be, in effect, prima facie evidence produced in support of a particular allegation before the judge is compellable to answer the allegation in question. They are cumulative protections, if you like-cumulative narrowing mechanisms. I do not think I can describe it any better than that or more succinctly than that. They are simply ways of confining the scope of what might otherwise be a totally sprawling inquiry and it is in nobody's interests that the sprawling get too far out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition was concerned about sub-clause (3) in view of a manifestation it had earlier today. However, I think that the form it is now in is satisfactory to the Opposition so I will not move amendment No. 3. The Opposition believes that amendment No. 4 to sub-clause (4)--

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Some other honourable senators might like to discuss the amendments. Are you taking them in order or are you allowing senators to range over any part of the clause?

—The question is that clause 5 stand as printed. Honourable senators can range over any part of clause 5. I am taking the amendments in the order that they are received. I am not taking the Bill sub-clause by sub-clause.

—The Opposition is concerned that sub-clause (4) is another attempt to unduly restrict the range of the Commission's inquiry, because it eliminates from consideration of the Commission not only the issues that were dealt with in the trials of Mr Justice Murphy but also any conduct to which those charges related. I believe that to go further as the second limb of sub-clause (4) provides unnecessarily restricts the Commission. Admittedly, there is an exception which ameliorates that restriction; nevertheless there may well be conduct which was in evidence at the trial which should be looked at in relation to misbehaviour even though it is not conduct which was part of the element, or elements, of the charges that were made against Mr Justice Murphy. We believe that we should restrict the Commission only to the extent that the jury's acquittal has disposed of the evidence which was strictly an element of certain charges. There may well be other conduct that was in question in other evidence given at the trial. Presumably any evidence given at the trial was relevant and therefore it may well be said that that second limb is very wide and would exclude the Commission from looking at quite a lot of other evidence which was not part and parcel of the elements of the charges which were the issues at the trial. For those reasons I will move amendment No. 4 which, as I have said, is the version that the Government had drafted but which it moved away from presumably with the same object as it has revealed in this Bill, that is, to endeavour to be more restrictive of the Commission than the general provisions of section 5 (1) would allow. SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 3, leave out sub-clause 5 (4), insert the following sub-clause:

``(4) The Commission shall not consider the issues dealt with in the trials leading to the acquittal of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy of certain criminal charges on 5 July, 1985 and 28 April, 1986 except to the extent that the Commission considers necessary for the proper examination of the other issues arising in the course of the Commission's inquiry.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that we can avoid a too protracted debate on this clause. I seem to have been doing nothing else but talking about it all day trying to get the language of it right. I say at the outset that there is no attempt in drafting this clause to build in any indefensible way walls around some particular area and not make it the subject of inquiry. The whole philosophy on which this Bill has been put together is that we need a capacity, once and for all, to deal with every conceivable allegation that someone might want to make in order to make it impossible at the end of the day for the whole process to start again. It would be utterly counterproductive to build walls around some area if to do so were only to create the possibility of further allegations being made at the end of the day. That is the starting point.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point to be reminded of is that in the drafting of this clause we wanted to circumscribe, so far as was reasonable, the capacity of the Commission to retill the soil of those endlessly protracted criminal trials in the Flannery and Briese matters. The particular conduct that was in issue up to that point was, after all, conduct within a fairly narrow compass. The argument was all about whether that conduct was such as to constitute an attempt to pervert the course of justice. The principle of autrefois acquit is well known and well accepted and there does not seem to be any argument with it so far as the immediate issue of criminal liability in respect of that conduct is concerned. That is essentially what clauses (4) (a) is directed to. However, we also thought it was reasonable to limit the capacity of the Commission to scrutinise exactly that same conduct whether or not the words alleged to have been used were used, with a view to testing that against some other arguably lesser rigid form of misbehaviour than criminal misbehaviour. We understood the Opposition to be saying as much as that in the joint statement made by Senator Chaney and Mr Spender on 29 April, when they said, in the aftermath of the acquittal:
The Opposition do not propose to take parliamentary action in terms of section 72 based on the specific issues dealt with in the criminal trial.

I do not want to get into an argument about what was meant, or not meant, by this statement but the way the Government took it was that, since it was obvious that it was not within our capacity in the Senate to relitigate the criminal liability question, what was being conveyed must have been the view of the Opposition that the Senate ought not to reconsider those factual matters by reference to some possibly less rigid definition of misbehaviour. It is really that position of the Opposition, which we think was a fair, reasonable and sensible position last week, that we were trying to pick up in clause 5 (4). There was a belief that the first draft, which the Opposition has now moved as an amendment, did not quite succeed in doing that, and thus the further draft which is now before us in the Bill. Let me make as clear as I can that there is no desire to circumscribe an inquiry by the Commission into some other issue which may involve a reconsideration of some perhaps of the evidence in the Briese and Flannery trials or may involve a consideration of some aspects of the way in which those trials were conducted.

Let me give two illustrations of what I have in mind. It has been suggested in at least one newspaper today that an allegation of perjury could properly be made against Mr Justice Murphy in respect of part of his evidence in the Briese and Flannery trials-I think round one-which was to the effect that he had only X number of conversations with Morgan Ryan over a period, whereas in reality he had X plus 10 or something of that kind. That was the suggestion, and I do not stop to argue whether that has any conceivable force behind it. The question as to whether perjury may have been involved is a quite different issue than any that was considered in the Briese and Flannery trials. Should the Commission be minded to pursue and allegation of that kind, it would on this drafting be perfectly free to do so.

Let me indicate another issue arising out of the Flannery and Briese trials, which the Commission might, if it were minded to do so, be able to pursue under the text of this amendment. It is being suggested in some quarters, I am not sure how seriously, that Mr Justice Murphy's choice not to go into the witness box but rather to make an unsworn statement on oath, the exercise of that legal right, might in the context of its being exercised by a High Court judge amount to misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution-on a very wide interpretation of that section.

That is a fairly extravagant allegation, but it is one that may be made. Given the width of some of the interpretations of section 72 that are floating around, it may not be all that extravagant at all. It may be made, and to the extent that it was made and the Commission felt that it ought to be pursued, it could be pursued under the language of this clause at the moment.

There has been no attempt to circumscribe in any untoward or indefensible fashion. There has simply been an attempt to ensure that there is an end to at least one part of this litigation-that is, the consideration of the particular factual matters that were immediately in issue in those two trials which have been the subject of jury determination. There is much more I can say on all this, but I do not want to burden the Committee with that if it is unnecessary to do so.
