SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bearing in mind again section 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act, let me state the intention of this clause from the Government's point of view. It uses language not normally associated with royal commission proceedings but rather language more apt to describe an ordinary court proceeding. The way in which we expect it to work is as follows: We do not intend to impose any restriction on the kind of material to which, in the first instance, the Commission may have regard. It is not intended that before the Commission can even consider material put before it that material must satisfy strict criteria of court admissibility. It is fair enough that the Commission should be able to range at large and consider material such as some of the transcripts and summaries of the Age tapes which may not, on their face, be strictly admissible unless subsequently corroborated by some evidence establishing their provenance.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying and what this clause is intended to bite upon is the stage of the Commission's inquiry at which it is actually making findings and, in particular, findings which are adverse to the person concerned. What we are saying, and maybe it is only stating what the Commission would do in practice, given the consequences that may flow from such findings, is that the material upon which the Commission relies at that stage must be material which satisfies criteria of admissibility. This context is different, and designedly so, from the normal royal commission context in which the commission can draw conclusions based on the best material available to it and not necessarily that which satisfies criteria of admissibility.

If I can put it this way, the reason why this more rigorous criterion is here inserted is that adverse consequences to the individual concerned will flow directly from the Commission's findings, assuming that they are adopted by the Parliament thereafter, whereas in a royal commission, where adverse findings are made by an individual there is usually another stage of the whole business to follow before the individual actually suffers anything, apart from, perhaps, damage to reputation. The ordinary royal commission of the kind we have been familiar with in recent years will identify someone as having been likely to have committed some serious criminal act or likely to have been a company or an agency responsible for a disaster of some kind. Before that responsibility or potential liability is turned into real liability and real pain there must be some other court proceedings. There must be a criminal action or a civil action or something of that kind. In this case the calamitous consequences flow directly from the findings, on the assumption I am making for this purpose that those findings are adopted by the Senate. It is for that reason that those findings must have a high degree of credibility and reliability, and the time honoured way in which the credibility and reliability of findings have been established is by requiring that they be based on the kind of evidence that is admissible in court proceedings. I know that is a technical explanation and I know that it is getting very late for long, boring technical explanations, but it is important that the intention behind some of these clauses be well understood in order to avoid subsequent controversy.

The Commission shall, unless it thinks the circumstances require otherwise, conduct the whole of its inquiry in private.

We believe that the proper approach is that the Commission should, unless it thinks the circumstances require otherwise, conduct the whole of its inquiry in public. That is the normal process by which the legal system and our parliamentary system operate. Admittedly, there are odd exceptions; the first Senate committee that inquired into this matter was one of them. Senator Lewis has explained what happened there. There are grave dangers when any body which is subject to great public attention and interest and which has great responsibility sits in private. It should sit in public unless there is some particular reason to sit in private. That would accommodate the sorts of concerns that Senator Chipp expressed about nuts or scuttlebutt or that sort of thing going around.

I do not think that these commissioners, on dealing with such a serious matter, would bother to have any hearings at all about minor and frivolous stuff that nut cases or others might put up or rumour, or innuendo, or gossip around the place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people think sex orgies are misconduct.

—The honourable senator knows that Senate committees get a lot of material that they do not bother to do anything more about; they just pigeon-hole it and forget it. I think that that sifting process will be quite easily taken care of, but for this Parliament to give the direction that it shall virtually sit in private unless there is some particular reason why it should sit in public, I think, is completely reversing the proper approach, the desirable approach, and the normal approach. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I need speak only very briefly on this because the issues are pretty well understood and pretty clear. Honourable senators have to read this section in conjunction with the next one about the report to Parliament which is expressly required by the legislation to be public, together with the evidence supporting and substantiating those findings, subject only to some exceptions which I think it will be agreed are reasonable. There is no intention whatsoever to conceal the nature of the evidence that is given before this inquiry or any of the findings that are made. SPEECH.PARA: It is thought on balance better for the inquiry itself to be conducted on a presumption of privacy because of the by now well-known problem with royal commissions and inquiries of these kinds of allegations-not necessarily obviously vexatious or obviously mischievous allegations; it may be quite seriously intended allegations-being made which are profoundly damaging insofar as they create a massive media splash, being the subject of page after page, day after day of media attention, and then at the end of the day the decision being made by the body in question that the allegations are not substantiated, that being given only minimal reporting, with massive damage being done to the reputations of individuals and in this instance the institution of the High Court itself. It has been under enough stress lately for us not to want to subject it to any more. It is a matter for judgment as to how one balances out these competing considerations. We believe that at the end of the day, given that there is no intention whatsoever-and it would again be counter-productive to make it the intention-to keep secret any of the material which does in fact emerge during the inquiry and which is believed by the Commission to be relevant, it is desirable that the presumption be towards in camera hearings.

(13) Page 4, sub-clause 8 (6), at the end of the sub-clause, add:
``, but shall cause to be laid before the Houses of the Parliament a statement indicating that a separate report has been prepared''.
(14) Page 4, after sub-clause 8 (6), add the following sub-clause:

``(7) A separate report prepared in accordance with sub-section (5) shall be laid before each House of the Parliament at the expiration of 10 sitting days of that House after a statement in respect of that separate report is laid before the House in accordance with sub-section (6), unless, before the expiration of that time, each House of the Parliament passes a resolution that the separate report not be laid before the Houses of the Parliament.''.

The purpose of these amendments is to better ensure that Parliament is fully informed and has complete access to the material upon which it may have to make a judgment about misbehaviour. As clause 8 is drafted, it does not spell out exactly the material that will be before the Parliament. We believe that it should spell out not only the findings of fact and the conclusions as to whether, in the opinion of the Commission, there has been proved misbehaviour, but also the material on which those findings of fact or those conclusions are based, and the reasons for those findings. We believe that the Commission should also be submitting with that report a complete record of the evidence that it has taken and of all other material presented to the Commission.

If Parliament is to be called upon to make a judgment in this matter, it must have all that material before it. The limitations in the clause do not require that. In fact, the Commission has to submit only a record of so much of the evidence as it thinks necessary to substantiate findings, whereas in the end Parliament must make a judgment itself and may require all of the record of evidence given before the Commission. Our other concern about clause 8 is the odd situation that might arise in that some possibly very material evidence may apparently be withheld from the Parliament. I do not know whether it is intended that that should be so. Certainly it is intended that it should not be made public when the Commission reports, because in certain circumstances which are set out in sub-clause (5)-I shall not read them-the Commission may find that there are problems in making certain of its findings public, or making public the evidence on which they are based. In that event, a separate report is delivered to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, together with a statement of this opinion. Then, finally, that report to the President or the Speaker shall not cause that material to be laid before both Houses of Parliament.

Perhaps it is not intended-I do not know-that the Parliament will never have access to that material, but certainly if that is intended, it is quite wrong. Parliament should be able to have access to that material. That judgment must ultimately be made by Parliament. The alternative code set out in the Opposition's amendments would leave the matter in Parliament's hands. If Parliament felt that certain material might have to be dealt with, whether or not it would have effects of the kind concerned in the circumstances of such a grave decision as Parliament is called upon to make, it is simply impossible to see how it could make such a decision if it did not have access to all the material on which the Commission has made its findings. Therefore, we press these amendments, which we believe are a more satisfactory way of dealing with this matter and one which is far more consistent with Parliament discharging its responsibilities than is clause 8 as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's amendments and the Government's clause are essentially two different ways of achieving the same result. There are some attractions which I readily acknowledge in the Opposition's drafting of these particular clauses. Maybe if we had had them before us in the latter stages of the drafting of this thing in the middle of last night there would have been some disposition to accept them. Let me make it clear that I do not think there are any more risks associated with the Government's drafting of these tabling procedures than is the case with the Opposition's alternative. It is true that there is some discretion vested in the Commission not to produce the entire body of evidence it might have taken or had submitted to it in the course of its inquiry, but the obligation is only to place before the Commission as part of the record or attach to the record so much of the evidence as it thinks necessary to substantiate its findings of fact and its conclusions.

SPEECH.PARA: If we have people of the kind of integrity and calibre we are talking about on this Commission they can be relied upon to get that right and not in any way conceal, deliberately or inadvertently, material which ought to be available to the Parliament.

The other matter is the different consideration of the material which would be generally acknowledged, at least as a prima facie claim, to be treated confidentially and circumspectly, because it may involve material which will be utilised or is capable of being utilised in impending prosecutions or because it relates to any of the other considerations set out in the Bill-fair trial, prejudice to safety or reputation, and so on. In relation to that kind of material, each of the two codes proposes a scheme for dealing with it. Senator Durack's amendment proposes that it be submitted subject to a recommendation from the Commission which can then be treated by the respective chambers of Parliament. The Government's Bill gives that material to the Presiding Officers without any specific restriction or direction as to how that material is to be dealt with. The absence of a specific direction or restriction is deliberate. It is left within the discretion and good sense of the Presiding Officers. If they want to make that material available to some or indeed all of the members of the respective chambers they are at liberty to do so in the way the Bill is cast at the moment. Whatever we do, it is important that material which should be before the Parliament in the final determination of this matter is before it. We believe that that result will be secured by the Government's clause, although we acknowledge some merit in the alternative approach that has been produced by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the matter cannot quite be left as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has put it. I would like the Minister to elaborate on that. I could have understood that clause if it had said something like this: `The Commission shall submit with its report a record of all that evidence before the Commission that the Commission finds necessary to substantiate its facts and its conclusions'. Surely, some less subjective judgment is necessary there. —About matters of drafting taste there is no disputation.
—De gustibus non est disputandum.

—De gustibus non est disputandum. I thank Senator Baume. I am indebted to him for his assistance. I am happy to give an assurance that it is the Government's intention that the Commission, under this clause, make available to this Parliament all that evidence which is relevant and necessary to substantiate the findings that it makes on a particular subject matter. That is the clear intent. I am sure, given the integrity and capacity of the people we appoint, that they will honour that intent and err on the side of generosity in the provision of material, even at the expense of the nation's pulpwood forests. I appreciate that that is another concern of the Australian Democrats which may be put at risk by such an interpretation.
—I take it that the Committee discussions on this Bill will naturally become available to the commissioners?
—Naturally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

Our amendment acknowledges that there may be some very sensitive material affecting someone's safety, for instance, which should not be made public. Does sub-clause (6) really preclude members and senators from having access to that report in private?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—The Minister does not think so; all right. Can we get that on the record?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many banks provide information on interest payments made to customers and on what basis.
(2) What is the relevant cut off point of the amounts of interest paid in respect to the information referred to in (1).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All banks in Australia provide details of interest payments made to customers. A basis for this is Income Tax sub-regulation 11 (2) which requires all companies (including banks) to provide each year to the Australian Taxation Office the names and addresses of persons to whom interest in excess of $100 was paid and the amount so paid.

(2) Not all interest payments above the $100 threshold are presently being reported to the Taxation Office. Specified tolerances above this amount for the various kinds of bank accounts have been set by the Commissioner of Taxation and are being progressively reduced. These tolerances have regard to the substantial costs and difficulties facing the banks in providing full information at this time and to the resources and facilities available to the Taxation Office to process the information. It is not appropriate for the Commissioner to make public the amounts of the specified tolerances.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any evidence that a climate of sustained low world oil prices will adversely affect the level of oil exploration activity in Australia.

(2) What is the level of activity of on-shore and off-shore oil exploration in Australia in terms of the number of exploratory wells sunk, and the amount of money spent on exploration over the last 3 years.

(3) What is the present level of Australia's crude oil self sufficiency, and to what level of crude oil discoveries will Australia have to maintain in order to maintain this level of self sufficiency.
(4) What are Australia's current national reserves of crude oil, at what rate are these reserves being depleted, and at what rate are discoveries being made.

(5) Based on projections of the data available, can the Minister for Resources and Energy provide an estimate of what Australia's level of crude oil self sufficiency will be in the years 1990, 1995 and 2000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) If world oil prices are sustained at the current low level for an extended period of time, it is likely that there will be some decline in exploration activity in Australia and overseas.

However, as most oil industry analysts currently expect oil prices to recover to 1985 levels during the 1990's, it is expected that many companies will continue with their exploration and development plans but possibly at a slower rate. Some marginal projects and exploration areas may be abandoned until oil prices recover. The quantitative effect on the level of exploration activity cannot be estimated at this stage. At the present time, companies are reviewing the timing of planned activities.

Although there are some exploration and development projects within Australia which might be classified as marginal, there are also many attractive exploration prospects and potentially viable discoveries over which companies will wish to retain tenure. The companies not willing to risk losing acreage in which the more immediate discoveries and developments are expected to be made, can be expected to continue to explore with a view to oil prices recovering in the 1990s.

Any decision on exploration and development activities will take account not only of oil price forecasts but a wide range of other factors. Australia is an attractive country for petroleum exploration-there are very good prospects for finding oil and our taxation regimes compare well with those of other countries. The maximum marginal taxation rate for new onshore developments is 68.4%. For offshore developments, the Government has introduced a resource rent tax (RRT) on greenfields offshore petroleum projects. The taxation rate of the RRT is 40% which, with normal company tax gives a marginal rate of 67.4%. The advantage of this tax is that it is profits based rather than production based, and that the tax is only applied once the project has reached the threshold rate of return (currently around 29%). If the returns on the project fall below the RRT threshold rate of return, then no tax is paid. The Government has also recently introduced the mechanism for a profits based tax-the resource rent royalty-to be applied to onshore developments. These rates are in fact equal to or lower than those in many other oil producing countries, including UK, Norway and Indonesia, where marginal tax rates are well over 80%.

(3) Australia's crude oil self-sufficiency for the first five months of 1985-86 reached a record level of 107% following a level of 95% achieved in 1984-85.
Oil self-sufficiency is defined as the ratio of crude oil and condensate production plus domestic consumption of naturally occurring LPG to domestic demand for petroleum products.

However, it must be recognised that the technical limit for absorption of Australian crude oil and feedstocks by refineries is about 80% of refining output requirements-the remaining 20% of refinery output is met from heavy crude oil which must be imported.

Estimates of future levels of crude oil self-sufficiency depend on many factors including demand forecasts, oil pricing forecasts, forecasts of production from existing and planned facilities and forecasts of production from as yet undiscovered fields. Taking all these uncertainties into account, the latest forecasts by the Department of Resources and Energy of future minimum levels of self-sufficiency are in the range:
Low
Probability

Probability

The Government is continuing to pursue a policy aimed at ensuring and adequate supply of energy is available to Australia at all times. In this context the government is seeking to achieve, in an economically efficient manner, an optimal level of self-sufficiency in liquid fuels over the longer term rather than pursuing an arbitrary target level of self-sufficiency. Consequently, precise rates of new oil discoveries needed to maintain current levels of self-sufficiency are not necessarily relevant to a full assessment of current policy developments. By way of example, production from new discoveries would need to be in the order of 120 million barrels a year in 1994-95 and 173 million barrels a year in 1999-2000 in order to maintain an 80 per cent level of self-sufficiency in those years.
However, the size and timing of discoveries needed to achieve this rate of new production is subject to considerable uncertainty and cannot be estimated with any measure of confidence.

(4) Under the McKelvey classification system, Australia's demonstrated economic resources of crude oil and condensate as at 30 June 1985 are 2.0 billion barrels (313 million kilolitres). Production of crude oil and condensate over the past ten years has amounted to 1.56 billion barrels (or 247.4 million kilolitres)-and average of 155.6 million barrels (24.7 million kilolitres) a year.

Additions to reserves are a result not only of new discoveries, but also reappraisal of known fields. Over the 10 years from 1975-76 to 1984-85 the additions to reserves have amounted to approximately 1.8 billion barrels (approximately 290 million kilolitres)-an average of 180 million barrels (29 million kilolitres) a year.
(5) See answer to (3).

(2) Liability found-Due to radiation exposure 5; and due to other causes 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 December 1985 (Hansard, page 3167) Senator Knowles asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of the Government's intention to legislate for the quarantining of farm losses from tax deductibility against off-farm income, can the Minister inform the Senate what will be the tax treatment for a farmer who, while operating his own property, obtains additional off-farm income by planting and growing crops on leased farm land? Has the Commissioner of Taxation informed the accountancy profession as to whether such income will be regarded as part of general farm income or included as off-farm income that will be subject to the quarantining provisions, as is currently being asserted by some accountants?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Minister for Primary Industry announced on 15 April 1986 that, because of the current depressed state of primary production, the Government has decided not to proceed with primary production loss quarantining measure. Instead, a review is to be carried out of the current application of the relevant provisions of the income tax law and a change will be made to the trading stock provisions to take breeding costs into account in the valuation of certain livestock acquired by natural increase.
